    
Great
Expectations
<EOS>
Charles
Dickens
  
1860
<EOS>
-
-1861
  
Information
about
the
source
     
Chapter
1
 
<EOS>
My
father
's
family
name
being
Pirrip
,
and
my
Christian
name
Philip
,
my
infant
tongue
could
make
of
both
names
nothing
longer
or
more
explicit
than
Pip
.
<EOS>
So
,
I
called
myself
Pip
,
and
came
to
be
called
Pip
.
  
<EOS>
I
give
Pirrip
as
my
father
's
family
name
,
on
the
authority
of
his
tombstone
and
my
sister
---
Mrs
Joe
Gargery
,
who
married
the
blacksmith
.
<EOS>
As
I
never
saw
my
father
or
my
mother
,
and
never
saw
any
likeness
of
either
of
them
(
for
their
days
were
long
before
the
days
of
photographs
)
,
my
first
fancies
regarding
what
they
were
like
,
were
unreasonably
derived
from
their
tombstones
.
<EOS>
The
shape
of
the
letters
on
my
father
's
,
gave
me
an
odd
idea
that
he
was
a
square
,
stout
,
dark
man
,
with
curly
black
hair
.
<EOS>
From
the
character
and
turn
of
the
inscription
,
 
\
"
Also
Georgiana
Wife
of
the
Above
,
"
<EOS>
\
 
<EOS>
I
drew
a
childish
conclusion
that
my
mother
was
freckled
and
sickly
.
<EOS>
To
five
little
stone
lozenges
,
each
about
a
foot
and
a
half
long
which
were
arranged
in
a
neat
row
beside
their
grave
,
and
were
sacred
to
the
memory
of
five
little
brothers
of
mine
---
who
gave
up
trying
to
get
a
living
,
exceedingly
early
in
that
universal
struggle
---
I
am
indebted
for
a
belief
I
religiously
entertained
that
they
had
all
been
born
on
their
backs
with
their
hands
in
their
trousers
-
pockets
,
and
had
never
taken
them
out
in
this
state
of
existence
.
  
<EOS>
Ours
was
the
marsh
country
,
down
by
the
river
,
within
,
as
the
river
wound
,
twenty
miles
of
the
sea
.
<EOS>
My
first
most
vivid
and
broad
impression
of
the
identity
of
things
,
seems
to
me
to
have
been
gained
on
a
memorable
raw
afternoon
towards
evening
.
<EOS>
At
such
a
time
I
found
out
for
certain
,
that
this
bleak
place
overgrown
with
nettles
was
the
churchyard
;
and
that
Philip
Pirrip
,
late
of
this
parish
,
and
also
Georgiana
wife
of
the
above
,
were
dead
and
buried
;
and
that
Alexander
,
Bartholomew
,
Abraham
,
Tobias
,
and
Roger
,
infant
children
of
the
aforesaid
,
were
also
dead
and
buried
;
and
that
the
dark
flat
wilderness
beyond
the
churchyard
,
intersected
with
dykes
and
mounds
and
gates
,
with
scattered
cattle
feeding
on
it
,
was
the
marshes
;
and
that
the
low
leaden
line
beyond
,
was
the
river
;
and
that
the
distant
savage
lair
from
which
the
wind
was
rushing
was
the
sea
;
and
that
the
small
bundle
of
shivers
growing
afraid
of
it
all
and
beginning
to
cry
,
was
Pip
.
  
<EOS>
"
Hold
your
noise
!
"
<EOS>
cried
a
terrible
voice
,
as
a
man
started
up
from
among
the
graves
at
the
side
of
the
church
porch
.
<EOS>
"
Keep
still
,
you
little
devil
,
or
I
'll
cut
your
throat
!
"
  
<EOS>
A
fearful
man
,
all
in
coarse
grey
,
with
a
great
iron
on
his
leg
.
<EOS>
A
man
with
no
hat
,
and
with
broken
shoes
,
and
with
an
old
rag
tied
round
his
head
.
<EOS>
A
man
who
had
been
soaked
in
water
,
and
smothered
in
mud
,
and
lamed
by
stones
,
and
cut
by
flints
,
and
stung
by
nettles
,
and
torn
by
briars
;
who
limped
,
and
shivered
,
and
glared
and
growled
;
and
whose
teeth
chattered
in
his
head
as
he
seized
me
by
the
chin
.
  
<EOS>
"
O
!
<EOS>
Do
n't
cut
my
throat
,
sir
,
"
I
pleaded
in
terror
.
<EOS>
"
Pray
do
n't
do
it
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Tell
us
your
name
!
"
said
the
man
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Quick
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Pip
,
sir
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Once
more
,
"
said
the
man
,
staring
at
me
.
<EOS>
"
Give
it
mouth
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Pip
.
<EOS>
Pip
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Show
us
where
you
live
,
"
said
the
man
.
<EOS>
"
Pint
out
the
place
!
"
  
<EOS>
I
pointed
to
where
our
village
lay
,
on
the
flat
in
-
shore
among
the
alder
-
trees
and
pollards
,
a
mile
or
more
from
the
church
.
  
<EOS>
The
man
,
after
looking
at
me
for
a
moment
,
turned
me
upside
down
,
and
emptied
my
pockets
.
<EOS>
There
was
nothing
in
them
but
a
piece
of
bread
.
<EOS>
When
the
church
came
to
itself---
for
he
was
so
sudden
and
strong
that
he
made
it
go
head
over
heels
before
me
,
and
I
saw
the
steeple
under
my
feet
---
when
the
church
came
to
itself
,
I
say
,
I
was
seated
on
a
high
tombstone
,
trembling
,
while
he
ate
the
bread
ravenously
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
young
dog
,
"
said
the
man
,
licking
his
lips
,
"
what
fat
cheeks
you
ha
'
got
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
believe
they
were
fat
,
though
I
was
at
that
time
undersized
for
my
years
,
and
not
strong
.
  
<EOS>
"
Darn
Me
if
I
could
n't
eat
em
,
"
said
the
man
,
with
a
threatening
shake
of
his
head
,
"
and
<EOS>
if
I
han't
half
a
mind
to't
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
earnestly
expressed
my
hope
that
he
would
n't
,
and
held
tighter
to
the
tombstone
on
which
he
had
put
me
;
partly
,
to
keep
myself
upon
it
;
partly
,
to
keep
myself
from
crying
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
lookee
here
!
"
said
the
man
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Where
's
your
mother
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
,
sir
!
"
said
I.
  
He
started
,
made
a
short
run
,
and
stopped
and
looked
over
his
shoulder
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
,
sir
!
<EOS>
"
I
timidly
explained
.
"
<EOS>
Also
Georgiana
.
<EOS>
That
's
my
mother
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
"
said
he
,
coming
back
.
"
<EOS>
And
is
that
your
father
alonger
your
mother
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
"
said
I
;
"
him
too
;
late
of
this
parish
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Ha
!
"
<EOS>
he
muttered
then
,
considering
.
<EOS>
"
Who
d'ye
live
with
<EOS>
---
supposin
'
you
're
kindly
let
to
live
,
which
I
han't
made
up
my
mind
about
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
sister
,
sir
---
Mrs
Joe
Gargery
---
wife
of
Joe
Gargery
,
the
blacksmith
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Blacksmith
,
eh
?
"
said
he
.
<EOS>
And
looked
down
at
his
leg
.
  
<EOS>
After
darkly
looking
at
his
leg
and
me
several
times
,
he
came
closer
to
my
tombstone
,
took
me
by
both
arms
,
and
tilted
me
back
as
far
as
he
could
hold
me
;
so
that
his
eyes
looked
most
powerfully
down
into
mine
,
and
mine
looked
most
helplessly
up
into
his
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
lookee
here
,
"
he
said
,
"
the
question
being
whether
you
're
to
be
let
to
live
.
<EOS>
You
know
what
a
file
is
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
know
what
wittles
is
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
.
"
  
<EOS>
After
each
question
he
tilted
me
over
a
little
more
,
so
as
to
give
me
a
greater
sense
of
helplessness
and
danger
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
get
me
a
file
.
"
<EOS>
He
tilted
me
again
.
"
<EOS>
And
you
get
me
wittles
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
tilted
me
again
.
<EOS>
"
You
bring
'em
both
to
me
.
"
<EOS>
He
tilted
me
again
.
<EOS>
"
Or
I
'll
have
your
heart
and
liver
out
.
"
<EOS>
He
tilted
me
again
.
  
<EOS>
I
was
dreadfully
frightened
,
and
so
giddy
that
I
clung
to
him
with
both
hands
,
and
said
,
"
If
you
would
kindly
Please
to
let
me
keep
upright
,
sir
,
perhaps
I
should
n't
be
sick
,
<EOS>
and
perhaps
I
could
attend
more
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
gave
me
a
most
tremendous
dip
and
roll
,
so
that
the
church
jumped
over
its
own
weather
-
cock
.
<EOS>
Then
,
he
held
me
by
the
arms
,
in
an
upright
position
on
the
top
of
the
stone
,
and
went
on
in
these
fearful
terms
:
  
<EOS>
"
You
bring
me
,
to
-
morrow
morning
early
,
that
file
and
them
wittles
.
<EOS>
You
bring
the
lot
to
me
,
at
that
old
Battery
over
yonder
.
<EOS>
You
do
it
,
and
you
never
dare
to
say
a
word
or
dare
to
make
a
sign
concerning
your
having
seen
such
a
person
as
me
,
or
any
person
sumever
,
and
you
shall
be
let
to
live
.
<EOS>
You
fail
,
or
you
go
from
my
words
in
any
partickler
,
no
matter
how
small
it
is
,
and
your
heart
and
your
liver
shall
be
tore
out
,
roasted
and
ate
.
<EOS>
Now
,
I
ai
n't
alone
,
as
you
may
think
I
am
.
<EOS>
There
's
a
young
man
hid
with
me
,
in
comparison
with
which
young
man
I
am
a
Angel
.
<EOS>
That
young
man
hears
the
words
I
speak
.
<EOS>
That
young
man
has
a
secret
way
pecooliar
to
himself
,
of
getting
at
a
boy
,
and
at
his
heart
,
and
at
his
liver
.
<EOS>
It
is
in
wain
for
a
boy
to
attempt
to
hide
himself
from
that
young
man
.
<EOS>
A
boy
may
lock
his
door
,
may
be
warm
in
bed
,
may
tuck
himself
up
,
may
draw
the
clothes
over
his
head
,
may
think
himself
comfortable
and
safe
,
but
that
young
man
will
softly
creep
and
creep
his
way
to
him
and
tear
him
open
.
<EOS>
I
am
a
keeping
that
young
man
from
harming
of
you
at
the
present
moment
,
with
great
difficulty
.
<EOS>
I
find
it
wery
hard
to
hold
that
young
man
off
of
your
inside
.
<EOS>
Now
,
what
do
you
say
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
said
that
I
would
get
him
the
file
,
and
I
would
get
him
what
broken
bits
of
food
<EOS>
I
could
,
and
I
would
come
to
him
at
the
Battery
early
in
the
morning
.
  
<EOS>
"
Say
Lord
strike
you
dead
if
you
do
n't
!
"
said
the
man
.
  
<EOS>
I
said
so
,
and
he
took
me
down
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"
he
pursued
,
"
you
remember
what
you
've
undertook
,
and
you
remember
that
young
man
,
and
you
get
home
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Goo
-
good
night
,
sir
,
"
I
faltered
.
  
<EOS>
"
Much
of
that
!
"
said
he
,
glancing
about
him
over
the
cold
wet
flat
.
<EOS>
"
I
wish
I
was
a
frog
.
<EOS>
Or
a
eel
!
"
  
<EOS>
At
the
same
time
,
he
hugged
his
shuddering
body
in
both
his
arms
---
clasping
himself
,
as
if
to
hold
himself
together
---
and
limped
towards
the
low
church
wall
.
<EOS>
As
I
saw
him
go
,
picking
his
way
among
the
nettles
,
and
among
the
brambles
that
bound
the
green
mounds
,
he
looked
in
my
young
eyes
as
if
he
were
eluding
the
hands
of
the
dead
people
,
stretching
up
cautiously
out
of
their
graves
,
to
get
a
twist
upon
his
ankle
and
pull
him
in
.
  
<EOS>
When
he
came
to
the
low
church
wall
,
he
got
over
it
,
like
a
man
whose
legs
were
numbed
and
stiff
,
and
then
turned
round
to
look
for
me
.
<EOS>
When
I
saw
him
turning
,
I
set
my
face
towards
home
,
and
made
the
best
use
of
my
legs
.
<EOS>
But
presently
I
looked
over
my
shoulder
,
and
saw
him
going
on
again
towards
the
river
,
still
hugging
himself
in
both
arms
,
and
picking
his
way
with
his
sore
feet
among
the
great
stones
dropped
into
the
marshes
here
and
there
for
stepping
-
places
when
the
rains
were
heavy
,
or
the
tide
was
in
.
  
<EOS>
The
marshes
were
just
a
long
black
horizontal
line
then
,
as
I
stopped
to
look
after
him
;
and
the
river
was
just
another
horizontal
line
,
not
nearly
so
broad
nor
yet
so
black
;
and
the
sky
was
just
a
row
of
long
angry
red
lines
and
dense
black
lines
intermixed
.
<EOS>
On
the
edge
of
the
river
I
could
faintly
make
out
the
only
two
black
things
in
all
the
prospect
that
seemed
to
be
standing
upright
;
one
of
these
was
the
beacon
by
which
the
sailors
steered
---
like
an
unhooped
cask
upon
a
pole
---
an
ugly
thing
when
you
were
near
it
;
the
other
a
gibbet
,
with
some
chains
hanging
to
it
which
had
once
held
a
pirate
.
<EOS>
The
man
was
limping
on
towards
this
latter
,
as
if
he
were
the
pirate
come
to
life
,
and
come
down
,
and
going
back
to
hook
himself
up
again
.
<EOS>
It
gave
me
a
terrible
turn
when
I
thought
so
;
and
as
I
saw
the
cattle
lifting
their
heads
to
gaze
after
him
,
I
wondered
whether
they
thought
so
too
.
<EOS>
I
looked
all
round
for
the
horrible
young
man
,
and
could
see
no
signs
of
him
.
<EOS>
But
,
now
I
was
frightened
again
,
and
ran
home
without
stopping
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
2
 
<EOS>
My
sister
,
Mrs
Joe
Gargery
,
was
more
than
twenty
years
older
than
I
,
and
had
established
a
great
reputation
with
herself

neighbours
because

.
<EOS>

Joe

.
  
<EOS>
She
was
not

-

,

that
she
must

made
Joe
Gargery
marry

by

.
<EOS>
Joe
was
a
fair

,

,

.
<EOS>
He

a

,

---

Hercules

.
  
<EOS>
My

,

Joe
,

,

of

.
<EOS>
She
was
tall

,

,

over
her
figure
behind
with

,

.
<EOS>
She

,

,

.
<EOS>
Though

<EOS>
Joe
's

,

,

---

<EOS>

<EOS>
Joe

"

<EOS>

"

-

.
<EOS>
First
,

<EOS>

Some

much

this
elixir
was
administered
to
me
as
a
choice
restorative
,
that
I
was
conscious
of
going
about
,
smelling
like
a
new
fence
.
<EOS>
On
this
particular
evening
the
urgency
of
my
case
demanded
a
pint
of
this
mixture
,
which
was
poured
down
my
throat
,
for
my
greater
comfort
,
while
Mrs
Joe
held
my
head
under
her
arm
,
as
a
boot
would
be
held
in
a
boot
-
jack
.
<EOS>
Joe
got
off
with
half
a
pint
;
but
was
made
to
swallow
that
(
much
to
his
disturbance
,
as
he
sat
slowly
munching
and
meditating
before
the
fire
)
,
"
because
he
had
had
a
turn
.
"
<EOS>
Judging
from
myself
,
I
should
say
he
certainly
had
a
turn
afterwards
,
if
he
had
had
none
before
.
  
<EOS>
Conscience
is
a
dreadful
thing
when
it
accuses
man
or
boy
;
but
when
,
in
the
case

a
boy
,
that
secret
burden
co
-
operates

another
secret

down

,

(
as
I

)

punishment
.
<EOS>
The
guilty
knowledge
that
I
was
going
to
rob
Mrs
Joe
<EOS>
---
I
never
thought
I
was
going
to
rob
Joe
,
for
I
never
thought
of
any
of
the
housekeeping
property
as
his
---
united

,

.
<EOS>
Then
,

,
of

,

could
n't
and

n't

until
to
-

,

.
<EOS>
At

,

,
What

with

,

,

!
<EOS>
If

.
<EOS>
But
,

,
nobody
's

?
  
<EOS>
It

,

,

\
his
\
 
leg
)
,

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"
Hark
!
<EOS>
"

,

"

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

?

,

"
Escaped
.
<EOS>
Escaped
.
<EOS>
Administering

.

\

"

.

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

.

her
?
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

!

<EOS>

Hulks
!

<EOS>
Joe

,

"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

"

!
"
<EOS>

,

.
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
Hulks

prison
-

,
right
'
cross
th
'
meshes
.
<EOS>
"
We

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

's

,

're

?
"
said

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
It

too
much

Mrs
Joe
,

.
<EOS>
"
I

what
,

,
"

,
"
I
did

's

.
<EOS>
It

,

,

.
<EOS>
People

,

,
and

,

;
and

always

.
<EOS>
Now
,

along

!
"
  
<EOS>
I
was
never

a

,

,

,

---
from

's

,
to

words
<EOS>
---
I
felt
fearfully

that
the
Hulks
were
handy

.
<EOS>
I
was
clearly
on

.
<EOS>
I
had

by

,
and
I

Mrs
Joe
.
  
<EOS>
Since
that

,
which
is
fur
enough
away
now
,
I
have
often
thought
that
few

know
what
secrecy

is
in

young
,

.
<EOS>
No

,
so
that

.
<EOS>
I
was
in

of
the

;
I

;

,

;

,

;

,

.
  
<EOS>

;

.
<EOS>

,

that

I

.
<EOS>
There

no

in

night
,

;

,

.
  
<EOS>

;

,

"
Stop

!
"
<EOS>

"

!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In

,

,

,

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

,

<EOS>
I

,

,

)
,

,

.

,

.
  
<EOS>
There

,

;

,

's

.
<EOS>
Then
,

as

,

when
I
ran
home

,

,

ran
for
the
misty

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
3
 
IT
was
a
rimy
morning
,
and
very
damp
.
<EOS>
I
had
seen
the
damp
lying
on
the
outside
of
my
little
window
,
as
if
some
goblin
had
been
crying
there
all
night
,
and
using
the
window
for
a
pocket
-
handkerchief
.
<EOS>
Now
,
I
saw
the
damp
lying
on
the
bare
hedges
and
spare
grass
,
like
a
coarser
sort
of
spiders
'
webs
;
hanging
itself
from
twig
to
twig
and
blade
to
blade
.
<EOS>
On
every
rail
and
gate
,
wet
lay
clammy
;
and
the
marsh
-
mist
was
so
thick
,
that
the
wooden
finger
on
the
post
directing
people
to
our
village
---
a
direction
which
they
never
accepted
,
for
they
never
came
there
---
was
invisible
to
me
until
I
was
quite
close
under
it
.
<EOS>
Then
,
as
I
looked
up
at
it
,
while
it
dripped
,
it
seemed
to
my
oppressed
conscience
like
a
phantom
devoting
me
to
the
Hulks
.
  
<EOS>
The
mist
was
heavier
yet
when
I
got
out
upon
the
marshes
,
so
that
instead
of
my
running
at
everything
,
everything
seemed
to
run
at
me
.
<EOS>
This
was
very
disagreeable
to
a
guilty
mind
.
<EOS>
The
gates
and
dykes
and
banks
came
bursting
at
me
through
the
mist
,
as
if
they
cried
as
plainly
as
could
be
,
"
A
boy
with
Somebody
-
else
's
pork
pie
!
<EOS>
Stop
him
!
"
<EOS>
The
cattle
came
upon
me
with
like
suddenness
,
staring
out
of
their
eyes
,
and
steaming
out
of
their
nostrils
,
"
Holloa
,
young
thief
!
"
<EOS>
One
black
ox
,
with
a
white
cravat
on
---
who
even
had
to
my
awakened
conscience
something
of
a
clerical
air
---
fixed
me
so
obstinately
with
his
eyes
,
and
moved
his
blunt
head
round
in
such
an
accusatory
manner
as
I
moved
round
,
that
I
blubbered
out
to
him
,
"
I
could
n't
help
it
,
sir
!
<EOS>
It
was
n't
for
myself
I
took
it
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Upon
which
he
put
down
his
head
,
blew
a
cloud
of
smoke
out
of
his
nose
,
and
vanished
with
a
kick
-
up
of
his
hind
-

and
a

of
his
tail
.
  
<EOS>
All
this
time
,
I
was
getting
on
towards
the
river
;
but
however
fast
I
went
,
<EOS>
I
could
n't
warm
my
feet
,
to
which
the
damp
cold
seemed
riveted
,
as
the
iron
was
riveted
to
the
leg
of
the
man
I
was
running
to
meet
.
<EOS>
I
knew
my
way
to
the
Battery
,
pretty
straight
,
for
I
had
been
down
there
on
a
Sunday
with
Joe
,
and
Joe
,
sitting
on
an
old
gun
,
had
told
me
that
when
I
was
'
prentice
to
him
regularly
bound
,
we
would
have
such
Larks
there
!
<EOS>
However
,
in
the
confusion
of
the
mist
,
I
found
myself
at
last
too
far
to
the
right
,
and
consequently
had
to
try
back
along
the
river
-
side
,
on
the
bank
of
loose
stones
above
the
mud
and
the
stakes
that
staked
the
tide
out
.
<EOS>
Making
my
way
along
here
with
all
despatch
,
I
had
just
crossed
a
ditch
which
I
knew
to
be
very
near
the
Battery
,
and
had
just
scrambled
up
the
mound
beyond
the
ditch
,
when
I
saw
the
man
sitting
before
me
.
<EOS>
His
back
was
towards
me
,
and
he
had
his
arms
folded
,
and
was
nodding
forward
,
heavy
with

.
  
<EOS>
I
thought
he
would
be
more
glad
if
I
came
upon
him
with
his
breakfast
,
in
that
unexpected

,
so
I
went
forward
softly
and
touched
him
on
the
shoulder
.
<EOS>
He
instantly
jumped
up
,
and
it
was
not
the
same
man
,
but
another
man
!
  
<EOS>
And
yet
this
man
was
dressed
in
coarse
grey
,
too
,
and
had
a
great
iron
on
his

,
and
was
lame
,
and

,
and

,
and
was
everything
that
the

was
;

had
not

,
and
had
a
flat

-

on
.
<EOS>
All

,

saw

,

in
:
he

oath
at

,
made

hit
at
me
<EOS>
---

down
,

---
and

ran

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
the
young

!
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
I
dare

.
  
<EOS>
I

,

---

,
as

all

<EOS>
He

,

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

Brandy
,
"

I.

"

<EOS>

.

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
4
 
I
FULLY
expected

find

Constable
in

,

.
<EOS>
But

,

.
<EOS>
Mrs
Joe

in

,

Joe
had

---

sooner

,
when

.

"
And

ha
'
 
\

\

?

.

.

"
<EOS>

!

!

.

"

.
<EOS>
"

)
<EOS>

slave
with

off
<EOS>
,

,

.
<EOS>

air
when
Mrs
Joe
darted
a
look
at
him
,
and
,
when
her
eyes
were
withdrawn
,
secretly
crossed
his
two
forefingers
,
and
exhibited
them
to
me
,
as
our
token
that
Mrs
Joe
was
in
a
cross
temper
.
<EOS>
This
was
so
much
her
normal
state
,
that
Joe
and
I
would
often
,
for
weeks
together
,
be
,
as
to
our
fingers
,
like
monumental
Crusaders
as
to
their
legs
.
  
<EOS>
We
were
to
have
a
superb
dinner
,
consisting
of
a
leg
of
pickled
pork
and
greens
,
and
a
pair
of
roast
stuffed
fowls
.
<EOS>
A
handsome
mince
-
pie
had
been
made
yesterday
morning
(
which
accounted
for
the
mincemeat
not
being
missed
)
,
and
the
pudding
was
already
on
the
boil
.
<EOS>
These
extensive
arrangements
occasioned
us
to
be
cut
off
unceremoniously
in
respect
of
breakfast
;
"
for
I
an't
,
"
said
Mrs
Joe
,
"
I
an't
a
going
to
have
no
formal
cramming
and
busting
and
washing
up
now
,
with
what
I
've
got
before
me
<EOS>
,
I
promise
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
So
,
we
had
our
slices
served
out
,
as
if
we
were
two
thousand
troops
on
a
forced
march
instead
of
a
man
and
boy
at
home
;
and
we
took
gulps
of
milk
and
water
,
with
apologetic
countenances
,
from
a
jug
on
the
dresser
.
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
,
Mrs
Joe
put
clean
white
curtains
up
,
and
tacked
a
new
flowered
-
flounce
across
the
wide
chimney
to
replace
the
old
one
,
and
uncovered
the
little
state
parlour
across
the
Passage
,
which
was
never
uncovered
at
any
other
time
,
but
passed
the
rest
of
the
year
in
a
cool
haze
of
silver
paper
,
which
even
extended
to
the
four
little
white
crockery
poodles
on
the
mantelshelf
,
each
with
a
black
nose
and
a
basket
of
flowers
in
his
mouth
,
and
each
the
counterpart
of
the
other
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Joe
was
a
very
clean
housekeeper
,
but
had
an
exquisite
art
of
making
her
cleanliness
more
uncomfortable
and
unacceptable
than
dirt
itself
.
<EOS>
Cleanliness
is
next
to
Godliness
,
and
some
people
do
the
same
by
their
religion
.
  
<EOS>
My
sister
having
so
much
to
do
,
was
going
to
church
vicariously
;
that
is
to
say
,
Joe
and
I
were
going
.
<EOS>
In
his
working
clothes
,
Joe
was
a
well
-
knit
characteristic
-
looking
blacksmith
;
in
his
holiday
clothes
,
he
was
more
like
a
scarecrow
in
good
circumstances
,
than
anything
else
.
<EOS>
Nothing
that
he
wore
then
,
fitted
him
or
seemed
to
belong
to
him
;
and
everything
that
he
wore
then
,
grazed
him
.
<EOS>
On
the
present
festive
occasion
he
emerged
from
his
room
,
when
the
blithe
bells
were
going
,
the
picture
of
misery
,
in
a
full
suit
of
Sunday
penitentials
.
<EOS>
As
to
me
,
I
think
my
sister
must
have
had
some
general
idea
that
I
was
a
young
offender
whom
an
Accoucheur
Policeman
had
taken
up
(
on
my
birthday
)
and
delivered
over
to
her
,
to
be
dealt
with
according
to
the
outraged

of
the
law
.
<EOS>
I
was
always
treated
as
if
I
had
insisted
on
being
born
,
in
opposition
to
the
dictates
of
reason
,
religion
,
and
morality
,
and
against
the
dissuading

of
my
best
friends
.
<EOS>
Even
when
I
was
taken
to
have
a
new
suit
of
clothes
,
the
tailor
had
orders
to
make
them
like
a
kind
of
Reformatory
,
and
on
no
account
to
let
me
have
the
free
use
of
my

.
  
<EOS>
Joe
and
<EOS>
I
going
to
church
,
therefore
,
must
have
been
a
moving
spectacle
for
compassionate
minds
.
<EOS>
Yet
,
what
I
suffered
outside
,
was
nothing
to
what
I
underwent
within
.
<EOS>
The
terrors
that
had
assailed
me
whenever
Mrs
Joe
had
gone
near
the
pantry
,
or
out

the
room
,
were
only
to
be
equalled
by
the
remorse
with
which
my
mind
dwelt
on
what
my
hands
had
done
.
<EOS>
Under
the
weight
of
my
wicked
secret
,
I
pondered
whether
the
Church
would
be
powerful
enough
to
shield
me
from
the
vengeance
of
the
terrible
young
man
,
if
I
divulged
to
that
establishment
.
<EOS>
I
conceived
the
idea
that
the
time
when
the
banns
were
read
and
when
the

said
,
"
Ye

now

declare

!
"
would

for

to
rise
and

.
<EOS>
I
am
far
from

that
I

not

by

to
this

,
but
for

Christmas
Day
and
no

.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Wopsle
,
the
clerk

,

to

;
and
Mr
Hubble
the

;

Uncle
Pumblechook
(
Joe
's

,
but
<EOS>
Mrs

)
,

.
<EOS>
The

was
half
-

.
<EOS>
When

,

,

,

(

)
for

,

most

.
<EOS>
And
still
,
not
a

of

.
  
<EOS>
The
time
came
,
without

any

to

,

.
<EOS>
Mr
Wopsle
,

to
a
Roman

,

a

;

understood
among

that

"

,
"

.
<EOS>
The

not

"

,
"
he

,

I

,
our
clerk
.
<EOS>
But
he
punished
the
Amens
tremendously
;
and

psalm
---
always

---

,

,
"
<EOS>
You
have

friend
overhead
;

of

style
!
"
  
<EOS>
I

to

---

ours
to

---

,
next

Mr
and

,

.
<EOS>
NB
.
<EOS>
I
was
not
allowed
to
call

uncle
,
under

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Joe
,
"
said

Pumblechook
:
a
large

-

middle

,
with

,

,

,

all

,
and

to
;
"
I
have

,
as
the

---
I

,

,

sherry

---
and
I
have

,
Mum
,
a

of
port
wine
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Every
Christmas

he
presented
himself
,
as

,
with

,
and

like

.
<EOS>
Every

,

Joe

,

,
"
Oh
,

-

-

-

!
<EOS>
This
IS
kind
!
"
<EOS>
Every

,

,

now

,
"
It
's

.
<EOS>
And

all

,

's
Sixpennorth
of

?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
meaning
me
.
  
<EOS>
We
dined
on
these

in
the

,
and

,
for
the
nuts

,

;
which

like

's

.
<EOS>
My
sister
was
uncommonly
lively
on
the
present

,
and
indeed
was
generally
more

in

Mrs

.
<EOS>
I
remember
Mrs
Hubble
as
a
little

-

person
in
sky

blue
,
who
held
a
conventionally
juvenile
position
,
because
she
had
married
Mr
Hubble
---
I
do
n't
know
at
what
remote

---
when
she
was
much

than
he
.
<EOS>
I
remember
Mr
Hubble
as
a
tough
high
-

man
,
of
a
saw
-

fragrance
,
with
his
legs
extraordinarily
wide

:
so
that
in
my
short
days
I
always
saw
some
miles
of
open
country
between
them
when
I
met
him
coming
up
the
lane
.
  
<EOS>
Among
this
good
company
I
should
have
felt
myself
,
even
if
I
had
n't
robbed
the
pantry
,
in
a
false
position
.
<EOS>
Not
because
I
was
squeezed
in
at
an
acute
angle
of
the
table

,
with
the
table
in

chest
,
and

Pumblechookian

in

eye
,
nor
because
I
was
not
allowed
to
speak
<EOS>
(
I
did
n't
want
to
speak
)
,
nor
because
I
was
regaled
with
the
scaly

of
the
drumsticks
of
the

,
and
with
those
obscure
corners
of
pork
of
which
the
pig
,
when
living
,
had
had

.
<EOS>
No
;
I
should
not
have
minded

,
if
they
would
only

left

alone
.
<EOS>
But
they
would
n't
leave
me
alone
.
<EOS>
They
seemed
to
think
the
opportunity
lost
,
if
they
failed
to
point
the
conversation
at
me
,
every

,
and
stick

.
<EOS>
I
might
have
been
an
unfortunate
little
bull
in

Spanish
arena
<EOS>
,
I
got
so
smartingly

up
by
these
moral

.
  
<EOS>
It
began
the
moment
we
sat

.
<EOS>
Mr
Wopsle
said
grace
with
theatrical

---
as
it
now

,
something
like

Richard
the
Third
---
and

.
<EOS>
Upon

fixed

,

,

,
"
Do

?
<EOS>
Be

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Especially
,
"
said

Pumblechook
,
"
be

,
boy
,
to
them
which
brought
you
up

hand
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Hubble
shook

,
and

that

,

"
Why

young
are

?
<EOS>
"
This

"
Naterally
wicious
.
<EOS>
"
Everybody

"
True
!
"
and

.
  
<EOS>
Joe
's

and

were
something

(
if

)
<EOS>
when

,

<EOS>
But

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
There

-

,

,
at

,
about

.
  
<EOS>
A

,

\

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
There

!
<EOS>

"

"

)
  
<EOS>
Joe

.
  
<EOS>
"
Swine
,
"

<EOS>

,

.
"
<EOS>
(

<EOS>
"

a
boy
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
Or
girl
,
"
suggested
Mr
Hubble
.
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
,
or
girl
,
Mr
Hubble
,
"
assented
Mr
Wopsle
,
rather
irritably
,
"
but
there
is
no
girl
present
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Besides
,
"
said
Mr
Pumblechook
,
turning
sharp
on
me
<EOS>
,
"
think
what
you
've
got
to
be
grateful
for
.
<EOS>
If
you
'd
been
born
a
Squeaker
---
"
  
"
<EOS>
He
 
\
was
,
\
 
<EOS>
if
ever
a
child
was
,
"
said
my
sister
,
most
emphatically
.
  
<EOS>
Joe
gave
me
some
more
gravy
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
but
I
mean
a
four
-
footed
Squeaker
,
"
said
Mr
Pumblechook
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
had
been
born
such
,
would
you
have
been
here
now
?
<EOS>
Not
you
---
"
  
"
Unless
in
that
form
,
"
said
Mr
Wopsle
,
nodding
towards
the
dish
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
do
n't
mean
in
that
form
,
sir
,
"
returned
Mr
Pumblechook
,
who
had
an
objection
to
being
interrupted
;
"
I
mean
,
enjoying
himself
with
his
elders
and
betters
,
and
improving
himself
with
their
conversation
,
and
rolling
in
the
lap
of
luxury
.
<EOS>
Would
he
have
been
doing
that
?
<EOS>
No
,
he
would
n't
.
<EOS>
And
what
would
have
been
your
destination
?
"
<EOS>
turning
on
me
again
.
<EOS>
"
You
would
have
been
disposed
of
for
so
many
shillings
according
to
the
market
price
of
the
article
,
and
Dunstable
the
butcher
would
have
come
up
to
you
as
you
lay
in
your
straw
,
and
he
would
have
whipped
you
under
his
left
arm
,
and
with
his
right
he
would
have
tucked
up
his
frock
to
get
a
penknife
from
out
of
his
waistcoat
-
pocket
,
and
he
would
have
shed
your
blood
and
had
your
life
.
<EOS>
No
bringing
up
by
hand
then
.
<EOS>
Not
a
bit
of
it
!
"
  
<EOS>
Joe
offered
me
more
gravy
,
which
I
was
afraid
to
take
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
was
a
world
of
trouble
to
you
,
ma'am
,
"
said
Mrs
Hubble
,
commiserating
my
sister
.
  
<EOS>
"
Trouble
?
"
echoed
my
sister
;
"
trouble
?
"
<EOS>
And
then
entered
on
a
fearful
catalogue
of
all
the
illnesses
I
had
been
guilty
of
,
and
all
the
acts
of
sleeplessness
I
had
committed
,
and
all
the
high
places
I
had
tumbled
from
,
and
all
the
low
places
I
had
tumbled
into
,
and
all
the
injuries
I
had
done
myself
,
and
<EOS>
all
the
times
she
had
wished
me
in
my
grave
,
and
I
had
contumaciously
refused
to
go
there
.
  
<EOS>
I
think
the
Romans
must
have
aggravated
one
another
very
much
,
with
their
noses
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
,
they
became
the
restless
people
they
were
,
in
consequence
.
<EOS>
Anyhow
,
Mr
Wopsle
's
Roman
nose
so
aggravated
me
,
during
the
recital
of
my
misdemeanours
,
that
I
should
have
liked
to
pull
it
until
he
howled
.
<EOS>
But
,
all
I
had
endured
up
to
this
time
,
was
nothing
in
comparison
with
the
awful
feelings
that
took
possession
of
me
when
the
pause
was
broken
which
ensued
upon
my
sister
's
recital
,
and
in
which
pause
everybody
had
looked
at
me
(
as
I
felt
painfully
conscious
)
with
indignation
and
abhorrence
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yet
,
"
said
Mr
Pumblechook
,
leading
the
company
gently
back
to
the
theme
from
which
they
had
strayed
,
"
Pork
---
regarded
as
biled
---
is
rich
,
too
;
ai
n't
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Have
a
little
brandy
,
uncle
,
"
said
my
sister
.
   
<EOS>
O
Heavens
,
it
had
come
at
last
!
<EOS>
He
would
find
it
was
weak
,
he
would
say
it
was
weak
,
and
I
was
lost
!
<EOS>
I
held
tight
to
the
leg
of
the
table
under
the
cloth
,
with
both
hands
,
and
awaited
my
fate
.
  
<EOS>
My
sister
went
for
the
stone
bottle
,
came
back
with
the
stone
bottle
,
and
poured
his
brandy
out
:
<EOS>
no
one
else
taking
any
.
<EOS>
The
wretched
man
trifled
with
his
glass
---
took
it
up
,
looked
at
it
through
the
light
,
put
it
down
---
prolonged
my
misery
.
<EOS>
All
this
time
,
Mrs
Joe
and
Joe
were
briskly
clearing
the
table
for
the
pie
and
pudding
.
  
<EOS>
I
could
n't
keep
my
eyes
off
him
.
<EOS>
Always
holding
tight
by
the
leg
of
the
table
with
my
hands
and
feet
,
I
saw
the
miserable
creature
finger
his
glass
playfully
,
take
it
up
,
smile
,
throw
his
head
back
,
and
drink
the
brandy
off
.
<EOS>
Instantly
afterwards
,
the
company
were
seized
with
unspeakable
consternation
,
owing
to
his
springing
to
his
feet
,
turning
round
several
times
in
an
appalling
spasmodic
whooping
-
cough
dance
,
and
rushing
out
at
the
door
;
he
then
became
visible
through
the
window
,
violently
plunging
and
expectorating
,
making
the
most
hideous
faces
,
and
apparently
out
of
his
mind
.
  
<EOS>
I
held
on
tight
,
while
Mrs
Joe
and
Joe
ran
to
him
.
<EOS>
I
did
n't
know
how
I
had
done
it
,
but
I
had
no
doubt
I
had
murdered
him
somehow
.
<EOS>
In
my
dreadful
situation
,
it
was
a
relief
when
he
was
brought
back
,
and
,
surveying
the
company
all
round
as
if
 
\
<EOS>
they
\
 
<EOS>
had
disagreed
with
him
,
sank
down
into
his
chair
with
the
one
significant
gasp
,
"
Tar
!
"
  
<EOS>
I
had
filled
up
the
bottle
from
the
tar
-
water
jug
.
<EOS>
I
knew
he
would
be
worse
by
-
and
-
by
.
<EOS>
I
moved
the
table
,
like
a
Medium
of
the
present
day
,
by
the
vigour
of
my
unseen
hold
upon
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Tar
!
"
cried
my
sister
,
in
amazement
.
<EOS>
"
Why
,
how
ever
could
Tar
come
there
?
"
  
<EOS>
But
,
Uncle
Pumblechook
,
who
was
omnipotent
in
that
kitchen
,
would
n't
hear

word
,
would
n't
hear
of
the
subject
,
imperiously
waved
it

away
with
his

,
and
asked
for
hot
gin
-
and
-
water
.
<EOS>
My
sister
,
who
had
begun
to
be
alarmingly

,
had
to
employ

actively
in
getting
the
gin
,
the
hot

,
the

,
and

,

.
<EOS>
For

time

least
,
I
was
saved
.
<EOS>
I
still
held
on
to
the
leg
of
the
table
,
but
clutched

now
with
the
fervour
of

.
  
<EOS>
By

,
I
became

to
release

and
partake
of

.
<EOS>
Mr
Pumblechook
partook
of
pudding
.
<EOS>
All
partook
of
pudding
.
<EOS>
The
course
terminated
,
and
Mr
Pumblechook
had
begun
to
beam
under
the
genial
influence
of
gin
-
and
-
water
.
<EOS>
I
began
to
think
I
should
get
over
the
day
,
when
my
sister
said
to
Joe
,
"
Clean
plates
---
cold
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
clutched
the
leg

the
table
again

,
and
pressed

to
my
bosom
as
if
it
had
been
the
companion
of
my
youth
and
friend

my

.
<EOS>
I
foresaw
what
was
coming
,
and
I
felt
that
this
time
I
really
was
gone
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
must
taste
,
"
said

,

"
You

,
to

,
such

Uncle

's
!
"
  
<EOS>
Must

!
<EOS>
Let
them
not
hope
to
taste
it
!
  
<EOS>
"
You
must
know
,
"
said
my
sister
,

,
"
it
's
a
pie
;
a
savoury
pork
pie
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
company
murmured
their

.
<EOS>
Uncle
Pumblechook
,
sensible
of
having
deserved
well
of
his
fellow

,
said
---
quite

,
<EOS>
all

---
"
<EOS>
Well
,
Mrs
Joe
,
we
'll

;

at

.
"
  
<EOS>
My
sister
went
out
to

.
<EOS>
I
heard
her
steps
proceed
to
the
pantry
.
<EOS>
I
saw
Mr
Pumblechook
balance
his
knife
.
<EOS>
I
saw
re
-
awakening
appetite
in
the
Roman
nostrils
of
Mr
Wopsle
.
<EOS>
I
heard
Mr
Hubble
remark
that
"
a
bit
of
savoury
pork
pie
would
lay
atop
of
anything

could
mention
,
and
do
no

,
"
and
I

,
"
You
shall
have
some
,
Pip
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
never
been
absolutely
certain
whether
I
uttered
a
shrill

,
merely
in
spirit
,
or

.
<EOS>
I
felt
that
I
could
bear
no
more
,
and
that
I
must
run
away
.
<EOS>
I
released
the
leg
of
the
table
,
and
ran
for
my
life
.
  
<EOS>
But
,
I
ran
no
further
than
the
house
door
,
for
there
I
ran
head
foremost
into
a
party
of
soldiers
with
their

:
one
of

held
out

pair
of
handcuffs
to
me
,
saying
,
"
Here
you
are
,
look
sharp
,
come
on
!
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
5
 
<EOS>
THE
apparition
of
a
file
of
soldiers
ringing
down
the
butt
-
ends
of
their
loaded
muskets
on
our
door
-
step
,
caused
the
dinner
-
party
to
rise
from
table
in

,
and
caused
Mrs
Joe
re
-
entering
the
kitchen
empty
-
handed
,
to
stop
short
and

,
in
her

of
"
Gracious
goodness
gracious
me
,
what
's
gone
---
with
the
---
pie
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
sergeant
and
I
were
in
the
kitchen
when
Mrs
Joe
stood
staring
;
at
which
crisis
<EOS>
I
partially
recovered
the
use
of
my
senses
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
sergeant
who
had
spoken
to
me
,
and
he
was
now
looking
round
at
the
company
,
with
his
handcuffs
invitingly
extended
towards
them
in
his
right
hand
,
and
his
left
on
my
shoulder
.
  
<EOS>
"
Excuse
me
,
ladies
and

,
"
said
the
sergeant
,
"
<EOS>
but
as
I
have
mentioned
at
the
door
to
this
smart
young
shaver
"
(
which
he
had
n't
)
,
"
I
am
on
a
chase
in
the
name
of
the
king
,
and
I
want
the
blacksmith
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
pray
what
might
you
want
with
 
\
him
?
"
<EOS>
\
 
retorted
my
sister
,
quick
to
resent

being
wanted

all
.
  
<EOS>
"
Missis
,
"
returned
the
gallant

,
"

,

should

,
the

of
his
fine
wife
's

;
speaking

the
king
,
I
answer
,
a
little
job
done
.
"
  
<EOS>
This
was
received
as
rather
neat
in
the
sergeant
;
insomuch
that
Mr
Pumblechook
cried
audibly
,
"
Good
again
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
see
,
blacksmith
,
"
said
the
sergeant
,
who
had
by
this

picked
out
Joe
with
his
eye
,
"
we
have
had
an
accident
with
these
,
and
I
find
the
lock
of
one
of
'em
goes
wrong
,
and
the
coupling
do
n't
act
pretty
.
<EOS>
As
they
are
wanted
for
immediate
service
,
will
you
throw
your
eye
over
them
?
"
  
<EOS>
Joe
threw
his
eye
over
them
,
and
pronounced
that
the
job
would
necessitate
the
lighting
of
his
forge
fire
,
and
would
take
nearer
two
hours
than
one
,
"
Will
it
?
<EOS>
Then
will
you
set
about
it
at
once
,
blacksmith
?
<EOS>
"
said
the
off
-
hand
sergeant
,
"
as
it
's
on
his
Majesty
's
service
.
<EOS>
And
if
my
men
can
bear
a
hand
anywhere
,
they
'll
make
themselves
useful
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
With
that
,
he
called
to
his
men
,
who
came
trooping
into
the
kitchen
one
after
another
,
and
piled
their
arms
in
a
corner
.
<EOS>
And
then
they
stood
about
,
as
soldiers
do
;
now
,
with
their
hands
loosely
clasped
before
them
;
now
,
resting
a
knee
or
a

;
now
,
easing
a
belt
or
a

;
now
,
opening
the
door
to
spit
stiffly
over
their
high

,
out
into
the
yard
.
  
<EOS>
All
these
things
I
saw
without
then
knowing
that
I
saw
them
,
for
<EOS>
I
was
in
an
agony
of
apprehension
.
<EOS>
But
,
beginning
to
perceive
that
the
handcuffs
were
not
for
me
,
and
that
the
military
had
so
far
got
the
better
of
the
pie
as
to
put
it
in
the
background
,
I
collected
a
little
more
of
my
scattered
wits
.
  
<EOS>
"
Would
you
give
me
the
Time
?
"
said
the
sergeant
,
addressing
himself
to
Mr
Pumblechook
,
as
to
a
man
whose
appreciative
powers
justified
the
inference
that
he
was
equal
to
the
time
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
just
gone
half
-
past
two
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
not
so
bad
,
"
said
the
sergeant
,
reflecting
;
"
even
if
I
was
forced
to
halt
here
<EOS>
nigh
two
hours
<EOS>
,
that
'll
do
.
<EOS>
How
far
might
you
call
yourselves
from
the
marshes
,
hereabouts
?
<EOS>
Not
above
a
mile
,
I
reckon
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Just
a
mile
,
"
said
Mrs
Joe
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
'll
do
.
<EOS>
We
begin
to
close
in
upon

about
dusk
.
<EOS>
A
little
before
dusk
,
my
orders
are
.
<EOS>
That
'll
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Convicts
,
sergeant
?
"
asked
Mr
Wopsle
,
in
a
matter
-
of
-
course
way
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
!
"
returned
the
sergeant
,
"
two
.
<EOS>
They
're
pretty
well
known
to
be
out
on
the
marshes
still
,
and
they
wo
n't
try
to
get
clear
of
'em
before
dusk
.
<EOS>
Anybody
here
seen
anything
of
any
such
game
?
"
  
<EOS>
Everybody
,
myself
excepted
,
said
no
,
with
confidence
.
<EOS>
Nobody
thought
of
me
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
said
the
sergeant
,
"
they
'll
find
themselves
trapped
in
a
circle
,
I
expect
,
sooner
than
they
count
on
.
<EOS>
Now
,
blacksmith
!
<EOS>
If
you
're
ready
,
his
Majesty
the
King
is
.
"
  
<EOS>
Joe
had
got
his
coat
and
waistcoat
and
cravat
off
,
and
his
leather
apron
on
,
and
passed
into
the
forge
.
<EOS>
One
of
the
soldiers
opened
its
wooden
windows
,
another
lighted
the
fire
,
another
turned
to
at
the
bellows
,
the
rest
stood
round
the
blaze
,
which
was
soon
roaring
.
<EOS>
Then
Joe
began
to
hammer
and
clink
,
hammer
and
clink
,
and
we
all
looked
on
.
  
<EOS>
The
interest
of
the
impending
pursuit
not
only
absorbed
the
general
attention
,
but
even
made
my
sister
liberal
.
<EOS>
She
drew
a
pitcher
of
beer
from
the
cask
,
for
the
soldiers
,
and
invited
the
sergeant
to
take
a
glass
of
brandy
.
<EOS>
But
Mr
Pumblechook
said
,
sharply
,
"
Give
him
wine
,
Mum
.
<EOS>
I
'll
engage
there
's
no
Tar
in
that
:
"
<EOS>
so
,
the
sergeant
thanked
him
and
said
that
as
he
preferred
his
drink
without
tar
,
he
would
take
wine
,
if
it
was
equally
convenient
.
<EOS>
When
it
was
given
him
,
he
drank
his
Majesty
's
health
and
Compliments
of
the
Season
,
and
took
it
all
at
a
mouthful
and
smacked
his
lips
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
stuff
,
eh
,
sergeant
?
<EOS>
"
said
Mr
Pumblechook
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
tell
you
something
,
"
returned
the
sergeant
;
"
I
suspect
that
stuff
's
of
your
providing
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Pumblechook
,
with
a
fat
sort
of
laugh
,
said
,
"
<EOS>
Ay
,
ay
?
<EOS>
Why
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Because
,
"
returned
the
sergeant
,
clapping
him
on
the
shoulder
,
"
you
're
a
man
that
knows
what
's
what
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
D'ye
think
so
?
"
said
Mr
Pumblechook
,
with
his
former
laugh
.
"
<EOS>
Have
another
glass
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
With
you
.
<EOS>
Hob
and
nob
,
"
returned
the
sergeant
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
top
of
mine
to
the
foot
of
yours
---
the
foot
of
yours
to
the
top
of
mine
---
Ring
once
,
ring
twice
---
the
best
tune
on
the
Musical
Glasses
!
<EOS>
Your
health
.
<EOS>
May
you
live
a
thousand
years
,
and
never
be
a
worse
judge
of
the
right
sort
than
you
are
at
the
present
moment
of
your
life
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
sergeant
tossed
off
his
glass
again
and
seemed
quite
ready
for
another
glass
.
<EOS>
I
noticed
that
Mr
Pumblechook
in
his
hospitality
appeared
to
forget
that
he
had
made
a
present
of
the
wine
,
but
took
the
bottle
from
Mrs
Joe
and
had
all
the
credit
of
handing
it
about
in
a
gush
of
joviality
.
<EOS>
Even
I
got
some
.
<EOS>
And
he
was
so
very
free
of
the
wine
that
he
even
called
for
the
other
bottle
,
and
handed
that
about
with
the
same
liberality
,
when
the
first
was
gone
.
  
<EOS>
As
I
watched
them
while
they
all
stood
clustering
about
the
forge
,
enjoying
themselves
so
much
,
I
thought
what
terrible
good
sauce
for
a
dinner
my
fugitive
friend
on
the
marshes
was
.
<EOS>
They
had
not
enjoyed
themselves
a
quarter
so
much
,
before
the
entertainment
was
brightened
with
the
excitement
he
furnished
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
when
they
were
all
in
lively
anticipation
of
"
the
two
villains
"
being
taken
,
and
when
the
bellows
seemed
to
roar
for
the
fugitives
,
the
fire
to
flare
for
them
,
the
smoke
to
hurry
away
in
pursuit
of
them
,
Joe
to
hammer
and
clink
for
them
,
and
all
the
murky
shadows
on
the
wall
to
shake
at
them
in
menace
as
the
blaze
rose
and
sank
and
the
red
-
hot
sparks
dropped
and
died
,
the
pale
afternoon
outside
,
almost
seemed
in
my
pitying
young
fancy
to
have
turned
pale
on
their
account
,
poor
wretches
.
  
<EOS>
At
last
,
Joe
's
job
was
done
,
and
the
ringing
and
roaring
stopped
.
<EOS>
As
Joe
got
on
his
coat
,
he
mustered
courage
to
propose
that
some
of
us
should
go
down
with
the
soldiers
and
see
what
came
of
the
hunt
.
<EOS>
Mr
Pumblechook
and
Mr
Hubble
declined
,
on
the
plea
of
a
pipe
and
ladies
'
society
;
but
Mr
Wopsle
said
he
would
go
,
if
Joe
would
.
<EOS>
Joe
said
he
was
agreeable
,
and
would
take
me
,
if
Mrs
Joe
approved
.
<EOS>
We
never
should
have
got
leave
to
go
,
I
am
sure
,
but
for
Mrs
Joe
's
curiosity
to
know
all
about
it
and
how
it
ended
.
<EOS>
As
it
was
,
she
merely
stipulated
,
"
If
you
bring
the
boy
back
with
his
head
blown
to
bits
by
a
musket
,
do
n't
look
to
me
to
put
it
together
again
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
sergeant
took
a
polite
leave
of
the
ladies
,
and
parted
from
Mr
Pumblechook
as
from
a
comrade
;
though
I
doubt
if
he
were
quite
as
fully
sensible
of
that
gentleman
's
merits
under
arid
conditions
,
as
when
something
moist
was
going
.
<EOS>
His
men
resumed
their
muskets
and
fell
in
.
<EOS>
Mr
Wopsle
,
Joe
,
and
I
,
received
strict
charge
to
keep
in
the
rear
,
and
to
speak
no
word
after
we
reached
the
marshes
.
<EOS>
When
we
were
all
out
in
the
raw
air
and
were
steadily
moving
towards
our
business
,
I
treasonably
whispered
to
Joe
,
"
I
hope
,
Joe
,
we
sha
n't
find
them
.
"
<EOS>
And
Joe
whispered
to
me
,
"
I
'd
give
a
shilling
if
they
had
cut
and
run
,
Pip
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
We
were
joined
by
no
stragglers
from
the
village
,
for
the
weather
was
cold
and
threatening
,
<EOS>
the
way
dreary
,
the
footing
bad
,
darkness
coming
on
,
and
the
people
had
good
fires
in
-
doors
and
were
keeping
the
day
.
<EOS>
A
few
faces
hurried
to
glowing
windows
and
looked
after
us
,
but
none
came
out
.
<EOS>
We
passed
the
finger
-
post
,
and
held
straight
on
to
the
churchyard
.
<EOS>
There
,
we
were
stopped
a
few
minutes
by
a
signal
from
the
sergeant
's
hand
,
while
two
or
three
of
his
men
dispersed
themselves
among
the
graves
,
and
also
examined
the
porch
.
<EOS>
They
came
in
again
without
finding
anything
,
and
then
we
struck
out
on
the
open
marshes
,
through
the
gate
at
the
side
of
the
churchyard
.
<EOS>
A
bitter
sleet
came
rattling
against
us
here
on
the
east
wind
,
and
Joe
took
me
on
his
back
.
  
<EOS>
Now
that
we
were
out
upon
the
dismal
wilderness
where
they
little
thought
I
had
been
within
eight
or
nine
hours
and
had
seen
both
men
hiding
,
I
considered
for
the
first
time
,
with
great
dread
,
if
we
should
come
upon
them
,
would
my
particular
convict
suppose
that
it
was
I
who
had
brought
the
soldiers
there
?
<EOS>
He
had
asked
me
if
I
was
a
deceiving
imp
,
and
he
had
said
I
should
be
a
fierce
young
hound
if
I
joined
the
hunt
against
him
.
<EOS>
Would
he
believe
that
I
was
both
imp
and
hound
in
treacherous
earnest
,
and
had
betrayed
him
?
  
<EOS>
It
was
of
no
use
asking
myself
this
question
now
.
<EOS>
There
I
was
,
on
Joe
's
back
,
and
there
was
Joe
beneath
me
,
charging
at
the
ditches
like
a
hunter
,
and
stimulating
Mr
Wopsle
not
to
tumble
on
his
Roman
nose
,
and
to
keep
up
with
us
.
<EOS>
The
soldiers
were
in
front
of
us
,
extending
into
a
pretty
wide
line
with
an
interval
between
man
and
man
.
<EOS>
We
were
taking
the
course
I
had
begun
with
,
and
from
which
I
had
diverged
in
the
mist
.
<EOS>
Either
the
mist
was
not
out
again
yet
,
or
the
wind
had
dispelled
it
.
<EOS>
Under
the
low
ted
glare
of
sunset
,
the
beacon
,
and
the
gibbet
,
and
the
mound
of
the
Battery
,
and
the
opposite
shore
of
the
river
,
were
plain
,
though
all
of
a
watery
lead
colour
.
  
<EOS>
With
my
heart
thumping
like
a
blacksmith
at
Joe
's
broad
shoulder
,
I
looked
all
about
for
any
sign
of
the
convicts
.
<EOS>
I
could
see
none
,
I
could
hear
none
.
<EOS>
Mr
Wopsle
had
greatly
alarmed
me
more
than
once
,
by
his
blowing
and
hard
breathing
;
but
I
knew
the
sounds
by
this
time
,
and
could
dissociate
them
from
the
object
of
pursuit
.
<EOS>
I
got
a
dreadful
start
,
when
I
thought
I
heard
the
file
still
going
;
but
it
was
only
a
sheep
bell
.
<EOS>
The
sheep
stopped
in
their
eating
and
looked
timidly
at
us
;
and
the
cattle
,
their
heads
turned
from
the
wind
and
sleet
,
stared
angrily
as
if
they
held
us
responsible
for
both
annoyances
;
but
,
except
these
things
,
and
the
shudder
of
the
dying
day
in
every
blade
of
grass
,
there
was
no
break
in
the
bleak
stillness
of
the
marshes
.
  
<EOS>
The
soldiers
were
moving
on
in
the
direction
of
the
old
Battery
,
and
we
were
moving
on
a
little
way
behind
them
,
when
,
all
of
a
sudden
,
we
all
stopped
.
<EOS>
For
,
there
had
reached
us
on
the
wings
of
the
wind
and
rain
,
a
long
shout
.
<EOS>
It
was
repeated
.
<EOS>
It
was
at
a
distance
towards
the
east
,
but
it
was
long
and
loud
.
<EOS>
Nay
,
there
seemed
to
be
two
or
more
shouts
raised
together
---
if
one
might
judge
from
a
confusion
in
the
sound
.
  
<EOS>
To
this
effect
the
sergeant
and
the
nearest
men
were
speaking
under
their
breath
,
when
Joe
and
I
came
up
.
<EOS>
After
another
moment
's
listening
,
Joe
(
who
was
a
good
judge
)
agreed
,
and
Mr
Wopsle
(
who
was
a
bad
judge
)
agreed
.
<EOS>
The
sergeant
,
a
decisive
man
,
ordered
that
the
sound
should
not
be
answered
,
but
that
the
course
should
be
changed
,
and
that
his
men
should
make
towards
it
"
at
the
double
.
"
<EOS>
So
we
slanted
to
the
right
(
where
the
East
was
)
,
and
Joe
pounded
away
so
wonderfully
,
that
I
had
to
hold
on
tight
to
keep
my
seat
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
run
indeed
now
,
and
what
Joe
called
,
in
the
only
two
words
he
spoke
all
the
time
,
"
a
Winder
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Down
banks
and
up
banks
,
and
over
gates
,
and
splashing
into
dykes
,
and
breaking
among
coarse
rushes
:
<EOS>
no
man
cared
where
he
went
.
<EOS>
As
we
came
nearer
to
the
shouting
,
it
became
more
and
more
apparent
that
it
was
made
by
more
than
one
voice
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
,
it
seemed
to
stop
altogether
,
and
then
the
soldiers
stopped
.
<EOS>
When
it
broke
out
again
,
the
soldiers
made
for
it
at
a
greater
rate
than
ever
,
and
we
after
them
.
<EOS>
After
a
while
,
we
had
so
run
it
down
,
that
we
could
hear
one
voice
calling
"
Murder
!
"
<EOS>
and
another
voice
,
"
Convicts
!
<EOS>
Runaways
!
<EOS>
Guard
!
<EOS>
This
way
for
the
runaway
convicts
!
<EOS>
"
Then
both
voices
would
seem
to
be
stifled
in
a
struggle
,
and
then
would
break
out
again
.
<EOS>
And
when
it
had
come
to
this
,
the
soldiers
ran
like
deer
,
and
Joe
too
.
  
<EOS>
The
sergeant
ran
in
first
,
when
we
had
run
the
noise
quite
down
,
and
two
of
his
men
ran
in
close
upon
him
.
<EOS>
Their
pieces
were
cocked
and
levelled
when
we
all
ran
in
.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
are
both
men
!
"
<EOS>
panted
the
sergeant
,
struggling
at
the
bottom
of
a
ditch
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Surrender
,
you
two
!
and
confound
you
for
two
wild
beasts
!
Come
asunder
!
"
  
<EOS>
Water
was
splashing
,
and
mud
was
flying
,
and
oaths
were
being
sworn
,
and
blows
were
being
struck
,
when
some
more
men
went
down
into
the
ditch
to
help
the
sergeant
,
and
dragged
out
,
separately
,
my
convict
and
the
other
one
.
<EOS>
Both
were
bleeding
and
panting
and
execrating
and
struggling
;
but
of
course
I
knew
them
both
directly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mind
!
"
said
my
convict
,
wiping
blood
from
his
face
with
his
ragged
sleeves
,
and
shaking
torn
hair
from
his
fingers
:
"
I
took
him
!
<EOS>
I
give
him
up
to
you
!
<EOS>
Mind
that
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
much
to
be
particular
about
,
"
said
the
sergeant
;
"
it
'll
do
you
small
good
,
my
man
,
being
in
the
same
plight
yourself
.
<EOS>
Handcuffs
there
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
expect
it
to
do
me
any
good
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
want
it
to
do
me
more
good
than
it
does
now
,
"
said
my

.
<EOS>
"
I
took

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
That

.
"
  
<EOS>

.

.
  
<EOS>
The

,

,

.
<EOS>
It

,

,

.
<EOS>
Before

,
four

,

.

,

.

"

.

.
<EOS>
"

.

I

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

,

.
<EOS>
The

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
No

,

,

,

,

,

,
"
Give

,

!
"
<EOS>
which
was

for

.
<EOS>
By

,

black
Hulk
lying

from

,

.
<EOS>
Cribbed

chains
<EOS>
,

-

seemed

to

.
<EOS>
We

,

.
<EOS>
Then
,

ends

were

into

water
,
and
went
out
,
as
if
it
were
all

with
him
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
6
 
<EOS>
My
state
of
mind
regarding
the
pilfering
from
which
I
had
been
so
unexpectedly
exonerated
,
did
not
impel
me
to
frank
disclosure
;
but
I
hope
it
had
some
dregs
of
good
at
the
bottom
of
it
.
  
<EOS>
I
do
not
recall
that
I
felt
any
tenderness
of
conscience
in
reference
to
Mrs
Joe
,
when
the
fear
of
being
found
out
was
lifted
off
me
.
<EOS>
But
I
loved
Joe
---
perhaps
for
no
better
reason
in
those
early
days
than
because
the
dear
fellow
let
me
love
him
---
and
,
as
to
him
,
my
inner
self
was
not
so
easily
composed
.
<EOS>
It
was
much
upon
my
mind
(
particularly
when
I
first
saw
him
looking
about
for
his
file
)
that
I
ought
to
tell
Joe
the
whole
truth
.
<EOS>
Yet
I
did
not
,
and
for
the
reason
that
I
mistrusted
that
if
I
did
,
he
would
think
me
worse
than
I
was
.
<EOS>
The
fear
of
losing
Joe
's
confidence
,
and
of
thenceforth
sitting
in
the
chimney
-
corner
at
night
staring
drearily
at
my
for
ever
lost
companion
and
friend
,
tied
up
my
tongue
.
<EOS>
I
morbidly
represented
to
myself
that
if
Joe
knew
it
,
I
never
afterwards
could
see
him
at
the
fireside
feeling
his
fair
whisker
,
without
thinking
that
he
was
meditating
on
it
.
<EOS>
That
,
if
Joe
knew
it
,
I
never
afterwards
could
see
him
glance
,
however
casually
,
at
yesterday
's
meat
or
pudding
when
it
came
on
to
-
day
's
table
,
without
thinking
that
he
was
debating
whether
I
had
been
in
the
pantry
.
<EOS>
That
,
if
Joe
knew
it
,
and
at
any
subsequent
period
of
our
joint
domestic
life
remarked
that
his
beer
was
flat
or
thick
,
the
conviction
that
he
suspected
Tar
in
it
,
would
bring
a
rush
of
blood
to
my
face
.
<EOS>
In
a
word
,
I
was
too
cowardly
to
do
what
I
knew
to
be
right
,
as
I
had
been
too
cowardly
to
avoid
doing
what
I
knew
to
be
wrong
.
<EOS>
I
had
had
no
intercourse
with
the
world
at
that
time
,
and
I
imitated
none
of
its
many
inhabitants
who
act
in
this
manner
.
<EOS>
Quite
an
untaught
genius
,
I
made
the
discovery
of
the
line
of
action
for
myself
.
  
<EOS>
As
I
was
sleepy
before
we
were
far
away
from
the
prison
-
ship
,
Joe
took
me
on
his
back
again
and
carried
me
home
.
<EOS>
He
must
have
had
a
tiresome
journey
of
it
,
for
Mr
Wopsle
,
being
knocked
up
,
was
in
such
a
very
bad
temper
that
if
the
Church
had
been
thrown
open
,
he
would
probably
have
excommunicated
the
whole
expedition
,
beginning
with
Joe
and
myself
.
<EOS>
In
his
lay
capacity
,
he
persisted
in
sitting
down
in
the
damp
to
such
an
insane
extent
,
that
when
his
coat
was
taken
off
to
be
dried
at
the
kitchen
fire
,
the
circumstantial
evidence
on
his
trousers
would
have
hanged
him
if
it
had
been
a
capital
offence
.
  
<EOS>
By
that
time
,
I
was
staggering
on
the
kitchen
floor
like
a
little
drunkard
,
through
having
been
newly
set
upon
my
feet
,
and
through
having
been
fast
asleep
,
and
through
waking
in
the
heat
and
lights
and
noise
of
tongues
.
<EOS>
As
I
came
to
myself
(
with
the
aid
of
a
heavy
thump
between
the
shoulders
,
and
the
restorative
exclamation
"
Yah
!
<EOS>
Was
there
ever
such
a
boy
as
this
!
"
<EOS>
from
my
sister
)
,
I
found
Joe
telling
them
about
the
convict
's
confession
,
and
all
the
visitors
suggesting
different
ways
by
which
he
had
got
into
the
pantry
.
<EOS>
Mr
Pumblechook
made
out
,
after
carefully
surveying
the
premises
,
that
he
had
first
got
upon
the
roof
of
the
forge
,
and
had
then
got
upon
the
roof
of
the
house
,
and
had
then
let
himself
down
the
kitchen
chimney
by
a
rope
made
of
his
bedding
cut
into
strips
;
and
as
Mr
Pumblechook
was
very
positive
and
drove
his
own
chaise
-
cart
---
over
everybody
<EOS>
---
it
was
agreed
that
it
must
be
so
.
<EOS>
Mr
Wopsle
,
indeed
,
wildly
cried
out
"
No
!
"
<EOS>
with
the
feeble
malice
of
a
tired
man
;
but
,
as
he
had
no
theory
,
and
no
coat
on
,
he
was
unanimously
set
at
nought
---
not
to
mention
his
smoking
hard
behind
,
as
he
stood
with
his
back
to
the
kitchen
fire
to
draw
the
damp
out
:
which
was
not
calculated
to
inspire
confidence
.
  
<EOS>
This
was
all
I
heard
that
night
before
my
sister
clutched
me
,
as
a
slumberous
offence
to
the
company
's
eyesight
,
and
assisted
me
up
to
bed
with
such
a
strong
hand
that
I
seemed
to
have
fifty
boots
on
,
and
to
be
dangling
them
all
against
the
edges
of
the
stairs
.
<EOS>
My
state
of
mind
,
as
I
have
described
it
,
began
before
I
was
up
in
the
morning
,
and
lasted
long
after
the
subject
had
died
out
,
and
had
ceased
to
be
mentioned
saving
on
exceptional
occasions
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
7
 
AT
<EOS>
the
time
when
I
stood
in
the
churchyard
,
reading
the
family
tombstones
<EOS>
,
I
had
just
enough
learning
to
be
able
to
spell
them
out
.
<EOS>
My
construction
even
of
their
simple
meaning
was
not
very
correct
,
for
I
read
"
wife
of
the
Above
"
as
a
complimentary
reference
to
my
father
's
exaltation
to
a
better
world
;
and
if
any
one
of
my
deceased
relations
had
been
referred
to
as
"
Below
,
"
I
have
no
doubt
I
should
have
formed
the
worst
opinions
of
that
member
of
the
family
.
<EOS>
Neither
,
were
my
notions
of
the
theological
positions
to
which
my
Catechism
bound
me
,
at
all
accurate
;
for
,
I
have
a
lively
remembrance
that
I
supposed
my
declaration
that
I
was
to
"
walk
in
the
same
all
the
days
of
my
life
,
"
laid
me
under
an
obligation
always
to
go
through
the
village
from
our
house
in
one
particular
direction
,
and
never
to
vary
it
by
turning
down
by
the
wheelwright
's
or
up
by
the
mill
.
  
<EOS>
When
I
was
old
enough
,
I
was
to
be
apprenticed
to
Joe
,
and
until
I
could
assume
that
dignity
<EOS>
I
was
not
to
be
what
Mrs
Joe
called
"
Pompeyed
,
"
<EOS>
or
(
as
I
render
it
)
pampered
.
<EOS>
Therefore
,
I
was
not
only
odd
-
boy
about
the
forge
,
but
if
any
neighbour
happened
to
want
an
extra
boy
to
frighten
birds
,
or
pick
up
stones
,
or
do
any
such
job
,
I
was
favoured
with
the
employment
.
<EOS>
In
order
,
however
.
<EOS>
that
our
superior
position
might
not
be
compromised
thereby
,
a
money
-
box
was
kept
on
the
kitchen
mantel
-
shelf
,
into
which
it
was
publicly
made
known
that
all
my
earnings
were
dropped
.
<EOS>
I
have
an
impression
that
they
were
to
be
contributed
eventually
towards
the
liquidation
of
the
National
Debt
,
but
<EOS>
I
know
I
had
no
hope
of
any
personal
participation
in
the
treasure
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Wopsle
's
great
-
aunt
kept
an
evening
school
in
the
village
;
that
is
to
say
,
she
was
a
ridiculous
old
woman
of
limited
means
and
unlimited
infirmity
,
who
used
to
go
to
sleep
from
six
to
seven
every
evening
,
in
the
society
of
youth
who
paid
twopence
per
week
each
,
for
the
improving
opportunity
of
seeing
her
do
it
.
<EOS>
She
rented
a
small
cottage
,
and
Mr
Wopsle
had
the
room
up
-
stairs
,
where
we
students
used
to
overhear
him
reading
aloud
in
a
most
dignified
and
terrific
manner
,
and
occasionally
bumping
on
the
ceiling
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
fiction
that
Mr
Wopsle
"
examined
"
the
scholars
,
once
a
quarter
.
<EOS>
What
he
did
on
those
occasions
was
to
turn
up
his
cuffs
,
stick
up
his
hair
,
and
give
us
Mark
Antony
's
oration
over
the
body
of
Caesar
.
<EOS>
This
was
always
followed
by
Collins
's
Ode
on
the
Passions
,
wherein
I
particularly
venerated
Mr
Wopsle
as
Revenge
,
throwing
his
blood
-
stained
sword
in
thunder
down
,
and
taking
the
War
-
denouncing
trumpet
with
a
withering
look
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
with
me
then
,
as
it
was
in
later
life
,
when
I
fell
into
the
society
of
the
passions
,
and
compared
them
with
Collins
and
Wopsle
,
rather
to
the
disadvantage
of
both
gentlemen
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Wopsle
's
great
-
aunt
,
besides
keeping
this
Educational
Institution
,
kept
---
in
the
same
room
---
a
little
general
shop
.
<EOS>
She
had
no
idea
what
stock
she
had
,
or
what
the
price
of
anything
in
it
was
;
but
there
was
a
little
greasy
memorandum
-
book
kept
in
a
drawer
,
which
served
as
a
Catalogue
of
Prices
,
and
by
this
oracle
Biddy
arranged
all
the
shop
transactions
.
<EOS>
Biddy
was
Mr
Wopsle
's
great
-
aunt
's
granddaughter
;
I
confess
myself
quite
unequal
to
the
working
out
of
the
problem
,
what
relation
she
was
to
Mr
Wopsle
.
<EOS>
She
was
an
orphan
like
myself
;
like
me
,
too
,
had
been
brought
up
by
hand
.
<EOS>
She
was
most
noticeable
,
I
thought
,
in
respect
of
her
extremities
;
for
,
her
hair
always
wanted
brushing
,
her
hands
always
wanted
washing
,
and
her
shoes
always
wanted
mending
and
pulling
up
at
heel
.
<EOS>
This
description
must
be
received
with
a
week
-
day
limitation
.
<EOS>
On
Sundays
,
she
went
to
church
elaborated
.
  
<EOS>
Much
of
my
unassisted
self
,
and
more
by
the
help
of
Biddy
than
of
Mr
Wopsle
's
great
-
aunt
,
I
struggled
through
the
alphabet
as
if
it
had
been
a
bramble
-
bush
;
getting
considerably
worried
and
scratched
by
every
letter
.
<EOS>
After
that
,
I
fell
among
those
thieves
,
the
nine
figures
,
who
seemed
every
evening
to
do
something
new
to
disguise
themselves
and
baffle
recognition
.
<EOS>
But
,
at
last
I
began
,
in
a
purblind
groping
way
,
to
read
,
write
,
and
cipher
,
on
the
very
smallest
scale
.
  
<EOS>
One
night
,
I
was
sitting
in
the
chimney
-
corner
with
my
slate
,
expending
great
efforts
on
the
production
of
a
letter
to
Joe
.
<EOS>
I
think
it
must
have
been
a
full
year
after
our
hunt
upon
the
marshes
,
for
it
was
a
long

after
,
and
it
was
winter
and

.
<EOS>
With

,

"
MI
DERE
JO
<EOS>
i
OPE
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

(

)

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
Pip
,

!
"

,

,
"

!
<EOS>
An't

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

like

,
"

,

:

.

"
Why
,

J^
,

,
"

!
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"

,

,

!

But

The

,

,

Joes

"

<EOS>
"

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Pursuing

"

,

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Pip
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why

,
Joe
,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Pip
,
"
said

,

preparations
,
they
drove
up
,
wrapped
to
the
eyes
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Joe
was
soon
landed
,
and
Uncle
Pumblechook
was
soon
down
too
,
covering
the
mare
with
a
cloth
,
and
we
were
soon
all
in
the
kitchen
,
carrying
so
much
cold
air
in
with
us
that
it
seemed
to
drive
all
the
heat
out
of
the
fire
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"
said
Mrs
Joe
,
unwrapping
herself
with
haste
and

,
and
throwing
her
bonnet
back
on
her
shoulders
where
it
hung
by
the
strings
:
"
if
this
boy
an't
grateful
this
night
,
he
never
will
be
!
"
  
<EOS>
I
looked
as
grateful
as
any
boy
possibly
could
,
who
was
wholly
uninformed
why
he
ought
to
assume
that
expression
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
only
to
be
hoped
,
"
said
my
sister
,
"
that
he
wo
n't
be
Pompeyed
.
<EOS>
But
I
have
my
fears
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
an't
in
that
line
,
Mum
,
"
said
Mr
Pumblechook
.
<EOS>
"
She
knows
better
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
?
<EOS>
I
looked
at
Joe
,
making
the
motion
with
my
lips
and

,
"
She
?
"
<EOS>
Joe
looked
at
me
,
making
the
motion
with
 
\
his
\
 
lips
and
eyebrows
,
"
She
?
<EOS>
"
My
sister
catching
him
in
the

,

the
back
of
his
hand
across
his
nose
with
his
usual

air

,

at

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
?
"
said
my
sister
,
in
her

.
<EOS>
"
What
are
you
staring
at
?
<EOS>
Is

a
-
fire
?
"
  
"
---
Which
some
individual
,
"
Joe
politely

,
"
mentioned---
she
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
she
is
a
she
,
I

?
"
said
my
sister
.
<EOS>
"
Unless

Miss
Havisham
a
he
.
<EOS>
And
I

'll

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Miss
Havisham
,
up

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Is

any
Miss
Havisham
down

?
"

.
<EOS>
"
She
wants
this
boy
to
go
and

there
.
<EOS>
And
of

's

.
<EOS>
And

,
"

,

to

,
"
or

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
had
heard
of
Miss
Havisham
up

---
<EOS>
everybody

miles
round
,
had
heard

Miss
Havisham
up
town
---
as
an
immensely

who

against

,
and
who

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
to

!
<EOS>
"
said
Joe
,

.
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
how
she
come
to

Pip
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Noodle
!
"
cried
my
sister
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Who
said
she
knew
him
?
"
  
"
---
Which
some
individual
,
"
Joe
again

,
"
<EOS>
mentioned
that
she

him
to
go
and

there
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
could

she
ask
Uncle
Pumblechook
if

a
boy

go
and

?
<EOS>
Is

Uncle

may

,
and

may
sometimes
<EOS>
---
we
wo

,

go

?
<EOS>
And
could

Uncle

?
<EOS>
And
could

Uncle
Pumblechook
,

us
---
though

,
Joseph
,
"

"

,

here
"
---

---
"
that
I
have

a

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Good
again
!
"

.
<EOS>
"
Well
put
!
<EOS>
Prettily
pointed
!
<EOS>
Good

!
<EOS>
Now
Joseph
,
you
know
the
case
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
No
,
Joseph
,
"
said

sister
,

,

the

hand
across
and

,
<EOS>
"
you
do

yet
---

---
know

.
<EOS>
You

,
but
you
do
 
\
not
,
\
 
Joseph
.
<EOS>
For
you
do
not
know
that
Uncle
Pumblechook
,
being
sensible
that
for
anything
we
can
tell
,
this
boy
's
fortune
may
be
made
by
his
going
to
Miss
Havisham
's
,
has

into

,
and
to

to
-

,
and

to
Miss
Havisham
's
to

morrow

.
<EOS>
And
Lor
-
a
-
mussy
me
!
"
cried

,
casting

in

,
"
<EOS>
here
I
stand
talking
to
mere

,
with
Uncle

,
and

mare

,
and

with
crock
and

from

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
With
that
,
she
pounced
upon
me
,
like
an
eagle
on
a
lamb
,
and
my
face
was
squeezed
into

in

,
and
my
head
was
put
under
taps
of
water

,
and
I
was
soaped
,
and

,
and
towelled
,
and
thumped
,
and
harrowed
,
and
rasped
,
until
I
really
was
quite
beside
myself
.
<EOS>
(
I
may
here
remark
that
I
suppose
myself
to
be
better
acquainted
than
any
living
authority
,
with
the
ridgy
effect
of
a
wedding
-
ring
,
passing
unsympathetically
over
the
human
countenance
.
)
  
<EOS>
When
my
ablutions
were
completed
,
I
was
put
into
clean
linen
of
the
stiffest
character
,
like
a
young
penitent
into
sackcloth
,
and
was
trussed
up
in
my
tightest
and
fearfullest
suit
.
<EOS>
I
was
then
delivered
over
to
Mr
Pumblechook
,
who
formally
received
me
as
if
he
were
the
Sheriff
,
and
who
let
off
upon
me
the
speech
that
I
knew
he
had
been
dying
to
make
all
along
:
<EOS>
"
Boy
,
be
for
ever
grateful
to
all
friends
,
but
especially
unto
them
which
brought
you
up
by
hand
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Good
-
bye
,
Joe
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
God
bless
you
,
Pip
,
old
chap
!
"
  
<EOS>
I
had
never
parted
from
him
before
,
and
what
with
my
feelings
and
what
with
soap
-

,
I
could
at
first
see
no

from
the
chaise
-
cart
.
<EOS>
But
they
twinkled
out
one

one
,
without
throwing
any
light
on
the
questions
why
on
earth
I
was
going
to
play
at
Miss
Havisham
's
,
and
what
on
earth
<EOS>
I
was
expected
to
play
at
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
8
 
<EOS>
MR
PUMBLECHOOK
's
premises
in
the
High
-
street
of
the
market
town
,
were
of
a
peppercorny
and
farinaceous
character
,
as
the
premises
of
a
corn
-
chandler
and
seedsman
should
be
.
<EOS>
It
appeared
to
me
that
he
must
be
a
very
happy
man
indeed
,
to
have
so
many
little
drawers
in
his
shop
;
and
I
wondered
when
I
peeped
into
one
or
two
on
the
lower
tiers
,
and
saw
the
tied
-
up
brown
paper
packets
inside
,
whether
the
flower
-
seeds
and
bulbs
ever
wanted
of
a
fine
day
to
break
out
of
those
jails
,
and
bloom
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
in
the
early
morning
after
my
arrival
that
I
entertained
this
speculation
.
<EOS>
On
the
previous
night
,
I
had
been
sent
straight
to
bed
in
an
attic
with
a
sloping
roof
,
which
was
so
low
in
the
corner
where
the
bedstead
was
,
that
I
calculated
the
tiles
as
being
within
a
foot
of
my
eyebrows
.
<EOS>
In
the
same
early
morning
,
I
discovered
a
singular
affinity
between
seeds
and
corduroys
.
<EOS>
Mr
Pumblechook
wore
corduroys
,
and
so
did
his
shopman
;
and
somehow
,
there
was
a
general
air
and
flavour
about
the
corduroys
,
so
much
in
the
nature
of
seeds
,
and
a
general
air
and
flavour
about
the
seeds
,
so
much
in
the
nature
of
corduroys
,
that
I
hardly
knew
which
was
which
.
<EOS>
The
same
opportunity
served
me
for
noticing
that
Mr
Pumblechook
appeared
to
conduct
his
business
by
looking
across
the
street
at
the
saddler
,
who
appeared
to
transact
his
business
by
keeping
his
eye
on
the
coach
-
maker
,
who
appeared
to
get
on
in
life
by
putting
his
hands
in
his
pockets
and
contemplating
the
baker
,
who
in
his
turn
folded
his
arms
and
stared
at
the
grocer
,
who
stood
at
his
door
and
yawned
at
the
chemist
.
<EOS>
The
watchmaker
,
always
poring
over
a
little
desk
with
a
magnifying
glass
at
his
eye
,
and
always
inspected
by
a
group
of
smock
-
frocks
poring
over
him
through
the
glass
of
his
shop
-
window
,
seemed
to
be
about
the
only
person
in
the
High
-
street
whose
trade
engaged
his
attention
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Pumblechook
and
I
breakfasted
at
eight
o'clock
in
the
parlour
behind
the
shop
,
while
the
shopman
took
his
mug
of
tea
and
hunch
of
bread
-
and
-
butter
on
a
sack
of
peas
in
the
front
premises
.
<EOS>
I
considered
Mr
Pumblechook
wretched
company
.
<EOS>
Besides
being
possessed
by
my
sister
's
idea
that
a
mortifying
and
penitential
character
ought
to
be
imparted
to
my
diet
---
besides
giving
me
as
much
crumb
as
possible
in
combination
with
as
little
butter
,
and
putting
such
a
quantity
of
warm
water
into
my
milk
that
it
would
have
been
more
candid
to
have
left
the
milk
out
altogether
---
his
conversation
consisted
of
nothing
but
arithmetic
.
<EOS>
On
my
politely
bidding
him
Good
morning
,
he
said
,
pompously
,
"
Seven
times
nine
,
boy
?
"
<EOS>
And
how
should
I
be
able
to
answer
,
dodged
in
that
way
,
in
a
strange
place
,
on
an
empty
stomach
!
<EOS>
I
was
hungry
,
but
before
I
had
swallowed
a
morsel
,
he
began
a
running
sum
that
lasted
all
through
the
breakfast
.
"
<EOS>
Seven
?
"
<EOS>
"
And
four
?
"
<EOS>
"
And
eight
?
"
<EOS>
"
And
six
?
"
<EOS>
"
And
two
?
"
<EOS>
"
And
ten
?
"
<EOS>
And
so
on
.
<EOS>
And
after
each
figure
was
disposed
of
,
it
was
as
much
as
I
could
do
to
get
a
bite
or
a
sup
,
before
the
next
came
;
while
he
sat
at
his
ease
guessing
nothing
,
and
eating
bacon
and
hot
roll
,
in
(
if
I
may
be
allowed
the
expression
)
a
gorging
and
gormandising
manner
.
  
<EOS>
For
such
reasons
I
was
very
glad
when
ten
o'clock
came
and
we
started
for
Miss
Havisham
's
;
though
I
was
not
at
all
at
my
ease
regarding
the
manner
in
which
I
should
acquit
myself
under
that
lady
's
roof
.
<EOS>
Within
a
quarter
of
an
hour
we
came
to
Miss
Havisham
's
house
,
which
was
of
old
brick
,
and
dismal
,
and
had
a
great
many
iron
bars
to
it
.
<EOS>
Some
of
the
windows
had
been
walled
up
;
of
those
that
remained
,
all
the
lower
were
rustily
barred
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
court
-
yard
in
front
,
and
that
was
barred
;
so
,
we
had
to
wait
,
after
ringing
the
bell
,
until
some
one
should
come
to
open
it
.
<EOS>
While
we
waited
at
the
gate
,
I
peeped
in
(
even
then
Mr
Pumblechook
said
,
"
<EOS>
And
fourteen
?
"
<EOS>
but
I
pretended
not
to
hear
him
)
,
and
saw
that
at
the
side
of
the
house
there
was
a
large
brewery
.
<EOS>
No
brewing
was
going
on
in
it
,
and
none
seemed
to
have
gone
on
for
a
long
long
time
.
  
<EOS>
A
window
was
raised
,
and
a
clear
voice
demanded
"
What
name
?
"
<EOS>
To
which
my
conductor
replied
,
"
Pumblechook
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
voice
returned
,
"
Quite
right
,
"
and
the
window
was
shut
again
,
and
a
young
lady
came
across
the
court
-
yard
,
with
keys
in
her
hand
.
  
<EOS>
"
This
,
"
said
Mr
Pumblechook
,
"
is
Pip
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
This
is
Pip
,
is
it
?
"
returned
the
young
lady
,
who
was
very
pretty
and
seemed
very
proud
;
"
come
in
,
Pip
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Pumblechook
was
coming
in
also
,
when
she
stopped
him
with
the
gate
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
Did
you
wish
to
see
Miss
Havisham
?
"
  
"
If
Miss
Havisham
wished
to
see
me
,
"
returned
Mr
Pumblechook
discomfited
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
girl
;
"
but
you
see
she
do
n't
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
said
it
so
finally
,
and
in
such
an
undiscussible
way
,
that
Mr
Pumblechook
,
though
in
a
condition
of
ruffled
dignity
,
could
not
protest
.
<EOS>
But
he
eyed
me
severely
---
as
if
I
had
done
anything
to
him
!
<EOS>
---
and
departed
with
the
words
reproachfully
delivered
:
"
Boy
!
<EOS>
Let
your
behaviour
here
be
a
credit
unto
them
which
brought
you
up
by
hand
!
<EOS>
"
I
was
not
free
from
apprehension
that
he
would
come
back
to
propound
through
the
gate
,
"
And
sixteen
?
"
<EOS>
But
he
did
n't
.
  
<EOS>
My
young
conductress
locked
the
gate
,
and
we
went
across
the
court
-
yard
.
<EOS>
It
was
paved
and
clean
,
but
grass
was
growing
in
every

.
<EOS>
The
brewery
buildings
had
a
little
lane
of
communication
with
it
;
and
the

of
that

stood
open
,
and
all
the
brewery
beyond
,
stood
open
,
away
to
the
high
enclosing
wall
;
and
all
was
empty
and
disused
.
<EOS>
The
cold
wind
seemed
to
blow
colder
there
,
than
outside
the
gate
;
and
it
made
a
shrill
noise
in
howling
in
and
out
at
the
open
sides
of
the
brewery
,
like
the
noise
of

in
the

of
a

sea
.
<EOS>
myself
in
a
pretty
large
room
,
well
lighted
with
wax

.
<EOS>
No
glimpse
of
daylight
was
to
be

in

.
<EOS>
It
was
a
dressing
-
room
,
as
I
supposed
from
the
furniture
,
though
much

was
of
forms
and

then

me
.
<EOS>
But

was
a

a

-
glass
,
and
that
I

to
be
a
fine
lady
's
dressing
-
table
.
  
<EOS>
Whether
I
should
have
made
out
this
object
so
soon
,
if
there
had
been
no
fine
lady
sitting
at
it
,
I
can
not

.
<EOS>
In
an

,

and
her

,
sat
the
strangest

have

,
or
shall

.
  
<EOS>
She
was
dressed
in
rich
materials
---
satins
,
and

,
and
silks
---
all
of
white
.
<EOS>
Her

were
white
.
<EOS>
And
she
had
a
long
white
veil
dependent
from
her
hair
,
and
she
had
bridal
flowers
in
her
hair
,
but
her
hair
was
white
.
<EOS>
Some
bright

sparkled
on
her

hands
,
and
some

lay

on

.
<EOS>
Dresses
,
less

than
the
dress
she

,
and
half

,
were

.
<EOS>
She
had
not
quite

dressing
for
she
had
<EOS>
but
one
shoe
on
---
the
other
was
on
the
table
near

hand
---
<EOS>
her
veil
was
but
half

,
her
watch
and

were

on
,
and
some

for

with
those

,
and

,
and

,
and
some

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
It
was

I

,

.
<EOS>
But
,

saw

within

which
ought

,
had

,
and

.
<EOS>
I
saw
that
the
bride
within
the

had
withered

dress
,
and
like

,
and
had
no

but

.
<EOS>
I

that
the

had
been

rounded

a

woman
,
and
that
the

,

.
<EOS>
Once
,

Fair
,
representing
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Once

,

.
<EOS>
Now
,
waxwork

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Who

?
"

<EOS>
"
Pip
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Pip
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr

's

,

.
<EOS>
Come
---
to

.
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
(

)

"
What

?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Your

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Broken
!
"
  
<EOS>
She

and

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

,

I
have
done

.
<EOS>
Play
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I

,
that

<EOS>
"
I

"

"

<EOS>
There

"
with

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
So

.
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Without

"
<EOS>
And

<EOS>

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
Her

.
  
<EOS>
She

<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>

?
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

.
"
<EOS>
(

)

"
Anything

?
<EOS>

.

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

,
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Play

,
out
.
  
<EOS>
Saving

's

.
<EOS>
It

---
most

.
<EOS>
Her

,

,

body
and
soul
,
within
and
without
,
under
the
weight
of
a
crushing
blow
.
  
<EOS>
I
played
the
game
to
an
end
with
Estella
,
and
she
beggared
me
.
<EOS>
She
threw
the
cards
down
on
the
table
when
she
had
won
them
all
,
as
if
she
despised
them
for
having
been
won
of
me
.
  
<EOS>
"
When
shall
I
have
you
here
again
?
"
said
Miss
Havisham
.
<EOS>
"
Let
me
think
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
was
beginning
to
remind
her
that
to
-
day
was
Wednesday
,
when
she
checked
me
with
her
former
impatient
movement
of
the
fingers
of
her
right
hand
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
,
there
!
<EOS>
I
know
nothing
of
days
of
the
week
;
I
know
nothing
of
weeks
of
the
year
.
<EOS>
Come
again
after
six
days
.
<EOS>
You
hear
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
ma'am
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Estella
,
take
him
down
.
<EOS>
Let
him
have
something
to
eat
,
and
let
him
roam
and
look
about
him
while
he
eats
.
<EOS>
Go
,
Pip
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
followed
the
candle
down
,
as
I
had
followed
the
candle
up
,
and
she
stood
it
in
the
place
where
we
had
found
it
.
<EOS>
Until
she
opened
the
side
entrance
,
I
had
fancied
,
without
thinking
about
it
,
that
it
must
necessarily
be
night
-
time
.
<EOS>
The
rush
of
the
daylight
quite
confounded
me
,
and
made
me
feel
as
if
I
had
been
in
the
candlelight
of
the
strange
room
many
hours
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
to
wait
here
,
you
boy
,
"
said
Estella
;
and
disappeared
and
closed
the
door
.
  
<EOS>
I
took
the
opportunity
of
being
alone
in
the
court
-
yard
,
to
look
at
my
coarse
hands
and
my
common
boots
.
<EOS>
My
opinion
of
those
accessories
was
not
favourable
.
<EOS>
They
had
never
troubled
me
before
,
but
they
troubled
me
now
,
as
vulgar
appendages
.
<EOS>
I
determined
to
ask
Joe
why
he
had
ever
taught
me
to
call
those
picture
-
cards
,
Jacks
,
which
ought
to
be
called
knaves
.
<EOS>
I
wished
Joe
had
been
rather
more
genteelly
brought
up
,
and
then
I
should
have
been
so
too
.
  
<EOS>
She
came
back
,
with
some
bread
and
meat
and
a
little
mug
of
beer
.
<EOS>
She
put
the
mug
down
on
the
stones
of
the
yard
,
and
gave
me
the
bread
and
meat
without
looking
at
me
,
as
insolently
as
if
I
were
a
dog
in
disgrace
.
<EOS>
I
was
so
humiliated
,
hurt
,
spurned
,
offended
,
angry
,
sorry
---
<EOS>
I
can
not
hit
upon
the
right
name
for
the
smart
<EOS>
---
God
knows
what
its
name
was
---
that
tears
started
to
my
eyes
.
<EOS>
The
moment
they
sprang
there
,
the
girl
looked
at
me
with
a
quick
delight
in
having
been
the
cause
of
them
.
<EOS>
This
gave
me
power
to
keep
them
back
and
to
look
at
her
:
<EOS>
so
,
she
gave
a
contemptuous
toss
---
<EOS>
but
with
a
sense
,
I
thought
,
of
having
made
too
sure
that
I
was
so
wounded
---
and
left
me
.
  
<EOS>
But
,
when
she
was
gone
,
I
looked
about
me
for
a
place
to
hide
my
face
in
,
and
got
behind
one
of
the
gates
in
the
brewery
-
lane
,
and
leaned
my
sleeve
against
the
wall
there
,
and
leaned
my
forehead
on
it
and
cried
.
<EOS>
As
I
cried
,
I
kicked
the
wall
,
and
took
a
hard
twist
at
my
hair
;
so
bitter
were
my
feelings
,
and
so
sharp
was
the
smart
without
a
name
,
that
needed
counteraction
.
  
<EOS>
My
sister
's
bringing
up
had
made
me
sensitive
.
<EOS>
In
the
little
world
in
which
children
have
their
existence
whosoever
brings
them
up
,
there
is
nothing
so
finely
perceived
and
so
finely
felt
,
as
injustice
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
only
small
injustice
that
the
child
can
be
exposed
to
;
but
the
child
is
small
,
and
its
world
is
small
,
and
its
rocking
-
horse
stands
as
many
hands
high
,
according
to
scale
,
as
a
big
-
boned
Irish
hunter
.
<EOS>
Within
myself
,
I
had
sustained
,
from
my
babyhood
,
a
perpetual
conflict
with
injustice
.
<EOS>
I
had
known
,
from
the
time
when
I
could
speak
,
that
my
sister
,
in
her
capricious
and
violent
coercion
,
was
unjust
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
had
cherished
a
profound
conviction
that
her
bringing
me
up
by
hand
,
gave
her
no
right
to
bring
me
up
by
jerks
.
<EOS>
Through
all
my
punishments
,
disgraces
,
fasts
and
vigils
,
and
other
penitential
performances
,
I
had
nursed
this
assurance
;
and
to
my
communing
so
much
with
it
,
in
a
solitary
and
unprotected
way
,
I
in
great
part
refer
the
fact
that
I
was
morally
timid
and
very
sensitive
.
  
<EOS>
I
got
rid
of
my
injured
feelings
for
the
time
,
by
kicking
them
into
the
brewery
wall
,
and
twisting
them
out
of
my
hair
,
and
then
I
smoothed
my
face
with
my
sleeve
,
and
came
from
behind
the
gate
.
<EOS>
The
bread
and
meat
were
acceptable
,
and
the
beer
was
warming
and
tingling
,
and
I
was
soon
in
spirits
to
look
about
me
.
  
<EOS>
To
be
sure
,
it
was
a
deserted
place
,
down
to
the
pigeon
-
house
in
the
brewery
-
yard
,
which
had
been
blown
crooked
on
its
pole
by
some
high
wind
,
and
would
have
made
the
pigeons
think
themselves
at
sea
,
if
there
had
been
any
pigeons
there
to
be
rocked
by
it
.
<EOS>
But
,
there
were
no
pigeons
in
the
dove
-
cot
,
no
horses
in
the
stable
,
<EOS>
no
pigs
in
the
sty
,
no
malt
in
the
store
-
house
,
no
smells
of
grains
and
beer
in
the
copper
or
the
vat
.
<EOS>
All
the
uses
and
scents
of
the
brewery
might
have
evaporated
with
its
last
reek
of
smoke
.
<EOS>
In
a
by
-
yard
,
there
was
a
wilderness
of
empty
casks
,
which
had
a
certain
sour
remembrance
of
better
days
lingering
about
them
;
but
it
was
too
sour
to
be
accepted
as
a
sample
of
the
beer
that
was
gone
---
and
in
this
respect
I
remember
those
recluses
as
being
like
most
others
.
  
<EOS>
Behind
the
furthest
end
of
the
brewery
,
was
a
rank
garden
with
an
old
wall
:
not
so
high
but
that
I
could
struggle
up
and
hold
on
long
enough
to
look
over
it
,
and
see
that
the
rank
garden
was
the
garden
of
the
house
,
and
that
it
was
overgrown
with
tangled
weeds
,
but
that
there
was
a
track
upon
the
green
and
yellow
paths
,
as
if
some
one
sometimes
walked
there
,
and
that
Estella
was
walking
away
from
me
even
then
.
<EOS>
But
she
seemed
to
be
everywhere
.
<EOS>
For
,
when
I
yielded
to
the
temptation
presented
by
the
casks
,
and
began
to
walk
on
them
,
I
saw
 
<EOS>
\
<EOS>
her
<EOS>
\
 
<EOS>
walking
on
them
at
the
end
of
the
yard
of
casks
.
<EOS>
She
had
her
back
towards
me
,
and
held
her
pretty
brown
hair
spread
out
in
her
two
hands
,
and
never
looked
round
,
and
passed
out
of
my
view
directly
.
<EOS>
So
,
in
the
brewery
itself---
by
which
I
mean
the
large
paved
lofty
place
in
which
they
used
to
make
the
beer
,
and
where
the
brewing
utensils
still
were
.
<EOS>
When
I
first
went
into
it
,
and
,
rather
oppressed
by
its
gloom
,
stood
near
the
door
looking
about
me
,
I
saw
her
pass
among
the
extinguished
fires
,
and
ascend
some
light
iron
stairs
,
and
go
out
by
a
gallery
high
overhead
,
as
if
she
were
going
out
into

.
  
<EOS>
It
was
in
this
place
,
and
at
this
moment
,
that
a
strange
thing
happened
to
my
fancy
.
<EOS>
I
thought
it
a
strange
thing
then
,
and
I
thought
it
a
stranger
thing
long
afterwards
.
<EOS>
I
turned
my
eyes
---
a
little
dimmed
by
looking
up
at
the
frosty
light
---
towards
a
great

in
a

of
the
building
near
me
on

right
hand
,
and
I

a
figure
hanging
there
by
