neck
.
<EOS>
A
figure
all
in
yellow
white
,
with
but
one
shoe
to
the
feet
;
and
it
hung
so
,
that
I
could
see
that
the
faded
trimmings
of
the
dress
were
like
earthy
paper
,
and
that
the
face
was
Miss
Havisham
's
,
with
a
movement
going
over
the
whole
countenance
as
if
she
were
trying
to
call
to
me
.
<EOS>
In
the
terror
of
seeing
the
figure
,
and
in
the
terror
of
being
certain
that
it
had
not
been
there
a
moment
before
,
I
at
first
ran
from
it
,
and
then
ran
towards
it
.
<EOS>
And
my
terror
was
greatest
of
all
,
when
I
found
no
figure
there
.
  
<EOS>
Nothing
less
than
the
frosty
light
of
the
cheerful
sky
,
the
sight
of
people
passing
beyond
the
bars
of
the
court
-
yard
gate
,
and
the
reviving
influence
of
the
rest
of
the
bread
and
meat
and
beer
,
would
have
brought
me
round
.
<EOS>
Even
with
those
aids
,
I
might
not
have
come
to
myself
as
soon
as
I
did
,
but
that
I
saw
Estella
approaching
with
the
keys
,
to
let
me
out
.
<EOS>
She
would
have
some
fair
reason
for
looking
down
upon
me
,
I
thought
,
if
she
saw
me
frightened
;
and
she
should
have
no
fair
reason
.
  
<EOS>
She
gave
me
a
triumphant
glance
in
passing
me
,
as
if
she
rejoiced
that
my
hands
were
so
coarse
and
my
boots
were
so
thick
,
and
she
opened
the
gate
,
and
stood
holding
it
.
<EOS>
I
was
passing
out
without
looking
at
her
,
when
she
touched
me
with
a
taunting
hand
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
do
n't
you
cry
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Because
I
do
n't
want
to
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
do
,
"
said
she
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
been
crying
till
you
are
half
blind
,
and
you
are
near
crying
again
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
laughed
contemptuously
,
pushed
me
out
,
and
locked
the
gate
upon
me
.
<EOS>
I
went
straight
to
Mr
Pumblechook
's
,
and
was
immensely
relieved
to
find
him
not
at
home
.
<EOS>
So
,
leaving
word
with
the
shopman
on
what
day
I
was
wanted
at
Miss
Havisham
's
again
,
I
set
off
on
the
four
-
mile
walk
to
our
forge
;
pondering
,
as
I
went
along
,
on
all
I
had
seen
,
and
deeply
revolving
that
I
was
a
common
labouring
-
boy
;
that
my
hands
were
coarse
;
that
my
boots
were
thick
;
that
I
had
fallen
into
a
despicable
habit
of
calling
knaves
Jacks
;
that
I
was
much
more
ignorant
than
I
had
considered
myself
last
night
,
and
generally
that
I
was
in
a
low
-
lived
bad
way
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
09
 
<EOS>
WHEN
I
reached
home
,
my
sister
was
very
curious
to
know
all
about
Miss
Havisham
's
,
and
asked
a
number
of
questions
.
<EOS>
And
I
soon
found
myself
getting
heavily
bumped
from
behind
in
the
nape
of
the
neck
and
the
small
of
the
back
,
and
having
my
face
ignominiously
shoved
against
the
kitchen
wall
,
because
I
did
not
answer
those
questions
at
sufficient
length
.
  
<EOS>
If
a
dread
of
not
being
understood
be
hidden
in
the
breasts
of
other
young
people
to
anything
like
the
extent
to
which
it
used
to
be
hidden
in
mine
---
which
I
consider
probable
,
as
I
have
no
particular
reason
to
suspect
myself
of
having
been
a
monstrosity
---
it
is
the
key
to
many
reservations
.
<EOS>
I
felt
convinced
that
if
I
described
Miss
Havisham
's
as
my
eyes
had
seen
it
,
I
should
not
be
understood
.
 
<EOS>
Not
only
that
,
but
<EOS>
I
felt
convinced
that
Miss
Havisham
too
would
not
be
understood
;
and
although
she
was
perfectly
incomprehensible
to
me
,
I
entertained
an
impression
that
there
would
be
something
coarse
and
treacherous
in
my
dragging
her
as
she
really
was
(
to
say
nothing
of
Miss
Estella
)
before
the
contemplation
of
Mrs.
Joe
.
 
<EOS>
Consequently
,
I
said
as
little
as
I
could
,
and
had
my
face
shoved
against
the
kitchen
wall
.
  
<EOS>
The
worst
of
it
was
that
that
bullying
old
Pumblechook
,
preyed
upon
by
a
devouring
curiosity
to
be
informed
of
all
I
had
seen
and
heard
,
came
gaping
over
in
his
chaise
-
cart
at
tea
-
time
,
to
have
the
details
divulged
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
And
the
mere
sight
of
the
torment
,
with
his
fishy
eyes
and
mouth
open
,
his
sandy
hair
inquisitively
on
end
,
and
his
waistcoat
heaving
with
windy
arithmetic
,
made
me
vicious
in
my
reticence
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
boy
,
"
Uncle
Pumblechook
began
,
as
soon
as
he
was
seated
in
the
chair
of
honour
by
the
fire
.
"
<EOS>
How
did
you
get
on
up
town
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
answered
,
"
Pretty
well
,
sir
,
"
and
my
sister
shook
her
fist
at
me
.
  
<EOS>
"
Pretty
well
?
"
Mr.
Pumblechook
repeated
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Pretty
well
is
no
answer
.
<EOS>
Tell
us
what
you
mean
by
pretty
well
,
boy
?
"
  
<EOS>
Whitewash
on
the
forehead
hardens
the
brain
into
a
state
of
obstinacy
perhaps
.
<EOS>
Anyhow
,
with
whitewash
from
the
wall
on
my
forehead
,
my
obstinacy
was
adamantine
.
<EOS>
I
reflected
for
some
time
,
and
then
answered
as
if
I
had
discovered
a
new
idea
,
"
I
mean
pretty
well
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
My
sister
with
an
exclamation
of
impatience
was
going
to
fly
at
me
---
I
had
no
shadow
of
defence
,
for
Joe
was
busy
in
the
forge
---
when
Mr
Pumblechook
interposed
with
"
No
!
<EOS>
Do
n't
lose
your
temper
.
<EOS>
Leave
this
lad
to
me
,
ma'am
;
leave
this
lad
to
me
.
"
<EOS>
Mr
Pumblechook
then
turned
me
towards
him
,
as
if
he
were
going
to
cut
my
hair
,
and
said
:
  
"
<EOS>
First
(
to
get
our
thoughts
in
order
)
:
Forty
-
three
pence
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
calculated
the
consequences
of
replying
"
Four
Hundred
Pound
,
"
and
finding
them
against
me
,
went
as
near
the
answer
as
I
could
---
which
was
somewhere
about
eightpence
off
.
<EOS>
Mr
Pumblechook
then
put
me
through
my
pence
-
table
from
"
twelve
pence
make
one
shilling
,
"
up
to
"
forty
pence
<EOS>
make
three
and
fourpence
,
"
and
then
triumphantly
demanded
,
as
if
he
had
done
for
me
,
"
\
Now
!
<EOS>
\
 
<EOS>
How
much
is
forty
-
three
pence
?
"
<EOS>
To
which
I
replied
,
after
a
long
interval
of
reflection
,
"
I
do
n't
know
.
"
<EOS>
And
I
was
so
aggravated
that
I
almost
doubt
if
I
did
know
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Pumblechook
worked
his
head
like
a
screw
to
screw
it
out
of
me
,
and
said
,
"
Is
forty
-
three
pence
seven
and
sixpence
three
fardens
,
for
instance
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
!
"
said
I.
<EOS>
And
although
my
sister
instantly
boxed
my
ears
,
it
was
highly
gratifying
to
me
to
see
that
the
answer
spoilt
his
joke
,
and
brought
him
to
a
dead
stop
.
  
<EOS>
"
Boy
!
<EOS>
What
like
is
Miss
Havisham
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Pumblechook
began
again
when
he
had
recovered
;
folding
his
arms
tight
on
his
chest
and
applying
the
screw
.
  
<EOS>
"
Very
tall
and
dark
,
"
I
told
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
she
,
uncle
?
"
asked
my
sister
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Pumblechook
winked
assent
;
from
which
I
at
once
inferred
that
he
had
never
seen
Miss
Havisham
,
for
she
was
nothing
of
the
kind
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
!
"
said
Mr
Pumblechook
conceitedly
.
<EOS>
(
"
This
is
the
way
to
have
him
!
<EOS>
We
are
beginning
to
hold
our
own
,
I
think
,
Mum
?
"
)
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
,
uncle
,
"
returned
Mrs
Joe
,
"
<EOS>
I
wish
you
had
him
always
:
you
know
so
well
how
to
deal

him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
boy
!
<EOS>
What
was
she
a
doing
of
,
when
you
went
in
to
-
day
?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
She
was

,
"
I

,
"
in
a
black

.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Pumblechook
and
Mrs
Joe
stared
at

---
as
they
well

---
and
both

,
"
In
a
black
velvet
coach
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
I.
"
<EOS>
And
Miss
Estella
---
that
's
her
niece
,
I

---
handed
her
in
cake

the

,
on

.
<EOS>
And
we
all

cake
and

.
<EOS>
And
I
got
up
behind
the

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Four
dogs
,
"

"
Large

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Immense
,
"
said
I.
"
<EOS>
And
they
fought
for
veal

out

.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Pumblechook
and
Mrs

stared

,

.
<EOS>
I
was
perfectly

---
a
reckless
witness
under

---
and
would

.
  
<EOS>
"
Where
 
\
was
\
 
<EOS>
this

,

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
In

's

.
<EOS>
"

.
"
<EOS>
But
there

.
<EOS>
"
I
added
this
saving

,
in

four

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

?
"

.
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll

,
Mum
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
My

,

's

.
<EOS>
She
's

,

---

---

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

"

"

<EOS>
Never

!
"
  
<EOS>

!
<EOS>

?

<EOS>

,

"

,

"

,

.
<EOS>
Do

do

\

that
,
\

.

Howsever
,

.

What

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We

,
"
I

.
<EOS>
(
I

,

.
)
  
<EOS>
"
Flags
!
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
<EOS>
I.
"
Estella
waved

,

I

,

Miss
Havisham
waved

sprinkled
all

,
out

.
<EOS>
And

and

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Swords
!
"
repeated

.
<EOS>
"
Where

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Out

,
"
said

"
<EOS>
And
I
saw

in

---
and
jam
---
and

.
<EOS>
And
there
was
no

in

,
but

was

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's

,
Mum
,
"
said
Mr
Pumblechook
,
with

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
That
's
the
state
of
the
case
,
for
that
much
I
've
seen
myself
.
"
<EOS>
And
then
they
both
stared
at
me
,
and
I
,
with
an
obtrusive

of
artlessness

my

,
stared
at
them
,
and
plaited
the
right
leg
of
my
trousers
with
my
right
hand
.
  
<EOS>
If
they
had
asked
me
any
more

I
should
undoubtedly
have
betrayed
myself
,
for
I
was
even
then
on
the
point
of
mentioning
that
there
was
a
balloon
in
the
yard
,
and
should
have
hazarded
the
statement
but
for
my
invention
being
divided
between
that
phenomenon
and
a
bear
in
the
brewery
.
<EOS>
They
were
so
much
occupied
,
however
,
in
discussing
the
marvels
I
had
already
presented
for
their

,
that
I
escaped
.
<EOS>
The
subject
still
held
them
when
Joe
came
in
from
his
work
to
have
a
cup
of
tea
.
<EOS>
To
whom
my
sister
,
more
for
the
relief
of
her
own
mind
than
for
the
gratification
of
his
,
related
my
pretended
experiences
.
  
<EOS>
Now
,
when
I
saw
Joe
open
his
blue

and
roll

all
round
the
kitchen
in
helpless
amazement
<EOS>
,
I
was
overtaken
by
penitence
;
but
only
as
regarded
him
---
not
in
the
least
as
regarded
the
other
two
.
<EOS>
Towards
Joe
,
and
Joe
only
,
I
considered
myself
a
young
monster
,
while
they
sat
debating
what
results
would
come
to
me
from
Miss
Havisham
's
acquaintance
and
favour
.
<EOS>
They
had
no
doubt
that
Miss
Havisham
would
"
do
something
"
for
me
;
their
doubts
related
to
the
form
that
something
would
take
.
<EOS>
My
sister
stood
out
for
"
property
.
"
<EOS>
Mr
Pumblechook
was
in
favour
of
a
handsome
premium
for
binding
me
apprentice
to
some
genteel
trade
---
say
,
the
corn
and
seed
trade
,
for
instance
.
<EOS>
Joe
fell
into
the
deepest
disgrace
with
both
,
for
offering
the
bright

that
I
might
only
be
presented
with
one

the
dogs
who
had
fought
for
the
veal
-
cutlets
.
<EOS>
"
If
a
fool
's
head
ca
n't
express
better
opinions
than
that
,
"
said
my
sister
,
"
and
you
have
got
any
work
to
do
,
you
had
better
go
and
do
it
.
"
<EOS>
So
he
went
.
  
<EOS>
After
Mr
Pumblechook
had
driven

,
and
when
my
sister
was
washing
up
,
I
stole
into
the
forge
to
Joe
,
and
remained
by
him
until
he
had
done
for
the
night
.
<EOS>
Then
I
said
,
"
Before

,
Joe
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Should

,
Pip
?
"
said

,

.
"
<EOS>
Then

.
<EOS>
What

,
Pip
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Joe
"
said

,

,
and

between

,
"
you

that

Havisham
's
?
"
  
"
Remember
?
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

!
<EOS>
Wonderful
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's

,
Joe
;
it
ai
n't

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
are
you
telling
of
,
Pip
?
"
<EOS>
cried

,

back

.
<EOS>
"
You
do

's
---
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes

;

's

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

?
<EOS>
Why

,

,

welwet

co
---
eh
?
"

,

.
"

But

,

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

.
"

"
\
A
\
 
dog
?
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
Come
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
As

,

.
<EOS>
"
Pip
,
old

!
<EOS>
This
wo

,

!
<EOS>
I

!
<EOS>
Where

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's

,

;

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Terrible
?
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Awful
!
<EOS>
What
possessed
you
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't

possessed
me
,
Joe
,
"
I

,

,

,

;
"
but
I
wish

had

taught

to

Knaves
at

,
Jacks
;
and
I
wish
my
boots
were
n't
so
thick
nor
my
hands
so
coarse
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
And
then
I
told
Joe
that
I
felt
very
miserable
,
and
that
I
had
n't
been
able
to
explain
myself
to
Mrs
Joe
and
Pumblechook
who
were
so
rude
to
me
,
and
that
there
had
been
a
beautiful
young
lady
at
Miss
Havisham
's
who
was
dreadfully
proud
,
and
that
she
had
said
I
was
common
,
and
that
I
knew
I
was
common
,
and
that
I
wished
I
was
not
common
,
and
that
the
lies
had
come
of
it
somehow
,
though
I
did
n't
know
how
.
  
<EOS>
This
was
a
case
of
metaphysics
,
at
least
as
difficult
for
Joe
to
deal
with
,
as
for
me
.
<EOS>
But
Joe
took
the
case
altogether
out
of
the
region
of
metaphysics
,
and
by
that
means
vanquished
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
's
one
thing
you
may
be
sure
of
,
Pip
,
"
said
Joe
,
after
some
rumination
,
"
namely
,
that
lies
is
lies
.
<EOS>
Howsever
<EOS>
they
come
,
they
did
n't
ought
to
come
,
and
they
come
from
the
father
of
lies
,
and
work
round
to
the
same
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
tell
no
more
of
'em
,
Pip
.
 
<EOS>
\
<EOS>
That
\
 
ai
n't
the
way
to
get
out
of
being
common
,
old
chap
.
<EOS>
And
as
to
being
common
,
I
do
n't
make
it
out
at
all
clear
.
<EOS>
You
are
oncommon
in
some
things
.
<EOS>
You
're
oncommon
small
.
<EOS>
Likewise
you
're
a
oncommon
scholar
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
am
ignorant
and
backward
,
Joe
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
see
what
a

you
wrote
last

!
<EOS>
Wrote

!
<EOS>
I

---
Ah
!
and

!
<EOS>
---
that
I
'll

were

wrote

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
<EOS>
You

of

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

,

afore

<EOS>
The

Ah

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
(

)
.
<EOS>
Whether

ca

;

.
<EOS>
Lookee

<EOS>
Which

.
<EOS>
If

ca

<EOS>
So

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

.
<EOS>
But

<EOS>
That

"
  
<EOS>
When

's

,

in

,
<EOS>
that

long

,
how
common

would
consider
Joe
,

mere

:

thick

,

.
<EOS>
I
thought

Joe
and

were
then

,
and
how

had

,

how
Miss
Havisham
and
Estella
never
sat
in
a

,
but

far

.
<EOS>
I
fell

what
I
"
used
to
do
"
<EOS>
when

was
at
Miss
Havisham
's
;
as

,

;
and
as

were
quite
an
old

,

.
  
<EOS>
That
was
a

to
me
,
for

made

in

.
<EOS>
But
,
it
is
the
same
with
any
life
.
<EOS>
Imagine
one
selected
day
struck
out
of
it
,
and
think
how
different
its
course
would
have
been
.
<EOS>
Pause
you
who
read
this
,
and
think
for

of
the
long
chain
of
iron
or
gold
,
of

or

,
that
would
never
have
bound
you
,
but
for
the
formation
of
the
first
link
on
one
memorable

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
10
 
<EOS>
THE
felicitous
idea
occurred
to
me
a
morning
or
two
later
when
I
woke
,
that
the
best
step
I
could
take
towards
making
myself
uncommon
was
to
get
out
of
Biddy
everything
she
knew
.
<EOS>
In
pursuance
of
this
luminous
conception
I
mentioned
to
Biddy
when
I
went
to
Mr
Wopsle
's
great
-
aunt
's
at
night
,
that
I
had
a
particular
reason
for
wishing
to
get
on
in
life
,
and
that
I
should
feel
very
much
obliged
to
her
if
she
would
impart
all
her
learning
to

.
<EOS>
Biddy
,
who
was
the
most
obliging
of
girls
,
immediately
said
she
would
,
and
indeed
began
to
carry
out
her
promise
within
five
minutes
.
  
<EOS>
The
Educational
scheme
or
Course
established
by
Mr
Wopsle
's
great
-
aunt
may
be
resolved
into
the
following
synopsis
.
<EOS>
The
pupils
ate
apples
and
put
straws
down
one
another
's
backs
,
until
Mr
Wopsle
's
great
-
aunt
collected
her
energies
,
and
made
an
indiscriminate
totter
at
them
with
a
birch
-
rod
.
<EOS>
After
receiving
the
charge
with
every
mark
of
derision
,
the
pupils
formed
in
line
and
buzzingly
passed
a
ragged
book
from
hand
to
hand
.
<EOS>
The
book
had
an
alphabet
in
it
,
some
figures
and
tables
,
and
a
little
spelling---
that
is
to
say
,
it
had
had
once
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
this
volume
began
to
circulate
,
Mr
Wopsle
's
great
-
aunt
fell
into
a
state
of
coma
;
arising
either
from
sleep
or
a
rheumatic
paroxysm
.
<EOS>
The
pupils
then
entered
among
themselves
upon
a
competitive
examination
on
the
subject
of
Boots
,
with
the
view
of
ascertaining
who
could
tread
the
hardest
upon
whose
toes
.
<EOS>
This
mental
exercise
lasted
until
Biddy
made
a
rush
at
them
and
distributed
three
defaced
Bibles
(
shaped
as
if
they
had
been
unskilfully
cut
off
the
chump
-
end
of
something
)
,
more
illegibly
printed
at
the
best
than
any
curiosities
of
literature
I
have
since
met
with
,
speckled
all
over
with
iron
-
mould
,
and
having
various
specimens
of
the
insect
world
smashed
between
their
leaves
.
<EOS>
This
part
of
the
Course
was
usually
lightened
by
several
single
combats
between
Biddy
and
refractory
students
.
<EOS>
When
the
fights
were
over
,
Biddy
gave
out
the
number
of
a
page
,
and
then
we
all
read
aloud
what
we
could
---
or
what
we
could
n't
---
in
a
frightful
chorus
;
Biddy
leading
with
a
high
shrill

voice
,
and
none
of
us
having
the
least
notion
of
,
or
reverence
for
,
what
we
were
reading
about
.
<EOS>
When
this
horrible
din
had
lasted
a
certain

,
it
mechanically

Mr
Wopsle
's
great
-
aunt
,
who
staggered
at
a
boy
fortuitously
,
and
pulled
his
ears
.
<EOS>
This
was
understood
to
terminate
the
Course
for
the
evening
,
and
we
emerged
into
the
air
with
shrieks
of
intellectual
victory
.
<EOS>
It
is
fair
to
remark
that
there
was
no
prohibition
against
any
pupil
's
entertaining
himself
with
a

or

ink
(
when
there

any
)
,
but
that

not

to

that
branch
of
study
in
the
winter
season
,
on
account
of
the
little
general
shop
in

the
classes
were

---
and
which
was
also
Mr
Wopsle
's
great
-
aunt
's
sitting
-
room
and
bed

---
being
but

through
the

one
low

dip
-

and
no

.
  
<EOS>
It
appeared

that
it
would

,
to

uncommon
under

:
nevertheless
,

resolved

,

that

Biddy
entered

,

,

,

,

,

D
which
she

,
and

I
supposed
,
until

,
to
be
a
design
for
a
buckle
.
  
<EOS>
Of
course
there
was
a
public
-
house
in
the
village
,
and
of
course
Joe
liked
sometimes
to

pipe
there
.
<EOS>
I
had
received
strict
orders
from
my
sister
to
call

Three
Jolly

,
that
evening
,
on
my

,
and
bring

at
my
peril
.
<EOS>
To
the
Three
Jolly
Bargemen
,
therefore
,
I
directed
my
steps
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
bar
at
the
Jolly
Bargemen
,
with
some
alarmingly
long
chalk
scores
in

on

wall
at

door
,
which
seemed

me
to

never

off
.
<EOS>
They
had
been
there
ever
since
I
could
remember
,
and
had
grown
more
than
I
had
.
<EOS>
But
there
was
a
quantity
of
chalk
about
our
country
,
and
perhaps
the
people
neglected
no
opportunity
of
turning
it
to
account
.
  
<EOS>
It
being
Saturday
night
,
I
found
the
landlord
looking
rather

at
these
records
,
but
as

was
with
Joe
and

,

merely

him

,
and
passed

,

,
and
where
Joe
was

pipe
in

Mr
Wopsle
and
a

.
<EOS>
Joe
greeted
me
as
usual
with
"
Halloa
,
Pip
,
old
chap
!
"
<EOS>
and
the

said

,
the
stranger
turned
his

and
looked
at
me
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
a
secret
-
looking
man
whom
I
had
never
seen
before
.
<EOS>
His
head
was
all
on
one

,
and
one

was
half

,
as

something

.
<EOS>
He
had
a
pipe
in

,
and
he
took

out
,
and
,
after
slowly
blowing
all

away
and
looking
hard

all

,

.
<EOS>
So
,
I
nodded
,
and
then
he
nodded
again
,
and
made
room
on
the
settle
beside
him
that
I
might
sit
down
there
.
  
<EOS>
But
,
as
I
was
used
to

Joe
whenever

,

"
No
,

,
sir
,
"
and
fell
into
the
space
Joe
made
for
me
on

.
<EOS>
The
strange
man
,
after
glancing
at
Joe
,
and
seeing
that
his
attention
was
otherwise
engaged
,
nodded
to
me
again
when
I
had
taken
my

,
and
then
rubbed
his
leg
---
in
a
very
odd
way
,
as
it

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
was
saying
,
"
said
the
strange
man
,

,
"
that
you

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
I
said

,

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
What

,

---
?
<EOS>
You
did

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Joe

,

.
<EOS>
"

,

?
<EOS>

?
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

,

,
"

,
I
ai

's

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Habit
?
<EOS>
No
,

,
"
but

,

.
<EOS>
Come
!
<EOS>
Put

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Rum
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Rum
,
"

.
"
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Rum
,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Three
Rums
!
"
cried

,
calling
to
the
landlord
.
"
<EOS>
Glasses
round
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
This
other

,
"
observed
Joe
,
by

Wopsle
,
"
is
a

that
you
would

give
it
out
Our

at

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Aha
!
"
said

,
quickly
,
and

.
"
<EOS>
The
lonely
church
,
right
out

the
marshes
,
with
the

round

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
it
,
"
said
Joe
.
  
<EOS>
The
stranger
,
with
a
comfortable
kind
of
grunt
over
his
pipe
,
put
his
legs
up
on
the
settle
that
he
had
to

.
<EOS>
He
wore
a
flapping
broad
-

traveller
's
hat
,
and
under
it
a
handkerchief
tied
over
his
head
in
the
manner
of
a
cap
:
so
that
he
showed
no
hair
.
<EOS>
As
he
looked
at
the
fire
,
I
thought
I
saw
a
cunning
expression
,
followed
by
a
half
-
laugh
,
come
into

face
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
acquainted
with
this
country
,
gentlemen
,
but
it
seems
a

country
towards
the
river
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Most
marshes
is
solitary
,
"
said
Joe
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
doubt
,
no
doubt
.
<EOS>
Do
you
find
any
gipsies
now
or

"

"

"

rum

.

?
<EOS>
"

to

.

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
a

<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
A

that

,

.
<EOS>
I

's
,

;

,

,

<EOS>
Chapter
11
 
AT
<EOS>
the

's
,

.
<EOS>
She
locked

,

,
and

into
the

.
<EOS>
She
took
no

,

,

,
"
You

this

-

,
"
and
took

.
  
<EOS>
The

was

long

,

seemed

of
the
Manor

.
<EOS>
We

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Here
,

reappeared
,

,

,
that

if

.
<EOS>
There

.
<EOS>
Like

's

's

,

.
  
<EOS>
We

the

,

,
and
into

.
<EOS>
There

,

,
"
You

,

.
"
<EOS>
"
There
'
,

the
window
,

,
and

"
there
,
"
in

.
  
<EOS>
It

,

,

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
This

,
as

box

.
<EOS>
There
had

some
light
snow
,

,
and
it

nowhere
else

;
but
,

,
and

,

.
  
<EOS>
I
divined

my

had
stopped

in

,
and
that

were

.
<EOS>
I
could

nothing
of

room
except

in

,
but
I
stiffened

with

that
I

under
close

.
  
<EOS>
There
were
three

in

room

.
<EOS>
Before

been
standing
at

window
five

,

somehow
conveyed
to
me
that
they
were
all
toadies

,
but
that

know

others
were
toadies

:
because
the
admission
that
he
or

did
know
it
,
would
have
made
him

her
out
to
be
a
toady
and

.
  
<EOS>
They
all
had
a
listless

dreary

of
waiting
somebody
's

,
and
the
most

of
the

had
to

.
<EOS>
This

,
whose

,
very

,

,
and
(
as

)

.
<EOS>
Indeed
,

better

a
Mercy
<EOS>
she
had
any
features
at
all
,
so
very
blank
and
high
<EOS>
was
the
dead
wall
of

.
  
<EOS>
"
Poor
dear
soul
!
"
said
this

,
with
an
abruptness
of
manner
quite
my
sister
's
.
<EOS>
"
Nobody
's
enemy
but
his
own
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
would

much
more
commendable
to
be
somebody
else
's

,
"
said

;
"
far

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Cousin
Raymond
,
"
observed

,
"
we
are
to
love

neighbour
.
  
<EOS>
"
Sarah

,
"

,
"
if
a

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
Miss

checking

,
"
The
idea
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>

"
<EOS>
\
<EOS>
Very
\
 
true

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Poor

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Camilla
presently

on

(
I

"
he

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

"
  
"
\
<EOS>
He

<EOS>

"

Was

<EOS>
The

!
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
She

,

<EOS>
"

"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
His

,

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
He

,

I

,

anything

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Boy

?
<EOS>
Hey
?
"

"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
Estella

"

!
<EOS>

<EOS>
From

,

.
<EOS>
A

damp
old

,
and

,

---

.
<EOS>
Certain

:
or
,

,
faintly

.
<EOS>
It

,

I
dare

had
once

,
but

.
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
An

;

that
its

,

yellow

out

<EOS>
I

,

,
I

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
I

,

,
as

were

.
<EOS>
But
,

blackbeetles
took
no

the

,
and
groped
about
the
hearth
in

,
as

they
were
short
-

and

,

.
  
<EOS>
These

had
fascinated
my
attention
<EOS>
and

,

Havisham

.
<EOS>
In

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
This
,
"

,

"

.
<EOS>
They

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
With

,

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
Mine

<EOS>
Walk

!
"
  
<EOS>
I

that

Havisham
round

.
<EOS>
Accordingly

,
and

,
and

(
founded

.
  
<EOS>
She

,

,
"
Slower
!
"
<EOS>
Still
,

an

,
and

,
she

the
hand
upon
my

,
and
worked
her
mouth
,
and
led
me
to
believe
that
we
were
going
fast
because
her
thoughts
went
fast
.
<EOS>
After

said
,
"
Call
Estella
!
"
<EOS>
so
I
went
out
on

and
roared

I

done

.
<EOS>
Mien
her
light
appeared
,
I
returned
to
Miss
Havisham
,
and
we
started
away
again
round
and
round
the
room
.
  
<EOS>
If

had
come

I
should

sufficiently

,

.
<EOS>
In

,
I

;
but
,
Miss
Havisham
twitched

,
and
we
posted

---
with

on
my

that

.
  
<EOS>
"
Dear

Havisham
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
How
well

look
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
Chapter
12
 
MY

.

the

.
<EOS>

,

that

.
<EOS>

that

.
<EOS>

,

in

.
<EOS>

,

Joe
,

<EOS>
But
,

---

.
  
<EOS>
Estella
was
always
about
,
and

,
but
never

I
might

.
<EOS>
Sometimes
,

;

;

.
<EOS>
Miss
Havisham

"

,

?
"

And

(

,

.
<EOS>
Also
,

,

of
Estella

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

"
Break
their
hearts
my

and

,
break

and
have
no

!
"
  
<EOS>
There

song
Joe
used
to
hum

of
at
the

,

Old
Clem
.
<EOS>

;

,

.
<EOS>

iron
,
and
was
a
mere
lyrical
excuse
for
the
introduction
of
Old
Clem
's
respected
name
.
<EOS>
Thus
,
you
were
to
hammer
boys
round
---
Old
Clem
!
<EOS>
With
a
thump
and
a
sound
---
Old
Clem
!
<EOS>
Beat
it
out
,
beat
it
out
---
Old
Clem
!
<EOS>
With
a
clink
for
the
stout
---
Old
Clem
!
<EOS>
Blow
the
fire
,
blow
the
fire
---
Old
Clem
!
<EOS>
Roaring
dryer
,
soaring
higher
---
Old
Clem
!
<EOS>
One
day
soon
after
the
appearance
of
the
chair
,
Miss
Havisham
suddenly
saying
to
me
with
the
impatient
movement
of
her
fingers
,
"
There
,
there
,
there
!
<EOS>
Sing
!
"
<EOS>
I
was
surprised
into
crooning
this
ditty
as
I
pushed
her
over
the
floor
.
<EOS>
It
happened
so
to
catch
her
fancy
,
that
she
took
it
up
in
a
low
brooding
voice
as
if
she
were
singing
in
her
sleep
.
<EOS>
After
that
,
it
became
customary
with
us
to
have
it
as
we
moved
about
,
and
Estella
would
often
join
in
;
though
the
whole
strain
was
so
subdued
,
even
when
there
were
three
of
us
,
that
it
made
less
noise
in
the
grim
old
house
than
the
lightest
breath
of
wind
.
  
<EOS>
What
could
I
become
with
these
surroundings
?
<EOS>
How
could
my
character
fail
to
be
influenced
by
them
?
<EOS>
Is
it
to
be
wondered
at
if
my
thoughts
were
dazed
,
as
my
eyes
were
,
when
I
came
out
into
the
natural
light
from
the
misty
yellow
rooms
?
  
<EOS>
Perhaps
,
I
might
have
told
Joe
about
the
pale
young
gentleman
,
if
I
had
not
previously
been
betrayed
into
those
enormous
inventions
to
which
I
had
confessed
.
<EOS>
Under
the
circumstances
,
I
felt
that
Joe
could
hardly
fail
to
discern
in
the
pale
young
gentleman
,
an
appropriate
passenger
to
be
put
into
the
black
velvet
coach
;
therefore
,
I
said
nothing
of
him
.
<EOS>
Besides
:
that
shrinking
from
having
Miss
Havisham
and
Estella
discussed
,
which
had
come
upon
me
in
the
beginning
,
grew
much
more
potent
as
time
went
on
.
<EOS>
I
reposed
complete
confidence
in
no
one
but
Biddy
;
but
,
I
told
poor
Biddy
everything
.
<EOS>
Why
it
came
natural
to
me
to
do
so
,
and
why
Biddy
had
a
deep
concern
in
everything
I
told
her
,
I
did
not
know
then
,
though
I
think
I
know
now
.
  
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
councils
went
on
in
the
kitchen
at
home
,
fraught
with
almost
insupportable
aggravation
to
my
exasperated
spirit
.
<EOS>
That
ass
,
Pumblechook
,
used
often
to
come
over
of
a
night
for
the
purpose
of
discussing
my
prospects
with
my
sister
;
and
I
really
do
believe
(
to
this
hour
with
less
penitence
than
I
ought
to
feel
)
,
that
if
these
hands
could
have
taken
a
linchpin
out
of
his
chaise
-
cart
,
they
would
have
done
it
.
<EOS>
The
miserable
man
was
a
man
of
that
confined
stolidity
of
mind
,
that
he
could
not
discuss
my
prospects
without
having
me
before
him
---
as
it
were
,
to
operate
upon
---
and
he
would
drag
me
up
from
my
stool
(
usually
by
the
collar
)
where
I
was
quiet
in
a
comer
,
and
,
putting
me
before
the
fire
as
if
I
were
going
to
be
cooked
,
would
begin
by
saying
,
"
Now
,
Mum
,
here
is
this
boy
!
<EOS>
Here
is
this
boy
which
you
brought
up
by
hand
.
<EOS>
Hold
up
your
head
,
boy
,
and
be
for
ever
grateful
unto
them
which
so
did
do
.
<EOS>
Now
,
Mum
,
with
respections
to
this
boy
!
"
<EOS>
And
then
he
would
rumple
my
hair
the
wrong
way
---
which
from
my
earliest
remembrance
,
as
already
hinted
,
I
have
in
my
soul
denied
the
right
of
any
fellow
-
creature
to
do
---
and
would
hold
me
before
him
by
the
sleeve
:
<EOS>
a
spectacle
of
imbecility
only
to
be
equalled
by
himself
.
  
<EOS>
Then
,
he
and
my
sister
would
pair
off
in
such
nonsensical
speculations
about
Miss
Havisham
,
and
about
what
she
would
do
with
me
and
for
me
,
that
I
used
to
want
---
quite
painfully
---
to
burst
into
spiteful

,
fly
at
Pumblechook
,
and
pummel
him
all
over
.
<EOS>
In
these
dialogues
,
my
sister
spoke
to
me
as
if
she
were
morally
wrenching
one
of
my
teeth
out
at
every
reference
;
while
Pumblechook
himself
,
self
-
constituted
my
patron
,
would
sit
supervising
me
with
a

eye
,
like
the
architect
of
my
fortunes
who
thought
himself
engaged
on
a
very
unremunerative
job
.
  
<EOS>
In
these
discussions
,
Joe
bore
no
part
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
often
talked
at
,
while
they
were
in
progress
,
by
reason
of
Mrs
Joe
's
perceiving
that
he
was
not
favourable
to
my
being
taken
from
the
forge
.
<EOS>
I
was
fully
old
enough
now
,
to
be
apprenticed
to
Joe
;
and
when
Joe
sat
with
the
poker
on
his
knees
thoughtfully
raking
out
the
ashes
between
the
lower
bars
,
my
sister
would
so
distinctly

innocent

into

on
his

,
that
she
would
dive
at
him
,
take
the
poker
out
of

,
shake

,
and
put
it
away
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
most
irritating
end
to
every
one
of
these
debates
.
<EOS>
All
in
a
moment
,
with
nothing
to
lead
up
to
it
,
my
sister
would
stop
herself
in
a
yawn
,
and
catching
sight
of
me
as
it
were

,
would
swoop
upon
me
with
,
"
Come
!
<EOS>
there
's
enough
of
 
\
you
!
<EOS>
You
\
 
get
along
to
bed
;
you
've
given
trouble
enough
for
one
night
,
I
hope
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
if
I
had
besought
them
as
a
favour
to
bother
my
life
out
.
  
<EOS>
We
went
on
in
this
way
for
a
long
time
,
and
it
seemed
likely
that
we
should
continue
to
go

in
this

for
a
long
time
,
when
,
one
day
,
Miss
Havisham

as

were

,

leaning

;
and
said
with
some
displeasure
:
  
"
You
are
growing
tall
,
Pip
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
thought
it
best
to
hint
,
through
the
medium
of
a
meditative

,
that
this
might
be
occasioned
by

.
  
<EOS>
She
said
no

the

;
but
,

presently

and
looked
at
me
again
;
and
presently
again
;
and
after
that
,
looked
frowning
and
moody
.
<EOS>
On
the
next
day
of
my
attendance
when
our
usual
exercise
was
over
,
and
I
had
landed
her
at
her

-

,
she
stayed
me
with
a
movement
of
her
impatient

:
  
<EOS>
"
Tell
me
the
name
again
of
that
blacksmith

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Joe
Gargery
,
ma'am
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Meaning
the
master
you
were
to
be

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Miss
Havisham
.
"
  
"
You
had

.
<EOS>
Would
Gargery
come
here

,
and
bring
your

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
signified
that
I
had
no

he
would

as

to

.
  
<EOS>
"
Then

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
At

,
Miss
Havisham
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
,
there
!
<EOS>
I
know
nothing
about
times
.
<EOS>
Let

come
soon
,
and
come
alone

you
.
"
  
<EOS>
When
I
got
home
at
night
,
and
delivered
this
message
for
Joe
,
my
sister
"
went
on
the
Rampage
,
"
in
a
more
alarming

than
at
any

.
<EOS>
She
asked
me
and
Joe
whether
we
supposed
she
was
door
-
mats
under
our
feet
,
and
how
we
dared
to
use
her
so
,
and
what
company
we
graciously
thought
she
 
\
<EOS>
was
\
 
<EOS>
fit
for
?
<EOS>
When

,
she
threw
a

-

at
Joe
,
burst

,
got
out
the
dustpan
---
which
was
always
a
very
bad
sign
---
put
on
her
coarse
apron
,
and
began
cleaning
up
to
a
terrible
extent
.
<EOS>
Not
satisfied
with
a
dry

,
she
took
to
a
pail
and

-
brush
,
and
cleaned
us
out
of
house
and
home
,
so
that
we
stood
shivering
in
the
back
-
yard
.
<EOS>
It
was
ten
o'clock
at
night
before
we
ventured
to
creep
in
again
,
and
then
she
asked
Joe
why
he
had
n't
married
a
Negress
Slave
at
once
?
<EOS>
Joe
offered
no
answer
,
poor
fellow
,
but
stood
feeling
his
whisker
and
looking
dejectedly
at
me
,
as
if
he
thought
it
really
might
have
been
a
better
speculation
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
13
 
IT
was
a
trial
to
my
feelings
on
the
next
day
but
one
,
to
see
Joe
arraying
himself
in
his
Sunday
clothes
to
accompany
me
to
Miss
Havisham
's
.
<EOS>
However
,
as
he
thought
his
court
-
suit
necessary
to
the
occasion
,
it
was
not
for
me
to
tell
him
that
he
looked
far
better
in
his
working
dress
;
the
rather
,
because
I
knew
he
made
himself
so
dreadfully
uncomfortable
,
entirely
on
my
account
,
and
that
it
was
for
me
he
pulled
up
his
shirt
-
collar
<EOS>
so
very
high
behind
,
that
it
made
the
hair
on
the
crown
of
his
head
stand
up
like
a
tuft
of
feathers
.
  
<EOS>
At
breakfast
time
my
sister
declared
her
intention
of
going
to
town
with
us
,
and
being
left
at
Uncle
Pumblechook
's
,
and
called
for
"
when
we
had
done
with
our
fine
ladies
"
---
a
way
of
putting
the
case
,
from
which
Joe
appeared
inclined
to
augur
the
worst
.
<EOS>
The
forge
was
shut
up
for
the
day
,
and
Joe
inscribed
in
chalk
upon
the
door
(
as
it
was
his
custom
to
do
on
the
very
rare
occasions
when
he
was
not
at
work
)
<EOS>
the
monosyllable
HOUT
,
accompanied
by
a
sketch
of
an
arrow
supposed
to
be
flying
in
the
direction
he
had
taken
.
  
<EOS>
We
walked
to
town
,
my
sister
leading
the
way
in
a
very
large
beaver
bonnet
,
and
carrying
a
basket
like
the
Great
Seal
of
England
in

,
a

,
a
spare

,
and
an
umbrella
,
though
it
was
a
fine

.
<EOS>
I
am
not
quite
clear
whether
these
articles
were
carried
penitentially
or

;
but
,
I
rather
think
they
were
displayed
as

---
much

Cleopatra
or
any
other
sovereign
lady
on
the
Rampage
might
exhibit
her

in
a

or

.
  
<EOS>
When
we
came
to
Pumblechook
's
,
my
sister
bounced
in
and
left
us
.
<EOS>
As
it
was
almost
noon
,
Joe
and
I
held
straight
on
to
Miss
Havisham
's
house
.
<EOS>
Estella
opened
the
gate
as
usual
,
and
,
the
moment
she
appeared
,
Joe
took
his
hat
off
and
stood
weighing
it
by
the
brim
in
both
his
hands
:
as
if
he
had
some
urgent
reason
in
his
mind
for
being
particular
to
half

quarter
of

ounce
.
  
<EOS>
Estella
took
no
notice
of
either
of
us
,
but
led
us
the
way
that
I
knew
so
well
.
<EOS>
I
followed
next
to
her
,
and
Joe
came
last
.
<EOS>
When
I
looked
back
at
Joe
in
the
long

,
he
was
still
weighing
his
hat
with
the
greatest
care
,
and
was
coming
after
us
in
long

on
the

.
  
<EOS>
Estella
told
me
we
were
both
to
go
in
,
<EOS>
so
I
took
Joe
by
the
coat
-
cuff
and
conducted
him
into
Miss
Havisham
's
presence
.
<EOS>
She
was
seated
at
her
dressing
-
table
,
and
looked
round
at
us
immediately
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
said
she
to
Joe
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
the
husband
of
the
sister
of
this
boy
?
"
  
<EOS>
I
could
hardly
have
imagined
dear
old
Joe
looking
so
unlike
himself
or
so
like
some
extraordinary
bird
;
standing
,
as
he
did
,
speechless
,
with
his
tuft
of

,
and
his
mouth
open
,
as
if
he
wanted
a
worm
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
the
husband
,
"
repeated
Miss
Havisham
,
"
of
the
sister
of
this
boy
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
very
aggravating
;
but
,
throughout

interview
Joe
persisted
in
addressing
Me
instead
of
Miss
Havisham
.
  
<EOS>
"
Which
I
meantersay
,
Pip
,
"
Joe
now
observed
in

,

,

,
"
as
I
hup

,

I

what

(

)

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Well
!
"
said
Miss
Havisham
.
<EOS>
"
And

reared

,

for

;

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
know
,
Pip
,
"

,
"

ever
friends
,

it

to
betwixt

,
as
being
calc'lated

lead

.
<EOS>
Not

,

,

---

,

---
not

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Has

,
"

"

If

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The

<EOS>
I

,

,

,

?
"

?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
One

fitted

shop

,

,
TO

.
  
<EOS>
The
Hall
was
a

,
I

,
with

than

---

---

(

)

,

,

-

.

Here
,

,

,

"

;
"

<EOS>
When

,

<EOS>
Chapter
14
 
IT
is

most

to
feel

of
home
.
<EOS>
There
may

black

in

,

but
,
that

,

.
  
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
But
,

,

.
<EOS>

best

;

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

?

Chapter

<EOS>

.

<EOS>
Now
,

kept

.
<EOS>
He

Dolge
---
a

---

he

a

I

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

;

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
What

WITH

of

Barnwell

more

.
  
<EOS>
Joe
had

,

<EOS>
Chapter
17
 
I
Now
fell
into
a
regular

of
apprenticeship
life
,
which
was

of

,

than

.

I

Pocket
still

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

but

,
and
she
gave

a
guinea
when
I
was
going
,
and
told
me

on

.
<EOS>
I
may
mention
at
once
that
this
became

.
<EOS>
I
tried

decline

the

,
but

no

than

,
if

?
<EOS>
Then
,
and
after

,
I
took

.
  
<EOS>
So
unchanging
was

dull
old

,
the
yellow

in

,
the
faded

in

by

-

glass
,

,
and

.
<EOS>
Daylight
never

as

,

.
<EOS>

,

heart
to
hate
my
trade
and
to
be
ashamed
of
home
.
  
<EOS>
Imperceptibly
I
became
conscious
of
a
change
in
Biddy
,
however
.
<EOS>
Her
shoes
came
up
at
the
heel
,
her
hair
grew
bright
and
neat
,
her
hands
were
always
clean
.
<EOS>
She
was
not
beautiful
---
she
was
common
,
and
could
not
be
like
Estella
---
but
she
was
pleasant
and
wholesome
and
sweet
-
tempered
.
<EOS>
She
had
not
been
with
us
more
than
a
year
(
I
remember
her
being
newly
out
of
mourning
at
the
time
it
struck
me
)
,
when
I
observed
to
myself
one
evening
that
she
had
curiously
thoughtful
and
attentive
eyes
;
eyes
that
were
very
pretty
and
very
good
.
  
<EOS>
It
came
of
my
lifting
up
my
own
eyes
from
a
task
I
was
poring
at
---
writing
some
passages
from
a
book
,
to
improve
myself
in
two
ways
at
once
by
a
sort
of
stratagem
---
and
seeing
Biddy
observant
of
what
I
was
about
.
<EOS>
I
laid
down
my
pen
,
and
Biddy
stopped
in
her
needlework
without
laying
it
down
.
  
<EOS>
"
Biddy
,
"
said
I
,
"
how
do
you
manage
it
?
<EOS>
Either
I
am
very
stupid
,
or
you
are
very
clever
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
that
I
manage
?
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
,
"
returned
Biddy
,
smiling
.
  
<EOS>
She
managed
our
whole
domestic
life
,
and
wonderfully
too
;
but
I
did
not
mean
that
,
though
that
made
what
I
did
mean
,
more
surprising
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
manage
,
Biddy
,
"
said
I
,
"
to
learn
everything
that
I
learn
,
and
always
to
keep
up
with
me
?
<EOS>
"
I
was
beginning
to
be
rather
vain
of
my
knowledge
,
<EOS>
for
I
spent
my
birthday
guineas
on
it
,
and
set
aside
the
greater
part
of
my
pocket
-
money
for
similar

;
though
I
have
no
doubt
,
now
,
that
the
little
I
knew
was
extremely
dear
at
the
price
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
might
as
well
ask
you
,
"
said
Biddy
,
"
how
 
\
you
\
 
manage
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
because
when
I
come
in
from
the
forge
of

night
,
any

can
see

turning
to
at
it
.
<EOS>
But
you
never
turn
to
at
it
,
Biddy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
I
must
catch
it
---
like
a
cough
,
"
said
Biddy
,
quietly
;
and
went
on
with
her
sewing
.
  
<EOS>
Pursuing
my
idea
as
I
leaned

in

at
Biddy
sewing
away
with
her

on
one

I
began
to
think
her
rather
an
extraordinary

.
<EOS>
For
,
I
called
to
mind
now
,
that
she
was
equally

in
the
terms
of
our
trade
,
and
the

of

.
<EOS>
In

whatever
I
knew
,
Biddy
knew
.
<EOS>
Theoretically
,
she
was
already
as
good

blacksmith
as
I
,
or
better
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
one
of
those
,
Biddy
,
"
said
I
,
"
who
make
the
most
of
every
chance
.
<EOS>
You
never
had
a
chance
before
you
came
here
,
and
see
how
improved

are
!
"
  
<EOS>
Biddy
looked
at
me
for
an
instant
,
and
went
on
with
her
sewing
.
<EOS>
"
I
was
your
first
teacher
though
;
was

I
?
"
<EOS>
said
she
,
as
she
sewed
.
  
<EOS>
"
Biddy
!
<EOS>
"
I
exclaimed
,
in

.
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
are
crying
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
I
am
not
,
"
said
Biddy
,
looking
up
and
laughing
.
<EOS>
"
What
put
that
in
your
head
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
What
could
have
put
it
in
my
head
,
but
the
glistening
of
a

as
it
dropped
on

work
?
<EOS>
I
sat
silent
,
recalling
what
a
drudge
she
had
been
until
Mr
Wopsle
's
great
-
aunt
successfully
overcame
that
bad
habit
of
living
,
so
highly
desirable
to
be
got
rid
of
by

.
<EOS>
I
recalled
the
hopeless

by
which
she
had
been

in
the
miserable

shop
and
the
miserable

noisy

,
with
that

old
bundle

always
to

.
<EOS>
I
reflected
that
even

those
untoward

there
must

been
latent
in
Biddy
what
was
now
developing
,
for
,
in
my
first
uneasiness
and
discontent
<EOS>
I
had
turned
to
her
for

,
as

.
<EOS>
Biddy
sat
quietly

,
shedding
no
more

,
and
while
I

and
thought

it

,

that

.
<EOS>
I
might

been
too
reserved
,
and
should
have
patronized

more
(
though
I
did

use

)
,
with
my

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Biddy
<EOS>
,
"
I
observed
,
when
I
had
done
turning
it
over
,
"
you
were
my
first
teacher
,
and
that
at
a
time
when
we
little
thought
of

being
together
like

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
poor

!
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
It

like
her
self
-

,
to

,
and
to

,
making

;
"

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
said

,
"
we
must

,

.
<EOS>
And

,

.
<EOS>
Let

a
quiet

the

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
My

was

;

Joe
more

on

,
and
Biddy
<EOS>
and

.
<EOS>
It
was
summer
-
time
,
and
lovely

.
<EOS>
When

had

the

and

,

,
I

Miss

and

with

,
in

.
<EOS>
When
we
came

the

,

I
resolved

.
  
<EOS>
"
Biddy
,
"

,
after

to

,
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
I

,

!
"
<EOS>
she

.
<EOS>
"
I
do

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Biddy
,
"
said

,
with

,
"
I

for

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
know

,
Pip
;

?
  
<EOS>
"
Biddy
,
"
I

"
I

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>
Do

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
"

,

"
I

;

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That

!
"
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Now

too
had
so

.
<EOS>
I

she

,

<EOS>

I

"

"

"

"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
---

!
"
  
<EOS>
Biddy

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Who

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
It

,

"

,

,

.

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

,
"
Biddy

"
I

---
<EOS>
but

---

.
<EOS>
And

,

---
<EOS>
but

---
she

worth

.
"
  
<EOS>
Exactly
what
I
myself
had
thought
,

.
<EOS>
Exactly

.
<EOS>
But

,

,
avoid
that

into
which
the
best
and
wisest

fall
every

?
  
<EOS>
"
It
may

,
"

"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
In

,
I

on

,
and
got
a

,

.
<EOS>

that

,

.
  
<EOS>
Biddy
was
the

of

,
and
she
tried
to

.
<EOS>
She

,
which

,
upon

,
one

<EOS>

---

---

,

;

ca

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,
"

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
If

first

(
dear
!
<EOS>
such

,

so

of
being
taught
herself
!
)
had
been
your
teacher
at
the
present
time
,
she
thinks
she
knows
what
lesson
she
would
set
.
<EOS>
But
it
would
be
a
hard
one
to
learn
,
and
you
have
got
beyond
her
,
and
it
's
of
no
use
now
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
,
with
a
quiet
sigh
for
me
,
Biddy
rose
from
the
bank
,
and
said
,
with
a
fresh
and
pleasant
change
of
voice
,
"
Shall
we
walk
a
little
further
,
or
go
home
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Biddy
,
"
I
cried
,
getting

,
putting
my

round

neck
,
and
giving

,
<EOS>
"
I
shall
always

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Till

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
know
I
never
shall
be
,
so
that
's
always
.
<EOS>
Not

have

anything
,
for
you

everything

---
as
I

at
home
the
other

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
said
Biddy
,
quite

,
as

looked

ships
.
<EOS>
And

,
with
her
former

;
"
shall
we
walk
a
little
further
,
or
go
home
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
said
to
Biddy
we
would
walk
a
little
further
,
and
we
did
so
,
and
the
summer
afternoon
toned
down
into
the
summer
evening
,
and
it
was
very
beautiful
.
<EOS>
I
began
to
consider
whether
I
was
not
more
naturally
and
wholesomely
situated
,
after
all
,
in
these

,
than
playing
beggar
my
neighbour
by
candlelight
in
the
room
with
the
stopped
clocks
,
and
being
despised
by
Estella
.
<EOS>
I
thought
it
would
be
very
good
for
me
if
I
could
get
her
out
of
my
head
,
with
all
the
rest
of
those
remembrances
and
fancies
,
and
could
go
to
work
determined
to
relish
what
I
had
to
do
,
and
stick
to
it
,
and
make
the
best
of
it
.
<EOS>
I
asked
myself
the
question
whether
I
did
not
surely
know
that
if
Estella
were
beside
me
at
that
moment
instead

Biddy
,
she

make

?
<EOS>
I
was
obliged
to

that
I
did
know
it
for
a

,
and
I
said
to

,
"
Pip
,
what
a
fool
you
are
!
"
  
<EOS>
We
talked
a
good
deal
as
we
walked
,
and
all
that
Biddy
said
seemed
right
.
<EOS>
Biddy
was
never
insulting
,
or
capricious
,
or
Biddy
to
-
day
and
somebody
else
to
-
morrow
;
she
would
have
derived
only
pain
,
and
no
pleasure
,
from
giving
me
pain
;
she
would
far
rather
have
wounded
her
own

than
mine
.
<EOS>
How
could
it
be
,
then
,
that
I
did
not
like
her
much
the
better
of
the
two
?
  
<EOS>
"
Biddy
,
"
said
I
,
when
we
were

,
"
I
wish
you
could
put
me
right
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
wish
I

!
"
said
Biddy
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
I

only

to
fall

---
you
do

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
,
not

!
"

.
<EOS>
"
Do

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
could
only

do

,
 
\
that
\

.
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
never

,

,
"
said
Biddy
.
  
<EOS>
It
did
not

so

that

,
as
it

done
if

<EOS>
I
therefore
observed
I
was
not

.
<EOS>
But
Biddy

she
 
\
was
,
<EOS>
\
 
<EOS>
and
she

.
<EOS>
In

to

;
and
yet
I
took
it
rather
ill
,
too
,
that
she
should
be
so
positive
on

.
  
<EOS>
When
we
came
near
the
churchyard
,
we
had
to
cross
an
embankment
,
and
get
over
a
stile
near

.
<EOS>
There
started
up
,
from
the

,
or

the

,
or

the

(
which
was
quite
in
his

)
,
Old
Orlick
.
  
<EOS>
"
Halloa
!
"
<EOS>
he

,
"
<EOS>
where

two

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Where

be

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well

,
"
said

,
"
I
'm

I
do

you

!
"
  
<EOS>
This

of
being

was
a
favourite
supposititious
case
of
his
.
<EOS>
He
attached
no
definite
meaning
to
the
word
that
I
am
aware

,
but
used

,
like
his
own
pretended

,
to

,
and
convey

of
something

.
<EOS>
When

,
I

that

,
he

.
  
<EOS>
Biddy
was
much
against
his
going
with

,
and
said
to

in

,
"
Do
n't
let
him
come
;
I
do
n't

.
"
<EOS>
As

.
<EOS>
He

,
and

,
but
came

.
  
<EOS>
Curious

that

of

had
never

any
account
<EOS>
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
<EOS>

,
"

---

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did

he

?
"
<EOS>
I

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"

,

again
<EOS>
,
"
he

;
but
he
dances

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
However
novel
and
peculiar
this

of
attachment
,

.
<EOS>
I
was
very

upon
Old

's

;
as

.
  
<EOS>
"
But

"

.
  
<EOS>
"

;

;

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nor

,
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Though
 
\
that
\

.
  
<EOS>
"
Exactly
,
"

;
"

Biddy
,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
<EOS>
He
had

in
Joe
's
establishment
,
by
reason
of
my
sister
's
sudden
fancy
for
him
,
or

.
<EOS>
He
quite

and

good

,

.
  
<EOS>
And

,

not

enough
before
,
I
complicated

fifty
thousand
-
fold
,
by
having
states
and
seasons
when
I

clear
that
Biddy
was

than
Estella
,
and
that

plain

to

,
had

to

,
but
offered

of
self
-
respect
and

.
<EOS>
At
those

,
I
would
decide
conclusively
that
my
disaffection
to
dear
old
Joe
and
the
forge
,
was
gone
,
and
that
I
was
growing

to

Biddy
---

some

the
Havisham
days
would
fall
upon
me
,
like
a
destructive
missile
,
and
scatter
my
wits
again
.
<EOS>
Scattered
wits
take
a
long
time
picking
up
;
and
often
,
before
I
had
got
them
well
together
,

by

,
that
perhaps
after
all
Miss
Havisham
was
going
to
make
my
fortune
when
my
time
was
out
.
  
<EOS>
If
my
time
had
run
out
,
it
would
have
left
me
still
at
the
height
of
my
perplexities
,
I
dare
say
.
<EOS>
It
never
did
run
out
,
however
,
but
was
brought
to
a
premature
end
,
as
I
proceed
to
relate
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
18
 
IT
was
in
the
fourth
year
of
my
apprenticeship
to
Joe
,
and
it
was
a
Saturday
night
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
group
assembled
round
the
fire
at
the
Three
Jolly
Bargemen
,
attentive
to
Mr
Wopsle
as
he
read
the
newspaper
aloud
.
<EOS>
Of
that
group
I
was
one
.
  
<EOS>
A
highly
popular
murder
had
been
committed
,
and
Mr
Wopsle
was
imbrued
in
blood
to
the
eyebrows
.
<EOS>
He
gloated
over
every
abhorrent
adjective
in
the
description
,
and
identified
himself
with
every
witness
at
the
Inquest
.
<EOS>
He
faintly
moaned
,
"
I
am
done
for
,
"
as
the
victim
,
and
he
barbarously
bellowed
,
"
I
'll
serve
you
out
,
"
as
the
murderer
.
<EOS>
He
gave
the
medical
testimony
,
in
pointed
imitation
of
our
local
practitioner
;
and
he
piped
and
shook
,
as
the
aged
turnpike
-
keeper
who
had
heard
blows
,
to
an
extent
so
very
paralytic
as
to
suggest
a
doubt
regarding
the
mental
competency
of
that
witness
.
<EOS>
The
coroner
,
in
Mr
Wopsle
's
hands
,
became
Timon
of
Athens
;
the
beadle
,
Coriolanus
.
<EOS>
He
enjoyed
himself
thoroughly
,
and
we
all
enjoyed
ourselves
,
and
were
delightfully
comfortable
.
<EOS>
In
this
cosy
state
of
mind
we
came
to
the
verdict
Wilful
Murder
.
  
<EOS>
Then
,
and
not
sooner
,
I
became
aware
of
a
strange
gentleman
leaning
over
the
back
of
the
settle
opposite
me
,
looking
on
.
<EOS>
There
was
an
expression
of
contempt
on
his
face
,
and
he
bit
the
side
of
a
great
forefinger
as
he
watched
the
group
of
faces
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
said
the
stranger
to
Mr
Wopsle
,
when
the
reading
was
done
,
"
you
have
settled
it
all
to
your
own
satisfaction
,
I
have
no

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Everybody
started
and
looked
up
,
as
if
it
were
the
murderer
.
<EOS>
He
looked
at
everybody
coldly
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
Guilty
,
of
course
?
"
said
he
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Out
with
it
.
<EOS>
Come
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
returned
Mr
Wopsle
,
"
without
having
the
honour
of
your
acquaintance
,
I
do
say
Guilty
.
<EOS>
"
Upon
this
,
we
all
took
courage
to
unite
in
a

murmur
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
you
do
,
"
said
the
stranger
;
"
I
knew
you
would
.
<EOS>
I
told

.
<EOS>
But
now
I
'll

you

.
<EOS>
Do
you

,
or

not

,
that
the
law

England
supposes
every
man
to
be

,
until

is
proved
<EOS>
---
proved
---
to

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
Mr
Wopsle
began
to

,
"
as

,
I
---
"
  
"
Come
!
"
<EOS>
said
the
stranger
,

his
forefinger
at

.
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
evade
the

.
<EOS>
Either
you
know

,
or
you
do
n't
know

.
<EOS>
Which

?
"
  
<EOS>
He
stood

one

and

,
in

---
as

---

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
!
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
you
know
it
,
or
do

know

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Certainly
I
know

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Certainly
you
know
it
.
<EOS>
Then
why
did

say

?
<EOS>
Now
,
I
'll

;
"
taking

,

"
<EOS>
\
<EOS>
Do
\
 
<EOS>
you

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr

,
"
I

---
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
What
?
<EOS>
You
wo

,
<EOS>
yes

?
<EOS>
Now
,

.
<EOS>
"

again
.
<EOS>
"
Attend

.
<EOS>
Are
you

,
or
are

,
that
none

these

have
yet

-

?
<EOS>
Come
,
I
only

word

.
<EOS>
Yes
,
or

?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Wopsle
hesitated
,
and
we
all
began
to
conceive
rather
a
poor
opinion
of
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
!
"
<EOS>
said
the
stranger
,
"
I
'll
help
you
.
<EOS>
You
do
n't
deserve
help
,
but
I
'll
help
you
.
<EOS>
Look
at
that
paper
you
hold
in
your
hand
.
<EOS>
What
is
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
?
"
repeated
Mr
Wopsle
,
eyeing
it
,
much
at
a
loss
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
it
,
"
pursued
the
stranger
in
his
most
sarcastic
and
suspicious
manner
,
"
the
printed
paper
you
have
just
been
reading
from
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Undoubtedly
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Undoubtedly
.
<EOS>
Now
,
turn
to
that
paper
,
and
tell
me
whether
it
distinctly
states
that
the
prisoner
expressly
said
that
his
legal
advisers
instructed
him
altogether
to
reserve
his
defence
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
read
that
just
now
,
"
Mr
Wopsle
pleaded
.
  
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
what
you
read
just
now
,
sir
;
I
do
n't
ask
you
what
you
read
just
now
.
<EOS>
You
may
read
the
Lord
's
Prayer
backwards
,
if
you
like
---
and
,
perhaps
,
have
done
it
before
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
Turn
to
the
paper
.
<EOS>
No
,
no
,
no
<EOS>
my
friend
<EOS>
;
not
to
the
top
of
the
column
;
you
know
better
than
that
;
to
the
bottom
,
to
the
bottom
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
(
We
all
began
to
think
Mr
Wopsle
full
of
subterfuge
.
)
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
?
<EOS>
Have
you
found
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Here
it
is
,
"
said
Mr
Wopsle
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
follow
that
passage
with
your
eye
,
and
tell
me
whether
it
distinctly
states
that
the
prisoner
expressly
said
that
he
was
instructed
by
his
legal
advisers
wholly
to
reserve
his
defence
?
<EOS>
Come
!
<EOS>
Do
you
make
that
of
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Wopsle
answered
,
"
Those
are
not
the
exact
words
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
the
exact
words
!
"
repeated
the
gentleman
,
bitterly
.
"
<EOS>
Is
that
the
exact
substance
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Mr
Wopsle
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
repeated
the
stranger
,
looking
round
at
the
rest
of
the
company
with
his
right
hand
extended
towards
the
witness
,
Wopsle
.
"
<EOS>
And
now
I
ask
you
what
you
say
to
the
conscience
of
that
man
who
,
with
that
passage
before
his
eyes
,
can
lay
his
head
upon
his
pillow
after
having
pronounced
a
fellow
-
creature
guilty
,
unheard
?
"
  
<EOS>
We
all
began
to
suspect
that
Mr
Wopsle
was
not
the
man
we
had
thought
him
,
and
that
he
was
beginning
to
be
found
out
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
that
same
man
,
remember
,
"
pursued
the
gentleman
,
throwing
his
finger
at
Mr
Wopsle
heavily
;
"
that
same
man
might
be
summoned
as
a
juryman
upon
this
very
trial
,
and
,
having
thus
deeply
committed
himself
,
might
return
to
the
bosom
of
his
family
and
lay
his
head
upon
his
pillow
,
after
deliberately
swearing
that
he
would
well
and
truly
try
the
issue
joined
between
Our
Sovereign
Lord
the
King
and
the
prisoner
at
the
bar
,
and
would
a
true
verdict
give
according
to
the
evidence
,
so
help
him
God
!
"
  
<EOS>
We
were
all
deeply
persuaded
that
the
unfortunate
Wopsle
had
gone
too
far
,
and
had
better
stop
in
his
reckless
career
while
there
was
yet
time
.
  
<EOS>
The
strange
gentleman
,
with
an
air
of
authority
not
to
be
disputed
,
and
with
a
manner
expressive
of
knowing
something
secret
about
every
one
of
us
that
would
effectually
do
for
each
individual
if
he
chose
to
disclose
it
,
left
the
back
of
the
settle
,
and
came
into
the
space
between
the
two
settles
,
in
front
of
the
fire
,
where
he
remained
standing
:
his
left
hand
in
his
pocket
,
and
he
biting
the
forefinger
of
his
right
.
  
<EOS>
"
From
information
I
have
received
,
"
said
he
,
looking
round
at
us
as
we
all
quailed
before
him
,
<EOS>
"
I
have
reason
to
believe
there
is
a
blacksmith
among
you
,
by
name
Joseph
---
or
Joe
---
Gargery
.
<EOS>
Which
is
the
man
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Here
is
the
man
,
"
said
Joe
.
  
<EOS>
The
strange
gentleman
beckoned
him
out
of
his
place
,
and
Joe
went
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
an
apprentice
,
"
pursued
the
stranger
,
"
commonly
known
as
Pip
?
<EOS>
Is
he
here
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
here
!
<EOS>
"
I
cried
.
  
<EOS>
The
stranger
did
not
recognize
me
,
but
I
recognized
him
as
the
gentleman
I
had
met
on
the
stairs
,
on
the
occasion
of
my
second
visit
to
Miss
Havisham
.
<EOS>
I
had
known
him
the
moment
I
saw
him
looking
over
the
settle
,
and
now
that
I
stood
confronting
him
with
his
hand
upon
my
shoulder
,
I
checked
off
again
in
detail
,
<EOS>
his
large
head
,
his
dark
complexion
,
his
deep
-
set
eyes
,
his
bushy
black
eyebrows
,
his
large
watch
-
chain
,
his
strong
black
dots
of
beard
and
whisker
,
and
even
the
smell
of
scented
soap
on
his
great
hand
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
wish
to
have
a
private
conference
with
you
two
,
"
said
he
,
when
he
had
surveyed
me
at
his
leisure
.
<EOS>
"
It
will
take
a
little
time
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
we
had
better
go
to
your
place
of
residence
.
<EOS>
I
prefer
not
to
anticipate
my
communication
here
;
you
will
impart
as
much
or
as
little
of
it
as
you
please
to
your
friends
afterwards
;
I
have
nothing
to
do
with
that
.
"
  
<EOS>
Amidst
a
wondering
silence
,
we
three
walked
out
of
the
Jolly
Bargemen
,
and
in
a
wondering
silence
walked
home
.
<EOS>
While
going
along
,
the
strange
gentleman
occasionally
looked
at
me
,
and
occasionally
bit
the
side
of
his
finger
.
<EOS>
As
we
neared
home
,
Joe
vaguely
acknowledging
the
occasion
as
an
impressive
and
ceremonious
one
,
went
on
ahead
to
open
the
front
door
.
<EOS>
Our
conference
was
held
in
the
state
parlour
,
which
was
feebly
lighted
by
one
candle
.
  
<EOS>
It
began
with
the
strange
gentleman
's
sitting
down
at
the
table
,
drawing
the
candle
to
him
,
and
looking
over
some
entries
in
his
pocket
-
book
.
<EOS>
He
then
put
up
the
pocket
-
book
and
set
the
candle
a
little
aside
:
after
peering
round
it
into
the
darkness
at
Joe
and
me
,
to
ascertain
which
was
which
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
name
,
"
he
said
,
"
is
Jaggers
,
and
I
am
a
lawyer
in
London
.
<EOS>
I
am
pretty
well
known
.
<EOS>
I
have
unusual
business
to
transact
with
you
,
and
I
commence
by
explaining
that
it
is
not
of
my
originating
.
<EOS>
If
my
advice
had
been
asked
,
I
should
not
have
been
here
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
asked
,
and
you
see
me
here
.
<EOS>
What
I
have
to
do
as
the
confidential
agent
of
another
,
I
do
.
<EOS>
No
less
,
no
more
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Finding
that
he
could
not
see
us
very
well
from
where
he
sat
,
he
got
up
,
and
threw
one
leg
over
the
back
of
a
chair
and
leaned
upon
it
;
thus
having
one
foot
on
the
seat
of
the
chair
,
and
one
foot
on
the
ground
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Joseph
Gargery
,
I
am
the
bearer
of
an
offer
to
relieve
you
of
this
young
fellow
your
apprentice
.
<EOS>
You
would
not
object
to
cancel
his
indentures
,
at
his
request
and
for
his
good
?
<EOS>
You
would
want
nothing
for
so
doing
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Lord
forbid
that
I
should
want
anything
for
not
standing
in
Pip
's
way
,
"
said
Joe
,
staring
.
  
<EOS>
"
Lord
forbidding
is
pious
,
but
not
to
the
purpose
,
"
returned
Mr
Jaggers
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
question
is
,
Would
you
want
anything
?
<EOS>
Do
you
want
anything
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
answer
is
,
"
returned
Joe
,
sternly
,
"
No
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
thought
Mr
Jaggers
glanced
at
Joe
,
as
if
he
considered
him
a
fool
for
his
disinterestedness
.
<EOS>
But
I
was
too
much
bewildered
between
breathless
curiosity
and
surprise
,
to
be
sure
of
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Very
well
,
"
said
Mr
Jaggers
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Recollect
the
admission
you
have
made
,
and
do
n't
try
to
go
from
it
presently
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who
's
a
-
going
to
try
?
"
retorted
Joe
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
say
anybody
is
.
<EOS>
Do
you
keep
a
dog
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
do
keep
a
dog
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Bear
in
mind
then
,
that
Brag
is
a
good
dog
,
but
Holdfast
is
a
better
.
<EOS>
Bear
that
in
mind
,
will
you
?
<EOS>
"
repeated
Mr
Jaggers
,
shutting
his
eyes
and
nodding
his
head
at
Joe
,
as
if
he
were
forgiving
him
something
.
"
<EOS>
Now
,
I
return
to
this
young
fellow
.
<EOS>
And
the
communication
I
have
got
to
make
is
,
that
he
has
Great
Expectations
.
"
  
<EOS>
Joe
and
I
gasped
,
and
looked
at
one
another
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
instructed
to
communicate
to
him
,
"
said
Mr
Jaggers
,
throwing
his
finger
at
me
sideways
,
"
that
he
will
come
into
a
handsome
property
.
<EOS>
Further
,
that
it
is
the
desire
of
the
present
possessor
of
that
property
,
that
he
be
immediately
removed
from
his
present
sphere
of
life
and
from
this
place
,
and
be
brought
up
as
a
gentleman
---
in
a
word
,
as
a
young
fellow
of
great
expectations
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
My
dream
was
out
;
my
wild
fancy
was
surpassed
by
sober
reality
;
Miss
Havisham
was
going
to
make
my
fortune
on
a
grand
scale
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Mr
Pip
,
"
pursued
the
lawyer
,
"
I
address
the
rest
of
what
I
have
to
say
,
to
you
.
<EOS>
You
are
to
understand
,
first
,
that
it
is
the
request
of
the
person
from
whom
I
take
my
instructions
,
that
you
always
bear
the
name
of
Pip
.
<EOS>
You
will
have
no
objection
,
I
dare
say
,
to
your
great
expectations
being
encumbered
with
that
easy
condition
.
<EOS>
But
if
you
have
any
objection
,
this
is
the
time
to
mention
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
My
heart
was
beating
so
fast
,
and
there
was
such
a
singing
in
my
ears
,
<EOS>
that
I
could
scarcely
stammer
I
had
no
objection
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
think
not
!
<EOS>
Now
you
are
to
understand
,
secondly
,
Mr
Pip
,
that
the
name
of
the
person
who
is
your
liberal
benefactor
remains
a
profound
secret
,
until
the
person
chooses
to
reveal
it
.
<EOS>
I
am
empowered
to
mention
that
it
is
the
intention
of
the
person
to
reveal
it
at
first
hand
by
word
of
mouth
to
yourself
.
<EOS>
When
or
where
that
intention
may
be
carried
out
,
I
can
not
say
;
no
one
can
say
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
years
hence
.
<EOS>
Now
,
you
are
distinctly
to
understand
that
you
are
most
positively
prohibited
from
making
any
inquiry
on
this
head
,
or
any
allusion
or
reference
,
however
distant
,
to
any
individual
whomsoever
as
 
\
<EOS>
the
\
 
individual
,
in
all
the
communications
you
may
have
with
me
.
<EOS>
If
you
have
a
suspicion
in
your
own
breast
,
keep
that
suspicion
in
your
own
breast
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
the
least
to
the
purpose
what
the
reasons
of
this
prohibition
are
;
they
may
be
the
strongest
and
gravest
reasons
,
or
they
may
be
mere
whim
.
<EOS>
This
is
not
for
you
to
inquire
into
.
<EOS>
The
condition
is
laid
down
.
<EOS>
Your
acceptance
of
it
,
and
your
observance
of
it
as
binding
,
is
the
only
remaining
condition
that
I
am
charged
with
,
by
the
person
from
whom
I
take
my
instructions
,
and
for
whom
I
am
not
otherwise
responsible
.
<EOS>
That
person
is
the
person
from
whom
you
derive
your
expectations
,
and
the
secret
is
solely
held
by
that
person
and
by
me
.
<EOS>
Again
,
not
a
very
difficult
condition
with
which
to
encumber
such
a
rise
in
fortune
;
but
if
you
have
any
objection
to
it
,
this
is
the
time
to
mention
it
.
<EOS>
Speak
out
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Once
more
,
I
stammered
with
difficulty
that
I
had
no
objection
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
think
not
!
<EOS>
Now
,
Mr
Pip
,
I
have
done
with
stipulations
.
<EOS>
"
Though
he
called
me
Mr
Pip
,
and
began
rather
to
make
up
to
me
,
he
still
could
not
get
rid
of
a
certain
air
of
bullying
suspicion
;
and
even
now
he
occasionally
shut
his
eyes
and
threw
his
finger
at
me
while
he
spoke
,
as
much
as
to
express
that
he
knew
all
kinds
of
things
to
my
disparagement
,
if
he
only
chose
to
mention
them
.
<EOS>
"
We
come
next
,
to
mere
details
of
arrangement
.
<EOS>
You
must
know
that
,
although
I
have
used
the
term
"
expectations
"
more
than
once
,
you
are
not
endowed
with
expectations
only
.
<EOS>
There
is
already
lodged
in
my
hands
,
a
sum
of
money
amply
sufficient
for
your
suitable
education
and
maintenance
.
<EOS>
You
will
please
consider
me
your
guardian
.
<EOS>
Oh
!
"
for
I
was

,
"
I

.
<EOS>
It

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

"

,

.

,

.
  
<EOS>
My

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

.
  
<EOS>

"

,

?
"

"
No
,

,

,

,
"

!
"
  
<EOS>
Biddy

,
and

.
<EOS>
Joe
held
his

and

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
After

,
they
both

;
but

,

.
  
<EOS>
I

Biddy
<EOS>
(

,
Joe
)

grave

I
considered

friends
under
,
to
know

and

.
<EOS>
It
would
all
come
out
in

,

,
and

nothing
was
to

,
save
that

from

.
<EOS>
Biddy
nodded

at

as

,
and
said

would

very

;

Joe
,
still

,

,
"
Ay
,
ay
,
I
'll
be
ekervally
partickler
,
Pip
;
"
and

again
,
and
went

at

of
my
being

,
that

did
n't

.
  
<EOS>
Infinite

were

by
Biddy
to

to
my
sister
some
idea
of
what
had
happened
.
<EOS>
To

best

,

entirely

.
<EOS>
She
laughed
and

,

,
the

"
Pip
"
and
"
Property
.
"
<EOS>
But
I

had

than
an
election
cry
,
and
I
can
not
suggest
a
darker
picture
of
her

.
  
<EOS>
I
never
could
have
believed
it
without
experience
,
but
as
Joe
and
Biddy
became
more
at
their
cheerful

again
,
I

quite

.
<EOS>
Dissatisfied
with
my
fortune
,
of
course
I
could
not
be
;
but
it
is
possible
that
I
may
have
been
,
without
quite
knowing
it
,
dissatisfied
with
myself
.
  
<EOS>
Anyhow
,
I
sat
with
my
elbow
on
my
knee
and
my
face
upon
my
hand
,
looking
into
the
fire
,
as
those
two
talked
about
my
going
away
,
and
about
what
they
should
do
without
me
,
and
all
that
.
<EOS>
And
whenever
I
caught
one
of
them
looking
at
me
,
though
never
  
so
pleasantly
(
and
they
often
looked
at
me
---
particularly
Biddy
)
,
<EOS>
I
  
felt
offended
:
as
if
they
were
expressing
some
mistrust
of
me
.
  
<EOS>
Though
Heaven
knows
they
never
did
by
word
or
sign
.
  
<EOS>
At
those
times
I
would
get
up
and
look
out
at
the
door
;
for
,
our
kitchen
door
opened
at
once
upon
the
night
,
and
stood
open
on
summer
evenings
to
air
the
room
.
<EOS>
The
very
stars
to
which
I
then
raised
my
eyes
<EOS>
,
I
am
afraid
I
took
to
be
but
poor
and
humble
stars
for
glittering
on
the
rustic
objects
among
which
I
had
passed
my
life
.
  
<EOS>
"
Saturday
night
,
"
said
I
,
when
we
sat
at
our
supper
of
bread
-
and
-
cheese
and
beer
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Five
more
days
,
and
then
the
day
before
 
\
<EOS>
the
\
 
day
!
<EOS>
They
'll
soon
go
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Pip
,
"
observed
Joe
,
whose
voice
sounded
hollow
in
his
beer
mug
.
<EOS>
"
They
'll
soon
go
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Soon
,
soon
go
,
"
said
Biddy
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
thinking
,
Joe
,
that
when
I
go
down
on
Monday
,
and
order
my
new
clothes
,
I
shall
tell
the
tailor
that
I
'll
come
and
put
them
on
there
,
or
that
I
'll
have
them
sent
to
Mr
Pumblechook
's
.
<EOS>
It
would
be
very
disagreeable
to
be
stared
at
by
all
the
people
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr
and
Mrs
Hubble
might
like
to
see
you
in
your
new
gen
-
teel
figure
too
,
Pip
,
"
said
Joe
,
industriously
cutting
his
bread
,
with
his
cheese
on
it
,
in
the
palm
of
his
left
hand
,
and
glancing
at
my
untasted
supper
as
if
he
thought
of
the
time
when
we
used
to
compare
slices
.
<EOS>
"
So
might
Wopsle
.
<EOS>
And
the
Jolly
Bargemen
might
take
it
as
a
compliment
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
just
what
I
do
n't
want
,
Joe
.
<EOS>
They
would
make
such
a
business
of
it
---
such
a
coarse
and
common
business
---
that
I
could
n't
bear
myself
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
that
indeed
,
Pip
!
"
said
Joe
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
could
n't
abear
yourself
---
"
  
Biddy
asked
me
here
,
as
she
sat
holding
my
sister
's

,
"
Have
you
thought
about
when
you
'll
show
yourself
to
Mr
Gargery
,
and
your
sister
,
and
me
?
<EOS>
You
will
show
yourself
to
us
;
wo

you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Biddy
,
"
I
returned
with
some
resentment
,
"
you
are
so
exceedingly
quick
that
it
's
difficult
to
keep
up
with
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
(
"
She
always
were
quick
,
"
observed
Joe
.
)
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
had
waited
another
moment
,
Biddy
,
you
would
have
heard
me
say
that
I
shall
bring
my
clothes
here
in
a
bundle
one
evening
---
most
likely
on
the
evening
before
I
go
away
.
"
  
<EOS>
Biddy
said
no
more
.
<EOS>
Handsomely
forgiving
her
,
I
soon
exchanged
an
affectionate
good
-
night
with
her
and
Joe
,
and
went
up
to
bed
.
<EOS>
When
I
got
into
my
little
room
,
I
sat
down
and
took
a
long
look
at
it
,
as
a
mean
little
room
that
I
should
soon
be
parted
from
and
raised
above
,
for
ever
.
<EOS>
It
was
furnished
with
fresh
young
remembrances
too
,
and
even
at
the
same
moment
I
fell
into
much
the
same
confused
division
of
mind
between
it
and
the
better
rooms
to
which
I
was
going
,
as
I
had
been
in
so
often
between
the
forge
and
Miss
Havisham
's
,
and
Biddy
and
Estella
.
  
<EOS>
The
sun
had
been
shining
brightly
all
day
on
the
roof
of
my
attic
,
and
the
room
was
warm
.
<EOS>
As
I
put
the
window
open
and
stood
looking
out
,
I
saw
Joe
come
slowly
forth
at
the
dark
door
below
,
and
take
a
turn
or
two
in
the
air
;
and
then
I
saw
Biddy
come
,
and
bring
him
a
pipe
and
light
it
for
him
.
<EOS>
He
never
smoked
so
late
,
and
it
seemed
to
hint
to
me
that
he
wanted
comforting
,
for
some
reason
or
other
.
  
<EOS>
He
presently
stood
at
the
door
immediately
beneath
me
,
smoking
his
pipe
,
and
Biddy
stood
there
too
,
quietly
talking
to
him
,
and
I
knew
that
they
talked
of
me
,
for
I
heard
my
name
mentioned
in
an
endearing
tone
by
both
of
them
more
than
once
.
<EOS>
I
would
not
have
listened
for
more
,
if
I
could
have
heard
more
:
<EOS>
so
,
I
drew
away
from
the
window
,
and
sat
down
in
my
one
chair
by
the
bedside
,
feeling
it
very
sorrowful
and
strange
that
this
first
night
of
my
bright
fortunes
should
be
the
loneliest
I
had
ever
known
.
  
<EOS>
Looking
towards
the
open
window
,
I
saw
light
wreaths
from
Joe
's
pipe
floating
there
,
and
I
fancied
it
was
like
a
blessing
from
Joe
---
not
obtruded
on
me
or
paraded
before
me
,
but
pervading
the
air
we
shared
together
.
<EOS>
I
put
my
light
out
,
and
crept
into
bed
;
and
it
was
an
uneasy
bed
now
,
and
I
never
slept
the
old
sound
sleep
in
it
any
more
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
19
 
MORNING
made
a
considerable
difference
in
my
general
prospect
of
Life
and
brightened
it
so
much
that
it
scarcely
seemed
the
same
.
<EOS>
What
lay
heaviest
on
my
mind
,
was
,
the
consideration
that
six
days
intervened
between
me
and
the
day
of
departure
;
for
,
I
could
not
divest
myself
of
a
misgiving
that
something
might
happen
to
London
in
the
meanwhile
,
and
that
,
when
I
got
there
,
it
would
be
either
greatly
deteriorated
or
clean
gone
.
  
<EOS>
Joe
and
Biddy
were
very
sympathetic
and
pleasant
when
I
spoke
of
our
approaching
separation
;
but
they
only
referred
to
it
when
I
did
.
<EOS>
After
breakfast
,
Joe
brought
out
my
indentures
from
the
press
in
the
best
parlour
,
and
we
put
them
in
the
fire
,
and
I
felt
that
I
was
free
.
<EOS>
With
all
the
novelty
of
my
emancipation
on
me
,
I
went
to
church
with
Joe
,
and
thought
,
perhaps
the
clergyman
would
n't
have
read
that
about
the
rich
man
and
the
kingdom
of
Heaven
,
if
he
had
known
all
.
  
<EOS>
After
our
early
dinner
I
strolled
out
alone
,
purposing
to
finish
off
the
marshes
at
once
,
and
get
them
done
with
.
<EOS>
As
I
passed
the
church
,
I
felt
(
as
I
had
felt
during
service
in
the
morning
)
<EOS>
a
sublime
compassion
for
the
poor
creatures
who
were
destined
to
go
there
,
Sunday
after
Sunday
,
all
their
lives
through
,
and
to
lie
obscurely
at
last
among
the
low
green
mounds
.
<EOS>
I
promised
myself
that
I
would
do
something
for
them
one
of
these
days
,
and
formed
a
plan
in
outline
for
bestowing
a
dinner
of
roast
-
beef
and
plum
-
pudding
,
a
pint
of
ale
,
and
a
gallon
of
condescension
,
upon
everybody
in
the
village
.
  
<EOS>
If
I
had
often
thought
before
,
with
something
allied
to
shame
,
of
my
companionship
with
the
fugitive
whom
I
had
once
seen
limping
among
those
graves
,
what
were
my
thoughts
on
this
Sunday
,
when
the
place
recalled
the
wretch
,
ragged
and
shivering
,
with
his
felon
iron
and
badge
!
<EOS>
My
comfort
was
,
that
it
happened
a
long
time
ago
,
and
that
he
had
doubtless
been
transported
a
long
way
off
,
and
that
he
was
dead
to
me
,
and
might
be
veritably
dead
into
the
bargain
.
  
<EOS>
No
more
low
wet
grounds
,
no
more
dykes
and
sluices
,
no
more
of
these
grazing
cattle
---
though
they
seemed
,
in
their
dull
manner
,
to
wear
a
more
respectful
air
now
,
and
to
face
round
,
in
order
that
they
might
stare
as
long
as
possible
at
the
possessor
of
such
great
expectations
---
farewell
,
monotonous
acquaintances
of
my
childhood
,
<EOS>
henceforth
I
was
for
London
and
greatness
:
not
for
smith
's
work
in
general
and
for
you
!
<EOS>
I
made
my
exultant
way
to
the
old
Battery
,
and
,
lying
down
there
to
consider
the
question
whether
Miss
Havisham
intended
me
for
Estella
,
fell
asleep
.
  
<EOS>
When
I
awoke
,
I
was
much
surprised
to
find
Joe
sitting
beside
me
,
smoking
his
pipe
.
<EOS>
He
greeted
me
with
a
cheerful
smile
on
my
opening
my
eyes
,
and
said
:
  
"
<EOS>
As
being
the
last
time
,
Pip
,
I
thought
I
'd
foller
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
Joe
,
I
am
very
glad
you
did
so
.
"
  
"
Thankee
,
Pip
.
"
  
"
You
may
be
sure
,
dear
Joe
,
"
I
went
on
,
after
we
had
shaken
hands
,
"
that
I
shall
never
forget
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
Pip
!
"
said
Joe
,
in
a
comfortable
tone
,
"
I
'm
sure
of
that
.
<EOS>
Ay
,
ay
,
old
chap
!
<EOS>
Bless
you
,
it
were
only
necessary
to
get
it
well
round
in
a
man
's
mind
,
to
be
certain
on
it
.
<EOS>
But
it
took
a
bit
of
time
to
get
it
well
round
,
the
change
come
so
oncommon
plump
;
did
n't
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
Somehow
,
I
was
not
best
pleased
with
Joe
's
being
so
mightily
secure
of
me
.
<EOS>
I
should
have
liked
him
to
have
betrayed
emotion
,
or
to
have
said
,
"
It
does
you
credit
,
Pip
,
"
or
something
of
that
sort
.
<EOS>
Therefore
,
I
made
no
remark
on
Joe
's
first
head
:
merely
saying
as
to
his
second
,
that
the
tidings
had
indeed
come
suddenly
,
but
that
I
had
always
wanted
to
be
a
gentleman
,
and
had
often
and
often
speculated
on
what
I
would
do
,
if
I
were
one
.
  
<EOS>
"
Have
you
though
?
"
said
Joe
.
<EOS>
"
Astonishing
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
pity
now
,
Joe
,
"
said
I
,
"
that
you
did
not
get
on
a
little
more
,
when
we
had
our
lessons
here
;
is
n't
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
do
n't
know
,
"
returned
Joe
.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
so
awful
dull
.
<EOS>
I
'm
only
master
of
my
own
trade
.
<EOS>
It
were
always
a
pity
as
I
was
so
awful
dull
;
but
it
's
no
more
of
a
pity
now
,
than
it
was
---
this
day
twelvemonth
---
<EOS>
do
n't
you
see
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
What
I
had
meant
was
,
that
when
I
came
into
my
property
and
was
able
to
do
something
for
Joe
,
it
would
have
been
much
more
agreeable
if
he
had
been
better
qualified
for
a
rise
in
station
.
<EOS>
He
was
so
perfectly
innocent
of
my
meaning
,
however
,
that
I
thought
I
would
mention
it
to
Biddy
in
preference
.
  
<EOS>
So
,
when
we
had
walked
home
and
had
had
tea
,
I
took
Biddy
into
our
little
garden
by
the
side
of
the
lane
,
and
,
after
throwing
out
in
a
general
way
for
the
elevation
of
her
spirits
,
that
I
should
never
forget
her
,
said
I
had
a
favour
to
ask
of
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
it
is
,
Biddy
,
"
said
I
,
"
that
you
will
not
omit
any
opportunity
of
helping
Joe
on
,
a
little
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
helping
him
on
?
"
asked
Biddy
,
with
a
steady
sort
of
glance
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
Joe
is
a
dear
good
fellow
---
in
fact
,
I
think
he
is
the
dearest
fellow
that
ever
lived
---
but
he
is
rather
backward
in
some
things
.
 
<EOS>
For
instance
,
Biddy
,
in
his
learning
and
his
manners
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Although
I
was
looking
at
Biddy
as
I
spoke
,
and
although
she
opened
her
eyes
very
wide
when
I
had
spoken
,
she
did
not
look
at
me
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
his
manners
!
<EOS>
wo
n't
his
manners
do
,
then
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Biddy
,
plucking
a
black
-
currant
leaf
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Biddy
,
they
do
very
well
here
---
"
  
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
they
 
<EOS>
\
<EOS>
do
\
 
very
well
here
?
<EOS>
"
interrupted
Biddy
,
looking
closely
at
the
leaf
in
her
hand
.
  
<EOS>
"
Hear
me
out
---
but
if
I
were
to
remove
Joe
into
a
higher
sphere
,
as
I
shall
hope
to
remove
him
when
I
fully
come
into
my
property
,
they
would
hardly
do
him
justice
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
do
n't
you
think
he
knows
that
?
"
asked
Biddy
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
such
a
very
provoking
question
(
for
it
<EOS>
had
never
in
the
most
distant
manner
occurred
to
me
)
,
that
I
said
,
snappishly
,
"
Biddy
,
what
do
you
mean
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Biddy
having
rubbed
the
leaf
to
pieces
between
her
hands
---
and
the
smell
of
a
black
-
currant
bush
has
ever
since
recalled
to
me
that
evening
in
the
little
garden
by
the
side
of
the
lane
---
said
,
"
Have
you
never
considered
that
he
may
be
proud
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Proud
?
<EOS>
"
I
repeated
,
with
disdainful
emphasis
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
there
are
many
kinds
of
pride
,
"
said
Biddy
,
looking
full
at
me
and
shaking
her
head
;
"
pride
is
not
all
of
one
kind
---
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Well
?
<EOS>
What
are
you
stopping
for
?
"
said
I.
  
"
Not
all
of
one
kind
,
"
resumed
Biddy
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
may
be
too
proud
to
let
any
one
take
him
out
of
a
place
that
he
is
competent
to
fill
,
and
fills
well
and
with
respect
.
<EOS>
To
tell
you
the
truth
,
I
think
he
is
:
though
it
sounds
bold
in
me
to
say
so
,
for
you
must
know
him
far
better
than
I
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Biddy
,
"
said
I
,
"
I
am
very
sorry
to
see
this
in
you
.
<EOS>
I
did
not
expect
to
see
this
in
you
.
<EOS>
You
are
envious
,
Biddy
,
and
grudging
.
<EOS>
You
are
dissatisfied
on
account
of
my
rise
in
fortune
,
and
you
ca
n't
help
showing
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
have
the
heart
to
think
so
,
"
returned
Biddy
,
"
say
so
.
<EOS>
Say
so
over
and
over
again
,
if
you
have
the
heart
to
think
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
have
the
heart
to
be
so
,
you
mean
,
Biddy
,
"
said
I
,
in
a
virtuous
and
superior
tone
;
"
do
n't
put
it
off
upon
me
.
<EOS>
I
am
very
sorry
to
see
it
,
and
it
's
a
---
<EOS>
it
's
a
bad
side
of
human
nature
.
<EOS>
I
did
intend
to
ask
you
to
use
any
little

you
might
have
after
I
was
gone
,
of
improving
dear
Joe
.
<EOS>
But

,
I
ask
you
nothing
.
<EOS>
I
am
extremely
sorry
to
see
this
in
you
,
Biddy
,
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
It
's
a---
<EOS>
it
's
a
bad
side
of
human
nature
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Whether
you
scold
me
or
approve

me
,
"
returned
poor
Biddy
,
"
you
may
equally
depend
upon
my
trying
to
do
all
that
lies
in
my
power
,
here
,
at
all

.
<EOS>
And
whatever
opinion
you
take
away
of
me
,
shall
make
no
difference
in
my

of
you
.
<EOS>
Yet
a
gentleman
should
not
be
unjust
neither
,
"
said
Biddy
,
turning
away

.
  
<EOS>
I
again
warmly
repeated
that
it
was
a
bad
side
of
human
nature
(
in
which
sentiment
,
waiving
its
application
,
I
have
since
seen
reason
to
think
I
was
right
)
,
and
I
walked
down
the
little
path
away
from
Biddy
,
and
Biddy
went
into
the
house
,
and
I
went
out
at
the
garden
gate
and
took
a
dejected
stroll
until
supper
-
time
;
again
feeling
it
very
sorrowful
and
strange
that
this
,
the
second
night
of
my
bright
fortunes
,
should
be
as
lonely
and
unsatisfactory
as
the
first
.
  
<EOS>
But
,
morning
once
more
brightened
my
view
,
and
I
extended
my
clemency
to
Biddy
,
and
we
dropped
the
subject
.
<EOS>
Putting
on
the
best
clothes
I
had
,
I
went
into
town
as
early
as
I
could
hope
to
find
the
shops
open
,
and
presented
myself
before
Mr
Trabb
,
the
tailor
:
who
was
having
his
breakfast
in
the
parlour
behind
his
shop
,
and
who
did
not
think
it
worth
his
while
to
come
out
to
me
,
but
called
me
in
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
said
Mr
Trabb
,
in
a
hail
-
fellow
-
well
-
met
kind
of
way
.
<EOS>
"
How
are
you
,
and
what
can
I
do
for
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Trabb
had
sliced
his
hot
roll
into
three
feather
beds
,
and
was
slipping
butter
in
between
the
blankets
,
and
covering
it
up
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
prosperous
old
bachelor
,
and
his
open
window
looked
into
a
prosperous
little
garden
and
orchard
,
and
there
was
a
prosperous
iron
safe
let
into
the
wall
at
the
side
of
his
fireplace
,
and
I
did
not
doubt
that
heaps
of
his
prosperity
were
put
away
in
it
in
bags
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr
Trabb
,
"
said
I
,
"
it
's
an
unpleasant
thing
to
have
to
mention
,
because
it
looks
like
boasting
;
but
I
have
come
into
a
handsome
property
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
A
change
passed
over
Mr
Trabb
.
<EOS>
He
forgot
the
butter
in
bed
,
got
up
from
the
bedside
,
and
wiped
his
fingers
on
the
table

,
exclaiming
,
"
Lord
bless
my

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
going
up
to
my
guardian
in
London
,
"
said
I
,
casually
drawing
some
guineas
out
of
my
pocket
and
looking
at
them
;
"
and
I
want
a
fashionable
suit
of
clothes
to
go
in
.
<EOS>
I
wish

pay
for

,
"
I
added
---
<EOS>
otherwise
I
thought
he
might
only
pretend
to
make

---
"
with
ready
money
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Trabb
,
as
he
respectfully
bent
his

,

,
and
took

touching

,
"
do
n't

me
by
mentioning
that
.
<EOS>
May
I
venture
to
congratulate
you
?
<EOS>
Would

do
me
the
favour
of
stepping
into
the
shop
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Trabb
's
boy
was
the
most
audacious
boy
in
all
that
country
-
side
.
<EOS>
Men
I
had
entered
he
was
sweeping
the

,
and
he
had
sweetened
his

by

me
.
<EOS>
He

when
I
came
out
into
the
shop
with
Mr
Trabb
,
and
he
knocked
the
broom
against
all
possible

,
to
express
(
as
I

)
equality
with

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Hold

,
"
said

,

,
"
or
I
'll

!
<EOS>
Do

,

.
<EOS>
Now
,
this
,
"

,

,

,
"
is

.
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
Give

Number
Four
,
you
!
"
<EOS>
(
To
the
boy
,
and
with

severe
stare
:
foreseeing
the
danger
of
that
miscreant
's
brushing
me
with

,
or

.
)
  
<EOS>
Mr
Trabb
never

until

on

.
<EOS>
Then
,

,

.
"
<EOS>
And

,
"

,
"

,
<EOS>
you
young

,
the

you

to

.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Trabb
then
bent
over
number
four
,
and
in
a
sort
of
deferential
confidence
recommended
it
to
me
as
a
light
article
for
summer
wear
,
an
article
much
in
vogue
among
the
nobility
and
gentry
,
an
article
that
it
would
ever
be
an
honour
to
him
to
reflect
upon
a
distinguished
fellow
-
townsman
's
(
if
he
might

for

fellow
-

)
having

.
"
<EOS>
Are

,

,
"
said

Trabb
to
the
boy
after

,
"
or

kick

and
bring

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
selected
the
materials
for
a

,
with
the

of
Mr
Trabb
's
judgment
,
and
re
-
entered
the

to

.
<EOS>
For
,
although
Mr
Trabb
had
my

already
,
and
had

been
quite
contented
with
it
,
he
said

that
it
"
would
n't

under

,

---
would

.
"
<EOS>
So
,
Mr
Trabb
measured
and

,
in

,
as

I
were
an
estate
and
he
the
finest
species

,
and
gave

such

of

that
I
felt
that
no
suit
of
clothes
could
possibly

for

.
<EOS>
When
he
had
at

and

to
Mr
Pumblechook
's
on

,
he

,
<EOS>
with
his

upon

,
"
I
know
,

,
that
London
gentlemen
can
not

local

,
as

;
but
if

would
give
me
a

now
and
then
in
the

of
a
townsman
,
I
should
greatly
esteem
it
.
<EOS>
Good
morning
,
sir
,
much
obliged
.
<EOS>
---
Door
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
last
word
was
flung
at
the
boy
,
who
had
not
the
least
notion
what
it
meant
.
<EOS>
But
I
saw
him
collapse
as
his
master
rubbed
me
out
with
his
hands
,
and
my
first
decided
experience
of
the
stupendous
power
of
money
,
was
,
that
it
had
morally
laid
upon
his
back
,
Trabb
's
boy
.
  
<EOS>
After
this
memorable
event
,
I
went
to
the
hatter
's
,
and
the
bootmaker
's
,
and
the
hosier
's
,
and
felt
rather
like
Mother
Hubbard
's
dog
whose
outfit
required
the
services
of
so
many
trades
.
<EOS>
I
also
went
to
the
coach
-
office
and
took
my
place
for
seven
o'clock
on
Saturday
morning
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
necessary
to
explain
everywhere
that
I
had
come
into
a
handsome
property
;
but
whenever
I
said
anything
to
that
effect
,
it
followed
that
the
officiating
tradesman
ceased
to
have
his
attention
diverted
through
the
window
by
the
High
-
street
,
and
concentrated
his
mind
upon
me
.
<EOS>
When
I
had
ordered
everything
I
wanted
,
I
directed
my
steps
towards
Pumblechook
's
,
and
,
as
I
approached
that
gentleman
's
place
of
business
,
I
saw
him
standing
at
his
door
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
waiting
for
me
with
great
impatience
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
out
early
with
the
chaise
-
cart
,
and
had
called
at
the
forge
and
heard
the
news
.
<EOS>
He
had
prepared
a
collation
for
me
in
the
Barnwell
parlour
,
and
he
too
ordered
his
shopman
to
"
come
out
of
the
gangway
"
as
my
sacred
person
passed
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
friend
,
"
said
Mr
Pumblechook
,
taking
me
by
both
hands
,
when
he
and
I
and
the
collation
were
alone
,
"
I
give
you
joy
of
your
good
fortune
.
<EOS>
Well
deserved
,
well
deserved
!
"
  
<EOS>
This
was
coming
to
the
point
,
and
I
thought
it
a
sensible
way
of
expressing

.
  
<EOS>
"
To
think
,
"
said
Mr
Pumblechook
,
after

,
"
that
I
should
have
been
the
humble

of
leading
up

this
,
is

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
begged
Mr
Pumblechook
to
remember
that
nothing
was
to
be
ever
said
or
hinted
,
on
that
point
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
young
friend
,
"
said
Mr
Pumblechook
,
"
if
you
will
allow
me
to
call
you
so
---
<EOS>
"
  
I
murmured
"
Certainly
,
"
and
Mr
Pumblechook
took
me
by
both
hands
again
,
and
communicated

to
his
waistcoat
,
which
had

,

,
"

friend
,
rely

doing
my
little
all
in

,
by
keeping
