fact
before
the
mind
of
Joseph
.
<EOS>
---
Joseph
!
"
said
Mr
Pumblechook
,
in

way

.
<EOS>
"
Joseph
!
!
<EOS>
Joseph
!
!
!
<EOS>
"
Thereupon
he
shook
his

and
tapped

,
expressing
his
sense
of
deficiency
in
Joseph
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
my
dear
young
friend
,
"
said
Mr
Pumblechook
,
"
you
must
be
hungry
,
you
must

.
<EOS>
Be

.
<EOS>
Here
is
a
chicken
had
round
from
the
Boar
,
here

had
round
from
the
Boar
,
here
's
one
or
two
little
things
had
round
from
the
Boar
,
that
I

.
<EOS>
But

I
,
"
said
Mr
Pumblechook
,
getting

the

,
"
see
afore
me
,
him
as
I
ever
sported

in

of

?
<EOS>
And
may
I
---
_
may
_
!
---
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
This
May
I
,
meant
might
he
shake
hands
?
<EOS>
I
consented
,
and
he
was
fervent
,
and
then

.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
is
wine
,
"
said
Mr
Pumblechook
.
<EOS>
"
Let
us
drink
,
Thanks
to
Fortune
,
and
may
she
ever
pick

her

with

!
<EOS>
And
yet
I
can
not
,
"
said
Mr
Pumblechook
,
getting

,
"
see
afore
me
<EOS>
One
---
and
likewise

to
One
---
without
again
expressing
---
May
<EOS>
I
---
<EOS>
_
may
_
 
I
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
said
he
might
,
and
he
shook
hands
with
me
again
,
and
emptied
his
glass
and
turned
it
upside
down
.
<EOS>
I
did
the
same
;
and
if
I
had
turned
myself
upside
down
before
drinking
,
the
wine
could
not
have
gone
more
direct
to
my
head
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Pumblechook
helped
me
to
the
liver
wing
,
and
to
the
best
slice
of
tongue
(
none
of
those
out
-
of
-
the
-
way
No
Thoroughfares
of
Pork
now
)
,
and
took
,

speaking
,
no

at
all
.
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
poultry
,
poultry
!
<EOS>
You
little
thought
,
"
said
Mr
Pumblechook
,
apostrophizing
the
fowl
in
the
dish
,
"
when
you
was
a
young

,
what
was
in

you
.
<EOS>
You
little
thought
you
was
to
be
refreshment
beneath
this
humble

for
one
as
---
<EOS>
Call

a

,
if
you
will
,
"
said
Mr
Pumblechook
,

,
"
but
<EOS>
may
I
?
 
<EOS>
_
may
_
 
I
---
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
began
to
be
unnecessary
to
repeat
the
form
of
saying
he
might
,
so
he
did
it
at
once
.
<EOS>
How
he
ever
did
it
so
often
without
wounding

with

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
your
sister
<EOS>
,
"
he

,

,
"
which

bringing

!
<EOS>
It

a

,
to
reflect
that
she
's
no

.
<EOS>
May
---
"
  
I

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
We
'll
drink
her

,
"

"
Ah
!
<EOS>
"

Pumblechook
,

quite

,
"
that
's

'em
,

!
"
<EOS>
(
I
do

Sir

,

he

I
,

)
;
"
that

,

<EOS>
Ever

.
<EOS>
It

,
"
said

servile

,

,
"
to

,
have

---
but
<EOS>
_
may
_
 
I
---
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
When

,

and

to

.
<EOS>
"
Let

never

,
"
said
Mr
Pumblechook
,
"
to
her

of

,
but
it
is
to
be
hoped
she
meant

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
At

,
I

that
he
was
getting

in
the

;
as

,
I
felt
all
face
,

in

.
  
<EOS>
I
mentioned

Mr
Pumblechook
that

new

to
his

,
and
he
was

.
<EOS>
I

reason
for
desiring
to
avoid

in
the

,
and
he
lauded

to

.
<EOS>
There

nobody
but

,
he

,
worthy
of
my
confidence
,
and
---
in

,
might
he
?
<EOS>
Then

asked
me
tenderly
if
I
remembered
our
boyish
games
at

,
and
how
we
had
gone
together
to

,
and
,
in

,
how

ever

fancy
and

?
<EOS>
If

as

,
I
should
have
known

,
and
should
in
my

of
hearts
have

.
<EOS>
Yet

,
I
remember

that

had
been
much

in

,
and
that
he
was
a
sensible
practical
good
-

.
  
<EOS>
By

he
fell
to
reposing
such
great

in
me
,
as
to

in

.
<EOS>
He
mentioned

there

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
What

was
wanting
to

,

be
More

.
<EOS>
Those
were
the

words
,
more
capital
.
<EOS>
Now

him
(
Pumblechook
)
that
if
that
capital
were
got
into
the
business
,
through
a

,

---

,

,

.
---

for
a
young

of
spirit

,
which
would

.
<EOS>
But
what
did
I
think
?
<EOS>
He
had
great

in
my

,
and
what
did
I

?
<EOS>
I
gave
it
as
my

.
<EOS>
"
Wait
a
bit
!
"
<EOS>
The
united

and

of
this
view
<EOS>
so

,
that
he
no

if

might
shake
hands
with

,
but
said

---
and

.
  
<EOS>
We
drank
all
the
wine
,
and
Mr
Pumblechook
pledged

over
and
over
again
to
keep
Joseph
up
to
the
mark
(
I
do
n't
know
what

)
,
and
to

(
I

what

)
.
<EOS>
He
also
made

for

,
and

,
that

,
"

,

,

'
.
"
<EOS>
He

that
it

a

thing

,

I

.
<EOS>
Finally

,

that
there

the

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
There
,

was

Mr
Pumblechook
's

.
<EOS>
He
was
a
long

,
and
was

.
<EOS>
I

,
and
he

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
my

,
"

,

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
This

.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
May

,

?
 
<EOS>
\
<EOS>
May
\
 
<EOS>
I
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
We

,

young

.
<EOS>
Then
,

;

.
  
<EOS>
I

scant

London
,
for

.
<EOS>
But
,

,

I

next

,
in

.
  
<EOS>
So
,
Tuesday
,

,
and
Thursday
,

;
and

I
went
to
Mr
Pumblechook
's
,

Havisham
.
<EOS>
Mr
Pumblechook
's
own
room
was
given
up
to
me
to
dress
in
,
and
was
decorated
with
clean
towels
expressly

.
<EOS>
My
clothes
were
rather

,

.
<EOS>
Probably
every

and

expected

,

's

.
<EOS>
But

,

,

's

limited

,

see

legs
<EOS>
it

.
<EOS>
It

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
This
was
all
as
it

,

:

,

,

's

.
  
<EOS>
I

Miss
Havisham
's
by
all

,
and
rang

bell

,
on

of
the

long

.
<EOS>
Sarah
Pocket
came
to

,
and
positively

saw

so

;
her

-

likewise
,

from
brown
to

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
?
"
 
<EOS>
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
,
good

!
 
<EOS>
What
do
you

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am

,
Miss
Pocket
,
"
said

,
"
and
want
to
say

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
was
not

,
for
she

,
while
she
went
to

to

.
<EOS>
After
a
very
short

,
she
returned
and
took
me
up
,
staring

me
all

.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Havisham
was
taking

in
the
room
with
the
long

,
leaning
on
her
crutch

.
<EOS>
The
room
was
lighted
as
of
yore
,
and
at
the
sound

our

,
she
stopped
and
turned
.
<EOS>
She
was
then
just
abreast
of
the
rotted
bride
-
cake
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
go
,
Sarah
,
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Pip
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
start
for
London
,
Miss
Havisham
,
to
-
morrow
,
"
I
was
exceedingly
careful
what
I
said
,
"
and
I
thought
you
would
kindly
not

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
gay
figure
,
Pip
,
"
said

,

,

,

who
had

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

Havisham
,
"
I

.
"
<EOS>
And
I
am
so

,
Miss
Havisham
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
ay
!
<EOS>
"

,

discomfited

Sarah
,

.
<EOS>
"
I
have
seen
Mr
Jaggers
.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
So

-

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Yes
,
Miss
Havisham
.
"
  
"
And

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
Miss
Havisham
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Miss
Havisham
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
Mr
Jaggers
is

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
Miss
Havisham
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
quite

on

,

of
Sarah
Pocket
's

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
"
she

;
"
you

.
<EOS>
Be

---
deserve

---

's

.
"
<EOS>
She

,

Sarah
,
and
Sarah
's

wrung
out

her

face
a

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Good
-

,
Pip
!
<EOS>
---
you
will
always

the

of
Pip
,
you

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Miss
Havisham
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Good
-

,
Pip
!
"
  
<EOS>
She

her

,
and
I
went
down
on
my
knee
and
put
it
to
my

.
<EOS>
I
had
not

how
I
should
take

of

;
it

me
at
the

,
to

.
<EOS>
She
looked
at
Sarah
Pocket
with
triumph
in
her
weird

,
and
so
I
left
my
fairy
godmother
,
with
both
her
hands
on
her

,
standing
in

the
dimly

room
beside

rotten

-
cake
that
was
hidden
in

.
  
<EOS>
Sarah
Pocket
conducted
me
down
,
as
if
I
were
a
ghost
who
must

seen
out
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
get
over
my
appearance
,
and
was
in
the
last
degree
confounded
.
<EOS>
I
said
"
Good
-
bye
,
Miss
Pocket
;
"
but
she
merely
stared
,
and
did
not
seem
collected
enough
to
know
that
I
had
spoken
.
<EOS>
Clear
of
the
house
,
I
made
the
best
of
my
way
back
to
Pumblechook
's
,
took
off
my
new
clothes
,
made
them
into
a
bundle
,
and
went
back
home
in
my
older
dress
,
carrying
it
---
to
speak
the
truth
---
much
more
at
my
ease
too
,
though
I
had
the
bundle
to
carry
.
  
<EOS>
And
now
,
those
six
days
which
were
to
have
run
out
so
slowly
,
had
run
out
fast
and
were
gone
,
and
to
-
morrow
looked
me
in
the
face
more
steadily
than
I
could
look
at
it
.
<EOS>
As
the
six
evenings
had
dwindled
away
,
to
five
,
to
four
,
to
three
,
to
two
,
I
had
become
more
and
more
appreciative
of
the
society
of
Joe
and
Biddy
.
<EOS>
On
this
last
evening
,
I
dressed
myself
out
in
my
new
clothes
,
for
their
delight
,
and
sat
in
my
splendour
until
bedtime
.
<EOS>
We
had
a
hot
supper
on
the
occasion
,
graced
by
the
inevitable
roast
fowl
,
and
we
had
some
flip
to
finish
with
.
<EOS>
We
were
all
very
low
,
and
none
the
higher
for
pretending
to
be
in
spirits
.
  
<EOS>
I
was
to
leave
our
village
at
five
in
the
morning
,
carrying
my
little
hand
-
portmanteau
,
and
I
had
told
Joe
that
I
wished
to
walk
away
all
alone
.
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
---
sore
afraid
---
that
this
purpose
originated
in
my
sense
of
the
contrast
there
would
be
between
me
and
Joe
,
if
we
went
to
the
coach
together
.
<EOS>
I
had
pretended
with
myself
that
there
was
nothing
of
this
taint
in
the
arrangement
;
but
when
I
went
up
to
my
little
room
on
this
last
night
,
I
felt
compelled
to
admit
that
it
might
be
so
,
and
had
an
impulse
upon
me
to
go
down
again
and
entreat
Joe
to
walk
with
me
in
the
morning
.
<EOS>
I
did
not
.
  
<EOS>
All
night
there
were
coaches
in
my
broken
sleep
,
going
to
wrong
places
instead
of
to
London
,
and
having
in
the
traces
,
now
dogs
,
now
cats
,
now
pigs
,
now
men
---
never
horses
.
<EOS>
Fantastic
failures
of
journeys
occupied
me
until
the
day
dawned
and
the
birds
were
singing
.
<EOS>
Then
,
I
got
up
and
partly
dressed
,
and
sat
at
the
window
to
take
a
last
look
out
,
and
in
taking
it
fell
asleep
.
  
<EOS>
Biddy
was
astir
so
early
to
get
my
breakfast
,
that
,
although
I
did
not
sleep
at
the
window
an
hour
,
I
smelt
the
smoke
of
the
kitchen
fire
when
I
started
up
with
a
terrible
idea
that
it
must
be
late
in
the
afternoon
.
<EOS>
But
long
after
that
,
and
long
after
I
had
heard
the
clinking
of
the
teacups
and
was
quite
ready
,
I
wanted
the
resolution
to
go
down
stairs
.
<EOS>
After
all
,
I
remained
up
there
,
repeatedly
unlocking
and
unstrapping
my
small
portmanteau
and
locking
and
strapping
it
up
again
,
until
Biddy
called
to
me
that
I
was
late
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
hurried
breakfast
with
no
taste
in
it
.
<EOS>
I
got
up
from
the
meal
,
saying
with
a
sort
of
briskness
,
as
if
it
had
only
just
occurred
to
me
,
"
Well
!
<EOS>
I
suppose
I
must
be
off
!
"
<EOS>
and
then
I
kissed
my
sister
who
was
laughing
and
nodding
and
shaking
in
her
usual
chair
,
and
kissed
Biddy
,
and
threw
my
arms
around
Joe
's
neck
.
<EOS>
Then
I
took
up
my
little
portmanteau
and
walked
out
.
<EOS>
The
last
I
saw
of
them
was
,
when
I
presently
heard
a
scuffle
behind
me
,
and
looking
back
,
saw
Joe
throwing
an
old
shoe
after
me
and
Biddy
throwing
another
old
shoe
.
<EOS>
I
stopped
then
,
to
wave
my
hat
,
and
dear
old
Joe
waved
his
strong
right
arm
above
his
head
,
crying
huskily
"
Hooroar
!
"
<EOS>
and
Biddy
put
her
apron
to
her
face
.
  
<EOS>
I
walked
away
at
a
good
pace
,
thinking
it
was
easier
to
go
than
I
had
supposed
it
would
be
,
and
reflecting
that
it
would
never
have
done
to
have
had
an
old
shoe
thrown
after
the
coach
,
in
sight
of
all
the
High
-
street
.
<EOS>
I
whistled
and
made
nothing
of
going
.
<EOS>
But
the
village
was
very
peaceful
and
quiet
,
and
the
light
mists
were
solemnly
rising
,
as
if
to
show
me
the
world
,
and
I
had
been
so
innocent
and
little
there
,
and
<EOS>
all
beyond
was
so
unknown
and
great
,
that
in
a
moment
with
a
strong
heave
and
sob
I
broke
into
tears
.
<EOS>
It
was
by
the
finger
-
post
at
the
end
of
the
village
,
and
I
laid
my
hand
upon
it
,
and
said
,
"
Good
-
bye
<EOS>
O
my
dear
,
dear
friend
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Heaven
knows
we
need
never
be
ashamed
of
our
tears
,
for
they
are
rain
upon
the
blinding
dust
of
earth
,
overlying
our
hard
hearts
.
<EOS>
I
was
better
after
I
had
cried
,
than
before
---
more
sorry
,
more
aware
of
my
own
ingratitude
,
more
gentle
.
<EOS>
If
I
had
cried
before
,
I
should
have
had
Joe
with
me
then
.
  
<EOS>
So
subdued
I
was
by
those
tears
,
and
by
their
breaking
out
again
in
the
course
of
the
quiet
walk
,
that
when
I
was
on
the
coach
,
and
it
was
clear
of
the
town
,
I
deliberated
with
an
aching
heart
whether
I
would
not
get
down
when
we
changed
horses
and
walk
back
,
and
have
another
evening
at
home
,
and
a
better
parting
.
<EOS>
We
changed
,
and
I
had
not
made
up
my
mind
,
and
still
reflected
for
my
comfort
that
it
would
be
quite
practicable
to
get
down
and
walk
back
,
when
we
changed
again
.
<EOS>
And
while
I
was
occupied
with
these
deliberations
,
I
would
fancy
an
exact
resemblance
to
Joe
in
some
man
coming
along
the
road
towards
us
,
and
my
heart
would
beat
high
.
<EOS>
---
As
if
he
could
possibly
be
there
!
  
<EOS>
We
changed
again
,
and
yet
again
,
and
it
was
now
too
late
and
too
far
to
go
back
,
and
I
went
on
.
<EOS>
And
the
mists
had
all
solemnly
risen
now
,
and
the
world
lay
spread
before
me
.
            
<EOS>
THIS
IS
THE
END
OF
THE
FIRST
STAGE
OF
                     
PIP
'S
EXPECTATIONS
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
20
 
<EOS>
THE
journey
from
our
town
to
the
metropolis
,
was
a
journey
of
about
five
hours
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
little
past
mid
-
day
when
the
four
-
horse
stage
-
coach
by
which
I
was
a
passenger
,
got
into
the
ravel
of
traffic
frayed
out
about
the
Cross
Keys
,
Wood
-
street
,
Cheapside
,
London
.
  
<EOS>
We
Britons
had
at
that
time
particularly
settled
that
it
was
treasonable
to
doubt
our
having
and
our
being
the
best
of
everything
:
<EOS>
otherwise
,
while
I
was
scared
by
the
immensity
of
London
,
I
think
I
might
have
had
some
faint
doubts
whether
it
was
not
rather
ugly
,
crooked
,
narrow
,
and
dirty
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Jaggers
had
duly
sent
me
his
address
;
it
was
,
Little
Britain
,
and
he
had
written
after
it
on
his
card
,
"
just
out
of
Smithfield
,
and
close
by
the
coach
-
office
.
"
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
a
hackney
-
coachman
,
who
seemed
to
have
as
many
capes
to
his
greasy
great
-
coat
as
he
was
years
old
,
packed
me
up
in
his
coach
and
hemmed
me
in
with
a
folding
and
jingling
barrier
of
steps
,
as
if
he
were
going
to
take
me
fifty
miles
.
<EOS>
His
getting
on
his
box
,
which
I
remember
to
have
been
decorated
with
an
old
weather
-
stained
pea
-
green
hammer
-
cloth
,
moth
-
eaten
into
rags
,
was
quite
a
work
of
time
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
wonderful
equipage
,
with
six
great
coronets
outside
,
and
ragged
things
behind
for
I
do
n't
know
how
many
footmen
to
hold
on
by
,
and
a
harrow
below
them
,
to
prevent
amateur
footmen
from
yielding
to
the
temptation
.
  
<EOS>
I
had
scarcely
had
time
to
enjoy
the
coach
and
to
think
how
like
a
straw
-
yard
<EOS>
it
was
,
and
yet
how
like
a
rag
-
shop
,
and
to
wonder
why
the
horses
'
nose
-
bags
were
kept
inside
,
when
I
observed
the
coachman
beginning
to
get
down
,
as
if
we
were
going
to
stop
presently
.
<EOS>
And
stop
we
presently
did
,
in
a
gloomy
street
,
at
certain
offices
with
an
open
door
,
whereon
was
painted
MR
.
<EOS>
JAGGERS
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
much
?
<EOS>
"
I
asked
the
coachman
.
  
<EOS>
The
coachman
answered
,
"
A
shilling
---
unless
you
wish
to
make
it
more
.
"
  
<EOS>
I
naturally
said
I
had
no
wish
to
make
it
more
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
it
must
be
a
shilling
,
"
observed
the
coachman
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
want
to
get
into
trouble
.
<EOS>
I
know
 
<EOS>
\
him
!
"
<EOS>
\
 
<EOS>
He
darkly
closed
an
eye
at
Mr
Jaggers
's
name
,
and
shook
his
head
.
  
<EOS>
When
he
had
got
his
shilling
,
and
had
in
course
of
time
completed
the
ascent
to
his
box
,
and
had
got
away
(
which
appeared
to
relieve
his
mind
)
,
I
went
into
the
front
office
with
my
little
portmanteau
in
my
hand
and
asked
,
Was
Mr
Jaggers
at
home
?
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
not
,
"
returned
the
clerk
.
<EOS>
"
He
is
in
Court
at
present
.
<EOS>
Am
I
addressing
Mr
pip
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
signified
that
he
was
addressing
Mr
Pip
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr
Jaggers
left
word
<EOS>
would
you
wait
in
his
room
.
<EOS>
He
could
n't
say
how
long
he
might
be
,
having
a
case
on
.
<EOS>
But
it
stands
to
reason
his
time
being
valuable
,
that
he
wo
n't
be
longer
than
he
can
help
.
"
  
<EOS>
With
those
words
,
the
clerk
opened
a
door
,
and
ushered
me
into
an
inner
chamber
at
the
back
.
<EOS>
Here
,
we
found
a
gentleman
with
one
eye
,
in
a
velveteen
suit
and
knee
-

,
who
wiped
his
nose
with
his
sleeve
on
being
interrupted
in
the
perusal
of
the
newspaper
.
  
<EOS>
"
Go
and
wait
outside
,
Mike
,
"
said
the
clerk
.
  
<EOS>
I
began
to
say
that
I
hoped
I
was
not
interrupting
---
when
the
clerk
shoved
this
gentleman
out
with
as
little
ceremony
as
I
ever
saw
used
,
and
tossing
his
fur
cap
out
after
him
,
left
me
alone
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Jaggers
's
room
was
lighted
by
a
skylight
only
,
and
was
a
most
dismal
place
;
the
skylight
,
eccentrically
patched
like
a
broken
head
,
and
the
distorted
adjoining
houses
looking
as
if
they
had
twisted
themselves
to
peep
down
at
me
through
it
.
<EOS>
There
were
not
so
many
papers
about
,
as
I
should
have
expected
to
see
;
and
there
were
some
odd
objects
about
,
that
I
should
not
have
expected
to
see
---
such
as
an
old
rusty
pistol
,
a
sword
in
a
scabbard
,
several
strange
-
looking
boxes
and
packages
,
and
two
dreadful
casts
on
a
shelf
,
of
faces
peculiarly
swollen
,
and
twitchy
about
the
nose
.
<EOS>
Mr
Jaggers
's
own
high
-
backed
chair
was
of
deadly
black
horse
-
hair
,
with
rows
of
brass
nails
round
it
,
like
a
coffin
;
and
I
fancied
I
could
see
how
he
leaned
back
in
it
,
and
bit
his
forefinger
at
the
clients
.
<EOS>
The
room
was
but
small
,
and
the
clients
seemed
to
have
had
a
habit
of
backing
up
against
the
wall
:
the
wall
,
especially
opposite
to
Mr
Jaggers
's
chair
,
being
greasy
with
shoulders
.
<EOS>
I
recalled
,
too
,
that
the
one
-
eyed
gentleman
had
shuffled
forth
against
the
wall
when
I
was
the
innocent
cause
of
his
being
turned
out
.
  
<EOS>
I
sat
down
in
the
cliental
chair
placed
over
against
Mr
Jaggers
's
chair
,
and
became
fascinated
by
the
dismal
atmosphere
of
the
place
.
<EOS>
I
called
to
mind
that
the
clerk
had
the
same
air
of
knowing
something
to
everybody
else
's
disadvantage
,
as
his
master
had
.
<EOS>
I
wondered
how
many
other
clerks
there
were
up
-
stairs
,
and
whether
they
all
claimed
to
have
the
same
detrimental
mastery
of
their
fellow
-
creatures
.
<EOS>
I
wondered
what
was
the
history
of
all
the
odd
litter
about
the
room
,
and
how
it
came
there
.
<EOS>
I
wondered
whether
the
two
swollen
faces
were
of
Mr
Jaggers
's
family
,
and
,
if
he
were
so
unfortunate
as
to
have
had
a
pair
of
such
ill
-
looking
relations
,
why
he
stuck
them
on
that
dusty
perch
for
the
blacks
and
flies
to
settle
on
,
instead
of
giving
them
a
place
at
home
.
<EOS>
Of
course
I
had
no
experience
of
a
London
summer
day
,
and
my
spirits
may
have
been
oppressed
by
the
hot
exhausted
air
,
and
by
the
dust
and
grit
that
lay
thick
on
everything
.
<EOS>
But
I
sat
wondering
and
waiting
in
Mr
Jaggers
's
close
room
,
until
I
really
could
not
bear
the
two
casts
on
the
shelf
above
Mr
Jaggers
's
chair
,
and
got
up
and
went
out
.
  
<EOS>
When
I
told
the
clerk
that
I
would
take
a
turn
in
the
air
while
I
waited
,
he
advised
me
to
go
round
the
corner
<EOS>
and
I
should
come
into
Smithfield
.
<EOS>
So
,
I
came
into
Smithfield
;
and
the
shameful
place
,
being
all
asmear
with
filth
and
fat
and
blood
and
foam
,
seemed
to
stick
to
me
.
<EOS>
So
,
I
rubbed
it
off
with
all
possible
speed
by
turning
into
a
street
where
I
saw
the
great
black
dome
of
Saint
Paul
's
bulging
at
me
from
behind
a
grim
stone
building
which
a
bystander
said
was
Newgate
Prison
.
<EOS>
Following
the
wall
of
the
jail
,
I
found
the
roadway
covered
with
straw
to
deaden
the
noise
of
passing
vehicles
;
and
from
this
,
and
from
the
quantity
of
people
standing
about
,
smelling
strongly
of
spirits
and
beer
,
I
inferred
that
the
trials
were
on
.
  
<EOS>
While
I
looked
about
me
here
,
an
exceedingly
dirty
and
partially
drunk
minister
of
justice
asked
me
if
I
would
like
to
step
in
and
hear
a
trial
or
so
:
informing
me
that
he
could
give
me
a
front
place
for
half
-
a
-
crown
,
whence
<EOS>
I
should
command
a
full
view
of
the
Lord
Chief
Justice
in
his
wig
and
robes
---
mentioning
that
awful
personage
like
waxwork
,
and
presently
offering
him
at
the
reduced
price
of
eighteenpence
.
<EOS>
As
I
declined
the
proposal
on
the
plea
of
an
appointment
,
he
was
so
good
as
to
take
me
into
a
yard
and
show
me
where
the
gallows
was
kept
,
and
also
where
people
were
publicly
whipped
,
and
then
he
showed
me
the
Debtors
'
Door
,
out
of
which
culprits
came
to
be
hanged
:
heightening
the
interest
of
that
dreadful
portal
by
giving
me
to
understand
that
"
four
on
'em
"
would
come
out
at
that
door
the
day
after
to
-
morrow
at
eight
in
the
morning
,
to
be
killed
in
a
row
.
<EOS>
This
was
horrible
,
and
gave
me
a
sickening
idea
of
London
:
the
more
so
as
the
Lord
Chief
Justice
's
proprietor
wore
(
from
his
hat
down
to
his
boots
and
up
again
to
his
pocket
-
handkerchief
inclusive
)
<EOS>
mildewed
clothes
,
which
had
evidently
not
belonged
to
him
originally
,
and
which
,
I
took
it
into
my
head
<EOS>
,
he
had
bought
cheap
of
the
executioner
.
<EOS>
Under
these
circumstances
I
thought
myself
well
rid
of
him
for
a

.
  
<EOS>
I
dropped
into
the
office
to
ask
if
Mr
Jaggers
had
come
in
yet
,
and
I
found
he
had
not
,
and
I
strolled

again
.
<EOS>
This
time
,
I
made
the
tour
of
Little
Britain
,
and
turned
into
Bartholomew
Close
;
and
now
I
became
aware
that
other
people
were
waiting
about
for
Mr
Jaggers
,
as
well

I.
<EOS>
There
were
two
men
of
secret
appearance
lounging
in
Bartholomew
Close
,
and
thoughtfully
fitting
their
feet
into
the
cracks
of
the

as
they
talked
together
,
one
of

said

other
when

first

,
that
"
Jaggers
would
do
it
if
it
was
to
be
done
.
<EOS>
"
There
was
a
knot
of
three
men
and
two
women
standing
at
a
corner
,
and
one
of

women
was
crying
on

dirty

,
and
the
other

by

as

,
"
Jaggers
is
for
him
,
'
Melia
,
and
what
more
 
\
could
\
 
you
have
?
"
There

red

Jew
who
came
into
the
Close
while
I
was

,
in

a

Jew
whom

upon

;
and

,
I
remarked
this
Jew
,
who
was
of
a

,

a

anxiety
under

,

,
in

,
with

,
"
Oh
Jaggerth
,
Jaggerth
,
Jaggerth
!
<EOS>
all
otherth
ith
Cag
-
Maggerth
,
give
me
Jaggerth
!
"
<EOS>
These
testimonies
to
the
popularity
of
my
guardian
made
a
deep
impression
on
me
,
and
I
admired
and
wondered
more
than
ever
.
  
<EOS>
At
length
,
as
I
was

iron

Bartholomew
Close
into
Little
Britain
,

coming

.
<EOS>
All

others
who
were

,

at

,
and
there
was
quite

.
<EOS>
Mr
Jaggers
,
putting
a

and

,
addressed

.
  
<EOS>
First
,

took

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
I
have
nothing
to

,
"

Mr

,

.
<EOS>
"
I
want
to
know
no
more
than
I
know
.
<EOS>
As

,
it
's

.
<EOS>
I
told

was

-

.
<EOS>
Have
you
paid
Wemmick
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
made

this

,

,
"

,
submissively
,

's

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do

,

,

.
<EOS>
Has
Wemmick

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Very

;

.
<EOS>
Now
,
I
wo
n't
have
it
!
"
<EOS>
said
Mr

,

at

to

behind

.
<EOS>
"
If
you
say

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
thought
,
Mr
Jaggers
---
<EOS>
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
That

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
\
<EOS>
You
\
 
thought
!
<EOS>
I
think

;
that

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Now

wo

.
<EOS>
I
wo

.
"

The

.
  
<EOS>
"
And
now
 
\
you
!
"
<EOS>
\
 
<EOS>

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
---
"
Oh
!
Amelia
,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Mr

.
<EOS>
"

"

,

that
but

you

could

?

<EOS>

Oh

,

!
"

.
"
<EOS>
Lord

,

,
<EOS>
well

!
"

Then

,
"

,

?

"
  
<EOS>
"
My
Bill
,

!
"
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,

!
"

.
<EOS>
"
Once

.
<EOS>
If

do

's

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Have

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

Oh

!
<EOS>
Every

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ma

.
 
<EOS>
Hown

?

"

Who

<EOS>
Habraham

.

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Holy

,

"
do

're
again

!
"

,
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
Get

<EOS>
"
Mithter

!
<EOS>
Half

!
<EOS>
My
hown
<EOS>
cuthen'th

Mithter

,

.
<EOS>
Mithter

!
<EOS>
Half

If

<EOS>
---
money

no

<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Mithter

Mithter

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
Without

,

,

.

Here

,
"

!
"

<EOS>
"
Well

,

,

"
arter

deal
o
'
trouble
<EOS>
,

---
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,

,
"

,

;
"
in

,

.

<EOS>
Mr
Jaggers
suddenly

most

.
<EOS>
"
Now
,
I

,
"

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Spooney
!
"

.
"
<EOS>
Soft
Head
!
<EOS>
Need

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,

"

,

"

what

<EOS>
Mike

,

Ayther

,

company
and
never

all

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Now
,

.
<EOS>

?
"

Mike

,

"
We

---
"

<EOS>
"
What
?
<EOS>
You
WILL
,

?
"
  
<EOS>
(

!
"

)

<EOS>
"
He
is

'

.
<EOS>
A

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is

?
"

I

,
"

,
"
a

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Take

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
The

indicated
,
was

.
<EOS>
We

to

,
behind

,

go
by

,

-

,

.
<EOS>
This

was
not

any

,
and
had
a
black

in
the

stage

,
which
was

.
  
<EOS>
"
Tell

,
"

,

.
<EOS>

.

,

.

"
True
,
"

<EOS>

,
Handel
,

that

London
it

---
for

---

that

,

.
<EOS>
It

,

.
<EOS>
Also
,

hand
,
but
under
.
<EOS>
This
has

.
<EOS>
You

better
(
which

)
,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He

.

"

,
"

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>

her

nothing
.
<EOS>
Her

was
a

down

,

.
<EOS>
I

;

that

<EOS>
You

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

reckoning
up
and
striking
a
balance
.
"
<EOS>
Not
directly
profitable
.
<EOS>
That
is
.
<EOS>
it
does
n't
pay
me
anything
,
and
I
have
to
---
keep
myself
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
This
certainly
had
not
a
profitable
appearance
,
and
I
shook
my

as
if
I
would
imply
that
it
would

difficult
to
lay

much

from

.
  
<EOS>
"
But
the
thing

,
"
said

Pocket
,
"
that
you
look
about

.
 
<EOS>
\
<EOS>
That
's
\
 
<EOS>
the
grand

.
<EOS>
You
are
in
a

,
you

,
and
you

.
"
  
<EOS>
It

a

that
you
could

a

,
you

,
and
look
about

;
but
I
silently

.
  
<EOS>
"
Then

,
"

"

.
<EOS>
And

!
<EOS>

.
"
  
<EOS>
This

;

.
<EOS>
His

,

,

.
<EOS>
It

,

.
<EOS>
It

<EOS>
the

,

upon

.
  
<EOS>
Yet
,

,

that

.
<EOS>
It

ways
,
and

on

.
<EOS>
In

,
and
went
half

to

Theatre
;
and
next

,

in

;
and
I

shod

,

.
  
<EOS>
On
a
moderate

,
it
was
many

,
that

,
since
I
had
left
Joe

.
<EOS>
The

,

of
that

,
and

any

.
<EOS>
That

Yet

,

,

<EOS>

.

.

"

ai

.

.

,

"

"

Here
!
<EOS>

<EOS>
Mrs

<EOS>
This

,

<EOS>
Thus

,
that
the

of
the

consisted

.
  
<EOS>
Under

,
when

,

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
23
 
MR
POCKET
said
he
was
glad
to
see
me
,
and
he
hoped
I

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
For
,
I
really
am

,
"
he

,
with

son
's

,
"
an

.
"
<EOS>
He
was
a
young

man
,
in
spite
of
his
perplexities
and
his
very
grey
hair
,
and
his
manner
seemed
quite
natural
.
<EOS>
I
use
the
word
natural
,
in
the
sense
of
its
being
unaffected
;
there
was
something
comic
in
his

,
as
though
it
would
have
been
downright

but
for
his
own
perception
that
it
was
very
near
being

.
<EOS>
When
he
had

with

a

,
he
said

Mrs
Pocket
,
with
a

his

,
which
were
black

,
"
Belinda
,
I
hope
you
have
welcomed

Pip
?
"
<EOS>
And
she
looked
up
from
her
book
,
and
said
,
"
Yes
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
She
then
smiled
upon
me
in
an
absent
state
of
mind
,
and
asked
me
if
I
liked
the
taste
of
orange
-
flower

?
<EOS>
As

had
no
bearing
,
near

remote
,
on

,
I
consider
it
to
have

,
like
her
previous

,
in

.
  
<EOS>
I
found
out
within
a

hours
,
and
may
mention

once
,
that
Mrs
Pocket
was
the
only
daughter
of
a
certain

Knight
,
who
had
invented
for
himself
a
conviction
that
his
deceased
father
would
have
been
made
a
Baronet
but
for
somebody
's
determined

arising
out
of
entirely
personal
motives
<EOS>
---
I
forget
whose
,
if
I

---
the
Sovereign

,
the

's
,
the
Lord

,
the

Canterbury
's
,
<EOS>
anybody

---
and
had
tacked
himself
on
to

of
the
earth
in
right
of
this

.
<EOS>
I
believe
he
had
been
knighted
himself
for
storming
the
English
grammar
at
the
point
of
the
pen
,
in
a
desperate
address
engrossed
on
vellum
,
on
the

of
the

first

of
some

or
other
,
and
for

some
Royal
Personage
either

or

.
<EOS>
Be
that

may
,
he
had
directed
Mrs
Pocket
to

up
from
her

as
one
who
in
the
nature
of
things
must
marry
a
title
,
and
who
was
to

guarded
from
the
acquisition
of

.
  
<EOS>
So
successful
a
watch
and
ward
had
been
established
over
the
young
lady
by
this
judicious
parent
,
that
she
had
grown
up
highly
ornamental
,
but
perfectly
helpless
and
useless
.
<EOS>
With
her
character
thus
happily
formed
,
in
the
first
bloom
of
her
youth
she
had
encountered
Mr
Pocket
:
who
was
also
in
the
first
bloom
of
youth
,
and
not
quite
decided
whether
to
mount
to
the
Woolsack
,
or
to
roof
himself
in
with
a
mitre
.
<EOS>
As
his
doing
the
one
or
the
other
was
a
mere
question
of
time
,
he
and
Mrs
Pocket
had
taken
Time
by
the
forelock
(
when
,
to
judge
from
its
length
,
it
would
seem
to
have
wanted
cutting
)
,
and
had
married
without
the
knowledge
of
the
judicious
parent
.
<EOS>
The
judicious
parent
,
having
nothing
to
bestow
or
withhold
but
his
blessing
,
had
handsomely
settled
that
dower
upon
them
after
a
short
struggle
,
and
had
informed
Mr
pocket
that
his
wife
was
"
a
treasure
for
a
Prince
.
"
<EOS>
Mr
Pocket
had
invested
the
Prince
's
treasure
in
the
ways
of
the
world
ever
since
,
and
it
was
supposed
to
have
brought
him
in
but
indifferent
interest
.
<EOS>
Still
,
Mrs
Pocket
was
in
general
the
object
of
a
queer
sort
of
respectful
pity
,
because
she
had
not
married
a
title
;
while
Mr
Pocket
was
the
object
of
a
queer
sort
of
forgiving
reproach
,
because
he
had
never
got
one
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Pocket
took
me
into
the
house
and
showed
me
my
room
:
which
was
a
pleasant
one
,
and
so
furnished
as
that
I
could
use
it
with
comfort
for
my
own
private
sitting
-
room
.
<EOS>
He
then
knocked
at
the
doors
of
two
other
similar
rooms
,
and
introduced
me
to
their
occupants
,
by
name
Drummle
and
Startop
.
<EOS>
Drummle
,
an
old
-
looking
young
man
of
a
heavy
order
of
architecture
,
was
whistling
.
<EOS>
Startop
,
younger
in
years
and
appearance
,
was
reading
and
holding
his
head
,
as
if
he
thought
himself
in
danger
of
exploding
it
with
too
strong
a
charge
of
knowledge
.
  
<EOS>
Both
Mr
and
Mrs
Pocket
had
such
a
noticeable
air
of
being
in
somebody
else
's
hands
,
that
I
wondered
who
really
was
in
possession
of
the
house
and
let
them
live
there
,
until
I
found
this
unknown
power
to
be
the
servants
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
smooth
way
of
going
on
,
perhaps
,
in
respect
of
saving
trouble
;
but
it
had
the
appearance
of
being
expensive
,
for
the
servants
felt
it
<EOS>
a
duty
they
owed
to
themselves
to
be
nice
in
their
eating
and
drinking
,
and
to
keep
a
deal
of
company
down
stairs
.
<EOS>
They
allowed
a
very
liberal
table
to
Mr
and
Mrs
Pocket
yet
it
always
appeared
to
me
that
by
far
the
best
part
of
the
house
to
have
boarded
in
,
would
have
been
the
kitchen
---
always
supposing
the
boarder
capable
of
self
-
defence
,
for
,
before
I
had
been
there
a
week
,
a
neighbouring
lady
with
whom
the
family
were
personally
unacquainted
,
wrote
in
to
say
that
she
had
seen
Millers
slapping
the
baby
.
<EOS>
This
greatly
distressed
Mrs
Pocket
,
who
burst
into
tears
on
receiving
the
note
,
and
said
that
it
was
an
extraordinary
thing
that
the
neighbours
could
n't
mind
their
own
business
.
  
<EOS>
By
degrees
I
learnt
,
and
chiefly
from
Herbert
,
that
Mr
Pocket
had
been
educated
at
Harrow
and
at
Cambridge
,
where
he
had
distinguished
himself
;
but
that
when
he
had
had
the
happiness
of
marrying
Mrs
Pocket
very
early
in
life
,
he
had
impaired
his
prospects
and
taken
up
the
calling
of
a
Grinder
.
<EOS>
After
grinding
a
number
of
dull
blades
---
of
whom
it
was
remarkable
that
their
fathers
,
when
influential
,
were
always
going
to
help
him
to
preferment
,
but
always
forgot
to
do
it
when
the
blades
had
left
the
Grindstone
---
he
had
wearied
of
that
poor
work
and
had
come
to
London
.
<EOS>
Here
,
after
gradually
failing
in
loftier
hopes
,
he
had
"
read
"
with
divers
who
had
lacked
opportunities
or
neglected
them
,
and
had
refurbished
divers
others
for
special
occasions
,
and
had
turned
his
acquirements
to
the
account
of
literary
compilation
and
correction
,
and
on
such
means
,
added
to
some
very
moderate
private
resources
,
still
maintained
the
house
I
saw
.
  
<EOS>
Mr
and
Mrs
Pocket
had
a
toady
neighbour
;
a
widow
lady
of
that
highly
sympathetic
nature
that
she
agreed
with
everybody
,
blessed
everybody
,
and
shed

and
tears
on
everybody
,
according
to
circumstances
.
<EOS>
This
lady
's
name
was
Mrs
Coiler
,
and
I
had
the
honour
of
taking
her
down
to
dinner
on
the

of
my
installation
.
<EOS>
She
gave
me
to
understand
on
the
stairs
,
that
it
was
a
blow
to
dear
Mrs
Pocket
that
dear
Mr
Pocket
should
be
under
the
necessity
of
receiving
gentlemen
to
read
with

.
<EOS>
That
did
not
extend
to
me
,
she
told

in
a

of
love
and
confidence
(
at
that
time
,
I
had
known
her
something
less

)
;
if
they
were
all
like
Me
,
it
would
be
quite
another

.
  
<EOS>
"
But
dear
Mrs
Pocket
,
"
said
Mrs
Coiler
,
"
after
her
early

(
not
that
dear
Mr
Pocket
was
to
blame
in
that
)
,
requires
so
much

---
"
  
"
Yes
,
ma'am
,
"
I
said
,
to
stop
her
,
for

was

going

.
  
<EOS>
"
And
she
is
of
so

---
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
ma'am
,
<EOS>
"
I
said
again
,
with
the
same

as

.
  
<EOS>
"
---
that
it
is
hard
,
"
said
Mrs
Coiler
,
"
to
have
dear
Mr
Pocket
's
time
and
attention
diverted
from
dear
Mrs
Pocket
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
could
not
help
thinking
that
it
might
be
harder
if
the
butcher
's
time
and
attention
were
diverted
from
dear
Mrs
Pocket
;
but
I
said
nothing
,
and
indeed
had
enough
to
do
in
keeping
a
bashful

upon
my
company
-
manners
.
  
<EOS>
It
came
to
my
knowledge
,
through
what
passed
between
Mrs
Pocket
and
Drummle
while
I
was
attentive
to
my
knife
and
fork
,
spoon
,
glasses
,
and
other
instruments
of
self
-

,
that
Drummle
,
whose
christian
name
was
Bentley
,
was
actually
the
next
heir
but
one
to
a
baronetcy
.
<EOS>
It
further
appeared
that
the
book
I
had
seen
Mrs
Pocket
reading
in
the
garden
,
was
all
about
titles
,
and
that
she
knew
the
exact
date
at
which
her
grandpapa
would
have
come
into
the
book
,
if
he
ever
had
come

.
<EOS>
Drummle
did
n't
say
much
,
but
in
his
limited
way
(
he
struck
me
as
a
sulky
kind
of
fellow
)
<EOS>
he
spoke
as
one
of
the
elect
,
and
recognized
Mrs
Pocket
as
a
woman
and
a

.
<EOS>
No
one
but
themselves
and
Mrs
Coiler
<EOS>
the
toady
neighbour
showed
any
interest
in
this
part
of
the
conversation
,
and
it
appeared
to
me
that
it
was
painful
to
Herbert
;
but
it
promised
to
last
a
long
time
,
when
the
page
came
in
with
the

of
a

.
<EOS>
It
was
,
in
effect
,
that
the
cook
had
mislaid
the
beef
.
<EOS>
To
my
unutterable
amazement
,
I
now
,
for
the
first
time
,
saw
Mr
Pocket
relieve
his
mind
by
going
through
a
performance
that
struck
me
as
very
extraordinary
,
but
which
made
no
impression
on
anybody
else
,
and
with
which
I
soon
became
as

as
the
rest
.
<EOS>
He
laid
down
the
carving
-
knife
and
fork
---
being
engaged
in
carving
,
at
the
moment
---
put
his
two
hands
into
his
disturbed
hair
,
and
appeared
to
make
an
extraordinary
effort
to
lift

up
by
it
.
<EOS>
When
he
had
done
this
,
and
had
not

himself
up
at
all
,
he
quietly
went
on
with
what
he
was
about
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Coiler
then
changed
the
subject
,
and
began
to
flatter
me
.
<EOS>
I
liked
it
for
a
few
moments
,
but
she
flattered
me
so
very
grossly
that
the
pleasure
was
soon
over
.
<EOS>
She
had
a
serpentine
way
of
coming
close
at
me
when
she
pretended
to
be
vitally
interested
in
the
friends
and

I
had
left
,
which
was
altogether
snaky
and
fork
-

;
and
when
she
made
an
occasional

upon
Startop
(
who
said
very
little
to

)
,
or

Drummle
(
who
said
less
)
,
I
rather
envied
them
for
being
on
the

side
of

.
  
<EOS>
After
dinner
the
children
were
introduced
,
and
Mrs
Coiler
made
admiring
comments
on
their
eyes
,
noses
,
and
legs
---
a
sagacious
way
of
improving
their
minds
.
<EOS>
There
were
four
little
girls
,
and
two
little
boys
,
besides
the
baby
who
might
have
been
either
,
and
the
baby
's
next
successor
who
was
as
yet
neither
.
<EOS>
They
were
brought
in
by
Flopson
and
Millers
,
much
as

those
two
non
-
commissioned
officers
had
been
recruiting
somewhere
for
children
and
had
enlisted
these
:
while
Mrs
Pocket
looked
at
the
young
Nobles
that
ought
to
have
been
,
as

rather

had
had
the

,
but

.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
!
<EOS>
Give
me

,
Mum
,
and

,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
take
it
that

,
or
you
'll
get
its
head
under

table
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Thus
advised
,
Mrs
Pocket
took
it
the
other
way
,
and
got
its
head
upon
the
table
;
which
was
announced
to
all
present
by
a
prodigious
concussion
.
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
,
dear
!
<EOS>
Give
it
me
back
,
Mum
,
"
said
Flopson
;
"
and
Miss
Jane
,
come
and
dance
to
baby
,
do
!
"
  
<EOS>
One
of
the
little
girls
,
a
mere
mite
who
seemed
to
have
prematurely
taken
upon
herself
some
charge
of
the
others
,
stepped
out
of
her
place
by
me
,
and
danced
to
and
from
the
baby
until
it
left
off
crying
,
and
laughed
.
<EOS>
Then
,
all
the
children
laughed
,
and
Mr
Pocket
(
who
in
the
meantime
had
twice
endeavoured
to
lift
himself
up
by
the
hair
)
laughed
,
and
we
all
laughed
and
were
glad
.
  
<EOS>
Flopson
,
by
dint
of
doubling
the
baby
at
the
joints
like
a
Dutch
doll
,
then
got
it
safely
into
Mrs
Pocket
's
lap
,
and
gave
it
the
nutcrackers
to
play

:
at
the

Mrs
Pocket
to
take

that

of
that

were
not
likely
to
agree
with
its
eyes
,
and
sharply
charging
Miss
Jane
to
look

.
<EOS>
Then
,
the
two
nurses
left
the
room
,
and
had
a
lively
scuffle
on
the
staircase
with
a
dissipated
page
who
had
waited
at
dinner
,
and
who
had
clearly
lost
half
his
buttons
at

.
  
<EOS>
I
was
made
very
uneasy
in
my

by
Mrs
Pocket
's

into
a
discussion
with
Drummle
respecting
two
baronetcies
,
while
she
ate
a
sliced
orange
steeped
in
sugar
and
wine
,
and
forgetting
all
about
the
baby
on
her
lap
:
who
did
most
appalling
things
with

.
<EOS>
At
length
,
little
Jane
perceiving
its
young
brains
to

,
softly
left
her
place
,
and
with
many

dangerous
weapon
away
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Pocket
finishing
her

at
about

,
and
not

this
,
said

Jane
:
  
<EOS>
"
You

child
,
how

?
<EOS>
Go
and

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mamma
dear
,
"
lisped

girl
,
"
baby
ood
have
put
hith

out
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
dare
you
tell
me

?
"
retorted

Pocket
.
<EOS>
"
Go
and
sit
down
in

chair

!
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Pocket
's

was
so

,
that
I
felt
quite
abashed
:
as

I
myself

.
  
<EOS>
"
Belinda
,
"

,

,
"

?
<EOS>
Jane
only

baby
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will

to

,
"
said

Pocket
.
<EOS>
"
I
am

,
Matthew
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Good

!
"

Pocket
,
in

.
"
<EOS>
Are
infants
to
be
nutcrackered
into
their

,
and

to

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
not

by
Jane
,
"
said

Pocket
,
with

that

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
I
hope
I
know

poor

's
position
.
<EOS>
Jane
,
indeed
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Pocket
got
his
hands
in
his

,
and
this

really

some

.
<EOS>
"
Hear
this
!
"
<EOS>
he

.
<EOS>
"
Babies
are
to
be

dead
,
for
people
's
poor
grandpapa
's
positions
!
"
Then

let

,

.
  
<EOS>
We
all
looked
awkwardly
at
the
table
-
cloth
while
this
was
going
on
.
<EOS>
A
pause
succeeded
,
during
which
the
honest
and
irrepressible
baby
made

series
of
leaps
and

at

Jane
,
who
appeared
to
me
to
be
the
only
member
of
the
family
(
irrespective
of
servants
)
with
whom
it
had
any
decided
acquaintance
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr
Drummle
,
"
said
Mrs
Pocket
,
"
will
you
ring
for
Flopson
?
<EOS>
Jane
,
you
undutiful
little
thing
,
go
and
lie
down
.
<EOS>
Now
,
baby
darling
,
come
with
ma
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
baby
was
the
soul
of
honour
,
and
protested
with
all
its
might
.
<EOS>
It
doubled
itself
up
the
wrong
way
over
Mrs
Pocket
's
arm
,
exhibited
a
pair
of
knitted
shoes
and
dimpled
ankles
to
the
company
in
lieu
of
its
soft
face
,
and
was
carried
out
in
the
highest
state
of
mutiny
.
<EOS>
And
it
gained
its
point
after
all
,
for
I
saw
it
through
the
window
within
a
few
minutes
,
being
nursed
by
little
Jane
.
  
<EOS>
It
happened
that
the
other
five
children
were
left
behind
at
the
dinner
-
table
,
through
Flopson
's
having
some
private
engagement
,
and
their
not
being
anybody
else
's
business
.
<EOS>
I
thus
became
aware
of
the
mutual
relations
between
them
and
Mr
Pocket
,
which
were
exemplified
in
the
following
manner
.
<EOS>
Mr
Pocket
,
with
the
normal
perplexity
of
his
face
heightened
and
his
hair
rumpled
,
looked
at
them
for
some
minutes
,
as
if
he
could
n't
make
out
how
they
came
to
be
boarding
and
lodging
in
that
establishment
,
and
why
they
had
n't
been
billeted
by
Nature
on
somebody
else
.
<EOS>
Then
,
in
a
distant
,
Missionary
way
he
asked
them
certain
questions
---
<EOS>
as
why
little
Joe
had
that
hole
in
his
frill
:
who
said
,
Pa
,
Flopson
was
going
to
mend
it
when
she
had
time
---
and
how
little
Fanny
came
by
that
whitlow
:
<EOS>
who
said
,
Pa
,
Millers
was
going
to
poultice
it
when
she
did
n't
forget
.
<EOS>
Then
,
he
melted
into
parental
tenderness
,
and
gave
them
a
shilling
apiece
and
told
them
to
go
and
play
;
and
then
as
they
went
out
,
with
one
very
strong
effort
to
lift
himself
up
by
the
hair
he
dismissed
the
hopeless
subject
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
evening
there
was
rowing
on
the
river
.
<EOS>
As
Drummle
and
Startop
had
each
a
boat
,
I
resolved
to
set
up
mine
,
and
to
cut
them
both
out
.
<EOS>
I
was
pretty
good
at
most
exercises
in
which
country
-
boys
are
adepts
,
but
,
as
I
was
conscious
of
wanting
elegance
of
style
for
the
Thames
---
not
to
say
for
other
waters
---
I
at
once
engaged
to
place
myself
under
the
tuition
of
the
winner
of
a
prize
-
wherry
who
plied
at
our
stairs
,
and
to
whom
I
was
introduced
by
my
new
allies
.
<EOS>
This
practical
authority
confused
me
very
much
,
by
saying
I
had
the
arm
of
a
blacksmith
.
<EOS>
If
he
could
have
known
how
nearly
the
compliment
lost
him
his
pupil
,
I
doubt
if
he
would
have
paid
it
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
supper
-
tray
after
we
got
home
at
night
,
and
I
think
we
should
all
have
enjoyed
ourselves
,
but
for
a
rather
disagreeable
domestic
occurrence
.
<EOS>
Mr
Pocket
was
in
good
spirits
,
when
a
housemaid
came
in
,
and
said
,
"
If
you
please
,
sir
,
I
should
wish
to
speak
to
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Speak
to
your
master
?
"
said
Mrs
Pocket
,
whose
dignity
was
refused
again
.
<EOS>
"
How
can
you
think
of
such
a
thing
?
<EOS>
Go
and
speak
to
Flopson
.
<EOS>
Or
speak
to
me
---
at
some
other
time
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Begging
your
pardon
,
ma'am
,
"
returned
the
housemaid
,
"
I
should
wish
to
speak
at
once
,
and
to
speak
to
master
.
"
  
<EOS>
Hereupon
,
Mr
Pocket
went
out
of
the
room
,
and
we
made
the
best
of
ourselves
until
he
came
back
.
  
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
pretty
thing
,
Belinda
!
"
said
Mr
Pocket
,
returning
with
a
countenance
expressive
of
grief
and

.
<EOS>
"
Here
's
the
cook
lying
insensibly
drunk
on
the
kitchen
floor
,
with
a
large
bundle
of
fresh
butter
made
up
in
the
cupboard
ready
to
sell
for
grease
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs
Pocket
instantly
showed
much
amiable
emotion
,
and
said
,
"
This
is
that
odious
Sophia
's
doing
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
,
Belinda
?
"
demanded
Mr
Pocket
.
  
<EOS>
"
Sophia
has
told
you
,
"
said
Mrs
Pocket
.
<EOS>
"
Did
I
not
see
her
with
my
own
eyes
and
hear
her
with
my
own
ears
,
come
into
the
room
just
now
and
ask
to
speak
to
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
has
she
not
taken
me
down
stairs
,
Belinda
,
"
returned
Mr
Pocket
,
"
and
shown
me
the
woman
,
and
the
bundle
too
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
do
you
defend
her
,
Matthew
,
"
said
Mrs
Pocket
,
"
for
making
mischief
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Pocket
uttered
a
dismal
groan
.
  
<EOS>
"
Am
I
,
grandpapa
's
granddaughter
,
to
be
nothing
in
the
house
?
"
said
Mrs
Pocket
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Besides
,
the
cook
has
always
been
a
very
nice
respectful
woman
,
and
said
in
the
most
natural
manner
when
she
came
to
look
after
the
situation
,
that
she
felt
I
was
born
to
be
a
Duchess
.
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
sofa
where
Mr
Pocket
stood
,
and
he
dropped
upon
it
in
the
attitude
of
the
Dying
Gladiator
.
<EOS>
Still
in
that
attitude
he
said
,
with
a
hollow
voice
,
"
Good
night
,
Mr
Pip
,
"
when
I
deemed
it
advisable
to
go
to
bed
and
leave
him
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
24
 
<EOS>
AFTER
two
or
three
days
,
when
I
had
established
myself
in
my
room
and
had
gone
backwards
and
forwards
to
London
several
times
,
and
had
ordered
all
I
wanted
of
my
tradesmen
,
Mr
Pocket
<EOS>
and
I
had
a
long
talk
together
.
<EOS>
He
knew
more
of
my
intended
career
than
I
knew
myself
,
for
he
referred
to
his
having
been
told
by
Mr
Jaggers
that
I
was
not
designed
for
any
profession
,
and
that
I
should
be
well
enough
educated
for
my
destiny
if
I
could
"
hold
my
own
"
with
the
average
of
young
men
in
prosperous
circumstances
.
<EOS>
I
acquiesced
,
of
course
,
knowing
nothing
to
the
contrary
.
  
<EOS>
He
advised
my
attending
certain
places
in
London
,
for
the
acquisition
of
such
mere
rudiments
as
I
wanted
,
and
my
investing
him
with
the
functions
of
explainer
and
director
of
all
my
studies
.
<EOS>
He
hoped
that
with
intelligent
assistance
I
should
meet
with
little
to
discourage
me
,
and
should
soon
be
able
to
dispense
with
any
aid
but
his
.
<EOS>
Through
his
way
of
saying
this
,
and
much
more
to
similar
purpose
,
he
placed
himself
on
confidential
terms
with
me
in
an
admirable
manner
;
and
I
may
state
at
once
that
he
was
always
so
zealous
and
honourable
in
fulfilling
his
compact
with
me
,
that
he
made
me
zealous
and
honourable
in
fulfilling
mine
with
him
.
<EOS>
lf
he
had
shown
indifference
as
a
master
,
I
have
no
doubt
I
should
have
returned
the
compliment
as
a
pupil
;
he
gave
me
no
such
excuse
,
and
each
of
us
did
the
other
justice
.
<EOS>
Nor
,
did
I
ever
regard
him
as
having
anything
ludicrous
about
him
---
or
anything
<EOS>
but
what
was
serious
,
honest
,
and
good
---
in
his
tutor
communication
with
me
.
  
<EOS>
When
these
points
were
settled
,
and
so
far
carried
out
as
that
I
had
begun
to
work
in
earnest
,
it
occurred
to
me
that
if
I
could
retain
my
bedroom
in
Barnard
's
Inn
,
my
life
would
be
agreeably
varied
,
while
my
manners
would
be
none
the
worse
for
Herbert
's
society
.
<EOS>
Mr
Pocket
did
not
object
to
this
arrangement
,
but
urged
that
before
any
step
could
possibly
be
taken
in
it
,
it
must
be
submitted
to
my
guardian
.
<EOS>
I
felt
that
his
delicacy
arose
out
of
the
consideration
that
the
plan
would
save
Herbert
some
expense
,
so
I
went
off
to
Little
Britain
and
imparted
my
wish
to
Mr
Jaggers
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
could
buy
the
furniture
now
hired
for
me
,
"
said
I
,
"
and
one
or
two
other
little
things
<EOS>
,
I
should
be
quite
at
home
there
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Go
it
!
"
said
Mr
Jaggers
,
with
a
short
laugh
.
<EOS>
"
I
told
you
you
'd
get
on
.
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
How
much
do
you
want
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
said
I
did
n't
know
how
much
.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
!
"
<EOS>
retorted
Mr
Jaggers
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
How
much
?
<EOS>
Fifty
pounds
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
not
nearly
so
much
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Five
pounds
?
"
said
Mr
Jaggers
.
  
<EOS>
This
was
such
a
great
fall
,
that
I
said
in
discomfiture
,
"
Oh
!
more
than
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
More
than
that
,
eh
!
"
retorted
Mr
Jaggers
,
lying
in
wait
for
me
,
with
his
hands
in
his
pockets
,
his
head
on
one
side
,
and
his
eyes
on
the
wall
behind
me
;
"
how
much
more
?
"
  
"
It
is
so
difficult
to
fix
a
sum
,
"
said
I
,
hesitating
.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
!
"
said
Mr
Jaggers
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Let
's
get
at
it
.
<EOS>
Twice
five
;
will
that
do
?
<EOS>
Three
times
five
;
will
that
do
?
<EOS>
Four
times
five
;
will
that
do
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
said
I
thought
that
would
do
handsomely
.
  
<EOS>
"
Four
times
five
will
do
handsomely
,
will
it
?
"
said
Mr
Jaggers
,
knitting
his
brows
.
<EOS>
"
Now
,
what
do
you
make
of
four
times
five
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
I
make
of
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
said
Mr
Jaggers
;
"
<EOS>
how
much
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
you
make
it
twenty
pounds
,
"
said
I
,
smiling
.
  
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
what
I
make
it
,
my
friend
,
"
observed
Mr
Jaggers
,
with
a
knowing
and
contradictory
toss
of
his
head
.
<EOS>
"
I
want
to
know
what
you
make
it
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
Twenty
pounds
,
of
course
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Wemmick
!
"
said
Mr
Jaggers
,
opening
his
office
door
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Take
Mr
Pip
's
written
order
,
and
pay
him
twenty
pounds
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
This
strongly
marked
way
of
doing
business
made
a
strongly
marked
impression
on
me
,
and
that
not
of
an
agreeable
kind
.
<EOS>
Mr
Jaggers
never
laughed
;
but
he
wore
great
bright
creaking
boots
,
and
,
in
poising
himself
on
these
boots
,
with
his
large
head
bent
down
and
his
eyebrows
joined
together
,
awaiting
an
answer
,
he
sometimes
caused
the
boots
to
creak
,
as
if
 
\
<EOS>
they
\
 
<EOS>
laughed
in
a
dry
and
suspicious
way
.
<EOS>
As
he
happened
to
go
out
now
,
and
as
Wemmick
was
brisk
and
talkative
,
I
said
to
Wemmick
that
I
hardly
knew
what
to
make
of
Mr
Jaggers
's
manner
.
  
<EOS>
"
Tell
him
that
,
and
he
'll
take
it
as
a
compliment
,
"
answered
Wemmick
;
"
he
do
n't
mean
that
you
 
\
<EOS>
should
\
 
<EOS>
know
what
to
make
of
it
.
<EOS>
---
Oh
!
"
<EOS>
for
I
looked
surprised
,
"
it
's
not
personal
;
it
's
professional
:
only
professional
.
"
  
<EOS>
Wemmick
was
at
his
desk
,
lunching
---
and
crunching
---
on
a
dry
hard
biscuit
;
pieces
of
which
he
threw
from
time
to
time
into
his
slit
of
a
mouth
,
as
if
he
were
posting
them
.
  
<EOS>
"
Always
seems
to
me
,
"
said
Wemmick
,
"
as
if
he
had
set
a
man
-
trap
and
was
watching
it
.
<EOS>
Suddenly
---
click
---
you
're
caught
!
"
  
<EOS>
Without
remarking
that
man
-
traps
were
not
among
the
amenities
of
life
,
I
said
I
supposed
he
was
very
skilful
?
  
<EOS>
"
Deep
,
"
said
Wemmick
,
"
as
Australia
.
<EOS>
"
Pointing
with
his
pen
at
the
office
floor
,
to
express
that
Australia
was
understood
,
for
the
purposes
of
the
figure
,
to
be
symmetrically
on
the
opposite
spot
of
the
globe
.
<EOS>
"
If
there
was
anything
deeper
,
"
added
Wemmick
,
bringing
his
pen
to
paper
,
"
he
'd
be
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
Then
,
I
said
I
supposed
he
had
a
fine
business
,
and
Wemmick
said
,
"
Ca
-
pi
-
tal
!
"
<EOS>
Then
I
asked
if
there
were
many
clerks
?
<EOS>
to
which
he
replied
:
  
"
We
do
n't
run
much
into
clerks
,
because
there
's
only
one
Jaggers
,
and
people
wo
n't
have
him
at
second
-
hand
.
<EOS>
There
are
only
four
of
us
.
<EOS>
Would
you
like
to
see
'em
?
<EOS>
You
are
one
of
us
,
as
I
may
say
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
accepted
the
offer
.
<EOS>
When
Mr
Wemmick
had
put
all
the
biscuit
into
the
post
,
and
had
paid
me
my
money
from
a
cash
-
box
in
a
safe
,
the
key
of
which
safe
he
kept
somewhere
down
his
back
and
produced
from
his
coat
-
collar
like
an
iron
pigtail
,
we
went
up
-
stairs
.
<EOS>
The
house
was
dark
and
shabby
,
and
the
greasy
shoulders
that
had
left
their
mark
in
Mr
Jaggers
's
room
,
seemed
to
have
been
shuffling
up

down

for

.
<EOS>
In
the
front

,
a

who

something

and

---
a
large

---
was
attentively

with
three
or

people
of

,

treated
as

as
everybody
seemed
to
be
treated
who

Mr
Jaggers
's

.
"
<EOS>
Getting
evidence
together
,
"

Mr

,
as

,
"
for
the

.
<EOS>
"

room

,
a

(
his

seemed

)

a

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
This

.

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
Famous

<EOS>
This

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
We

,

,

<EOS>
If

.
<EOS>
"

"
<EOS>

"
Now

!
"
<EOS>
The

shivered

.
<EOS>
Thieves

,

.
<EOS>
Which

,

,
<EOS>
for

;

;

,

,

in

that

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
25
 
BENTLEY
DRUMMLE
,
who
was
so
sulky
a
fellow
that
he
even
took
up
a
book
<EOS>
as
if
its
writer
had
done
him
an
injury
,
did
not
take
up
an
acquaintance
in
a
more
agreeable
spirit
.
<EOS>
Heavy
in
figure
,
movement
,
and
comprehension
---
in
the
sluggish
complexion
of
his
face
,
and
in
the
large
awkward
tongue
that
seemed
to
loll
about
in
his
mouth
as
he
himself
lolled
about
in
a
room
<EOS>
---
he
was
idle
,
proud
,
niggardly
,
reserved
,
and
suspicious
.
<EOS>
He
came
of
rich
people
down
in
Somersetshire
,
who
had
nursed
this
combination
of
qualities
until
they
made
the
discovery
that
it
was
just
of
age
and
a
blockhead
.
<EOS>
Thus
,
Bentley
Drummle
had
come
to
Mr
Pocket
when
he
was
a
head
taller
than
that
gentleman
,
and
half
a
dozen
heads
thicker
than
most
gentlemen
.
  
<EOS>
Startop
had
been
spoilt
by
a
weak
mother
and
kept
at
home
when
he
ought
to
have
been
at
school
,
but
he
was
devotedly
attached
to
her
,
and
admired
her
beyond
measure
.
<EOS>
He
had
a
woman
's
delicacy
of
feature
,
and
was
---
"
as
you
may
see
,
though
you
never
saw
her
,
"
said
Herbert
to
me
---
exactly
like
his
mother
.
<EOS>
It
was
but
natural
that
I
should
take
to
him
much
more
kindly
than
to
Drummle
,
and
that
,
even
in
the
earliest
evenings
of
our
boating
,
he
and
I
should
pull
homeward
abreast
of
one
another
,
conversing
from
boat
to
boat
,
while
Bentley
Drummle
came
up
in
our
wake
alone
,
under
the
overhanging
banks
and
among
the
rushes
.
<EOS>
He
would
always
creep
in
-
shore
like
some
uncomfortable
amphibious
creature
,
even
when
the
tide
would
have
sent
him
fast
upon
his
way
;
and
I
always
think
of
him
as
coming
after
us
in
the
dark
or
by
the
back
-
water
,
when
our
own
two
boats
were
breaking
the
sunset
or
the
moonlight
in
mid
-
stream
.
  
<EOS>
Herbert
was
my
intimate
companion
and
friend
.
<EOS>
I
presented
him
with
a
half
-
share
in
my
boat
,
which
was
the
occasion
of
his
often
coming
down
to
Hammersmith
;
and
my
possession
of
a
half
-
share
in
his
chambers
often
took
me
up
to
London
.
<EOS>
We
used
to
walk
between
the
two
places
at
all
hours
.
<EOS>
I
hive
an
affection
for
the
road
yet
(
though
it
is
not
so
pleasant
a
road
as
it
was
then
)
,
formed
in
the
impressibility
of
untried
youth
and
hope
.
  
<EOS>
When
I
had
been
in
Mr
Pocket
's
family
a
month
or
two
,
Mr
and
Mrs
Camilla
turned
up
.
<EOS>
Camilla
was
Mr
Pocket
's
sister
.
<EOS>
Georgiana
,
whom
I
had
seen
at
Miss
Havisham
's
on
the
same
occasion
,
also
turned
up
.
<EOS>
She
was
a
cousin
---
an
indigestive
single
woman
,
who
called
her
rigidity
religion
,
and
her
liver
love
.
<EOS>
These
people
hated
me
with
the
hatred
of
cupidity
and
disappointment
.
<EOS>
As
a
matter
of
course
,
they
fawned
upon
me
in
my
prosperity
with
the
basest
meanness
.
<EOS>
Towards
Mr
Pocket
,
as
a
grown
-
up
infant
with
no
notion
of
his
own
interests
,
they
showed
the
complacent
forbearance
I
had
heard
them
express
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Pocket
they
held
in
contempt
;
but
they
allowed
the
poor
soul
to
have
been
heavily
disappointed
in
life
,
because
that
shed
a
feeble
reflected
light
upon
themselves
.
  
<EOS>
These
were
the
surroundings
among
which
I
settled
down
,
and
applied
myself
to
my
education
.
<EOS>
I
soon
contracted
expensive
habits
,
and
began
to
spend
an
amount
of
money
that
within
a
few
short
months
I
should
have
thought
almost
fabulous
;
but
through
good
and
evil
I
stuck
to
my
books
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
other
merit
in
this
,
than
my
having
sense
enough
to
feel
my
deficiencies
.
<EOS>
Between
Mr
Pocket
and
Herbert
<EOS>
I
got
on
fast
;
and
,
with
one

always

I

,
and
clear

road
<EOS>
,

.
  
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
He

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

"
Pick

.
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Wemmick

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
My
own
doing
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Looks

;

?
"
  
<EOS>
I

commended

.
<EOS>
I

the

;

queerest

(

)
,

.

"

"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

---
so
---

.
"
  
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
There

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

<EOS>

,

.

<EOS>
"

"
  
"
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>

,

"
  
<EOS>
"

,

?
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Never

,
"

<EOS>
"
Never

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Never

.
<EOS>
No
;

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.

<EOS>
Of
course
I
felt
my
good
faith
involved
in
the
observance
of
his
request
.
<EOS>
The
punch
being
very
nice
,
we
sat
there
drinking
it
and
talking
,
until
it
was
almost
nine
o'clock
.
"
<EOS>
Getting
near
gun
-
fire
,
"
said
Wemmick
then
,
as
he
laid
down
his
pipe
;
"
it
's
the
Aged
's
treat
.
"
  
<EOS>
Proceeding
into
the
Castle
again
,
we
found
the
Aged
heating
the
poker
,
with
expectant
eyes
,
as
a
preliminary
to
the
performance
of
this
great
nightly
ceremony
.
<EOS>
Wemmick
stood
with
his
watch
in
his
hand
,
until
the
moment
was
come
for
him
to
take
the
red
-
hot
poker
from
the
Aged
,
and
repair
to
the
battery
.
<EOS>
He
took
it
,
and
went
out
,
and
presently
the
Stinger
went
off
with
a
Bang
that
shook
the
crazy
little
box
of
a
cottage
as
if
it
must
fall
to
pieces
,
and
made
every
glass
and
teacup
in
it
ring
.
<EOS>
Upon
this
,
the
Aged
---
who
I
believe
would
have
been
blown
out
of
his
arm
-
chair
but
for
holding
on
by
the
elbows
---
cried
out
exultingly
,
"
He
's
fired
!
<EOS>
I
heerd
him
!
"
<EOS>
and
I
nodded
at
the
old
gentleman
until
it
is
no
figure
of
speech
to
declare
that
I
absolutely
could
not
see
him
.
  
<EOS>
The
interval
between
that
time
and
supper
,
Wemmick
devoted
to
showing
me
his
collection
of
curiosities
.
<EOS>
They
were
mostly
of
a
felonious
character
;
comprising
the
pen
with
which
a
celebrated
forgery
had
been
committed
,
a
distinguished
razor
or
two
,
some
locks
of
hair
,
and
several
manuscript
confessions
written
under
condemnation
---
upon
which
Mr
Wemmick
set
particular
value
as
being
,
to
use
his
own
words
,
"
every
one
of
'em
Lies
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
These
were
agreeably
dispersed
among
small
specimens
of
china
and
glass
various
neat
trifles
made
by
the
proprietor
of
the
museum
,
and
some
tobacco
-
stoppers
carved
by
the
Aged
.
<EOS>
They
were
all
displayed
in
that
chamber
of
the
Castle
into
which
I
had
been
first
inducted
,
and
which
served
,
not
only
as
the
general
sitting
-
room
but
as
the
kitchen
too
,
if
I
might
judge
from
a
saucepan
on
the
hob
,
and
a
brazen
bijou
over
the
fireplace
designed
for
the
suspension
of
a
roasting
-
jack
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
neat
little
girl
in
attendance
,
who
looked
after
the
Aged
in
the
day
.
<EOS>
When
she
had
laid
the
supper
-
cloth
,
the
bridge
was
lowered
to
give
her
means
of
egress
,
and
she
withdrew
for
the
night
.
<EOS>
The
supper
was
excellent
;
and
though
the
Castle
was
rather
subject
to
dry
-
rot
insomuch
that
it
tasted
like
a
bad
nut
,
and
though
the
pig
might
have
been
farther
off
,
I
was
heartily
pleased
with
my
whole
entertainment
.
<EOS>
Nor
was
there
any
drawback
on
my
little
turret
bedroom
,
beyond
there
being
such
a
very
thin
ceiling
between
me
and
the
flagstaff
,
that
when
I
lay
down
on
my
back
in
bed
,
it
seemed
as
if
I
had
to
balance
that
pole
on
my
forehead
all
night
.
  
<EOS>
Wemmick
was
up
early
in
the
morning
,
and
I
am
afraid
I
heard
him
cleaning
my
boots
.
<EOS>
After
that
,
he
fell
to
gardening
,
and
I
saw
him
from
my
gothic
window
pretending
to
employ
the
Aged
,
and
nodding
at
him
in
a
most
devoted
manner
.
<EOS>
Our
breakfast
was
as
good
as
the
supper
,
and
at
half
-
past
eight
precisely
we
started
for
Little
Britain
.
<EOS>
By
degrees
,
Wemmick
got
dryer
and
harder
as
we
went
along
,
and
his
mouth
tightened
into
a
post
-
office
again
.
<EOS>
At
last
,
when
we
got
to
his
place
of
business
and
he
pulled
out
his
key
from
his
coat
-
collar
,
he
looked
as
unconscious
of
his
Walworth
property
as
if
the
Castle
and
the
drawbridge
and
the
arbour
and
the
lake
and
the
fountain
and
the
Aged
,
had
all
been
blown
into
space
together
by
the
last
discharge
of
the
Stinger
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
26
 
IT
fell
out
as
Wemmick
had
told
me
it
would
,
that
I
had
an
early
opportunity
of
comparing
my
guardian
's
establishment
with
that
of
his
cashier
and
clerk
.
<EOS>
My
guardian
was
in
his
room
,
washing
his
hands
with
his
scented
soap
,
when
I
went
into
the
office
from
Walworth
;
and
he
called
me
to
him
,
and
gave
me
the
invitation
for
myself
and
friends
which
Wemmick
had
prepared
me
to
receive
.
"
<EOS>
No
ceremony
,
"
he
stipulated
,
"
and
no
dinner
dress
,
and
say
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
I
asked
him
where
we
should
come
to
(
for
I
had
no
idea
where
he
lived
)
,
and
I
believe
it
was
in
his
general
objection
to
make
anything
like
an
admission
,
that
he
replied
,
"
Come
here
,
and
I
'll
take
you
home
with
me
.
<EOS>
"
I
embrace
this
opportunity
of
remarking
that
he
washed
his
clients
off
,
as
if
he
were
a
surgeon
or
a
dentist
.
<EOS>
He
had
a
closet
in
his
room
,
fitted
up
for
the
purpose
,
which
smelt
of
the
scented
soap
like
a
perfumer
's
shop
.
<EOS>
It
had
an
unusually
large
jack
-
towel
on
a
roller
inside
the
door
,
and
he
would
wash
his
hands
,
and
wipe
them
and
dry
them
all
over
this
towel
,
whenever
he
came
in
from
a
police
-
court
or
dismissed
a
client
from
his
room
.
<EOS>
When
I
and
my
friends
repaired
to
him
at
six
o'clock
next
day
,
he
seemed
to
have
been
engaged
on
a
case
of
a
darker
complexion
than
usual
,
for
,
we
found
him
with
his
head
butted
into
this
closet
,
not
only
washing
his
hands
,
but
laving
his
face
and
gargling
his
throat
.
<EOS>
And
even
when
he
had
done
all
that
,
and
had
gone
all
round
the
jack
-
towel
,
he
took
out
his
penknife
and
scraped
the
case
out
of
his
nails
before
he
put
his
coat
on
.
  
<EOS>
There
were
some
people
slinking
about
as
usual
when
we
passed
out
into
the
street
,
who
were
evidently
anxious
to
speak
with
him
;
but
there
was
something
so
conclusive
in
the
halo
of
scented
soap
which
encircled
his
presence
,
that
they
gave
it
up
for
that
day
.
<EOS>
As
we
walked
along
westward
,
he
was
recognized
ever
and
again
by
some
face
in
the
crowd
of
the
streets
,
and
whenever
that
happened
he
talked
louder
to
me
;
but
he
never
otherwise
recognized
anybody
,
or
took
notice
that
anybody
recognized
him
.
  
<EOS>
He
conducted
us
to
Gerrard
-
street
,
Soho
,
to
a
house
on
the
south
side
of
that
street
.
<EOS>
Rather
a
stately
house
of
its
kind
,
but
dolefully
in
want
of
painting
,
and
with
dirty
windows
.
<EOS>
He
took
out
his
key
and
opened
the
door
,
and
we
all
went
into
a
stone
hall
,
bare
,
gloomy
,
and
little
used
.
<EOS>
So
,
up
a
dark
brown
staircase
into
a
series
of
three
dark
brown
rooms
on
the
first
floor
.
<EOS>
There
were
carved
garlands
on
the
panelled
walls
,
and
as
he
stood
among
them
giving
us
welcome
,
I
know
what
kind
of
loops
I
thought
they
looked
like
.
  
<EOS>
Dinner
was
laid
in
the
best
of
these
rooms
;
the
second
was
his
dressing
-
room
;
the
third
,
his
bedroom
.
<EOS>
He
told
us
that
he
held
the
whole
house
,
but
rarely
used
more
of
it
than
we
saw
.
<EOS>
The
table
was
comfortably
laid
---
<EOS>
no
silver
in
the
service
,
of
course
---
and
at
the
side
of
his
chair
was
a
capacious
dumb
-
waiter
,
with
a
variety
of
bottles
and
decanters
on
it
,
and
four
dishes
of
fruit
for
dessert
.
<EOS>
I
noticed
throughout
,
that
he
kept
everything
under
his
own
hand
,
and
distributed
everything
himself
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
bookcase
in
the
room
;
I
saw
,
from
the
backs
of
the
books
,
that
they
were
about
evidence
,
criminal
law
,
criminal
biography
,
trials
,
acts
of
parliament
,
and
such
things
.
<EOS>
The
furniture
was
all
very
solid
and
good
,
like
his
watch
-
chain
.
<EOS>
It
had
an
official
look
,
however
,
and
there
was
nothing
merely
ornamental
to
be
seen
.
<EOS>
In
a
corner
,
was
a
little
table
of
papers
with
a
shaded
lamp
:
so
that
he
seemed
to
bring
the
office
home
with
him
in
that
respect
too
,
and
to
wheel
it
out
of
an
evening
and
fall
to
work
.
  
<EOS>
As
he
had
scarcely
seen
my
three
companions
until
now
---
for
,
he
and
I
had
walked
together
---
he
stood
on
the
hearth
-
rug
,
after
ringing
the
bell
,
and
took
a
searching
look
at
them
.
<EOS>
To
my
surprise
,
he
seemed
at
once
to
be
principally
if
not
solely
interested
in
Drummle
.
  
<EOS>
"
Pip
,
"
said
he
,
putting
his
large
hand
on
my
shoulder
and
moving
me
to
the
window
,
"
I
do
n't
know
one
from
the
other
.
<EOS>
Who
's
the
Spider
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
spider
?
"
said
I.
  
"
The
blotchy
,
sprawly
,
sulky
fellow
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
Bentley
Drummle
,
"
I
replied
;
"
the
one
with
the
delicate
face
is
Startop
.
"
  
<EOS>
Not
making
the
least
account
of
"
the
one
with
the
delicate
face
,
"
he
returned
,
"
Bentley
Drummle
is
his
name
,
is
it
?
<EOS>
I
like
the
look
of
that
fellow
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
immediately
began
to
talk
to
Drummle
:
not
at
all
deterred
by
his
replying
in
his
heavy
reticent
way
,
but
apparently
led
on
by
it
to
screw
discourse
out
of
him
.
<EOS>
I
was
looking
at
the
two
,
when
there
came
between
me
and
them
,
the
housekeeper
,
with
the
first
dish
for
the
table
.
  
<EOS>
She
was
a
woman
of
about
forty
<EOS>
,
I
supposed
---
<EOS>
but
I
may
have
thought
her
younger
than
she
was
.
<EOS>
Rather
tall
,
of
a
lithe
nimble
figure
,
extremely
pale
,
with
large
faded
eyes
,
and
a
quantity
of
streaming
hair
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
say
whether
any
diseased
affection
of
the
heart
caused
her
lips
to
be
parted
as
if
she
were
panting
,
and
her
face
to
bear
a
curious
expression
of
suddenness
and
flutter
;
but
I
know
that
I
had
been
to
see
Macbeth
at
the
theatre
,
a
night
or
two
before
,
and
that
her
face
looked
to
me
as
if
it
were
all
disturbed
by
fiery
air
,
like
the
faces
I
had
seen
rise
out
of
the
Witches
'
caldron
.
  
<EOS>
She
set
the
dish
on
,
touched
my
guardian
quietly
on
the
arm
with
a
finger
to
notify
that
dinner
was
ready
,
and
vanished
.
<EOS>
We
took
our
seats
at
the
round
table
,
and
my
guardian
kept
Drummle
on
one
side
of
him
,
while
Startop
sat
on
the
other
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
noble
dish
of
fish
that
the
housekeeper
had
put
on
table
,
and
we
had
a
joint
of
equally
choice
mutton
afterwards
,
and
then
an
equally
choice
bird
.
<EOS>
Sauces
,
wines
,
all
the
accessories
we
wanted
,
and
all
of
the
best
,
were
given
out
by
our
host
from
his
dumb
-
waiter
;
and
when
they
had
made
the
circuit
of
the
table
,
he
always
put
them
back
again
.
<EOS>
Similarly
,
he
dealt
us
clean
plates
and
knives
and
forks
,
for
each
course
,
and
dropped
those
just
disused
into
two
baskets
on
the
ground
by
his
chair
.
<EOS>
No
other
attendant
than
the
housekeeper
appeared
.
<EOS>
She
set
on
every
dish
;
and
I
always
saw
in
her
face
,
a
face
rising
out
of
the
caldron
.
<EOS>
Years
afterwards
,
I
made
a
dreadful
likeness
of
that
woman
,
by
causing
a
face
that
had
no
other
natural
resemblance
to
it
than
it
derived
from
flowing
hair
,
to
pass
behind
a
bowl
of
flaming
spirits
in
a
dark
room
.
  
<EOS>
Induced
to
take
particular
notice
of
the
housekeeper
,
both
by
her
own
striking
appearance
and
by
Wemmick
's
preparation
,
I
observed
that
whenever
she
was
in
the
room
,
she
kept
her
eyes
attentively
on
my
guardian
,
and
that
she
would
remove
her
hands
from
any
dish
she
put
before
him
,
hesitatingly
,
as
if
she
dreaded
his
calling
her
back
,
and
wanted
him
to
speak
when
she
was
nigh
,
if
he
had
anything
to
say
.
<EOS>
I
fancied
that
I
could
detect
in
his
manner
a
consciousness
of
this
,
and
a
purpose
of
always
holding
her
in
suspense
.
  
<EOS>
Dinner
went
off
gaily
,
and
,
although
my
guardian
seemed
to
follow
rather
than
originate
subjects
,
I
knew
that
he
wrenched
the
weakest
part
of
our
dispositions
out
of
us
.
<EOS>
For
myself
,
I
found
that
I
was
expressing
my
tendency
to
lavish
expenditure
,
and
to
patronize
Herbert
,
and
to
boast
of
my
great
prospects
,
before
I
quite
knew
that
I
had
opened
my
lips
.
<EOS>
It
was
so
with
all
of
us
,
but
with
no
one
more
than
Drummle
:
the
development
of
whose
inclination
to
gird
in
a
grudging
and
suspicious
way
at
the
rest
,
was
screwed
out
of
him
before
the
fish
was
taken
off
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
not
then
,
but
when
we
had
got
to
the
cheese
,
that
our
conversation
turned
upon
our
rowing
feats
,
and
that
Drummle
was
rallied
for
coming
up
behind
of
a
night
in
that
slow
amphibious
way
of
his
.
<EOS>
Drummle
upon
this
,
informed
our
host
that
he
much
preferred
our
room
to
our
company
,
and
that
as
to
skill
he
was
more
than
our
master
,
and
that
as
to
strength
he
could
scatter
us
like
chaff
.
<EOS>
By
some
invisible
agency
,
my
guardian
wound
him
up
to
a
pitch
little
short
of
ferocity
about
this
trifle
;
and
he
fell
to
baring
and
spanning
his
arm
to
show
how
muscular
it
was
,
and
we
all
fell
to
baring
and
spanning
our
arms
in
a
ridiculous
manner
.
  
<EOS>
Now
,
the
housekeeper
was
at
that
time
clearing
the
table
;
my
guardian
,
taking
no
heed
of
her
,
but
with
the
side
of

,
was

biting
the
side
of
his

and
showing
an
interest
in
Drummle
,
that
,

,
was

.
<EOS>
Suddenly
,
he
clapped

on

's
,
like

,

.
<EOS>
So

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
Molly
,

.

<EOS>

Molly

"

"

\
<EOS>
both
\

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

<EOS>

"
<EOS>
MY

,

.

<EOS>
We

.

<EOS>
\
   
<EOS>
I
received
this
letter
by
post
on
Monday
morning
,
and
therefore
its
appointment
was
for
next
day
.
<EOS>
Let
me
confess
exactly
,
with
what
feelings
I
looked
forward
to
Joe
's
coming
.
  
<EOS>
Not
with
pleasure
,
though
I
was
bound
to
him
by
so
many
ties
;
no
;
with
considerable
disturbance
,
some
mortification
,
and
a
keen
sense
of
incongruity
.
<EOS>
If
I
could
have
kept
him
away
by
paying
money
,
I
certainly
would
have
paid
money
.
<EOS>
My
greatest
reassurance
was
,
that
he
was
coming
to
Barnard
's
Inn
,
not
to
Hammersmith
,
and
consequently
would
not
fall
in
Bentley
Drummle
's
way
.
<EOS>
I
had
little
objection
to
his
being
seen
by
Herbert
or
his
father
,
for
both
of
whom
I
had
a
respect
;
but
I
had
the
sharpest
sensitiveness
as
to
his
being
seen
by
Drummle
,
whom
I
held
in
contempt
.
<EOS>
So
,
throughout
life
,
our
worst
weaknesses
and
meannesses
are
usually
committed
for
the
sake
of
the
people
whom
we
most
despise
.
  
<EOS>
I
had
begun
to
be
always
decorating
the
chambers
in
some
quite
unnecessary
and
inappropriate
way
or
other
,
and
very
expensive
those
wrestles
with
Barnard
proved
to
be
.
<EOS>
By
this
time
,
the
rooms
were
vastly
different
from
what
I
had
found
them
,
and
I
enjoyed
the
honour
of
occupying
a
few
prominent
pages
in
the
books
of
a

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
for

.
<EOS>
"
Then
,
they
both
laughed
,
and
began
cracking
nuts
,
and
spitting

about
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
As
I
really
think
I
should
have
liked

do
myself
,
if

had
been
in
their
place

.
  
<EOS>
At
length
,

was
voted
that
there

the

,
and
that
he
must
either
go
in

.
<EOS>
So
,

got
into

,

,

,
and

<EOS>
"
Good

,
Handel
!
"
<EOS>
Herbert

<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>
It

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

,
and

cursed

.
<EOS>
It

,

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

.

This

.

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

"
No
,
"

"

.
<EOS>
VERB
.
<EOS>
SAP
.
  
<EOS>
I

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
29
 
BETIMES
in
the
morning
<EOS>
I
was
up
and
out
.
<EOS>
It
was
too
early
yet
to
go
to
Miss
Havisham
's
,
so
I
loitered
into
the
country
on
Miss
Havisham
's
side

town
---
which
was
not
Joe
's
side
;
I
could
go
there
to
-
morrow
---
thinking
about
my
patroness
,
and
painting
brilliant
pictures
of
her
plans
for
me
.
  
<EOS>
She
had
adopted
Estella
,
she
had
as
good
as
adopted
me
,
and
it
could
not
fail
to
be
her
intention
to
bring
us
together
.
<EOS>
She
reserved
it
for
me
to
restore
the
desolate
house
,
admit
the
sunshine
into
the
dark
rooms
,
set
the
clocks
a
going
and
the
cold

a

,
tear

,
destroy

---
in

,
do
all

shining

of
the
young
Knight

,
and

Princess
.
<EOS>
I
had
stopped

at

as
I
passed
;
and
its
seared
red

,

,

,

,

I

.
<EOS>
Estella
was
the
inspiration
of
it
,
and
the
heart
of
it
,
of
course
.
<EOS>
But
,
though
she
had
taken
such
strong

of

,

my

and

so

,

,

did
not
,
even
that

,
invest

any

those
she

.
<EOS>
I
mention
this
in
this
place
,
of
a
fixed
purpose
,
because
it
is
the
clue
by
which
I
am
to
be
followed
into
my
poor
labyrinth
.
<EOS>
According
to
my
experience
,
the
conventional
notion
of
a
lover
can
not
be
always
true
.
<EOS>
The
unqualified
truth
is
,
that
when
I
loved
Estella
with
the
love
of
a
man
,
I
loved
her
simply
because
I
found
her
irresistible
.
<EOS>
Once
for
all
;
I
knew
to
my
sorrow
,
often
and
often
,
if
not
always
,
that
I
loved
her
against
reason
,
against
promise
,
against
peace
,
against
hope
,
against
happiness
,
against
all
discouragement
that
could
be
.
<EOS>
Once
for
all
;
I
loved
her
none
the
less
because
I
knew
it
,
and
it
had
no
more
influence
in
restraining
me
,
than
if
I
had
devoutly

her
to
be
human
perfection
.
  
<EOS>
I
so
shaped
out
my
walk
as
to
arrive
at
the
gate
at
my
old
time
.
<EOS>
When
I
had
rung
at
the
bell
with

,
I
turned
my
back
upon
the
gate
,
while
I
tried
to
get
my

and
keep
the

of

moderately
quiet
.
<EOS>
I
heard
the
side

open
,
and
steps
come
across
the
court
-
yard
;
but
I
pretended
not
to
hear
,
even
when
the
gate
swung
on
its
rusty
hinges
.
  
<EOS>
Being
at
last
touched
on
the
shoulder
,
I
started
and
turned
.
<EOS>
I
started
much
more
naturally

,
to
find

a
man
in

.
<EOS>
The
last

I
should

expected

in

of
porter
at

Havisham
's

.
  
<EOS>
"
Orlick
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
young
master
,

's
more
changes
than

.
<EOS>
But

,

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
entered

,
and

,
and

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
!
"
said

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
Here
I
am
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
How

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
come
here
,
"
he

,
"

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are

here

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
ai
n't
here
for
harm
,
young
master
,
I

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
was
not

.
<EOS>
I
had
leisure
to
entertain
the
retort
in
my
mind
,
while
he
slowly

heavy

from

,
up
my
legs
and
arms
,
to
my
face
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
you
have
left
the
forge
?
<EOS>
"
I
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
this
look
like
a
forge
?
"
replied
Orlick
,
sending
his
glance
all
<EOS>
round
him
with
an
air
of
injury
.
<EOS>
"
Now
,
do
it
look
like
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
I
asked
him
how
long
he
had
left
Gargery
's
forge
?
  
<EOS>
"
One
day
is
so
like
another
here
,
"
he

,
"
that
I
do
n't
know
without
casting
it
up
.
<EOS>
However
,
I
come
here
some
time
since
you
left
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
could
have
told
you
that
,
Orlick
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
said
he
,
drily
.
<EOS>
"
But
then
you
've
got
to
be
a
scholar
.
"
  
<EOS>
By
this
time
we
had
come
to
the
house
,
where
I
found
his
room
to
be
one
just
within
the
side
door
,
with
a
little
window
in
it
looking
on
the
court
-
yard
.
<EOS>
In
its
small
proportions
,
it
was
not
unlike
the
kind
of
place
usually
assigned
to
a
gate
-
porter
in
Paris
.
<EOS>
Certain
keys
were
hanging
on
the
wall
,
to
which
he
now
added
the
gate
-
key
;
and
his
patchwork
-
covered
bed
was
in
a
little
inner
division
or

.
<EOS>
The
whole
had
a
slovenly
confined
and

,
like
a
cage
for
a
human
dormouse
:
while
he
,
looming
dark
and
heavy
in
the
shadow
of
a
corner
by
the
window
,
looked
like
the
human
dormouse
for
whom
it
was
fitted
up
---
as
indeed
he
was
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
saw
this
room
before
,
"
I
remarked
;
"
but
there
used
to
be
no
Porter
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
he
;
"
not
till
it
got
about
that
there
was
no
protection
on
the
premises
,
and
it
come
to
be
considered
dangerous
,
with
convicts
and
Tag
and
Rag
and
Bobtail
going
up
and
down
.
<EOS>
And
then
I
was
recommended
to
the
place
as
a
man
who
could
give
another
man
as
good
as
he
brought
,
and
I
took
it
.
<EOS>
It
's
easier
than
bellowsing
and
hammering
.
<EOS>
---
That
's
loaded
,
that
is
.
"
  
<EOS>
My

had
been
caught
by
a
gun
with
a
brass
bound
stock
over
the
chimney
-
piece
,
and
his
eye
had
followed
mine
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
said
I
,
not

,
"

go
up

Miss
Havisham
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Bum
me
,
if
I
know
!
"
<EOS>
he

,
first

and

;
"
my
orders

here
,
young

.
<EOS>
I

this
here
<EOS>
bell
a
rap
with
this
here

,
and
you

passage
till

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
expected
,
I

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Burn
me
twice
over
,

I

!
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
Upon

I
turned

long

which
I

first

my

,

bell

.
<EOS>
At

,

Sarah
Pocket
:
who

green

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"

.
<EOS>
"
You
,

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

,
Miss
Pocket
.
<EOS>
I

that
Mr
Pocket
and

are
all

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are

?
"

,
with

"
they

,

.
<EOS>
Ah
,
Matthew
,
Matthew
!
<EOS>
You
know
your
way
,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Tolerably
,
for
I
had
gone
up
the

in

,
many

.
<EOS>
I
ascended

now
,
in
lighter
boots
than
of
yore
,
and
tapped
in

the

Miss
Havisham
's

.
<EOS>
"
Pip
's
rap
,
"
I
heard

say
,

;
"
come
in
,
Pip
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
was
in

,
in
the
old

,
with
her
two
hands
crossed
on

,
her

resting
on

,
and
her

on

.
<EOS>
Sitting
near

,
with
the
white
shoe
that
had
never
been

,
in
her

,
and
her

bent

she

,
was
an

whom

.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
in
,
Pip
,
"
Miss
Havisham
continued

,

;
"
come

,
Pip
,
how
do

do
,
Pip
?
<EOS>
so
you
kiss
my
hand
as

,

?
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Well
?
"
  
<EOS>
She

,
only
moving

,
and

,
  
"
<EOS>
Well
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

"

,
"
that

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
?
"
  
<EOS>
The

I
had

before
,
lifted

and

,
and
then

that
the

Estella
's

.
<EOS>
But

so
much

,

,
so

,
in

winning

.
<EOS>
I

,

,
that

back
into
the
coarse
and
common
boy
again
.
<EOS>
O
the
sense
of
distance
and
disparity
that
came
upon

,
and
the

that
came
about
her
!
  
<EOS>
She
gave
me
her
hand
.
<EOS>
I
stammered
something
about
the

I
felt
in

again
,
and
about

for
a
long
,
long

.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you

her
much

,
Pip
?
"

Havisham
,
with
her

,
and

,

<EOS>
"

,

,

of

<EOS>
"
  
"
What
?
<EOS>
You

into

?
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
Do

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I

,

,
and
the
like
.
<EOS>
Estella

and
said
she

.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
 
\
<EOS>
he
\
 
changed
?
<EOS>
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Very

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Less
coarse
and
common
?
"
said
Miss
Havisham
,
playing

Estella
's

.
  
<EOS>
Estella
laughed
,
and
looked
at
the
shoe
in
her
hand
,
and
laughed
again
,
and
looked
at
me
,
and
put

.
<EOS>
She
treated
me
as
a
boy
still
,
but
she
lured
me

.
  
<EOS>
We
sat
in
the
dreamy
room
among
the
old
strange

which
had
so
wrought
upon
me
,
and
I
learnt
that
she
had
but
just
come
home
from
France
,
and
that
she
was
going
to
London
.
<EOS>
Proud
and
wilful
as
of
old
,
she
had
brought
those
qualities
into
such
subjection
to
her
beauty
that
it
was
impossible
and
out
of
nature
---
or
I
thought

---
to
separate
them
from
her
beauty
.
<EOS>
Truly
it
was
impossible
to
dissociate
her
presence
from
all
those
wretched
hankerings
after
money
and
gentility
that
had

---
from
all
those
ill

regulated

that
had
first

ashamed
of
home
and
Joe
---
from
all
those
visions
that
had
raised
her
face
in
the
glowing
fire
,
struck

out
of
the
iron

,

from

of

to
look
in

the

and
flit

.
<EOS>
In
a

,
it
was
impossible

to
separate
her
,
in
the
past
or

,

the
innermost

.
  
<EOS>
It
was
settled
that
I
should
stay
there
all
the
rest
of

day
,
and
return
to
the

,
and

London
to
-

.
<EOS>
When

for
a

,

Havisham
sent

to

in
the

:

in
by
-
and

,

,
I
should
wheel
her
about
a
little
as

of
yore
.
  
<EOS>
So
,
Estella
and
I
went
out
into
the

by

through

I
had
strayed
to

,
now
Herbert
;
I
,

hem

;
she
,
quite

.
<EOS>
As

near

,

:
  
"
I
must

to
hide

see
that
fight
that

:
but
I
did
,

I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
rewarded
me
very
much
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did
I
?
<EOS>
"
she

,
in

.
<EOS>
"
I
remember
I
entertained

your

,
because
I
took

ill
that

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are

?
<EOS>
I

,

read

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
  
<EOS>
I
made

with

,
for
it
seemed
to
have
a
boyish

,
and
she
already

.
  
<EOS>
"
Since

,
"

<EOS>
"
Naturally
,
"

<EOS>
"
And

,
"
she

;
"
what
was

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
In

,
I

,
of

Joe
;
but

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

your

,

?
"

,

,

in

.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
the
least
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
air
of

and

with

she
walked
at
my
side
,
and
the
air

and

I

,

strongly

.
<EOS>
It

,

.
  
<EOS>
The

was
too
overgrown

rank
for

in
with

,

made

round

.
<EOS>
I

her
to

where
I
had
seen

casks
,
that
first
old

,
and

,

"
Did
I
?
<EOS>
"
I

,
and

,
"
I
do

.
"
<EOS>
"
Not

you

?
"

"
No
,
"
said

,
and

.
<EOS>
I
verily

that
her
not
remembering
and
not
minding
in
the
least
,
made
me
cry
again
,
inwardly
---
and
that
is
the
sharpest

of
all
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
must
know
,
"
said
Estella
,
condescending

me
as

and

,
"
that
I
have
no
heart
---
if
that
has
anything
to
do

my

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
got
through
some
jargon
to
the
effect
that
I
took
the
liberty
of
doubting
that
.
<EOS>
That
I
knew
better
.
<EOS>
That
there
could
be
no
such

without
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
I
have
a
heart
to
be
stabbed
in
or
shot
in
<EOS>
,
I
have
no
doubt
,
"
said
Estella
,
"
and
,

,
if
it
ceased

beat
I
should

be
.
<EOS>
But
you
know
what
I
mean
.
<EOS>
I
have
no
softness
there
,
no
---
sympathy
---

---
nonsense
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
What
 
\
was
\
 
<EOS>
it
that
was
borne
in
upon
my
mind
when
she
stood
still
and
looked
attentively
at
me
?
<EOS>
Anything
that
I
had
seen
in
Miss
Havisham
?
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
In
some
of
her
looks
and
gestures
there
was
that
tinge
of
resemblance
to
Miss
Havisham
which
may
often
be
noticed
to
have
been
acquired
by
children
,
from
grown
persons
with
whom
they
have
been
much
associated
and
secluded
,
and
which
,
when
childhood
is
passed
,
will
produce
a
remarkable
occasional
likeness
of
expression
between
faces
that
are
otherwise
quite
different
.
<EOS>
And
yet
I
could
not
trace
this
to
Miss
Havisham
.
<EOS>
I
looked
again
,
and
though
she
was
still
looking
at
me
,
the
suggestion
was
gone
.
  
<EOS>
What
 
\
was
\
 
<EOS>
it
?
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
serious
,
"
said
Estella
,
not
so
much
with
a
frown
<EOS>
(
for
her
brow
was
smooth
)
as
with
a
darkening
of
her
face
;
"
if
we
are
to
be
thrown
much
together
,
you
had
better
believe
it
at
once
.
<EOS>
No
!
"
<EOS>
imperiously
stopping
me
as
I
opened
my
lips
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
bestowed
my
tenderness
anywhere
.
<EOS>
I
have
never
had
any
such
thing
.
"
  
<EOS>
In
another
moment
we
were
in
the
brewery
so
long
disused
,
and
she
pointed
to
the
high
gallery
where
I
had
seen
her
going
out
on
that
same
first

,
and
told
me
she
remembered
to
have
been

there
,
and
to
have
seen

scared

.
<EOS>
As

followed
her
white
hand
,
again
the
same
dim
suggestion
that
I
could
not
possibly
grasp
,
crossed
me
.
<EOS>
My
involuntary
start
occasioned
her
to
lay
her
hand
upon
my
arm
.
<EOS>
Instantly
the
ghost
passed
once
more
,
and
was
gone
.
  
<EOS>
What
 
\
was
\
 
<EOS>
it
?
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
matter
?
"
asked
Estella
.
<EOS>
"
Are
you
scared
again
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
be
,
if
I
believed
what
you
said
just
now
,
"
I

,
to

.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
you
do

?
<EOS>
Very
well
.
<EOS>
It
is
said
,
at
any
rate
.
<EOS>
Miss
Havisham
will
soon

expecting
you
at
your
old
post
,
though
I

that
might
be
laid

now
,
with
other

.
<EOS>
Let

make
one
more
round
of
the
garden
,
and
then
go

.
<EOS>
Come
!
<EOS>
You
shall
not

for
my
cruelty
to

;
you
shall
be
my
Page
,

shoulder
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Her
handsome
dress
had
trailed
upon
the
ground
.
<EOS>
She
held
it
in
one
hand
now
,
and
with
the
other
lightly
touched
my
shoulder
as
we
walked
.
<EOS>
We
walked
round
the
ruined
garden
twice
or
thrice
more
,
and
it
was
all
in
bloom
for
me
.
<EOS>
If

green

of

in
the

the
old

had
been
the
most

that

,
