.
  
<EOS>
There

no

years
between

,
to
remove
her
far
from

;
we
were
of
nearly

age
,

told

more
in

;

her

,

in
the

,
and

I
felt
that
our
patroness
had
chosen

for
one
another
.
<EOS>
Wretched
boy
!
  
<EOS>
At
last
we
went
back
into
the
house
,
and
there
I
heard
,
with

,
that
my
guardian
had
come

to

Havisham

,
and
would

.
<EOS>
The
old

in
the
room
where
the
mouldering
table
was
spread
,
had
been
lighted
while
we

,
and
Miss
Havisham
was

.
  
<EOS>
It
was
like
pushing
the
chair
itself
back
into
the

,
when
we

the
old
slow

round
about

.
<EOS>
But
,

,

grave

in
the
chair
fixing

her
<EOS>
,
Estella
looked
more
bright

than
before
,
and
I
was
under
stronger

.
  
<EOS>
The
time
so
melted
away
,
that
our
early
dinner

hour
drew
close

,
and
Estella
left

to

.
<EOS>
We
had

near
the

of
the

,
and
Miss
Havisham
,
with
one

her

,

that

.
<EOS>
As
Estella
looked

her

,
Miss
Havisham
kissed
that
hand
to
her
,
with
a

intensity
that
was
of
its
kind
quite

.
  
<EOS>
Then
,
Estella
being
gone
and
we
two
left
alone
<EOS>
,
she
turned
to
me
,
and
said

:
  
"
Is
she
beautiful
,
graceful
,
well
-
grown
?
<EOS>
Do
you
admire
her
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Everybody
must
who
sees
her
,
Miss
Havisham
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
drew
an
arm
<EOS>
round
my
neck
,
and
drew
my
head
close
down
to
hers
as
she
sat
in

.
<EOS>
"
Love
her
,
love
her
,
love
her
!
<EOS>
How
does
she
use
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
Before
I
could
answer
(
if
I
could
have

so

)
,
she

,
"
Love
her
,
love
her
,
love
her
!
<EOS>
If
she
favours
you
,
love
her
.
<EOS>
If
she
wounds
you
,
love
her
.
<EOS>
If
she
tears
your
heart
to
pieces
---
and
as
it
gets
older
and
stronger
,
it
will
tear

---
love
her
,
love
her
,
love
her
!
"
  
<EOS>
Never
had
I
seen
such
passionate
eagerness
as
was
joined
to
her
utterance
of
these
words
.
<EOS>
I
could
feel
the
muscles
of
the
thin
arm
round
my
neck
,
swell
with
the
vehemence
that
possessed
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
Hear
me
,
Pip
!
<EOS>
I
adopted
her
to
be
loved
.
<EOS>
I
bred
her
and
educated
her
,
to
be
loved
.
<EOS>
I
developed
her
into
what
she
is
,
that
she
might
be
loved
.
<EOS>
Love
her
!
"
  
<EOS>
She
said
the
word
often
enough
,
and
there
could
be
no
doubt
that
she
meant
to
say

;
but
if
the
often

had
been
hate
instead
of
love
---
despair
---
revenge
---
dire
death
---
it
could
not
have
sounded
from
her
lips
more
like

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
tell
you
,
"
said
she
,
in
the
same
hurried
passionate
whisper
,
"
what
real
love
is
.
<EOS>
It
is
blind
devotion
,
unquestioning
self
-
humiliation
,
utter
submission
,
trust
and
belief
against
yourself
and
against
the
whole
world
,
giving
up
your
whole
heart
and
soul
to
the
smiter
---
as
I
did
!
"
  
<EOS>
When
she
came
to
that
,
and
to
a
wild
cry
that
followed
that
,
I
caught
her
round

waist
.
<EOS>
For
she
rose
up
in
the
chair
,
in
her
shroud
of
a
dress
,
and
struck
at
the
air
as
if
she
would
as
soon
have
struck
herself
against
the

and
fallen
dead
.
  
<EOS>
All
this
passed
in
a
few
seconds
.
<EOS>
As
I
drew
her
down
into
her
chair
,
I
was
conscious
of
a
scent
that
I
knew
,
and
turning
,
saw
my
guardian
in
the
room
.
  
<EOS>
He
always
carried
<EOS>
(
I
have
not
yet
mentioned
it
,
I
think
)
<EOS>
a
pocket
-
handkerchief
of
rich
silk
and
of
imposing

,
which
was
of
great
value
to
him
in
his
profession
.
<EOS>
I
have
seen
him
so
terrify
a
client
or
a
witness
by
ceremoniously
unfolding
this
pocket
-
handkerchief
as
if
he
were

his

,
and
then

,
<EOS>
as

not

to
do

before
such
client
or
witness
committed
himself
,
that
the
self
-
committal
has
followed

,
quite
as

matter

course
.
<EOS>
When
I
saw
him
in
the
room
,
he
had
this
expressive
pocket
-
handkerchief
in
both

,
and
was
looking

.
<EOS>
On

,

said

,
by

,
"
Indeed
?
<EOS>
Singular
!
"
<EOS>
and
then
put
the
handkerchief
to
its
right
use
with
wonderful
effect
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Havisham
had
seen
him
as
soon
as
I
,
and
was
(
like
everybody
else
)
afraid
of
him
.
<EOS>
She
made
a
strong

to
compose
herself
,
and
stammered
that
he
was
as

as

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
punctual
as
ever
,
"
he

,
coming

.
"
<EOS>
(
How

,
Pip
?
<EOS>
Shall

,
Miss
Havisham
?
<EOS>
Once

?
)
<EOS>
And

you

,
Pip
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
told
him
when
I
had
arrived
,
and
how
Miss
Havisham
had
wished

to
come
and
see
Estella
.
<EOS>
To

,
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
Very
fine

!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then

pushed
Miss
Havisham

,
with

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Pip
!
<EOS>
How
often
have
you
seen
Miss
Estella
before
?
"
<EOS>
said

,
when

.
  
<EOS>
"
How
often
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
How
many
times
?
<EOS>
Ten

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
Certainly

so

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Twice
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Jaggers
,
"
interposed

Havisham
,
much

;
"
leave

,

go

.
"
  
<EOS>
He
complied
,
and
we
groped

down

dark

.
<EOS>
While

were
still

those

back
,
he

me
how

I
had
seen
Miss
Havisham
eat

;
offering

a

of
choice
,
as
usual
,
between
a
hundred

and

.
  
<EOS>
I
considered
,
and
said
,
"
Never
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
never
will
,
Pip
<EOS>
,
"
he
retorted
,
with
a

.
<EOS>
"
She
has
never
allowed
herself
to
be
seen
doing
either
,
since
she
lived
this
present
life
of
hers
.
<EOS>
She
wanders
about

,
and
then
lays
hands
on
such

as

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Pray
,

,
"
said

,
"

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
may
,
"
said
he
,
"
and
I
may
decline
to
answer

.
<EOS>
Put
your

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Estella
's
name
.
<EOS>
Is
it
Havisham
or
---
?
<EOS>
"
I
had
nothing
to
add
.
  
<EOS>
"
Or
what
?
"
said
he
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
it
Havisham
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
Havisham
.
"
  
<EOS>
This
brought
us
to
the
dinner
-
table
,
where
she
and
Sarah
Pocket
awaited
us
.
<EOS>
Mr
Jaggers
presided
,
Estella
sat
opposite
to
him
,
I
faced
my
green
and
yellow
friend
.
<EOS>
We
dined
very
well
,
and
were
waited
on
by
a
maid
-
servant
whom
I
had
never
seen
in
all
my
comings
and
goings
,
but
who
,
for
anything
I
know
,
had
been
in
that
mysterious
house
the
whole
time
.
<EOS>
After
dinner
,
a
bottle
of
choice
old
port
was
placed
before
my
guardian
(
he
was
evidently
well
acquainted
with
the
vintage
)
,
and
the
two
ladies
left
us
.
  
<EOS>
Anything
to
equal
the
determined
reticence
of
Mr
Jaggers
under
that
roof
<EOS>
,
I
never
saw
elsewhere
,
even
in
him
.
<EOS>
He
kept
his
very
looks
to
himself
,
and
scarcely
directed
his
eyes
to
Estella
's
face
once
during
dinner
.
<EOS>
When
she
spoke
to
him
,
he
listened
,
and
in
due
course
answered
,
but
never
looked
at
her
,
that
I
could
see
.
<EOS>
On
the
other
hand
,
she
often
looked
at
him
,
with
interest
and
curiosity
,
if
not
distrust
,
but
his
face
never
showed
the
least
consciousness
.
<EOS>
Throughout
dinner
he
took
a
dry
delight
in
making
Sarah
Pocket
greener
and
yellower
,
by
often
referring
in
conversation
with
me
to
my
expectations
;
but
here
,
again
,
he
showed
no
consciousness
,
and
even
made
it
appear
that
he
extorted
---
and
even
did
extort
,
though
I
do
n't
know
<EOS>
how
---
those
references
out
of
my
innocent
self
.
  
<EOS>
And
when
he
and
I
were
left
alone
together
,
he
sat
with
an
air
upon
him
of
general
lying
by
in
consequence
of
information
<EOS>
he
possessed
,
that
really
was
too
much
for
me
.
<EOS>
He
cross
-
examined
his
very
wine
when
he
had
nothing
else
in
hand
.
<EOS>
He
held
it
between
himself
and
the
candle
,
tasted
the
port
,
rolled
it
in
his
mouth
,
swallowed
it
,
looked
at
his
glass
again
,
smelt
the
port
,
tried
it
,

,
filled
again
,
and
cross

,

the

be

.
<EOS>

\
<EOS>
her

<EOS>
Chapter
31
 
ON

,

.
<EOS>
The

;

<EOS>
My

,
with

,
and
I
could

wished
that

.
  
<EOS>
Several

.
<EOS>
The

,

to

.
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
It

"

front
,
sir
,
to
the
back
of
the
pit
,
and
<EOS>
whenever
his
reading
brought
him
into
profile
,
I
called
out
"
<EOS>
I
do
n't
see
no
wafers
!
"
<EOS>
And
at
night
his
reading
was
lovely
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Waldengarver
smiled
at
me
,
as
much
as
to
say
"
a
faithful
dependent
---
I
overlook
his
folly
;
"
and
then
said
aloud
,
"
My
view
is
a
little
classic
and
thoughtful
for
them
here
;
but
they
will
improve
,
they
will
improve
.
"
  
<EOS>
Herbert
<EOS>
and
I
said
together
,
<EOS>
Oh
,
no
doubt
they
would
improve
.
  
<EOS>
"
Did
you
observe
,
gentlemen
,
"
said
Mr
Waldengarver
,
"
that
there
was
a
man
in
the
gallery
who
endeavoured
to
cast
derision
on
the
service
---
I
mean
,
the
representation
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
We
basely
replied
that
we
rather
thought
we
had
noticed
such
a
man
.
<EOS>
I
added
,
"
He
was
drunk
,
no
doubt
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
<EOS>
no
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Wopsle
,
"
not
drunk
.
<EOS>
His
employer
would
see
to
that
,
sir
.
<EOS>
His
employer
would
not
allow
him
to
be
drunk
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
know
his
employer
?
"
said
I.
  
Mr
Wopsle
shut
his
eyes
,
and
opened
them
again
;
performing
both

very
slowly
.
<EOS>
"
You
must
have
observed
,
gentlemen
,
"
said
he
,
"
an
ignorant
and
a
blatant

,
with
a

and

of
low

,
who
went
through
---
I
will

sustained
---
<EOS>
the
role
(
if
I
may
use

)
of
Claudius
King
of
Denmark
.
<EOS>
That
is
his
employer
,
gentlemen
.
<EOS>
Such
is
the
profession
!
"
  
<EOS>
Without

whether
I
should
have
been
more

for
Mr
Wopsle
if
he
had
been
in

,
I
was
so

him
as
it
was
,
that
I
took
the

of
his
turning
round
to
have

---
which

out

---
to
ask

what

having

home

?
<EOS>
Herbert
said
he
thought
it
would
be
kind
to
do

;
therefore
I
invited
him
,
and
he
went
to
Barnard
's
with

,
wrapped
up
to
the

,
and
we
did
our
best
for
him
,
and
he
sat
until
two

in
the
morning
,
reviewing
his

and

his

.
<EOS>
I
forget
in
detail
what
they
were
,
but
I
have
a
general
recollection
that
he
was
to
begin
with
reviving
the
Drama
,
and
to
end
with
crushing
it
;
inasmuch
as
his
decease
would
leave
it
utterly
bereft
and
without
a
chance
or
hope
.
  
<EOS>
Miserably
I
went
to
bed
after
all
,
and
miserably
thought
of
Estella
,
and
miserably
dreamed
that
my
expectations
were
all
cancelled
,
and
that
I
had
to
give
my
hand
in
marriage
to
Herbert
's
  
Clara
,
or
play
Hamlet
to
Miss
Havisham
's
Ghost
,
before
twenty
thousand
people
,
without
knowing
twenty
words
of
it
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
32
 
ONE
day
when
I
was
busy
with
my
books
and
Mr
Pocket
,
I
received
a
note
by
the
post
,
the
mere
outside
of
which
threw
me
into
a
great
flutter
;
for
,
though
I
had
never
seen
the
handwriting
in
which
it
was
addressed
<EOS>
,
I
divined
whose
hand
it
was
.
<EOS>
It
had
no
set
beginning
,
as
Dear
Mr
Pip
,
or
Dear
Pip
,
or
Dear
Sir
,
or
Dear
Anything
,
but
ran
thus
:
  
"
I
am
to
come
to
London
the
day
after
to
-
morrow
by
the
mid

day
coach
.
<EOS>
I
believe
it
was
settled
you
should
meet
me
?
<EOS>
At
all
events
Miss
Havisham
has
that
impression
,
and
I
write
in
obedience
to
it
.
<EOS>
She
sends
you
her
regard
.
<EOS>
---
Yours
,
ESTELLA
.
"
   
<EOS>
If
there
had
been
time
,
I
should
probably
have
ordered
several
suits
of
clothes
for
this
occasion
;
but
as
there
was
not
,
I
was
fain
to
be
content
with
those
I
had
.
<EOS>
My
appetite
vanished
instantly
,
and
I
knew
no
peace
or
rest
until
the
day
arrived
.
<EOS>
Not
that
its
arrival
brought
me
either
;
for
,
then
I
was
worse
than
ever
,
and
began
haunting
the
coach
-
office
in
Wood
-
street
,
Cheapside
,
before
the
coach
had
left
the
Blue
Boar
in
our

.
<EOS>
For
all
that
I
knew
this
perfectly
well
<EOS>
,
I
still
felt
as
if
it
were
not
safe
to
let
the
coach
-
office
be
out
of
my
sight
longer
than
five
minutes
at
a
time
;
and
in
this
condition
of
unreason
I
had
performed
the
first
half
-
hour
of
a
watch
of
four
or
five
hours
,
when
Wemmick
ran
against
me
.
  
<EOS>
"
Halloa
,
Mr
Pip
,
"

;
"
how
do
you
do
?
<EOS>
I
should

thought
this
was
 
<EOS>
\
your
\
 
beat
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I

who

coming

by

,
and
I

the
Castle
and

Aged
.
  
<EOS>
"
Both

,

,
"
said

,
"

Aged
.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
He
'll
be
eighty
-
two

.
<EOS>
I

of
firing
eighty
-
two

,
if
the

should
n't
complain
,
and
that

of

.
<EOS>
However
,

.
<EOS>
Mere
<EOS>
do

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
To

office
?
<EOS>
"

,
for

was

.
  
<EOS>
"
Next

,
"
returned

,
"
I

Newgate
.
<EOS>
We
are
in
a
banker's
-
parcel
case
just
at
present
,
and
I
have

down

,
and
thereupon
must

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did

client

?
"
I

.
  
<EOS>
"
Bless

,

,
"

,

.
"
<EOS>
But

is

.
<EOS>
So
might

I
be
.
<EOS>
Either

might

of
it
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Only

,
"
I

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yah
!
"
said

,

on

;
"
you
're
a
deep
one
,
Mr
Pip
!
<EOS>
Would

like

Newgate
?
<EOS>
Have

to

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
had
so
much
time
to
spare
,
that
the

came
as
a
relief
,
notwithstanding
its
irreconcilability
with
my

.
<EOS>
Muttering

,

into

,
and
ascertained

the

with

nicest

and
much
to
the

,
the

which

---
which

knew

,
quite
as
well

he
.
<EOS>
I
then
rejoined
Mr
Wemmick
,
and
affecting
to
consult
my
watch
and
to
be
surprised
by
the
information
I
had
received
,
accepted
his
offer
.
  
<EOS>
We
were
at
Newgate
in
a
few
minutes
,
and
we
passed
through
the
lodge
where
some
fetters
were
hanging
up
on
the
bare
walls
among
the
prison
rules
,
into
the
interior
of
the
jail
.
<EOS>
At
that
time
,
jails
were
much
neglected
,
and
the
period
of
exaggerated
reaction
consequent
on
all
public
wrong
-
doing
---
and
which
is
always
its
heaviest
and
longest
punishment
---
was
still
far
off
.
<EOS>
So
,
felons
were
not
lodged
and
fed
better
than
soldiers
(
to
say
nothing
of
paupers
)
,
and
seldom
set
fire
to
their
prisons
with
the
excusable
object
of
improving
the
flavour
of
their
soup
.
<EOS>
It
was
visiting
time
when
Wemmick
took
me
in
;
and
a
potman
was
going
his
rounds
with
beer
;
and
the
prisoners
,
behind
bars
in
yards
,
were
buying
beer
,
and
talking
to
friends
;
and
a
frouzy
,
ugly
,
disorderly
,
depressing
scene
it
was
.
  
<EOS>
It
struck
me
that
Wemmick
walked
among
the
prisoners
,
much
as
a
gardener
might
walk
among
his
plants
.
<EOS>
This
was
first
put
into
my
head
by
his
seeing
a
shoot
that
had
come
up
in
the
night
,
and
saying
,
"
What
,
Captain
Tom
?
<EOS>
Are
 
<EOS>
\
<EOS>
you
\
 
there
?
<EOS>
Ah
,
indeed
!
"
<EOS>
and
also
"
Is
that
Black
Bill
behind
the
cistern
?
<EOS>
Why
I
did
n't
look
for
you
these
two
months
;
how
do
you
find
yourself
?
"
<EOS>
Equally
in
his
stopping
at
the
bars
and
attending
to
anxious

---
always
singly
---
Wemmick
with
his
post
-
office
in
an
immovable
state
,
looked
at
them
while
in
conference
,
as
if
he
were
taking
particular
notice
of
the
advance
they
had
made
,
since
last
observed
,
towards
coming
out
in
full
blow
at
their
trial
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
highly
popular
,
and
I
found
that
he
took
the
familiar
department
of
Mr
Jaggers
's
business
:
though
something
of
the
state
of
Mr
Jaggers
hung
about
him
too
,
forbidding
approach
beyond
certain
limits
.
<EOS>
His
personal
recognition
of
each
successive
client
was
comprised
in
a
nod
,
and
in
his
settling
his
hat
a
little
easier
on
his
head
with
both
hands
,
and
then
tightening
the
post
-
office
,
and
putting
his
hands
in
his
pockets
.
<EOS>
In
one
or
two
instances
,
there
was
a
difficulty
respecting
the
raising
of
fees
,
and
then
Mr
Wemmick
,
backing
as
far
as
possible
from
the
insufficient
money
produced
,
said
,
"
It
's
no
use
,
my
boy
.
<EOS>
I
'm
only
a

.
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
take
it
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
go
on
in
that
way
with

.
<EOS>
If

are
unable
to
make

quantum
,
my
boy
,
you
had
better
address

to
a

;
there

in
the

,
you

,

,

;
that

to
you
,
speaking

subordinate
.
<EOS>
Do

try
on

measures
.
<EOS>
Why
should
you
?
<EOS>
Now
,
who
's
next
?
"
  
<EOS>
Thus
,
we
walked
through
Wemmick
's
greenhouse
,
until

,
"
Notice

I

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
Almost

"
Colonel

!
"

;
"

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
All

,

"

\

"

"

"

"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
By
-
the

;

.
<EOS>
"
The
man

up

.
<EOS>
"
I
am

.
 
<EOS>
\
<EOS>

\

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

,
"
<EOS>
A

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

As

<EOS>
Well
,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
What
 
\
was
\

Chapter
33

dress

.

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

!
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
We

,

,

.

.

"

.

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,

,

)
,

.
<EOS>
You

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
They

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
This
was
very

,

.
<EOS>

---

,

---

,

:
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
I
may

that

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
You

I
laugh

.
<EOS>
Oh
,
those
people
with
Miss

,

!
"
<EOS>
She

,
and
even

why
,

,
for

,

.
<EOS>

;

,

.

,

,

made

.
<EOS>
For
you
were
not

that

.
<EOS>
---
I
was
.
<EOS>
You

not
your

against

,

,

<EOS>
---
I

.
<EOS>
You

<EOS>
---
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"

"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Why

.
  
<EOS>
A

---

Here

The

,

.
  
<EOS>
Mr

;

.
<EOS>
But

(

)

.

.
  
<EOS>
Mr

.

---
<EOS>
Well
---
<EOS>
No
,

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
34
 
<EOS>
A
s
<EOS>
I
had
grown

to
my
expectations
<EOS>
,

.
<EOS>
Their

.
<EOS>
I

Joe
.
<EOS>
My
conscience
was
not

any

about
Biddy
.
<EOS>
When

like

---

,
with

's

,
and
had

Joe
in

.
<EOS>
Many

,

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
Yet

was
so

,

.
<EOS>
That

.
<EOS>
Now
,

,
I

difficulty
,
and
so
I
perceived
---
<EOS>
though
dimly
enough
perhaps
---
that
it
was
not
beneficial
to
anybody
,
and
,
above
all
,
that
it
was
not
beneficial
to
Herbert
.
<EOS>
My
lavish
habits
led
his
easy
nature
into
expenses
that
he
could
not
afford
,
corrupted
the
simplicity
of
his
life
,
and
disturbed
his
peace
with
anxieties
and
regrets
.
<EOS>
I
was
not
at
all
remorseful
for
having
unwittingly
set
those
other
branches
of
the
Pocket
family
to
the
poor
arts
they
practised
:
because
such
littlenesses
were
their
natural
bent
,
and
would
have
been
evoked
by
anybody
else
,
if
I
had
left
them
slumbering
.
<EOS>
But
Herbert
's
was
a
very
different
case
,
and
it
often
caused
me
a
twinge
to
think
that
I
had
done
him
evil
service
in
crowding
his
sparely
-
furnished
chambers
with
incongruous
upholstery
work
,
and
placing
the
canary
-
breasted
Avenger
at
his
disposal
.
  
<EOS>
So
now
,
as
an
infallible
way
of
making
little
ease
<EOS>
great
ease
<EOS>
,
I
began
to
contract
a
quantity
of
debt
.
<EOS>
I
could
hardly
begin
but
Herbert
must
begin
too
,
so
he
soon
followed
.
<EOS>
At
Startop
's
suggestion
,
we
put
ourselves
down
for
election
into
a
club
called
The
Finches
of
the
Grove
:
the
object
of
which
institution
<EOS>
I
have
never
divined
,
if
it
were
not
that
the
members
should
dine
expensively
once
a
fortnight
,
to
quarrel
among
themselves
as
much
as
possible
after
dinner
,
and
to
cause
six
waiters
to
get
drunk
on
the
stairs
.
<EOS>
I
know
that
these
gratifying
social
ends
were
so
invariably
accomplished
,
that
Herbert
and
I
understood
nothing
else
to
be
referred
to
in
the
first
standing
toast
of
the
society
:
which
ran
"
Gentlemen
,
may
the
present
promotion
of
good
feeling
ever
reign
predominant
among
the
Finches
of
the
Grove
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
Finches
spent
their
money
foolishly
(
the
Hotel
we
dined
at
was
in
Covent
-
garden
)
,
and
the
first
Finch
I
saw
,
when
I
had
the
honour
of
joining
the
Grove
,
was
Bentley
Drummle
:
at
that
time
floundering
about
town
in
a
cab
of
his
own
,
and
doing
a
great
deal
of
damage
to
the
posts
at
the
street
corners
.
<EOS>
Occasionally
,
he
shot
himself
out
of
his
equipage
head
-
foremost
over
the
apron
;
and
I
saw
him
on
one
occasion
deliver
himself
at
the
door
of
the
Grove
in
this
unintentional
way
---
like
coals
.
<EOS>
But
here
I
anticipate
a
little
.
<EOS>
for
I
was
not
a
Finch
,
and
could
not
be
,
according
to
the
sacred
laws
of
the
society
,
until
I
came
of
age
.
  
<EOS>
In
my
confidence
in
my
own
resources
,
I
would
willingly
have
taken
Herbert
's
expenses
on
myself
;
but
Herbert
was
proud
,
and
I
could
make
no
such
proposal
to
him
.
<EOS>
So
,
he
got
into
difficulties
in
every
direction
,
and
continued
to
look
about
him
.
<EOS>
When
we
gradually
fell
into
keeping
late
hours
and
late
company
,
I
noticed
that
he
looked
about
him
with
a
desponding
eye
at
breakfast
-
time
;
that
he
began
to
look
about
him
more
hopefully
about
mid
-
day
;
that
he
drooped
when
he
came
into
dinner
;
that
he
seemed
to
descry
Capital
in
the
distance
rather
clearly
,
after
dinner
;
that
he
all
but
realized
Capital
towards
midnight
;
and
that
at
about
two
o'clock
in
the
morning
,
he
became
so
deeply
despondent
again
as
to
talk
of
buying
a
rifle
and
going
to
America
,
with
a
general
purpose
of
compelling
buffaloes
to
make
his
fortune
.
  
<EOS>
I
was
usually
at
Hammersmith
about
half
the
week
,
and
when
I
was
at
Hammersmith
<EOS>
I
haunted
Richmond
:
whereof
separately
by
-
and
-
by
.
<EOS>
Herbert
would
often
come
to
Hammersmith
when
I
was
there
,
and
I
think
at
those
seasons
his
father
would
occasionally
have
some
passing
perception
that
the
opening
he
was
looking
for
,
had
not
appeared
yet
.
<EOS>
But
in
the
general
tumbling
up
of
the
family
,
his
tumbling
out
in
life
somewhere
,
was
a
thing
to
transact
itself
somehow
.
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
Mr
Pocket
grew
greyer
,
and
tried
oftener
to
lift
himself
out
of
his
perplexities
by
the
hair
.
<EOS>
While
Mrs
Pocket
tripped
up
the
family
with
her
footstool
,
read
her
book
of
dignities
,
lost
her
pocket
-
handkerchief
,
told
us
about
her
grandpapa
,
and
taught
the
young
idea
how
to
shoot
,
by
shooting
it
into
bed
whenever
it
attracted
her
notice
.
  
<EOS>
As
I
am
now
generalizing
a
period
of
my
life
with
the
object
of
clearing
my
way
before
me
,
I
can
scarcely
do
so
better
than
by
at
once
completing
the
description
of
our
usual
manners
and
customs
at
Barnard
's
Inn
.
  
<EOS>
We
spent
as
much
money
as
we
could
,
and
got
as
little
for
it
as
people
could
make
up
their
minds
to
give
us
.
<EOS>
We
were
always
more
or
less
miserable
,
and
most
of
our
acquaintance
were
in
the
same
condition
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
gay
fiction
among
us
that
we
were
constantly
enjoying
ourselves
,
and
a
skeleton
truth
that
we
never
did
.
<EOS>
To
the
best
of
my
belief
,
our
case
was
in
the
last
aspect
a
rather
common
one
.
  
<EOS>
Every
morning
,
with
an
air
ever
new
,
Herbert
went
into
the
City
to
look
about
him
.
<EOS>
I
often
paid
him
a
visit
in
the
dark
back
-
room
in
which
he
consorted
with
an
ink
-
jar
,
a
hat
-
peg
,
a
coal
-
box
,
a
string
-
box
,
an
almanack
,
a
desk
and
stool
,
and
a
ruler
;
and
I
do
not
remember
that
I
ever
saw
him
do
anything
else
but
look
about
him
.
<EOS>
If
we
all
did
what
we
undertake
to
do
,
as
faithfully
as
Herbert
did
,
we
might
live
in
a
Republic
of
the
Virtues
.
<EOS>
He
had
nothing
else
to
do
,
poor
fellow
,
except
at
a
certain
hour
of
every
afternoon
to
"
go
to
Lloyd
's
"
---
in
observance
of
a
ceremony
of
seeing
his
principal
,
I
think
.
<EOS>
He
never
did
anything
else
in
connexion
with
Lloyd
's
that
I
could
find
out
,
except
come
back
again
.
<EOS>
When
he
felt
his
case
unusually
serious
,
and
that
he
positively
must
find
an
opening
,
he
would
go
on
'
Change
at
a
busy
time
,
and
walk
in
and
out
,
in
a
kind
of
gloomy
country
dance
figure
,
among
the
assembled
magnates
.
<EOS>
"
For
,
"
says
Herbert
to
me
,
coming
home
to
dinner
on
one
of
those
special
occasions
,
"
I
find
the
truth
to
be
,
Handel
,
that
an
opening
wo
n't
come
to
one
,
but
one
must
go
to
it
---
so
I
have
been
.
"
  
<EOS>
If
we
had
been
less
attached
to
one
another
,
I
think
we
must
have
hated
one
another
regularly
every
morning
.
<EOS>
I
detested
the
chambers
beyond
expression
at
that
period
of
repentance
,
and
could
not
endure
the
sight
of
the
Avenger
's
livery
:
which
had
a
more
expensive
and
a
less
remunerative
appearance
then
,
than
at
any
other
time
in
the
four
-
and
-
twenty
hours
.
<EOS>
As
we
got
more
and
more
into
debt
,
breakfast
became
a
hollower
and
hollower
form
,
and
,
being
on
one
occasion
at
breakfast
-
time
threatened
(
by
letter
)
with
legal
proceedings
,
"
not
unwholly
unconnected
,
"
as
my
local
paper
might
put
it
,
"
with
jewellery
,
"
I
went
so
far
as
to
seize
the
Avenger
by
his
blue
collar
and
shake
him
off
his
feet
---
so
that
he
was
actually
in
the
air
,
like
a
booted
Cupid
---
for
presuming
to
suppose
that
we
wanted
a
roll
.
  
<EOS>
At
certain
times
---
meaning
at
uncertain
times
,
for
they
depended
on
our
humour
---
I
would
say
to
Herbert
,
as
if
it
were
a
remarkable
discovery
:
  
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Herbert
,
we
are
getting
on
badly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Handel
,
"
Herbert
would
say
to
me
,
in
all
sincerity
,
"
if
you
will
believe
me
,
those
very
words
were
on
my
lips
,
by
a
strange
coincidence
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
,
Herbert
,
"
I
would
respond
,
"
let
us
look
into
our
affairs
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
We
always
derived
profound
satisfaction
from
making
an
appointment
for
this
purpose
.
<EOS>
I
always
thought
this
was
business
,
this
was
the
way
to
confront
the
thing
,
this
was
the
way
to
take
the
foe
by
the
throat
.
<EOS>
And
I
know
Herbert
thought
so
too
.
  
<EOS>
We
ordered
something
rather
special
for
dinner
,
with
a
bottle
of
something
similarly
out
of
the
common
way
,
in
order
that
our
minds
might
be
fortified
for
the
occasion
,
and
we
might
come
well
up
to
the
mark
.
<EOS>
Dinner
over
,
we
produced
a
bundle
of
pens
,
a
copious
supply
of
ink
,
and
a
goodly
show
of
writing
and
blotting
paper
.
<EOS>
For
,
there
was
something
very
comfortable
in
having
plenty
of
stationery
.
  
<EOS>
I
would
then
take
a
sheet
of
paper
,
and
write
across
the
top
of
it
,
in
a
neat
hand
,
the
heading
,
"
Memorandum
of
Pip
's
debts
;
"
with
Barnard
's
Inn
and
the
date
very
carefully
added
.
<EOS>
Herbert
would
also
take
a
sheet
of
paper
,
and
write
across
it
with
similar
formalities
,
"
Memorandum
of
Herbert
's
debts
.
"
  
<EOS>
Each
of
us
would
then
refer
to
a
confused
heap
of
papers
at
his
side
,
which
had
been
thrown
into
drawers
,
worn
into
holes
in
pockets
,
half
-
burnt
in
lighting
candles
,
stuck
for
weeks
into
the
looking
-
glass
,
and
otherwise
damaged
.
<EOS>
The
sound
of
our
pens
going
,
refreshed
us
exceedingly
,
insomuch
that
I
sometimes
found
it
difficult
to
distinguish
between
this
edifying
business
proceeding
and
actually
paying
the
money
.
<EOS>
In
point
of
meritorious
character
,
the
two
things
seemed
about
equal
.
  
<EOS>
When
we
had
written
a
little
while
,
I
would
ask
Herbert
how
he
got
on
?
<EOS>
Herbert
probably
would
have
been
scratching
his
head
in
a
most
rueful
manner
at
the
sight
of
his
accumulating
figures
.
  
<EOS>
"
They
are
mounting
up
,
Handel
,
"
Herbert
would
say
;
"
upon
my
life
,
they
are
mounting
up
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Be
firm
,
Herbert
,
"
I
would
retort
,
plying
my
own
pen
with
great
assiduity
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Look
the
thing
in
the
face
.
<EOS>
Look
into
your
affairs
.
<EOS>
Stare
them
out
of
countenance
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
So
I
would
,
Handel
,
only
they
are
staring
 
<EOS>
\
<EOS>
me
<EOS>
\
 
out
of
countenance
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
However
,
my
determined
manner
would
have
its
effect
,
and
Herbert
would
fall
to
work
again
.
<EOS>
After
a
time
he
would
give
up
once
more
,
on
the
plea
that
he
had
not
got
Cobbs
's
bill
,
or
Lobbs
's
,
or
Nobbs
's
,
as
the
case
might
be
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
,
Herbert
estimate
;
estimate
it
in
round
numbers
,
and
put
it
down
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
a
fellow
of
resource
you
are
!
"
<EOS>
my
friend
would
reply
,
with
admiration
.
"
<EOS>
Really
your
business
powers
are
very
remarkable
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
thought
so
too
.
<EOS>
I
established
with
myself
on
these
occasions
,
the
reputation
of
a
first
-
rate
man
of
business
---
prompt
,
decisive
,
energetic
,
clear
,
cool
-
headed
.
<EOS>
When
I
had
got
all
my
responsibilities
down
upon
my
list
,
I
compared
each
with
the
bill
,
and
ticked
it
off
.
<EOS>
My
self
-
approval
when
I
ticked
an
entry
was
quite
a
luxurious
sensation
.
<EOS>
When
I
had
no
more
ticks
to
make
,
I
folded
all
my
bills
up
uniformly
,
docketed
each
on
the
back
,
and
tied
the
whole
into
a
symmetrical
bundle
.
<EOS>
Then
I
did
the
same
for
Herbert
(
who
modestly
said
he
had
not
my
administrative
genius
)
,
and
felt
that
I
had
brought
his
affairs
into
a
focus
for
him
.
  
<EOS>
My
business
habits
had
one
other
bright
feature
,
which
I
called
"
leaving
a
Margin
.
<EOS>
"
For
example
;
supposing
Herbert
's
debts
to
be
one
hundred
and
sixty
-
four
pounds
four
-
and
-
twopence
,
I
would
say
,
"
Leave
a
margin
,
and
put
them
down
at
two
hundred
.
"
<EOS>
Or
,
supposing
my
own
to
be
four
times
as
much
,
I
would
leave
a
margin
,
and
put
them
down
at
seven
hundred
.
<EOS>
I
had
the
highest
opinion
of
the
wisdom
of
this
same
Margin
,
but
I
am
bound
to
acknowledge
that
on
looking
back
,
I
deem
it
to
have
been
an
expensive
device
.
<EOS>
For
,
we
always
ran
into
new
debt
immediately
,
to
the
full
extent
of
the
margin
,
and
sometimes
,
in
the
sense
of
freedom
and
solvency
it
imparted
,
got
pretty
far
on
into
another
margin
.
  
<EOS>
But
there
was
a
calm
,
a
rest
,
a
virtuous
hush
,
consequent
on
these
examinations
of
our
affairs
that
gave
me
,
for
the
time
,
an
admirable
opinion
of
myself
.
<EOS>
Soothed
by
my
exertions
,
my
method
,
and
Herbert
's
compliments
,
I
would
sit
with
his
symmetrical
bundle
and
my
own
on
the
table
before
me
among
the
stationery
,
and
feel
like
a
Bank
of
some
sort
,
rather
than
a
private
individual
.
  
<EOS>
We
shut
our
outer
door
on
these
solemn
occasions
,
in
order
that
we
might
not
be
interrupted
.
<EOS>
I
had
fallen
into
my
serene
state
one
evening
,
when
we
heard
a
letter
dropped
through
the
slit
in
the
said
door
,
and
fall
on
the
ground
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
for
you
,
Handel
,
"
said
Herbert
,
going
out
and
coming
back
with
it
,
"
<EOS>
and
I
hope
there
is
nothing
the
matter
.
<EOS>
"
This
was
in
allusion
to
its
heavy

and
border
.
  
<EOS>
The

was
signed
TRABB
&
CO
,
and
its
contents
were
simply
,
that
I
was
an
honoured

,
and
that
they

to
inform

that
Mrs
J
Gargery
had
departed
this
life
on
Monday

,
at
twenty

six
in
the
evening
,
and
that
my
attendance
was
requested
at
the
interment
on
Monday
next
at
three
o'clock
in
the
afternoon
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
35
 
IT
was
the
first
time
that
a
grave
had
opened
in
my
road
of
life
,
and
the
gap
it
made
in
the
smooth
ground
was
wonderful
.
<EOS>
The
figure
of
my
sister
in
her
chair
by
the
kitchen
fire
,
haunted
me
night
and
day
.
<EOS>
That
the
place
could
possibly
be
,
without
her
,
was
something
my
mind
seemed
unable
to
compass
;
and
whereas
she
had
seldom
or
never
been
in
my
thoughts
of
late
,
I
had
now
the
strangest
ideas
that
she
was
coming
towards
me
in
the
street
,
or
that
she
would
presently
knock
at
the
door
.
<EOS>
In
my
rooms
too
,
with
which
she
had
never
been
at
all
associated
,
there
was
at
once
the
blankness
of
death
and
a
perpetual
suggestion
of
the
sound
of
her
voice
or
the
turn
of
her
face
or
figure
,
as
if
she
were
still
alive
and
had
been
often
there
.
  
<EOS>
Whatever
my
fortunes
might
have
been
,
I
could
scarcely
have
recalled
my
sister
with
much
tenderness
.
<EOS>
But
I
suppose
there
is
a
shock
of
regret
which
may
exist
without
much
tenderness
.
<EOS>
Under
its
influence
(
and
perhaps
to
make
up
for
the
want
of
the
softer

)
I
was
seized
with
a
violent
indignation
against
the
assailant
from
whom
she
had
suffered
so
much
;
and
I
felt
that
on
sufficient
proof
I
could
have
revengefully
pursued
Orlick
,
or
any
one
else
,
to
the
last

.
  
<EOS>
Having
written
to
Joe
,
to

,
and
to

that
I
should
come
to
the

,
I
passed
the

days
in
the
curious
state
of
mind
I
have
glanced
at
.
<EOS>
I
went
down
early
in
the
morning
,
and
alighted
at
the
Blue
Boar
in
good
time
to
walk
over
to
the
forge
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
fine
summer
weather
again
,
and
,
as
I

along
,
the
times
when
I
was
a
little

,
and
my
sister
did
not

,
vividly

.
<EOS>
But

upon

that

edge
of
Tickler
.
<EOS>
For

,

that
the

when

well

memory
that
others

in
the

.
  
<EOS>
At

,

that
Trabb

Co.

put

.
<EOS>
Two

,

---
as

---

from
the
Boar
for

bridal

,
in

<EOS>
clasped

.
<EOS>
All

,

,

.
  
<EOS>

,

)

,

.
<EOS>
Here
,

,

,

black

---

.

\
<EOS>
Here
\
 
they

!
"
<EOS>
"
\
<EOS>
Here
\

!
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
Of

,

;

,

,

.

.

.

---
to

it
<EOS>
,
I

,

.
  
<EOS>

,

:

,

.
<EOS>
Soon

,

,

,

,

;

,

,

.

,

:

,

Man

.
  
<EOS>
He

"

.

"

?
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

?
"
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
do
so
,
Mr
Pip
,
"

Biddy
,
in

,
but

.
<EOS>
"
I

speaking

,

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How

<EOS>
If

mo
---
"
  
"
How

?
"
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

,
Mr

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
You

,
Mr

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
Except

"

.
  
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
So
,

.
  
<EOS>
"

"
  
<EOS>
"
They

.
<EOS>
She

---

"
Joe
.
"
<EOS>

,

Mr

.
<EOS>
She

,

<EOS>
And

"
<EOS>
Joe

"

.

<EOS>
Biddy

;
the

,

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
---

"

I

,

<EOS>
By

,

she

,
of

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
Biddy

<EOS>

"

,

<EOS>
"
This

!
<EOS>
Do

,

,

.
<EOS>
This

.
"
  
<EOS>
For

,

,

,

,
deem

.
<EOS>
As

,

,

,

,
what

,
Biddy

.
  
<EOS>
Early
in

morning
,
I
was
to

.
<EOS>
Early

morning
,
I
was

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
There

,

,

that

.

"

!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
No

!
<EOS>
---

.

<EOS>
"
Never

,

,
"

Joe
,
"

Pip
!
"
  
<EOS>
Biddy

,

.

Biddy
,
"

,

"
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

,
"
she

;
"
let

,

I

.
"
  
<EOS>
Once

,
the
mists
were
rising
as

.
<EOS>
If

disclosed

,
as

,
that

should
not

back
,
and
that
Biddy
was
quite
right
,
all
I
can
say
is
---
they
were
quite
right
too
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
36
 
HERBERT
<EOS>
and
I
went
on
from
bad
to
worse
,
in
the
way
of
increasing
our
debts
,
looking
into
our
affairs
,
leaving
Margins
,
and
the
like
exemplary
transactions
;
and
Time
went
on
,
whether
or
no
,
as
he
has
a
way
of
doing
;
and
I
came
of
age
---
in
fulfilment
of
Herbert
's
prediction
,
that
I
should
do
so
before
I
knew
where
I
was
.
  
<EOS>
Herbert
himself
had
come
of
age
,
eight
months
before
me
.
<EOS>
As
he
had
nothing
else
than
his
majority
to
come
into
,
the
event
did
not
make
a
profound
sensation
in
Barnard
's
Inn
.
<EOS>
But
we
had
looked
forward
to
my
one
-
and
-
twentieth
birthday
,
with
a
crowd
of
speculations
and
anticipations
,
for
we
had
both
considered
that
my
guardian
could
hardly
help
saying
something
definite
on
that
occasion
.
  
<EOS>
I
had
taken
care
to
have
it
well
understood
in
Little
Britain
,
when
my
birthday
was
.
<EOS>
On
the
day
before
it
,
I
received
an
official
note
from
Wemmick
,
informing
me
that
Mr
Jaggers
would
be
glad
if
I
would
call
upon
him
at
five
in
the
afternoon
of
the
auspicious
day
.
<EOS>
This
convinced
us
that
something
great
was
to
happen
,
and
threw
me
into
an
unusual
flutter
when
I
repaired
to
my
guardian
's
office
,
a
model
of
punctuality
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
outer
office
Wemmick
offered
me
his
congratulations
,
and
incidentally
rubbed
the
side
of
his
nose
with
a
folded
piece
of
tissue
-
paper
that
I
liked
the
look
of
.
<EOS>
But
he
said
nothing
respecting
it
,
and
motioned
me
with
a
nod
into
my
guardian
's
room
.
<EOS>
It
was
November
,
and
my
guardian
was
standing
before
his
fire
leaning
his
back
against
the
chimney
-
piece
,
with
his
hands
under
his
coat
-
tails
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Pip
,
"
said
he
,
"
I
must
call
you
Mr
Pip
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
Congratulations
,
Mr
Pip
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
We
shook
hands
---
he
was
always
a
remarkably
short
shaker
---
and
I
thanked
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Take
a
chair
,
Mr
Pip
,
"
said
my
guardian
.
  
<EOS>
As
I
sat
down
,
and
he
preserved
his
attitude
and
bent
his
brows
at
his
boots
,
I
felt
at
a
disadvantage
,
which
reminded
me
of
that
old
time
when
I
had
been
put
upon
a
tombstone
.
<EOS>
The
two
ghastly
casts
on
the
shelf
were
not
far
from
him
,
and
their
expression
was
as
if
they
were
making
a
stupid
apoplectic
attempt
to
attend
to
the
conversation
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
my
young
friend
,
"
my
guardian
began
,
as
if
I
were
a
witness
in
the
box
,
"
I
am
going
to
have
a
word
or
two
with
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
please
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
suppose
,
"
said
Mr
Jaggers
,
bending

to

at

ground
,
and
then

back
to

,
"
what
do
you
suppose
you
are
living

the
rate

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
At
the
rate
of
,

?
"
  
"
At
"

Mr
Jaggers
,
still

,
"
the
---
rate
---
of
?
"
And
then
looked
all
round
the
room
,
and
paused
with

pocket
-

in

hand
,
half

.
  
<EOS>
I
had
looked
into
my
affairs
so
often
,
that
I
had
thoroughly
destroyed
any
slight
notion
I
might
ever
have
had
of
their
bearings
.
<EOS>
Reluctantly
,
I
confessed
myself
quite
unable
to
answer
the
question
.
<EOS>
This
reply
seemed
agreeable
to
Mr
Jaggers
,
who
said
,
"
I
thought
so
!
"
and
blew
his
nose
with
an
air

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
I
have
asked
 
\
<EOS>
you
\
 
<EOS>
a

,
my

,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Have
you
anything
to
ask
 
\
me
?
"
<EOS>
\
   
<EOS>
"
Of

would

,
sir
;
but
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ask

,
"
said

Jaggers
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
.
Ask

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Waive

,

,
"
said
Mr
Jaggers
,
"
and

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
looked
about
me
,
but
there
appeared
to
be
now
no
possible
escape
from
the
inquiry
,
"
Have
---
<EOS>
I
---
anything
to
receive
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
On
that
,
Mr
Jaggers
said
,
triumphantly
,
"
I
thought
we
should
come
to
it
!
"
and
called
to
Wemmick
to
give
him
that
piece
of
paper
.
<EOS>
Wemmick
appeared
,
handed
it
in
,
and
disappeared
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Mr
Pip
,
"
said
Mr
Jaggers
,
"
attend
,
if
you
please
.
<EOS>
You
have
been
drawing
pretty
freely
here
;
your
name
occurs
pretty
often
in
Wemmick
's
cash
-
book
;
but
you
are
in
debt
,
of
course
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
afraid
I
must
say
yes
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
know
you
must
say
yes
;
do
n't
you
?
"
said
Mr
Jaggers
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
ask
you
what
you
owe
,
because
you
do
n't
know
;
and
if
you
did
know
,
you
would
n't
tell
me
;
you
would
say
less
.
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes
,
my
friend
,
"
cried
Mr
Jaggers
,
waving
his
forefinger
to
stop
me
,
as
I
made
a
show
of
protesting
:
<EOS>
"
it
's
likely
enough
that
you
think
you
would
n't
,
but
you
would
.
<EOS>
You
'll
excuse
me
,
but
I
know
better
than
you
.
<EOS>
Now
,
take
this
piece
of
paper
in
your
hand
.
<EOS>
You
have
got
it
?
<EOS>
Very
good
.
<EOS>
Now
,
unfold
it
and
tell
me
what
it
is
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
bank
-
note
,
"
said
I
,
"
for
five
hundred
pounds
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
a
bank
-
note
,
"
repeated
Mr
Jaggers
,
"
for
five
hundred
pounds
.
<EOS>
And
a
very
handsome
sum
of
money
too
,
I
think
.
<EOS>
You
consider
it
so
?
  
<EOS>
"
How
could
I
do
otherwise
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
But
answer
the
question
,
"
said
Mr
Jaggers
.
  
<EOS>
"
Undoubtedly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
consider
it
,
undoubtedly
,
a
handsome
sum
of
money
.
<EOS>
Now
,
that
handsome
sum
of
money
,
Pip
,
is
your
own
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
present
to
you
on
this
day
,
in
earnest
of
your
expectations
.
<EOS>
And
at
the
rate
of
that
handsome
sum
of
money
per
annum
,
and
at
no
higher
rate
,
you
are
to
live
until
the
donor
of
the
whole
appears
.
<EOS>
That
is
to
say
,
you
will
now
take
your
money
affairs
entirely
into
your
own
hands
,
and
you
will
draw
from
Wemmick
one
hundred
and
twenty
-
five
pounds
per
quarter
,
until
you
are
in
communication
with
the
fountain
-
head
,
and
no
longer
with
the
mere
agent
.
<EOS>
As
I
have
told
you
before
,
I
am
the
mere
agent
.
<EOS>
I
execute
my
instructions
,
and
I
am
paid
for
doing
so
.
<EOS>
I
think
them
injudicious
,
but
I
am
not
paid
for
giving
any
opinion
on
their
merits
.
  
<EOS>
I
was
beginning
to
express
my
gratitude
to
my
benefactor
for
the
great
liberality
with
which
I
was
treated
,
when
Mr
Jaggers
stopped
me
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
paid
;
Pip
,
"
said
he
,
coolly
,
"
to
carry
your
words
to
any
one
;
"
and
then
gathered
up
his
coat
-
tails
,
as
he
had
gathered
up
the
subject
,
and
stood
frowning
at
his
boots
as
if
he
suspected
them
of
designs
against
him
.
  
<EOS>
After
a
pause
,
I
hinted
:
  
"
There
was
a
question
just
now
,
Mr
Jaggers
,
which
you
desired
me
to
waive
for
a
moment
.
<EOS>
I
hope
I
am
doing
nothing
wrong
in
asking
it
again
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
?
"
said
he
.
  
<EOS>
I
might
have
known
that
he
would
never
help
me
out
;
but
it
took
me
aback
to
have
to
shape
the
question
afresh
,
as
if
it
were
quite
new
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Is
it
likely
,
"
I
said
,
after
hesitating
,
"
that
my
patron
,
the
fountain
-
head
you
have
spoken
of
,
Mr
Jaggers
,
will
soon
---
"
there
I
delicately
stopped
.
  
<EOS>
"
Will
soon
what
?
"
asked
Mr
Jaggers
.
<EOS>
"
That
's
no
question
as
it
stands
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Will
soon
come
to
London
,
"
said
I
,
after
casting
about
for
a
precise
form
of
words
,
"
or
summon
me
anywhere
else
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Now
here
,
"
replied
Mr
Jaggers
,
fixing
me
for
the
first
time
with
his
dark
deep
-
set
eyes
,
"
we
must
revert
to
the
evening
when
we
first
encountered
one
another
in
your
village
.
<EOS>
What
did
I
tell
you
then
,
Pip
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
told
me
,
Mr
Jaggers
,
that
it
might
be
years
hence
when
that
person
appeared
.
"
  
"
Just
so
,
"
said
Mr
Jaggers
;
"
that
's
my
answer
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
As
we
looked
full
at
one
another
,
I
felt
my
breath
come
quicker
in
my
strong
desire
to
get
something
out
of
him
.
<EOS>
And
as
I
felt
that
it
came
quicker
,
and
as
I
felt
that
he
saw
that
it
came
quicker
,
I
felt
that
I
had
less
chance
than
ever
of
getting
anything
out
of
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
suppose
it
will
still
be
years
hence
,
Mr
Jaggers
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr
Jaggers
shook
his
head
---
not
in
negativing
the
question
,
but
in
altogether
negativing
the
notion
that
he
could
anyhow
be
got
to
answer
it
---
and
the
two
horrible
casts
of
the
twitched
faces
looked
,
when
my
eyes
strayed
up
to
them
,
as
if
they
had
come
to
a
crisis
in
their
suspended
attention
,
and
were
going
to
sneeze
.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
!
"
said
Mr
Jaggers
,
warming
the
backs
of
his
legs
with
the
backs
of
his
warmed
hands
,
"
I
'll
be
plain
with
you
,
my
friend
Pip
.
<EOS>
That
's
a
question
I
must
not
be
asked
.
<EOS>
You
'll
understand
that
,
better
,
when
I
tell
you
it
's
a
question
that
might
compromise
 
\
me
.
<EOS>
\
 
<EOS>
Come
!
<EOS>
I
'll
go
a
little
further
with
you
;
I
'll
say
something
more
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
bent
down
so
low
to
frown
at
his
boots
,
that
he
was
able
to
rub
the
calves
of
his
legs
in
the
pause
he
made
.
  
<EOS>
"
When
that
person
discloses
,
"
said
Mr
Jaggers
,
straightening
himself
,
"
you
and
that
person
will
settle
your
own
affairs
.
<EOS>
When
that
person
discloses
,
my
part
in
this
business
will
cease
and
determine
.
<EOS>
When
that
person
discloses
,
it
will
not
be
necessary
for
me
to
know
anything
about
it
.
<EOS>
And
that
's
all
I
have
got
to
say
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
We
looked
at
one
another
until
I
withdrew
my
eyes
,
and
looked
thoughtfully
at
the
floor
.
<EOS>
From
this
last
speech
I
derived
the
notion
that
Miss
Havisham
,
for
some
reason
or
no
reason
,
had
not
taken
him
into
her
confidence
as
to
her
designing
me
for
Estella
;
that
he
resented
this
,
and
felt
a
jealousy
about
it
;
or
that
he
really
did
object
to
that
scheme
,
and
would
have
nothing
to
do
with
it
.
<EOS>
Men
<EOS>
I
raised
my
eyes
again
<EOS>
,
I
found
that
he
had
been
shrewdly
looking
at
me
all
the
time
,
and
was
doing
so
still
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
that
is
all
you
have
to
say
,
sir
,
"
I
remarked
,
"
there
can
be
nothing
left
for
me
to
say
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
nodded
assent
,
and
pulled
out
his
thief
-
dreaded
watch
,
and
asked
me
where
I
was
going
to
dine
?
<EOS>
I
replied
at
my
own
chambers
,
with
Herbert
.
<EOS>
As
a
necessary
sequence
,
I
asked
him
if
he
would
favour
us
with
his
company
,
and
he
promptly
accepted
the
invitation
.
<EOS>
But
he
insisted
on
walking
home
with
me
,
in
order
that
I
might
make
no
extra
preparation
for
him
,
and
first
he
had
a
letter
or
two
to
write
,
and
(
of
course
)
had
his
hands
to
wash
.
<EOS>
So
,
I
said
I
would
go
into
the
outer
office
and
talk
to
Wemmick
.
  
<EOS>
The
fact
was
,
that
when
the
five
hundred
pounds
had
come
into
my
pocket
,
a
thought
had
come
into
my
head
which
had
been
often
there
before
;
and
it
appeared
to
me
that
Wemmick
was
a
good
person
to
advise
with
,
concerning
such
thought
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
already
locked
up
his
safe
,
and
made
preparations
for
going
home
.
<EOS>
He
had
left
his
desk
,
brought
out
his
two
greasy
office
candlesticks
and
stood
them
in
line
with
the
snuffers
on
a
slab
near
the
door
,
ready
to
be
extinguished
;
he
had
raked
his
fire
low
,
put
his
hat
and
great
-
coat
ready
,
and
was
beating
himself
all
over
the
chest
with
his
safe
-
key
,
as
an
athletic
exercise
after
business
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr
Wemmick
,
"
said
I
,
"
I
want
to
ask
your
opinion
.
<EOS>
I
am
very
desirous
to
serve
a
friend
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Wemmick
tightened
his
post
-
office
and
shook
his
head
,
as
if
his
opinion
were
dead
against
any
fatal
weakness
of
that
sort
.
  
<EOS>
"
This
friend
,
"
I
pursued
,
"
is
trying
to
get
on
in
commercial
life
,
but
has
no
money
,
and
finds
it
difficult
and
disheartening
to
make
a
beginning
.
<EOS>
Now
,
I
want
somehow
to
help
him
to
a
beginning
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
With
money
down
?
"
said
Wemmick
,
in
a
tone
drier
than
any
sawdust
.
  
<EOS>
"
With
 
\
some
\
 
money
down
,
"
I
replied
,
for
an
uneasy
remembrance
shot
across
me
of
that
symmetrical
bundle
of
papers
at
home
;
"
with
 
\
<EOS>
some
\
 
<EOS>
money
down
,
and
perhaps
some
anticipation
of
my
expectations
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr
Pip
,
"
said
Wemmick
,
"
I
should
like
just
to
run
over
with
you
on
my
fingers
,
if
you
please
,
the
names
of
the
various
bridges
up
as
high
as
Chelsea
Reach
.
<EOS>
Let
's
see
;
there
's
London
,
one
;
Southwark
,
two
;
Blackfriars
,
three
;
Waterloo
,
four
;
Westminster
,
five
;
Vauxhall
,
six
.
"
<EOS>
He
had
checked
off
each
bridge
in
its
turn
,
with
the
handle
of
his
safe
-
key
on
the
palm
of
his
hand
.
<EOS>
"
There
's
as
many
as
six
,
you
see
,
to
choose
from
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
understand
you
,
"
said
<EOS>
I.
  
"
Choose
your
bridge
,
Mr
Pip
,
"
returned
Wemmick
,
"
and
take
a
walk
upon
your
bridge
,
and
pitch
your
money
into
the
Thames
over
the
centre
arch
of
your
bridge
,
and
you
know
the
end
of
it
.
<EOS>
Serve
a
friend
with
it
,
and
you
may
know
the
end
of
it
too
---
but
it
's
a
less
pleasant
and
profitable
end
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
could
have
posted
a
newspaper
in
his
mouth
,
he
made
it
so
wide
after
saying
this
.
  
<EOS>
"
This
is
very
discouraging
,
"
said
I.
  
"
<EOS>
Meant
to
be
so
,
"
said
Wemmick
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
is
it
your
opinion
,
"
I
inquired
,
with
some
little
indignation
,
"
that
a
man
should
never
---
"
  
"
---
Invest
portable
property
in
a
friend
?
"
said
Wemmick
.
<EOS>
"
Certainly
he
should
not
.
<EOS>
Unless
he
wants
to
get
rid
of
the
friend
---
and
then
it
becomes
a
question
how
much
portable
property
it
may
be
worth
to
get
rid
of
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
that
,
"
said
I
,
"
is
your
deliberate
opinion
,
Mr
Wemmick
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
,
"
he
returned
,
"
is
my
deliberate
opinion
in
this
office
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
"
said
I
,
pressing
him
,
for
I
thought
I
saw
him
near
a
loophole
here
;
"
but
would
that
be
your
opinion
at
Walworth
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr
Pip
,
"
he
replied
,
with
gravity
,
"
Walworth
is
one
place
,
and
this
office
is
another
.
<EOS>
Much
as
the
Aged
is
one
person
,
and
Mr
Jaggers
is
another
.
<EOS>
They
must
not
be
confounded
together
.
<EOS>
My
Walworth
sentiments
must
be
taken
at
Walworth
;
none
but
my
official
sentiments
can
be
taken
in
this
office
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very
well
,
"
said
I
,
much
relieved
,
"
then
I
shall
look
you
up
at
Walworth
,
you
may
depend
upon
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr
Pip
,
"
he
returned
,
"
you
will
be
welcome
there
,
in
a
private
and
personal
capacity
.
"
  
<EOS>
We
had
held
this
conversation
in
a
low
voice
,
well
knowing
my
guardian
's
ears
to
be
the
sharpest
of
the
sharp
.
<EOS>
As
he
now
appeared
in
his
doorway
,
towelling
his
hands
,
Wemmick
got
on
his
great
-
coat
and
stood
by
to
snuff
out
the
candles
.
<EOS>
We
all
three
went
into
the
street
together
,
and
from
the
door
-
step
Wemmick
turned
his
way
,
and
Mr
Jaggers
and
I
turned

.
  
<EOS>
I

<EOS>

<EOS>
Chapter

DEEMING

<EOS>
The

,

<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
The
Aged

;

,
that
the
pig
in

back
premises
became
strongly

,
and
repeatedly

participate

the

.
 
<EOS>
The
flag
had

,
and

had

,
at
the
right
moment
of
time
,
and
I

.
<EOS>
Nothing

,

of
John
and
Miss
Skiffins
:
which
little
doors
were
a
prey
to
some

that
made

until
I

used

.
<EOS>
I
inferred

there

;
and
I
rather

that
a
classic

she

,

with

,

.
  
<EOS>
We

,
and

,

warn

.
<EOS>
The
Aged
especially
,
might
have
passed

,
just

.
<EOS>
After

---

,

,

.
<EOS>
Then
,

,

,

,
"

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
Wemmick
explained

while
the
Aged

,
that
this
was
according

,
and

.
<EOS>
"
I
wo

"

,
"

many

<EOS>
---

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
All

,

,

"

.
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

"

,
"

.
<EOS>
We

attention
,
Aged
One
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
All

,
John
,
all

!
"
returned
the

old
man
:
so

and

,
that
it
really

.
  
<EOS>
The
Aged
's

reminded

of
the
classes
at
Mr
Wopsle
's
great
-
aunt
's
,
with
the

that

.
<EOS>
As

close

,

into

,

.
<EOS>
But
Wemmick
was
equally

,
and

Aged
read
on
,
quite
unconscious
of
his
many

.
<EOS>
Whenever

looked
at
us
,
we

greatest
interest
and

,
and
nodded
until
he

.
  
<EOS>
As

,

,

of

round

Skiffins
's

.
<EOS>
In

Skiffins
;

with

green
  
glove
,

again

,

.

Miss

.
  
<EOS>
By
-

,

,

<EOS>
Shortly

,

<EOS>

Skiffins
.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
At

.
<EOS>
This

,

:

,

<EOS>
Miss

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
At

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
A

,

,

.

.
<EOS>
It

to

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
38
 
Is
that
staid
old
house
near
the
Green
at
Richmond
should
ever
come
to
be
haunted
when
I
am
dead
,
it
will
be
haunted
,
surely
,
by
my
ghost
.
<EOS>
O
the
many
,
many
nights
and

through
which
the
unquiet
spirit
within
me
haunted
that
house
when
Estella
lived
there
!
<EOS>
Let
my
body
be
where
it
would
,
my
spirit
was
always
wandering
,
wandering
,
wandering
,
about
that
house
.
  
<EOS>
The
lady
with
whom
Estella
was
placed
,
Mrs
Brandley
by
name
,
was
a
widow
,
with
one
daughter
several
years
older
than
Estella
.
<EOS>
The
mother
looked
young
,
and
the
daughter
looked
old
;
the
mother
's

was
pink
,
and
the
daughter
's
was
yellow
;
the
mother
set
up
for

,
and
the
daughter
for
theology
.
<EOS>
They
were
in
what
is
called
a
good
position
,
and
visited
,
and
were
visited

,
numbers

people
.
<EOS>
Little
,

,

between

Estella
,
but
the
understanding
was
established
that

were
necessary
to
her
,
and
that
she
was

to
them
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Brandley
had
been
a
friend
of
Miss
Havisham
's
before
the
time
of
her

.
  
<EOS>
In
Mrs
Brandley
's

and

Mrs
Brandley
's

,
I
suffered
every
kind
and
degree

that
Estella
could

.
<EOS>
The
nature
of
my
relations
with
her
,
which
placed
me
on
terms
of
familiarity
without
placing
me

,
conduced
to
my

.
<EOS>
She
made
use
of
me
to
tease
other

,
and
she
turned
the
very
familiarity
between
herself
and
me
,
to
the
account
of
putting
a
constant
slight
on
my

to
her
.
<EOS>
If
I
had
been
her
secretary
,
steward
,
half
-
brother
,
poor
relation
---
if
I
had
been
a
younger

of
her
appointed

---
I
could
not
have
seemed
to
myself
,
further
from
my
hopes
when
I
was
nearest
to
her
.
<EOS>
The

of
calling
her
by
her

and

,
became
under
the

an

of
my

;
and
while
I
think
it
likely
that
it
almost
maddened
her
other
lovers
,
I
know
too
certainly
that
it
almost
maddened
me
.
  
<EOS>
She
had
admirers
without
end
.
<EOS>
No
doubt
my
jealousy
made
an
admirer
of
every
one
who
went
near
her
;
but
there
were
more
than

.
  
<EOS>
I
saw
her
often
at
Richmond
,
I

,
and

;

,

---

.
<EOS>
I
never

one

's

,
and

mind
all
round
<EOS>
the

with

.
  
<EOS>
Throughout

---

,

,

I

time
<EOS>
---

.
<EOS>
There

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Pip
,
Pip
,
"

,

"

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Of

?
"
  
"

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Warning

,

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do

!
<EOS>
If

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
should

Love
was
commonly

,
but
for
the
reason
that
I
always
was

---
and

---

,

.
<EOS>
My

,
that
this

her

laid

with
her

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
At

rate
"

,
"

given

,

you
wrote

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
true
"

Estella
,
with
a
cold

.
  
<EOS>
After

,

,

:
  
<EOS>
"
The

round

.
<EOS>
You

,

<EOS>
She

,

Can

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

!
"

"

?

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
And

,
"

,

:
<EOS>
Miss
Havisham

,

.
<EOS>
We

but

,

,

House
.
  
<EOS>
She
was

;

,

.
<EOS>
She
hung

's

,

,

,

her
own

,
as
though

were
devouring
the
beautiful
creature
she
had
reared
.
  
<EOS>
From
Estella
she
looked
at
me
,
with
a

that
seemed
to
pry

my
heart
and

.
<EOS>
"
How
does
she
use
you
,
Pip
;
how
does
she
use
you
?
"
<EOS>
she
asked
me
again
,
with
her
witch
-
like
eagerness
,
even
in
Estella
's
hearing
.
<EOS>
But
,
when
we
sat
by
her
flickering
fire
at
night
,
she
was
most
weird
;
for
then
,
keeping
Estella
's
hand
drawn
through
her
arm
and
clutched
in
her
own
hand
,
she
extorted
from
her
,
by
dint
of
referring
back
to
what
Estella
had
told
her
in
her
regular
letters
,
the
names
and
conditions
of
the
men
whom
she
had
fascinated
;
and
as
Miss
Havisham
dwelt
upon
this
roll
,
with
the
intensity
of
a
mind
mortally
hurt
and
diseased
,
she
sat
with
her
other
hand
on
her
crutch
stick
,
and
her
chin
on
that
,
and
her
wan
bright
eyes
glaring
at
me
,
a
very
spectre
.
  
<EOS>
I
saw
in
this
,
wretched
though
it
made
me
,
and
bitter
the
sense
of
dependence
and
even
of
degradation
that
it
awakened
<EOS>
---
I
saw
in
this
,
that
Estella
was
set
to
wreak
Miss
Havisham
's
revenge
on
men
,
and
that
she
was
not
to
be
given
to
me
until
she
had
gratified
it
for
a
term
.
<EOS>
I
saw
in
this
,
a
reason
for
her
being
beforehand
assigned
to
me
.
<EOS>
Sending
her
out
to
attract
and
torment
and
do
mischief
,
Miss
Havisham
sent
her
with
the
malicious
assurance
that
she
was
beyond
the
reach
of
all
admirers
,
and
that
all
who
staked
upon
that
cast
were
secured
to
lose
.
<EOS>
I
saw
in
this
,
that
I
,
too
,
was
tormented
by
a
perversion
of
ingenuity
,
even
while
the
prize
was
reserved
for
me
.
<EOS>
I
saw
in
this
,
the
reason
for
my
being
staved
off
so
long
,
and
the
reason
for
my
late
guardian
's
declining
to
commit
himself
to
the
formal
knowledge
of
such
a
scheme
.
<EOS>
In
a
word
,
I
saw
in
this
,
Miss
Havisham
as
I
had
her
then
<EOS>
and
there
before
my
eyes
,
and
always
had
had
her
before
my
eyes
;
and
I
saw
in
this
,
the
distinct
shadow
of
the
darkened
and
unhealthy
house
in
which
her
life
was
hidden
from
the
sun
.
  
<EOS>
The
candles
that
lighted
that
room
of
hers
were
placed
in
sconces
on
the
wall
.
<EOS>
They
were
high
from
the
ground
,
and
they
burnt
with
the
steady
dulness
of
artificial
light
in
air
that
is
seldom
renewed
.
<EOS>
As
I
looked
round
at
them
,
and
at
the
pale
gloom
they
made
,
and
at
the
stopped
clock
,
and
at
the
withered
articles
of
bridal
dress
upon
the
table
and
the
ground
,
and
at
her
own
awful
figure
with
its
ghostly
reflection
thrown
large
by
the
fire
upon
the
ceiling
and
the
wall
,
I
saw
in
everything
the
construction
that
my
mind
had
come
to
,
repeated
and
thrown
back
to
me
.
<EOS>
My
thoughts
passed
into
the
great
room
across
the
landing
where
the
table
was
spread
,
and
I
saw
it
written
,
as
it
were
,
in
the
falls
of
the
cobwebs
from
the
centre
-
piece
,
in
the
crawlings
of
the
spiders
on
the
cloth
,
in
the
tracks
of
the
mice
as
they
betook
their
little
quickened
hearts
behind
the
panels
,
and
in
the
gropings
and
pausings
of
the
beetles
on
the
floor
.
  
<EOS>
It
happened
on
the
occasion
of
this
visit
that
some
sharp
words
arose
between
Estella
and
Miss
Havisham
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
first
time
I
had
ever
seen
them
opposed
.
  
<EOS>
We
were
seated
by
the
fire
,
as
just
now
described
,
and
Miss
Havisham
still
had
Estella
's
arm
drawn
through
her
own
,
and
still
clutched
Estella
's
hand
in
hers
,
when
Estella
gradually
began
to
detach
herself
.
<EOS>
She
had
shown
a
proud
impatience
more
than
once
before
,
and
had
rather
endured
that
fierce
affection
than
accepted
or
returned
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
!
"
said
Miss
Havisham
,
flashing
her
eyes
upon
her
,
"
are
you
tired
of
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Only
a
little
tired
of
myself
,
"
replied
Estella
,
disengaging
her
arm
,
and
moving
to
the
great
chimney
-
piece
,
where
she
stood
looking
down
at
the
fire
.
  
<EOS>
"
Speak
the
truth
,
you
ingrate
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Miss
Havisham
,
passionately
striking
her
stick
upon
the
floor
;
"
you
are
tired
of
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
Estella
looked
at
her
with
perfect
composure
,
and
again
looked
down
at
the
fire
.
<EOS>
Her
graceful
figure
and
her
beautiful
face
expressed
a
self
-
possessed
indifference
to
the
wild
heat
of
the
other
,
that
was
almost
cruel
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
stock
and
stone
!
"
exclaimed
Miss
Havisham
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
You
cold
,
cold
heart
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
?
"
said
Estella
,
preserving
her
attitude
of
indifference
as
she
leaned
against
the
great
chimney
-
piece
and
only
moving
her
eyes
;
"
do
you
reproach
me
for
being
cold
?
<EOS>
You
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
not
?
"
<EOS>
was
the
fierce
retort
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
should
know
,
"
said
Estella
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
what
you
have
made
me
.
<EOS>
Take
all
the
praise
,
take
all
the
blame
;
take
all
the
success
,
take
all
the
failure
;
in
short
,
take
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
O
,
look
at
her
,
look
at
her
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Miss
Havisham
,
bitterly
;
"
<EOS>
Look
at
her
,
so
hard
and
thankless
,
on
the
hearth
where
she
was
reared
!
<EOS>
Where
I
took
her
into
this
wretched
breast
when
it
was
first
bleeding
from
its
stabs
,
and
where
I
have
lavished
years
of
tenderness
upon
her
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
At
least
I
was
no
party
to
the
compact
,
"
said
Estella
,
"
<EOS>
for
if
I
could
walk
and
speak
,
when
it
was
made
,
it
was
as
much
as
I
could
do
.
<EOS>
But
what
would
you
have
?
<EOS>
You
have
been
very
good
to
me
,
and
I
owe
everything
to
you
.
<EOS>
What
would
you
have
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Love
,
"
replied
the
other
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
,
"
said
Miss
Havisham
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mother
by
adoption
,
"
retorted
Estella
,
never
departing
from
the
easy
grace
of
her
attitude
,
never
raising
her
voice
as
the
other
did
,
never
yielding
either
to
anger
or
tenderness
,
"
Mother
by
adoption
,
I
have
said
that
I
owe
everything
to
you
.
<EOS>
All
I
possess
is
freely
yours
.
<EOS>
All
that
you
have
given
me
,
is
at
your
command
to
have
again
.
<EOS>
Beyond
that
,
I
have
nothing
.
<EOS>
And
if
you
ask
me
to
give
you
what
you
never
gave
me
,
<EOS>
my
gratitude
and
duty
can
not
do
impossibilities
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did
I
never
give
her
love
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Miss
Havisham
,
turning
wildly
to
me
.
<EOS>
"
Did
I
never
give
her
a
burning
love
,
inseparable
from
jealousy
at
all
times
,
and
from
sharp
pain
,
while
she
speaks
thus
to
me
!
<EOS>
Let
her
call
me
mad
,
let
her
call
me
mad
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
should
I
call
you
mad
,
"
returned
Estella
,
"
I
,
of
all
people
?
<EOS>
Does
any
one
live
,
who
knows
what
set
purposes
you
have
,
half
as
well
as
I
do
?
<EOS>
Does
any
one
live
,
who
knows
what
a
steady
memory
you
have
,
half
as
well
as
I
do
?
<EOS>
I
who
have
sat
on
this
same
hearth
on
the
little
stool
that
is
even
now
beside
you
there
,
learning
your
lessons
and
looking
up
into
your
face
,
when
your
face
was
strange
and
frightened
me
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Soon
forgotten
!
"
<EOS>
moaned
Miss
Havisham
.
<EOS>
"
Times
soon
forgotten
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
not
forgotten
,
"
retorted
Estella
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
forgotten
,
but
treasured
up
in
my
memory
.
<EOS>
When
have
you
found
me
false
to
your
teaching
?
<EOS>
When
have
you
found
me
unmindful
of
your
lessons
?
<EOS>
When
have
you
found
me
giving
admission
here
,
"
she
touched
her
bosom
with
her
hand
,
"
to
anything
that
you
excluded
?
<EOS>
Be
just
to
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
proud
,
so
proud
!
"
moaned
Miss
Havisham
,
pushing
away
her
grey
hair
with
both
her
hands
.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
taught
me
to
be
proud
?
"
returned
Estella
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Who
praised
me
when
I
learnt
my
lesson
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
hard
,
so
hard
!
"
moaned
Miss
Havisham
,
with
her
former
action
.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
taught
me
to
be
hard
?
"
returned
Estella
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Who
praised
me
when
I
learnt
my
lesson
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
But
to
be
proud
and
hard
to
 
\
me
!
"
<EOS>
\
 
<EOS>
Miss
Havisham
quite
shrieked
,
as
she
stretched
out
her
arms
.
<EOS>
"
Estella
,
Estella
,
Estella
,
to
be
proud
and
hard
to
 
\
me
!
"
<EOS>
\
   
<EOS>
Estella
looked
at
her
for
a
moment
with
a
kind
of
calm
wonder
,
but
was
not
otherwise
disturbed
;
when
the
moment
was
past
,
she
looked
down
at
the
fire
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
think
,
"
said
Estella
,
raising
her
eyes
after
a
silence
,
"
why
you
should
be
so
unreasonable
when
I
come
to
see
you
after
a
separation
.
<EOS>
I
have
never
forgotten
your
wrongs
and
their
causes
.
<EOS>
I
have
never
been
unfaithful
to
you
or
your
schooling
.
<EOS>
I
have
never
shown
any
weakness
that
I
can
charge
myself
with
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Would
it
be
weakness
to
return
my
love
?
"
exclaimed
Miss
Havisham
.
"
<EOS>
But
yes
,
yes
,
she
would
call
it
so
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
begin
to
think
,
"
said
Estella
,
in
a
musing
way
,
after
another
moment
of
calm
wonder
,
"
that
I
almost
understand
how
this
comes
about
.
<EOS>
If
you
had
brought
up
your
adopted
daughter
wholly
in
the
dark
confinement
of
these
rooms
,
and
had
never
let
her
know
that
there
was
such
a
thing
as
the
daylight
by
which
she
has
never
once
seen
your
face
---
if
you
had
done
that
,
and
then
,
for
a
purpose
had
wanted
her
to
understand
the
daylight
and
know
all
about
it
,
you
would
have
been
disappointed
and
angry
?
"
  
<EOS>
Miss
Havisham
,
with
her
head
in
her
hands
,
sat
making
a
low

,
and
swaying
herself
on
her
chair
,
but
gave
no

.
  
<EOS>
"
Or
,
"
said
Estella
,
"
---
which
is
a
nearer
case
---
if
you
had
taught
her
,
from
the
dawn
of
her
intelligence
,
with
your
utmost
energy
and
might
,
that
there
was
such
a
thing
as
daylight
,
but
that
it
was
made
to
be
her
enemy
and

,
and
she
must

turn
against

,
for
it
had
blighted
you
and

else

;
---
if
you
had
done
this
,
and
then
,
for
a
purpose
,
had
wanted
her
to
take
naturally
to
the
daylight
<EOS>
and
she
could
not
do
it
,
you
would
have
been
disappointed
and
angry
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Miss
Havisham
sat
listening
(
or
it
seemed
so
,
for
I
could
not
see
her
face
)
,
but
still
made
no

.
  
<EOS>
"
So
,
"
said
Estella
,
"
I
must
be
taken
as
I
have
been
made
.
<EOS>
The
success
is
not
mine
,
the
failure
is
not
mine
,
but
the
two
together
make
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
Miss
Havisham
had
settled
down
,
I
hardly
knew
how
,
upon
the
floor
,
among
the
faded
bridal
relics
with
which
it
was
strewn
.
<EOS>
I
took
advantage
of
the
moment
---
I
had
sought
one
from
the
first
---
to
leave
the
room
,
after
beseeching
Estella
's
attention
to
her
,
with
a
movement
of
my
hand
.
<EOS>
When
I
left
,
Estella
was
yet
standing
by
the
great
chimney
-
piece
,
just
as
she
had
stood
throughout
.
<EOS>
Miss
Havisham
's
grey
hair
was
all
adrift
upon
the
ground
,
among
the
other
bridal
wrecks
,
and
was
a
miserable
sight
to
see
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
with
a
depressed
heart
that
I
walked
in
the
starlight
for
an
hour
and
more
,
about
the
court
-
yard
,
and
about
the
brewery
,
and
about
the
ruined
garden
.
<EOS>
When
I
at
last
took
courage
to
return
to
the
room
,
I
found
Estella
sitting
at
Miss
Havisham
's
knee
,
taking
up
some
stitches
in
one
of
those
old
articles
of
dress
that
were
dropping
to
pieces
,
and
of
which
I
have
often
been
reminded
since
by
the
faded
tatters
of
old
banners
that
I
have
seen
hanging
up
in
cathedrals
.
<EOS>
Afterwards
,
Estella
and
I
played
at
cards
,
as
of
yore
---
only
we
were
skilful
now
,
and
played
French
games
---
and
so
the
evening
wore
away
,
and
I
went
to
bed
.
  
<EOS>
I
lay
in
that
separate
building
across
the
court
-
yard
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
first
time
I
had
ever
lain
down
to
rest
in
Satis
House
,
and
sleep
refused
to
come
near
me
.
<EOS>
A
thousand
Miss
Havishams
haunted
me
.
<EOS>
She
was
on
this
side
of
my
pillow
,
on
that
,
at
the
head
of
the
bed
,
at
the
foot
,
behind
the
half
-
opened
door
of
the
dressing
-
room
,
in
the
dressing
-
room
,
in
the
room
overhead
,
in
the
room
beneath
---
everywhere
.
<EOS>
At
last
,
when
the
night
was
slow
to
creep
on
towards
two
o'clock
,
I
felt
that
I
absolutely
could
no
longer
bear
the
place
as
a
place
to
lie
down
in
,
and
that
I
must
get
up
.
<EOS>
I
therefore
got
up
and
put
on
my
clothes
,
and
went
out
across
the
yard
into
the
long
stone
passage
,
designing
to
gain
the
outer
court
-
yard
and
walk
there
for
the
relief
of
my
mind
.
<EOS>
But
,
I
was
no
sooner
in
the
passage
than
I
extinguished
my
candle
;
for
,
I
saw
Miss
Havisham
going
along
it
in
a
ghostly
manner
,
making
a
low
cry
.
<EOS>
I
followed
her
at
a
distance
,
and
saw
her
go
up
the
staircase
.
<EOS>
She
carried
a
bare
candle
in
her
hand
,
which
she
had
probably
taken
from
one
of
the
sconces
in
her
own
room
,
and
was
a
most
unearthly
object
by
its
light
.
<EOS>
Standing
at
the
bottom
of
the
staircase
,
I
felt
the
mildewed
air
of
the
feast
-
chamber
,
without
seeing
her
open
the
door
,
and
I
heard
her
walking
there
,
and
so
across
into
her
own
room
,
and
so
across
again
into
that
,
never
ceasing
the
low
cry
.
<EOS>
After
a
time
,
I
tried
in
the
dark
both
to
get
out
,
and
to
go
back
,
but
I
could
do
neither
until
some
streaks
of
day
strayed
in
and
showed
me
where
to
lay
my
hands
.
<EOS>
During
the
whole
interval
,
whenever
I
went
to
the
bottom
of
the
staircase
,
I
heard
her
footstep
,
saw
her
light
pass
above
,
and
heard
her
ceaseless
low
cry
.
  
<EOS>
Before
we
left
next
day
,
there
was
no
revival
of
the
difference
  
between
her
and
Estella
,
nor
was
it
ever
revived
on
any
similar
  
occasion
;
and
there
were
four
similar
occasions
,
to
the
best
of
my
remembrance
.
<EOS>
Nor
,
did
Miss
Havisham
's
manner
towards
Estella
in
anywise
change
,
except
that
I
believed
it
to
have
something
like
fear
infused
among
its
former
characteristics
.
  
<EOS>
It
is
impossible
to
turn
this
leaf
of
my
life
,
without
putting
Bentley
Drummle
's
name
upon
it
;
or
I
would
,
very
gladly
.
  
<EOS>
On
a
certain
occasion
when
the
Finches
were
assembled
in
force
,
and
when
good
feeling
was
being
promoted
in
the
usual
manner
by
nobody
's
agreeing
with
anybody
else
,
the
presiding
Finch
called
the
Grove
to
order
,
forasmuch
as
Mr
Drummle
had
not
yet
toasted
a
lady
;
which
,
according
to
the
solemn
constitution
of
the
society
it
was
the
brute
's
turn
to
do
that
day
.
<EOS>
I
thought
I
saw
him
leer
in
an
ugly
way
at
me
while
the
decanters
were
going
round
,
but
as
there
was
no
love
lost
between
us
,
that
might
easily
be
.
<EOS>
What
was
my
indignant
surprise
when
he
called
upon
the
company
to
pledge
him
to
"
Estella
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Estella
who
?
<EOS>
"
said
I.
  
<EOS>
"
Never
you
mind
,
"
retorted
Drummle
.
  
<EOS>
"
Estella
of
where
?
"
said
I.
"
You
are
bound
to
say
of
where
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Which
he
was
,
as
a
Finch
.
  
<EOS>
"
Of
Richmond
,
gentlemen
,
"
said
Drummle
,
putting
me
out
of
the
question
,
"
and
a
peerless
beauty
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Much
he
knew
about
peerless
beauties
,
a
mean
miserable
idiot
!
<EOS>
I
whispered
Herbert
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
that
lady
,
"
said
Herbert
,
across
the
table
,
when
the
toast
had

.
  
<EOS>
"
\
<EOS>
Do
\
 
you
?
"
said
Drummle
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
do
I
<EOS>
,
"
I
added
,
with
a
scarlet
face
.
  
<EOS>
"
\
<EOS>
Do
\
 
you
?
"
said
Drummle
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
\
<EOS>
Oh
,
\
 
Lord
!
"
  
<EOS>
This
was
the
only
retort
---
except
glass
or

---
that
the
heavy
creature
was
capable

making
;
but
,
I
became
as
highly
incensed
by
it
as
if
it
had
been
barbed
with

,
and
I
immediately
rose
in
my
place
and
said
that
I
could
not
but
regard
it
as
being
like
the
honourable
Finch
's
impudence
to
come
down
to
that
Grove
<EOS>
---
we
always
talked
about
coming
down

that
Grove
,
as
a
neat
Parliamentary
turn
of
expression
---
down
to
that
Grove
,
proposing
  
a
lady
of
whom
he
knew
nothing
.
<EOS>
Mr
Drummle
upon
this
,
starting
  
up
,
demanded
what
I
meant
by
that
?
<EOS>
Whereupon
,
I
made
him
the
  
extreme
reply
that
I
believed
he
knew
where
I
was
to
be
found
.
   
<EOS>
Whether
it
was
possible
in
a
Christian
country
to
get
on
without
  
blood
,
after

,
was
a

Finches

.
  
<EOS>
The

grew

,

,
that
at

members
told
six

,
during

,
that
they
  
believed
 
\
<EOS>
they
\
 
<EOS>
knew
where
 
\
<EOS>
they
\
 
<EOS>
were

.
<EOS>
However
,
it
was
  
<EOS>
decided
at
last
(
the

)
that
if
Mr
  
Drummle
would
bring
never

,

,
<EOS>
Mr
Pip
  
must

,
as
a

Finch
,
for
"
having

into
a
warmth
which
.
<EOS>
"
Next

was
appointed
for
  
the
production
(
lest

should
take
cold
from

)
,
  
and
next

Drummle
appeared
with

little

in
  
Estella
's
hand
,
that
she
had
had
the
honour
of
dancing
with
him
  
several

.
<EOS>
This
left
me
no
course
but
to
regret
that
I
had
been
  
"
betrayed
into
a
warmth
<EOS>
which
,
"
and
on
the
whole
to
repudiate
,
as
  
untenable
,
the
idea
that
I
was
to
be
found
anywhere
.
<EOS>
Drummle
and
  
<EOS>
I
then
sat
snorting
at
one
another
for
an
hour
,
while
the
Grove
  
engaged
in
indiscriminate
contradiction
,
and
finally
the
promotion
  
of
good
feeling
was
declared
to
have
gone
ahead
at
an
amazing
  
rate
.
  
<EOS>
I
tell
this
lightly
,
but
it
was
no
light
thing
to
me
.
<EOS>
For
,
I
can
not
adequately
express
what
pain
it
gave
me
to
think
that
Estella
should
show
any
favour
to
a
contemptible
,
clumsy
,
sulky
booby
,
so
very
far
below
the
average
.
<EOS>
To
the
present
moment
,
I
believe
it
to
have
been
referable
to
some
pure
fire
of
generosity
and
disinterestedness
in
my
love
for
her
,
that
I
could
not
endure
the
thought
of
her
stooping
to
that
hound
.
<EOS>
No
doubt
I
should
have
been
miserable
whomsoever
she
had
favoured
;
but
a
worthier
object
would
have
caused
me
a
different
kind
and
degree
of
distress
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
easy
for
me
to
find
out
,
and
I
did
soon
find
out
,
that
Drummle
had
begun
to
follow
her
closely
,
and
that
she
allowed
him
to
do
it
.
<EOS>
A
little
while
,
and
he
was
always
in
pursuit
of
her
,
and
he
and
I
crossed
one
another
every
day
.
<EOS>
He
held
on
,
in
a
dull
persistent
way
,
and
Estella
held
him
on
;
now
with
encouragement
,
now
with
discouragement
,
now
almost
flattering
him
,
now
openly
despising
him
,
now
knowing
him
very
well
,
now
scarcely
remembering
who
he
was
.
  
<EOS>
The
Spider
,
as
Mr
Jaggers
had
called
him
,
was
used
to
lying
in
wait
,
however
,
and
had
the
patience
of
his
tribe
.
<EOS>
Added
to
that
,
he
had
a
blockhead
confidence
in
his
money
and
in
his
family
greatness
,
which
sometimes
did
him
good
service
---
almost
taking
the
place
of
concentration
and
determined
purpose
.
<EOS>
So
,
the
Spider
,
doggedly
watching
Estella
,
outwatched
many
brighter
insects
,
and
would
often
uncoil
himself
and
drop
at
the
right
nick
of
time
.
  
<EOS>
At
a
certain
Assembly
Ball
at
Richmond
(
there
used
to
be
Assembly
Balls
at
most
places
then
)
,
where
Estella
had
outshone
all
other
beauties
,
this
blundering
Drummle
so
hung
about
her
,
and
with
so
much
toleration
on
her
part
,
that
I
resolved
to
speak
to
her
concerning
him
.
<EOS>
I
took
the
next
opportunity
:
which
was
when
she
was
waiting
for
Mrs
Brandley
to
take
her
home
,
and
was
sitting
apart
among
some
flowers
,
ready
to
go
.
<EOS>
I
was
with
her
,
for
I
almost
always
accompanied
them
to
and

such

.
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
tired
,
Estella
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Rather
,
Pip
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
should
be
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Say

,
I

not

;
for
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Recounting

's

?
"
said

"
Surely

,
Estella
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
do

?
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

Estella
,
"

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
should

?
"

,

.
<EOS>
"

"
  
<EOS>
"

,

"

For

<EOS>

Can

"

Well

"

<EOS>
Yes

<EOS>

"

"

,

<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
A

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

,

addle

;

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
?
"

again
;
and
each

,

opened

lovely

the
wider
.
  
<EOS>
To

the

of

past

,

,
and

,
"
Well
!
<EOS>
Then
,
that
is
why
it
makes
me
wretched
.
"
  
<EOS>
Now
,
if
I
could
have
believed
that
she
favoured
Drummle
with
any

making
me
---
me
---
wretched
,
I
should
have
been

better

;
but
in
that
habitual
way
of
hers
,
she
put
me

,
that
I
could

nothing

.
  
<EOS>
"
Pip
,
"
said

,

,
"
do

.
<EOS>
It

,
and
may
be
meant
to

.
<EOS>
It
's
not
worth

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes

is
,
"
said
I
,
"
because
I
can
not
bear
that
people
should
say
,
"
she
throws
away
her
graces
and

on
a
mere
boor
,
the
lowest
in
the
crowd
.
"
<EOS>
"
  
"
I
can
bear
it
,
"
said
Estella
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
do
n't
be
so
proud
,
Estella
,

so

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Calls
me
proud
and

in
this

!
"
said
Estella
,
opening
her
hands
.
"
<EOS>
And
in
his
last

reproached
me
for
stooping
to
a
boor
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
doubt
you
do
,
"
said
I
,
something

,
"
for
I
have
seen

give
him
looks
and

this

,
such
as
you
never
give
to
---
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you

,
"
said

,

with
a
fixed

serious
,
if

,

,
"
to
deceive

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
deceive
and
entrap

,
Estella
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
and
many
others
---
all
of
them
hut
you
.
<EOS>
Here
is
Mrs
Brandley
.
<EOS>
I
'll
say
no
more
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
And
now
that
I
have
given
the
one
chapter
to
the
theme
that
so
filled
my
heart
,
and
so
often
made
it
ache
and
ache
again
<EOS>
,
I
pass
on
,
unhindered
,
to
the
event
that
had
impended
over
me
longer
yet
;
<EOS>
the
event
that
had
begun
to
be
prepared
for
,
before
I
knew
that
the
world
held
Estella
,
and
in
the
days
when
her
baby
intelligence
was
receiving
its
first
distortions
from
Miss
Havisham
's
wasting
hands
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
Eastern
story
,
the
heavy
slab
that
was
to
fall
on
the
bed
of
state
in
the
flush
of
conquest
was
slowly
wrought
out

the
quarry
,
the
tunnel
for
the
rope
to
hold
it
in
its
place
was
slowly
carried
through
the

of
rock
,
the
slab
was
slowly
raised
and
fitted
in
the
roof
,
the
rope
was
rove
to
it
and
slowly
taken
through
the
miles
of
hollow
to
the
great
iron
ring
.
<EOS>
All
being
made
ready
with
much

,
and
the
hour
come
,
the
sultan
was
aroused
in
the
dead
of
the
night
,
and

that
was
to
sever

was
put
into

,
and
he

,

,

.
<EOS>
So
,

my

;
all

near

,
that

,

;
and

,

the

my

dropped
upon

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
39
 
<EOS>
I
WAS
three
-

-

years
of
age
.
<EOS>
Not

had

on
the
subject

my

,
and
my

.
<EOS>
We
had

Barnard
's
Inn
more
than

,
and
lived
in
the
Temple
.
<EOS>
Our
chambers
were
in
Garden

,
down

.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Pocket
<EOS>
and
I
had
for
some

our

,
though

continued

the
best

.
<EOS>
Notwithstanding

---
which

the

held

---
I
had
a
taste
for
reading
,
and
read
regularly
so

.
<EOS>
That
matter
of
Herbert
's
was

,

was
as

.
  
<EOS>
Business

.
<EOS>
I

,
and

.
<EOS>
Dispirited

<EOS>
It

;

<EOS>
Day

<EOS>
So

;

<EOS>
Violent

,
and
the
day
just

as

read
<EOS>
had

.
  
<EOS>
Alterations

,

<EOS>
We

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

)
<EOS>
afore

.

"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

Up

<EOS>
Lord
strike

,
"
I

,
wotever

was

I

,
"
if

ai

!
<EOS>
"
It

.
<EOS>
As

'

,

.
<EOS>
It

,

<EOS>
the

wot

---

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
That

<EOS>

I

"
I

"
<EOS>

"
If

,

?
<EOS>
"
This

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He

<EOS>
I

.
  
<EOS>
"
It

,

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
But

,

,

.
<EOS>
At

.
<EOS>
Dear
boy
,
I

!
"
  
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
Throughout
,

had
seemed

;

<EOS>
"
Where

?
"
<EOS>
he

.
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
To

?
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

"

,

,
"

;

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

?

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"

"

?
<EOS>
Caution
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
By
G
#
#
#
#
,

Death
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
's

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
was

for

.
<EOS>
It
's
death
to
come

.
<EOS>
There
's

overmuch
coming
back
of
late
years
,
and
I
should
of

if
took
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Nothing
was
needed
but
this
;
the
wretched
man
,
after
loading
wretched
me
with
his
gold
and

chains
for
years
,
had
risked
his

to
come
to
me
,
and
I

there

!
<EOS>
If

;

;

.
<EOS>
On

,

,

naturally
and

.
  
<EOS>
My

,

.
<EOS>
While

;
and

,
I

my

on

at
his

.
<EOS>
It
almost

if

must

,

.
  
<EOS>
When

's

between

than

?
<EOS>
He

,
but

"

's

"

.
<EOS>
I

,

laid

,
and

blood
again

when

again

.
  
<EOS>
I

,

,
and

in

,

,

.
<EOS>
For

,
I

too

;
and
it

not
until
I
began

,
that
I

fully
to

how

was
,
and
how

in

I
had

was

.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Havisham
's
intentions
towards
me
,
all
a
mere
dream
<EOS>
;
Estella
not
designed
for
me
;
I
only
suffered
in
Satis
House
as
a
convenience
,
a
sting
for
the
greedy
relations
,
a
model
with
a

heart
to
practise
on
when
no
other

was
at

;
those
were
the
first

I

.
<EOS>
But
,

all
---
it
was
for
the
convict
,
guilty
of
I
knew
not
what

,
and
liable
to

rooms
where
I
sat
thinking
,
and

at
the
Old
Bailey

,
that
I
had
deserted
Joe
.
  
<EOS>
I
would
not

gone
back
to
Joe
now
,
I
would
not

gone
back
to
Biddy
now
,
for

:
simply
,
I
suppose
,
because
my
sense
of

own

to

was

than

.
<EOS>
No
wisdom
on
earth
could

that

and

;
but
I

never
,
never
,
never
,

what
I
had

.
  
<EOS>
In
every
rage
of
wind
and

,
I
heard

.
<EOS>
Twice
,
I
could
have
sworn
there
was
a
knocking
and

at

outer
door
.
<EOS>
With

upon

,
I
began
either
to

recall
that
I
had
had
mysterious

of
this
man
's

.
<EOS>
That
,
for
weeks
gone
by
,
I
had
passed
faces
in
the
streets
which
I
had
thought
like
his
.
<EOS>
That
,
these
likenesses
had
grown
more
numerous
,
as
he
,
coming
over
the
sea
,
had
drawn
nearer
.
<EOS>
That
,
his
wicked
spirit
had
somehow
sent
these
messengers
to
mine
,
and
that
now
on
this

night
he
was
as
good
as
his
word
,
and
with
me
.
  
<EOS>
Crowding
up

these

came
the

that
I
had
seen
him
with
my
childish

to

;
that
I
had
heard

other

reiterate
that

had

;
that
I
had
seen

down
in
the
ditch
tearing
and

like

.
<EOS>
Out
of

I
brought
into
the
light
of
the
fire
,
a
half
-
formed
terror
that
it
might
not
be
safe
to
be
shut

there
with
him
in
the
dead
of
the
wild

.
<EOS>
This
dilated
until
it
filled
the
room
,
and
impelled
me
to
take
a
candle
and
go
in
and
look
at
my
dreadful
burden
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
rolled
a
handkerchief
round
his
head
,
and
his
face
was
set
and
lowering
in
his
sleep
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
asleep
,
and
quietly
too
,
though
he
had
a
pistol
lying
on
the
