.
<EOS>
Assured
of
this
,
I
softly
removed
the
key
to
the
outside
of
his
door
,
and
turned
it
on
him
before
I
again
sat
down
by
the
fire
.
<EOS>
Gradually
I
slipped
from
the
chair
and
lay
on
the
floor
.
<EOS>
When
I
awoke
,
without
having
parted
in
my
sleep
with
the
perception
of
my
wretchedness
,
the
clocks
of
the
Eastward
churches
were
striking
five
,
the
candles
were
wasted
out
,
the
fire
was
dead
,
and
the
wind
and
rain
intensified
the
thick
black
darkness
.
           
<EOS>
THIS
IS
THE
END
OF
THE
SECOND
STAGE
OF
                     
PIP
'S
EXPECTATIONS
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
40
 
IT
was
fortunate
for
me
that
I
had
to
take
precautions
to
ensure
(
so
far
as
I
could
)
<EOS>
the
safety
of
my
dreaded
visitor
;
for
,
this
thought
pressing
on
me
when
I
awoke
,
held
other
thoughts
in
a
confused
concourse
at
a
distance
.
  
<EOS>
The
impossibility
of
keeping
him
concealed
in
the
chambers
was
self
-
evident
.
<EOS>
It
could
not
be
done
,
and
the
attempt
to
do
it
would
inevitably
engender
suspicion
.
<EOS>
True
,
I
had
no
Avenger
in
my
service
now
,
but
I
was
looked
after
by
an
inflammatory
old
female
,
assisted
by
an
animated
rag
-
bag
whom
she
called
her
niece
,
and
to
keep
a
room
secret
from
them
would
be
to
invite
curiosity
and
exaggeration
.
<EOS>
They
both
had
weak
eyes
,
which
I
had
long
attributed
to
their
chronically
looking
in
at
keyholes
,
and
they
were
always
at
hand
when
not
wanted
;
indeed
that
was
their
only
reliable
quality
besides
larceny
.
<EOS>
Not
to
get
up
a
mystery
with
these
people
,
I
resolved
to
announce
in
the
morning
that
my
uncle
had
unexpectedly
come
from
the
country
.
  
<EOS>
This
course
I
decided
on
while
I
was
yet
groping
about
in
the
darkness
for
the
means
of
getting
a
light
.
<EOS>
Not
stumbling
on
the
means
after
all
,
I
was
fain
to
go
out
to
the
adjacent
Lodge
and
get
the
watchman
there
to
come
with
his
lantern
.
<EOS>
Now
,
in
groping
my
way
down
the
black
staircase
I
fell
over
something
,
and
that
something
was
a
man
crouching
in
a
corner
.
  
<EOS>
As
the
man
made
no
answer
when
I
asked
him
what
he
did
there
,
but
eluded
my
touch
in
silence
,
I
ran
to
the
Lodge
and
urged
the
watchman
to
come
quickly
:
telling
him
of
the
incident
on
the
way
back
.
<EOS>
The
wind
being
as
fierce
as
ever
,
we
did
not
care
to
endanger
the
light
in
the
lantern
by
rekindling
the
extinguished
lamps
on
the
staircase
,
but
we
examined
the
staircase
from
the
bottom
to
the
top
and
found
no
one
there
.
<EOS>
It
then
occurred
to
me
as
possible
that
the
man
might
have
slipped
into
my
rooms
;
so
,
lighting
my
candle
at
the
watchman
's
,
and
leaving
him
standing
at
the
door
,
I
examined
them
carefully
,
including
the
room
in
which
my
dreaded
guest
lay
asleep
.
<EOS>
All
was
quiet
,
and
assuredly
no
other
man
was
in
those
chambers
.
  
<EOS>
It
troubled
me
that
there
should
have
been
a
lurker
on
the
stairs
,
on
that
night
of
all
nights
in
the
year
,
and
I
asked
the
watchman
,
on
the
chance
of
eliciting
some
hopeful
explanation
as
I
handed
him
a
dram
at
the
door
,
whether
he
had
admitted
at
his
gate
any
gentleman
who
had
perceptibly
been
dining
out
?
<EOS>
Yes
,
he
said
;
at
different
times
of
the
night
,
three
.
<EOS>
One
lived
in
Fountain
Court
,
and
the
other
two
lived
in
the
Lane
,
and
he
had
seen
them
all
go
home
.
<EOS>
Again
,
the
only
other
man
who
dwelt
in
the
house
of
which
my
chambers
formed
a
part
,
had
been
in
the
country
for
some
weeks
;
and
he
certainly
had
not
returned
in
the
night
,
because
we
had
seen
his
door
with
his
seal
on
it
as
we
came
up
-
stairs
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
night
being
so
bad
,
sir
,
"
said
the
watchman
,
as
he
gave
me
back
my
glass
,
"
uncommon
few
have
come
in
at
my
gate
.
<EOS>
Besides
them
three
gentlemen
that
I
have
named
<EOS>
,
I
do
n't
call
to
mind
another
since
about
eleven

,
when
a
stranger
asked
for
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
uncle
,
"
I
muttered
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
saw
him
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
Oh
yes
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Likewise
the
person
with
him
?
"
  
"
Person
with
him
!
"
<EOS>
I
repeated
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
judged
the
person
to
be
with
him
,
"
returned

watchman
.
<EOS>
"
The
person
stopped
,
when
he
stopped
to
make
inquiry
of
me
,
and
the
person
took
this
way
when
he
took
this
way
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
sort
of
person
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
watchman
had
not
particularly
noticed
;
he
should
say
a
working
person
;
to
the
best
of
his
belief
,
he
had
a

,

.
<EOS>
The

than
I
did
,
and
naturally
;
not
having
my

for

.
  
<EOS>
When
I

,
which

thought

well

do
without
prolonging
explanations
<EOS>
,
my

much

these

.
<EOS>
Whereas

of

---

,

,
some

,
who

---
and

might

---
<EOS>
still
,
joined
,
they
had
an
ugly

to
one
as
prone
to
distrust
and
fear
as
the
changes
of
a
few
hours
had
made

.
  
<EOS>
I
lighted
my
fire
,
which
burnt

at
that

of
the

,
and
fell

.
<EOS>
I
seemed
to
have

a
whole
night
when
the
clocks
struck
six
.
<EOS>
As
there
was
full
an

,

again
;
now
,

,

about
nothing
,
in

;
now
,
making

of
the
wind
in

;
at

falling

into
a

from
which

woke

.
  
<EOS>
All

I
had
never
been
able

,
nor
could

do

yet
.
<EOS>
I
had
not

to

.
<EOS>
I

greatly

and

,
but
in
an

.
<EOS>
As

any

for
the

,

formed

.
<EOS>
When

,
all
of
a

;
when

;

thought

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
At

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

was

.
  
<EOS>
The

,

<EOS>

;
the
weather
wo

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.

"
  
<EOS>
"

do

,

the

's
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very

,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Then
,

"

"

"

"

,

!
<EOS>

"

"

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Chapter
44
 
IN

room

,

<EOS>
I

"

<EOS>
Estella

.

"

Well

,
that
she
might
regard
me
the
more
attentively
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Because
,
"
said
I
,
"
I
began
the
service
myself
,
more
than
two
years
ago
,
without
his
knowledge
,
and
I
do
n't
want
to
be
betrayed
.
<EOS>
Why
I
fail
in
my
ability
to
finish
it
,
I
can
not
explain
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
part
of
the
secret
which
is
another
person
's
and
not
mine
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
gradually
withdrew
her
eyes
from
me
,
and
turned
them
on
the
fire
.
<EOS>
After
watching
it
for
what
appeared
in
the
silence
and
by
the
light
of
the
slowly
wasting
candles
to
be
a
long
time
,
she
was
roused
by
the
collapse
of
some
of
the
red
coals
,
and
looked
towards
me
again
---
at
first
,
vacantly
---
then
,
with
a
gradually
concentrating
attention
.
<EOS>
All
this
time
,
Estella
knitted
on
.
<EOS>
When
Miss
Havisham
had
fixed
her
attention
on
me
,
she
said
,
speaking
as
if
there
had
been
no
lapse
in
our
dialogue
:
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
else
?
"
  
"
Estella
,
"
said
I
,
turning
to
her
now
,
and
trying
to
command
my
trembling
voice
,
"
you
know
I
love
you
.
<EOS>
You
know
that
I
have
loved
you
long
and
dearly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
raised
her
eyes
to
my
face
,
on
being
thus
addressed
,
and
her
fingers
plied
their
work
,
and
she
looked
at
me
with
an
unmoved
countenance
.
<EOS>
I
saw
that
Miss
Havisham
glanced
from
me
to
her
,
and
from
her
to
me
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
have
said
this
sooner
,
but
for
my
long
mistake
.
<EOS>
It
induced
me
to
hope
that
Miss
Havisham
meant
us
for
one
another
.
<EOS>
While
I
thought
you
could
not
help
yourself
,
as
it
were
,
I
refrained
from
saying
it
.
<EOS>
But
I
must
say
it
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Preserving
her
unmoved
countenance
,
and
with
her
fingers
still
going
,
Estella
shook
her
head
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
,
"
said
I
,
in
answer
to
that
action
;
"
I
know
.
<EOS>
I
have
no
hope
that
I
shall
ever
call
you
mine
,
Estella
.
<EOS>
I
am
ignorant
what
may
become
of
me
very
soon
,
how
poor
I
may
be
,
or
where
I
may
go
.
<EOS>
Still
,
I
love
you
.
<EOS>
I
have
loved
you
ever
since
I
first
saw
you
in
this
house
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Looking
at
me
perfectly
unmoved
and
with
her
fingers
busy
,
she
shook
her
head
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
would
have
been
cruel
in
Miss
Havisham
,
horribly
cruel
,
to
practise
on
the
susceptibility
of
a
poor
boy
,
and
to
torture
me
through
all
these
years
with
a
vain
hope
and
an
idle
pursuit
,
if
she
had
reflected
on
the
gravity
of
what
she
did
.
<EOS>
But
I
think
she
did
not
.
<EOS>
I
think
that
in
the
endurance
of
her
own
trial
,
she
forgot
mine
,
Estella
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
saw
Miss
Havisham
put
her
hand
to
her
heart
and
hold
it
there
,
as
she
sat
looking
by
turns
at
Estella
and
at
me
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
seems
,
"
said
Estella
,
very
calmly
,
"
that
there
are
sentiments
,
fancies
<EOS>
---
I
do
n't
know
how
to
call
them
---
which
I
am
not
able
to
comprehend
.
<EOS>
When
you
say
you
love
me
,
I
know
what
you
mean
,
as
a
form
of
words
;
but
nothing
more
.
<EOS>
You
address
nothing
in
my
breast
,
you
touch
nothing
there
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
care
for
what
you
say
at
all
.
<EOS>
I
have
tried
to
warn
you
of
this
;
now
,
have
I
not
?
"
  
<EOS>
I
said
in
a
miserable
manner
,
"
Yes
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
But
you
would
not
be
warned
,
for
you
thought
I
did
not
mean
it
.
<EOS>
Now
,
did
you
not
think
so
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
thought
and
hoped
you
could
not
mean
it
.
<EOS>
You
,
so
young
,
untried
,
and
beautiful
,
Estella
!
<EOS>
Surely
it
is
not
in
Nature
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
in
 
<EOS>
\
<EOS>
my
\
 
nature
,
"
she
returned
.
<EOS>
And
then
she
added
,
with
a
stress
upon
the
words
,
"
It
is
in
the
nature
formed
within
me
.
<EOS>
I
make
a
great
difference
between
you
and
all
other
people
when
I
say
so
much
.
<EOS>
I
can
do
no
more
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
it
not
true
,
"
said
I
,
"
that
Bentley
Drummle
is
in
town
here
,
and
pursuing
you
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
quite
true
,
"
she
replied
,
referring
to
him
with
the
indifference
of
utter
contempt
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
you
encourage
him
,
and
ride
out
with
him
,
and
that
he
dines
with
you
this
very
day
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
seemed
a
little
surprised
that
I
should
know
it
,
but
again
replied
,
"
Quite
true
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
can
not
love
him
,
Estella
!
"
  
<EOS>
Her
fingers
stopped
for
the
first
time
,
as
she
retorted
rather
angrily
,
"
What
have
I
told
you
?
<EOS>
Do
you
still
think
,
in
spite
of
it
,
that
I
do
not
mean
what
I
say
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
You
would
never
marry
him
,
Estella
?
"
  
<EOS>
She
looked
towards
Miss
Havisham
,
and
considered
for
a
moment
with
her
work
in
her
hands
.
<EOS>
Then
she
said
,
"
Why
not
tell
you
the
truth
?
<EOS>
I
am
going
to
be
married
to
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
dropped
my
face
into
my
hands
,
but
was
able
to
control
myself
better
than
I
could
have
expected
,
considering
what
agony
it
gave
me
to
hear
her
say
those
words
.
<EOS>
When
I
raised
my
face
again
,
there
was
such
a
ghastly
look
upon
Miss
Havisham
's
,
that
it
impressed
me
,
even
in
my
passionate
hurry
and
grief
.
  
<EOS>
"
Estella
,
dearest
dearest
Estella
,
do
not
let
Miss
Havisham
lead
you
into
this
fatal
step
.
<EOS>
Put
me
aside
for
ever
---
you
have
done
so
<EOS>
,
I
well
know
<EOS>
---
but
bestow
yourself
on
some
worthier
person
than
Drummle
.
<EOS>
Miss
Havisham
gives
you
to
him
,
as
the
greatest
slight
and
injury
that
could
be
done
to
the
many
far
better
men
who
admire
you
,
and
to
the
few
who
truly
love
you
.
<EOS>
Among
those
few
,
there
may
be
one
who
loves
you
even
as
dearly
,
though
he
has
not
loved
you
as
long
,
as
I.
Take
him
,
and
I
can
bear
it
better
,
for
your
sake
!
"
  
<EOS>
My
earnestness
awoke
a
wonder
in
her
that
seemed
as
if
it
would
have
been
touched
with
compassion
,
if
she
could
have
rendered
me
at
all
intelligible
to
her
own
mind
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
going
,
"
she
said
again
,
in
a
gentler
voice
,
"
to
be
married
to
him
.
<EOS>
The
preparations
for
my
marriage
are
making
,
and
I
shall
be
married
soon
.
<EOS>
Why
do
you
injuriously
introduce
the
name
of
my
mother
by
adoption
?
<EOS>
It
is
my
own
act
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Your
own
act
,
Estella
,
to
fling
yourself
away
upon
a
brute
?
"
  
"
On
whom
should
I
fling
myself
away
?
"
she
retorted
,
with
a
smile
.
"
<EOS>
Should
I
fling
myself
away
upon
the
man
who
would
the
soonest
feel
<EOS>
(
if
people
do
feel
such
things
)
that
I
took
nothing
to
him
?
<EOS>
There
!
<EOS>
It
is
done
.
<EOS>
I
shall
do
well
enough
,
and
so
will
my
husband
.
<EOS>
As
to
leading
me
into
what
you
call
this
fatal
step
,
Miss
Havisham
would
have
had
me
wait
,
and
not
marry
yet
;
but
I
am
tired
of
the
life
I
have
led
,
which
has
very
few
charms
for
me
,
and
I
am
willing
enough
to
change
it
.
<EOS>
Say
no
more
.
<EOS>
We
shall
never
understand
each
other
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Such
a
me
an
brute
,
such
a
stupid
brute
!
<EOS>
"
I
urged
in
despair
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
afraid
of
my
being
a
blessing
to
him
,
"
said
Estella
;
<EOS>
"
I
shall
not
be
that
.
<EOS>
Come
!
<EOS>
Here
is
my
hand
.
<EOS>
Do
we
part
on
this
,
<EOS>
you
visionary
boy
---
or
man
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
O
Estella
!
<EOS>
"
I
answered
,
as
my
bitter
tears
fell
fast
on
her
hand
,
do
what
I
would
to
restrain
them
;
"
even
if
I
remained
in
England
and
could
hold
my
head
up
with
the
rest
,
how
could
I
see
you
Drummle
's
wife
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nonsense
,
"
she
returned
,
"
nonsense
.
 
<EOS>
This
will
pass
in
no
time
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Never
,
Estella
!
"
  
"
You
will
get
me
out
of
your
thoughts
in
a
week
.
"
  
"
Out
of
my
thoughts
!
<EOS>
You
are
part
of
my
existence
,
part
of
myself
.
<EOS>
You
have
been
in
every
line
I
have
ever
read
,
since
I
first
came
here
,
the
rough
common
boy
whose
poor
heart
you
wounded
even
then
.
<EOS>
You
have
been
in
every
prospect
I
have
ever
seen
since
---
<EOS>
on
the
river
,
on
the
sails
of
the
ships
,
on
the
marshes
,
in
the
clouds
,
in
the
light
,
in
the
darkness
,
in
the
wind
,
in
the
woods
,
in
the
sea
,
in
the
streets
.
<EOS>
You
have
been
the
embodiment
of
every
graceful
fancy
that
my
mind
has
ever
become
acquainted
with
.
<EOS>
The
stones
of
which
the
strongest
London
buildings
are
made
,
are
not
more
real
,
or
more
impossible
to
be
displaced
by
your
hands
,
than
your
presence
and
influence
have
been
to
me
,
there
and
everywhere
,
and
will
be
.
<EOS>
Estella
,
to
the
last
hour
of
my
life
,
you
can
not
choose
but
remain
part
of
my
character
,
pad
of
the
little
good
in
me
,
part
of
the
evil
.
<EOS>
But
,
in
this
separation
I
associate
you
only
with
the
good
,
and
I
will
faithfully
hold
you
to
that
always
,
for
you
must
have
done
me
far
more
good
than
harm
,
let
me
feel
now
what
sharp
distress
<EOS>
I
may
.
<EOS>
O
God
bless
you
,
God
forgive
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
In
what
    
of
unhappiness
I
got
these
broken
words
out
of
myself
,
I
do
n't
know
.
<EOS>
The
rhapsody
welled
up
within
me
,
like
blood
from
an
inward
wound
,
and
gushed
out
.
<EOS>
I
held
her
hand
to
my
lips
some
lingering
moments
,
and
so
I
left
her
.
<EOS>
But
ever
afterwards
,
I
remembered
---
and
soon
afterwards
with
stronger
reason
---
that
while
Estella
looked
at
me
merely
with
incredulous
wonder
,
the
spectral
figure
of
Miss
Havisham
,
her
hand
still
covering
her
heart
,
seemed
all
resolved
into
a
ghastly
stare
of
pity
and
remorse
.
  
<EOS>
All
done
,
all
gone
!
<EOS>
So
much
was
done
and
gone
,
that
when
I
went
out
at
the
gate
,
the
light
of
the
day
seemed
of
a
darker
colour
than
when
I
went
in
.
<EOS>
For
a
while
,
I
hid
myself
among
some
lanes
and
by
-
paths
,
and
then
struck
off
to
walk
all
the
way
to
London
.
<EOS>
For
,
I
had
by
that
time
come
to
myself
so
far
,
as
to
consider
that
I
could
not
go
back
to
the
inn
and
see
Drummle
there
;
that
I
could
not
bear
to
sit
upon
the
coach
and
be
spoken
to
;
that
I
could
do
nothing
half
so
good
for
myself
as
tire
myself
out
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
past
midnight
when
I
crossed
London
Bridge
.
<EOS>
Pursuing
the
narrow
intricacies
of
the
streets
which
at
that
time
tended
westward
near
the
Middlesex
shore
of
the
river
,
my
readiest
access
to
the
Temple
was
close
by
the
river
-
side
,
through
Whitefriars
.
<EOS>
I
was
not
expected
till
to
-
morrow
,
but
I
had
my
keys
,
and
,
if
Herbert
were
gone
to
bed
,
could
get
to
bed
myself
without
disturbing
him
.
  
<EOS>
As
it
seldom
happened
that
I
came
in
at
that
Whitefriars
gate
after
the
Temple
was
closed
,
and
as
I
was
very
muddy
and
weary
,
I
did
not
take
it
ill
that
the
night
-
porter
examined
me
with
much
attention
as
he
held
the
gate
a
little
way
open
for
me
to
pass
in
.
<EOS>
To
help
his
memory
I
mentioned
my
name
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
not
quite
sure
,
sir
,
but
I
thought
so
.
<EOS>
Here
's
a
note
,
sir
.
<EOS>
The
messenger
that
brought
it
,
said
would
you
be
so
good
as
read
it
by
my
lantern
?
"
  
<EOS>
Much
surprised
by
the
request
,
I
took
the
note
.
<EOS>
It
was
directed
to
Philip
Pip
,
Esquire
,
and
on
the
top
of
the
superscription
were
the
words
,
"
PLEASE
READ
THIS
,
HERE
.
<EOS>
"
I
opened
it
,
the
watchman
holding
up
his
light
,
and
read
inside
,
in
Wemmick
's
writing
:
  
"
DON'T
GO
HOME
.
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
45
 
TURNING
from
the
Temple
gate
as
soon
as
I
had
read
the
warning
,
I
made
the
best
of
my
way
to
Fleet
-
street
,
and
there
got
a
late
hackney
chariot
and
drove
to
the
Hummums
in
Covent
Garden
.
<EOS>
In
those
times
a
bed
was
always
to
be
got
there
at
any
hour
of
the
night
,
and
the
chamberlain
,
letting
me
in
at
his
ready
wicket
,
lighted
the
candle
next
in
order
on
his
shelf
,
and
showed
me
straight
into
the
bedroom
next
in
order
on
his
list
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
sort
of
vault
on
the
ground
floor
at
the
back
,
with
a
despotic
monster
of
a
four
-
post
bedstead
in
it
,
straddling
over
the
whole
place
,
putting
one
of
his
arbitrary
legs
into
the
fire
-
place
and
another
into
the
doorway
,
and
squeezing
the
wretched
little
washing
-
stand
in
quite
a
Divinely
Righteous
manner
.
  
<EOS>
As
I
had
asked
for
a
night
-
light
,
the
chamberlain
had
brought
me
in
,
before
he
left
me
,
the
good
old
constitutional
rush
-
light
of
those
virtuous
days
---
an
object
like
the
ghost
of
a
walking
-
cane
,
which
instantly
broke
its
back
if
it
were
touched
,
which
nothing
could
ever
be
lighted
at
,
and
which
was
placed
in
solitary
confinement
at
the
bottom
of
a
high
tin
tower
,
perforated
with
round
holes
that
made
a
staringly
wide
-
awake
pattern
on
the
walls
.
<EOS>
When
I
had
got
into
bed
,
and
lay
there
footsore
,
weary
,
and
wretched
<EOS>
,
I
found
that
I
could
no
more
close
my
own
eyes
than
I
could
close
the
eyes
of
this
foolish
Argus
.
<EOS>
And
thus
,
in
the
gloom
and
death
of
the
night
,
we
stared
at
one
another
.
  
<EOS>
What
a
doleful
night
!
<EOS>
How
anxious
,
how
dismal
,
how
long
!
<EOS>
There
was
an
inhospitable
smell
in
the
room
,
of
cold
soot
and
hot
dust
;
and
,
as
I
looked
up
into
the
corners
of
the
tester
over
my
head
,
I
thought
what
a
number
of
blue
-
bottle
flies
from
the
butchers
'
,
and
earwigs
from
the
market
,
and
grubs
from
the
country
,
must
be
holding
on
up
there
,
lying
by
for
next
summer
.
<EOS>
This
led
me
to
speculate
whether
any
of
them
ever
tumbled
down
,
and
then
I
fancied
that
I
felt
light
falls
on
my
face
---
<EOS>
a
disagreeable
turn
of
thought
,
suggesting
other
and
more
objectionable
approaches
up
my
back
.
<EOS>
When
I
had
lain
awake
a
little
while
,
those
extraordinary
voices
with
which
silence
teems
,
began
to
make
themselves
audible
.
<EOS>
The
closet
whispered
,
the
fireplace
sighed
,
<EOS>
the
little
washing
-
stand
ticked
,
and
one
guitar
-
string
played
occasionally
in
the
chest
of
drawers
.
<EOS>
At
about
the
same

,
the
eyes
on
the
wall
acquired
a
new
expression
,
and
in
every
one
of
those
staring
rounds
I
saw
written
,
DON'T
GO
HOME
.
  
<EOS>
Whatever
night
-
fancies
and
night
-
noises
crowded
on
me
,
they
never
warded
off
this
DONT
GO
HOME
.
<EOS>
It
plaited
itself
into
whatever
I
thought
of
,
as
a
bodily
pain
would
have
done
.
<EOS>
Not
long
before
,
I
had
read
in
the
newspapers
,
how
a
gentleman
unknown
had
come
to
the
Hummums
in
the
night
,
and
had
gone
to
bed
,
and
had
destroyed
himself
,
and
had
been

in
the
morning

in
blood
.
<EOS>
It
came
into
my
head
that
he
must
have
occupied
this
very
vault
of
mine
,
and
I
got
out
of
bed
to
assure
myself
that
there
were
no
red
marks
about
;
then
opened
the
door
to
look
out
into
the
passages
,
and
cheer
myself
with
the
companionship
of
a
distant
light
,
near
which
I
knew
the
chamberlain
to
be
dozing
.
<EOS>
But
all
this
time
,
why
I
was
not
to
go
home
,
and
what
had
happened
at
home
,
and
when
I
should
go
home
,
and
whether
Provis
was
safe

home
,
were
questions

so

,
that
one
might
have
supposed
there
could

no

room
in
it
for
any
other
theme
.
<EOS>
Even
when
I
thought
of
Estella
,
and
how

had
parted
that

for
ever
,
and
when
I
recalled
all

her

,

the

---
even

I
was
pursuing
,
here

there

everywhere
,
the
caution
Do

go
home
.
<EOS>
When
at
last
I
dozed
,
in
sheer

of
mind
and
body
,
it
became
a
vast
shadowy
verb
which
I
had
to
conjugate
.
<EOS>
Imperative
mood
,
present
tense
:
<EOS>
Do
not
thou
go
home
,
let
him
not
go
home
,
let

not

,
do

<EOS>
or

,
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Then
,

not

;
and

,

;
until

and

and

.
  
<EOS>
I
had
left
directions
that
I

at
seven
;
for

that

Wemmick

his

<EOS>
It

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
The
Castle

.
<EOS>
The

,

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

He

<EOS>
Previous

,

All

,
ai

.

"

.

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
He

\
<EOS>

46
 
<EOS>

;

Old

.
  
<EOS>
It

what
stranded
ships

in
dry
docks
<EOS>

,
what

.
<EOS>

,

I

.

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

establishment
at
Hammersmith
,
and
that
on
her
being
recalled
home
to
nurse
her
father
,
he
and
she
had
confided
their
affection
to
the
motherly
Mrs
Whimple
,
by
whom
it
had
been
fostered
and
regulated
with
equal
kindness
and
discretion
,
ever
since
.
<EOS>
It
was
understood
that
nothing
of
a
tender
nature
could
possibly
be
confided
to
old
Barley
,
by
reason
of
his
being
totally
unequal
to
the
consideration
of
any
subject
more
psychological
than
Gout
,
Rum
,
and
Purser
's
stores
.
  
<EOS>
As
we
were
thus
conversing
in
a
low
tone
while
Old
Barley
's
sustained
growl
vibrated
in
the
beam
that
crossed
the
ceiling
,
the
room
door
opened
,
and
a
very
pretty
"
slight
dark
-
eyed
girl
of
twenty
or
so
,
came
in
with
a
basket
in
her
hand
:
whom
Herbert
tenderly
relieved
of
the
basket
,
and
presented
blushing
,
as
"
Clara
.
<EOS>
"
She
really
was
a
most
charming
girl
,
and
might
have
passed
for
a
captive
fairy
,
whom
that
truculent
Ogre
,
Old
Barley
,
had
pressed
into
his
service
.
  
<EOS>
"
Look
here
,
"
said
Herbert
,
showing
me
the
basket
,
with
a
compassionate
and
tender
smile
after
we
had
talked
a
little
;
"
here
's
poor
Clara
's
supper
,
served
out
every
night
.
<EOS>
Here
's
her
allowance
of
bread
,
and
here
's
her
slice
of
cheese
,
and
here
's
her
rum
---
which
I
drink
.
<EOS>
This
is
Mr
Barley
's
breakfast
for
to
-
morrow
,
served
out
to
be
cooked
.
<EOS>
Two
mutton
chops
,
three
potatoes
,
some
split
peas
,
a
little
flour
,
two
ounces
of
butter
,
a
pinch
of
salt
,
and
all
this
black
pepper
.
<EOS>
It
's
stewed
up
together
,
and
taken
hot
,
and
it
's
a
nice
thing
for
the
gout
,
I
should
think
!
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
something
so
natural
and
winning
in
Clara
's
resigned
way
of
looking
at
these
stores
in
detail
,
as
Herbert
pointed
them
out
,
---
and
something
so
confiding
,
loving
,
and
innocent
,
in
her
modest
manner
of
yielding
herself
to
Herbert
's
embracing
arm
---
and
something
so
gentle
in
her
,
so
much
needing
protection
on
Mill
Pond
Bank
,
by
Chinks
's
Basin
,
and
the
Old
Green
Copper
Rope
-
Walk
,
with
Old
Barley
growling
in
the
beam
---
that
I
would
not
have
undone
the
engagement
between
her
and
Herbert
,
for
all
the
money
in
the
pocket
-
book
<EOS>
I
had
never
opened
.
  
<EOS>
I
was
looking
at
her
with
pleasure
and
admiration
,
when
suddenly
the
growl
swelled
into
a
roar
again
,
and
a
frightful
bumping
noise
was
heard
above
,
as
if
a
giant
with
a
wooden
leg
were
trying
to
bore
it
through
the
ceiling
to
come
at
us
.
<EOS>
Upon
this
Clara
said
to
Herbert
,
"
Papa
wants
me
,
darling
!
"
and
ran
away
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
an
unconscionable
old
shark
for
you
!
"
said
Herbert
.
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
suppose
he
wants
now
,
Handel
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
"
said
I.
"
Something
to
drink
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
it
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Herbert
,
as
if
I
had
made
a
guess
of
extraordinary
merit
.
"
<EOS>
He
keeps
his
grog
ready
-
mixed
in
a
little
tub
on
the
table
.
<EOS>
Wait
a
moment
,
and
you
'll
hear
Clara
lift
him
up
to
take
some
.
<EOS>
---
There
he
goes
!
"
<EOS>
Another
roar
,
with
a
prolonged
shake
at
the
end
.
"
<EOS>
Now
,
"
said
Herbert
,
as
it
was
succeeded
by
silence
,
"
he
's
drinking
.
<EOS>
Now
,
"
said
Herbert
,
as
the
growl
resounded
in
the
beam
once
more
,
"
he
's
down
again
on
his
back
!
"
  
<EOS>
Clara
returned
soon
afterwards
,
and
Herbert
accompanied
me
up
-
stairs
to
see
our
charge
.
<EOS>
As
we
passed
Mr
Barley
's
door
,
he
was
heard
hoarsely
muttering
within
,
in
a
strain
that
rose
and
fell
like
wind
,
the
following
Refrain
;
in
which
I
substitute
good
wishes
for
something
quite
the
reverse
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ahoy
!
<EOS>
Bless
your
eyes
,
here
's
old
Bill
Barley
.
<EOS>
Here
's
old
Bill
Barley
,
bless
your
eyes
.
<EOS>
Here
's
old
Bill
Barley
on
the
flat
of
his
back
,
by
the
Lord
.
<EOS>
Lying
on
the
flat
of
his
back
,
like
a
drifting
old
dead
flounder
,
here
's
your
old
Bill
Barley
,
bless
your
eyes
.
<EOS>
Ahoy
!
<EOS>
Bless
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
In
this
strain
of
consolation
,
Herbert
informed
me
the
invisible
Barley
would
commune
with
himself
by
the
day
and
night
together
;
often
while
it
was
light
,
having
,
at
the
same
time
,
one
eye
at
a
telescope
which
was
fitted
on
his
bed
for
the
convenience
of
sweeping
the
river
.
  
<EOS>
In
his
two
cabin
rooms
at
the
top
of
the
house
,
which
were
fresh
and
airy
,
and
in
which
Mr
Barley
was
less
audible
than
below
,
I
found
Provis
comfortably
settled
.
<EOS>
He
expressed
no
alarm
,
and
seemed
to
feel
none
that
was
worth
mentioning
;
but
it
struck
me
that
he
was
softened
---
indefinably
,
for
I
could
not
have
said
how
,
and
could
never
afterwards
recall
how
when
I
tried
;
but
certainly
.
  
<EOS>
The
opportunity
that
the
day
's
rest
had
given
me
for
reflection
,
had
resulted
in
my
fully
determining
to
say
nothing
to
him
respecting
Compeyson
.
<EOS>
For
anything
I
knew
,
his
animosity
towards
the
man
might
otherwise
lead
to
his
seeking
him
out
and
rushing
on
his
own
destruction
.
<EOS>
Therefore
,
when
Herbert
and
I
sat
down
with
him
by
his
fire
,
I
asked
him
first
of
all
whether
he
relied
on
Wemmick
's
judgment
and
sources
of
information
?
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
ay
,
dear
boy
!
"
<EOS>
he
answered
,
with
a
grave
nod
,
"
Jaggers
knows
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
,
I
have
talked
with
Wemmick
,
"
said
I
,
"
and
have
come
to
tell
you
what
caution
lie
gave
me
and
what
advice
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
This
I
did
accurately
,
with
the
reservation
just
mentioned
;
and
I
told
him
how
Wemmick
had
heard
,
in
Newgate
prison
(
whether
from
officers
or
prisoners
I
could
not
say
)
,
that
he
was
under
some
suspicion
,
and
that
my
chambers
had
been
watched
;
how
Wemmick
had
recommended
his
keeping
close
for
a
time
,
and
my
keeping
away
from
him
;
and
what
Wemmick
had
said
about
getting
him
abroad
.
<EOS>
I
added
,
that
of
course
,
when
the
time
came
,
I
should
go
with
him
,
or
should
follow
close
upon
him
,
as
might
be
safest
in
Wemmick
's
judgment
.
<EOS>
What
was
to
follow
that
,
I
did
not
touch
upon
;
neither
indeed
was
I
at
all
clear
or
comfortable
about
it
in
my
own
mind
,
<EOS>
now
that
I
saw
him
in
that
softer
condition
,
and
in
declared
peril
for
my
sake
.
<EOS>
As
to
altering
my
way
of
living
,
by
enlarging
my
expenses
,
I
put
it
to
him
whether
in
our
present
unsettled
and
difficult
circumstances
,
it
would
not
be
simply
ridiculous
,
if
it
were
no
worse
?
  
<EOS>
He
could
not
deny
this
,
and
indeed
was
very
reasonable
throughout
.
<EOS>
His
coming
back
was
a
venture
,
he
said
,
and
he
had
always
known
it
to
be
a
venture
.
<EOS>
He
would
do
nothing
to
make
it
a
desperate
venture
,
and
he
had
very
little
fear
of
his
safety
with
such
good
help
.
  
<EOS>
Herbert
,
who
had
been
looking
at
the
fire
and
pondering
,
here
said
that
something
had
come
into
his
thoughts
arising
out
of
Wemmick
's
suggestion
,
which
it
might
be
worth
while
to
pursue
.
<EOS>
"
We
are
both
good
watermen
,
Handel
,
and
could
take
him
down
the
river
ourselves
when
the
right
time
comes
.
<EOS>
No
boat
would
then
be
hired
for
the
purpose
,
and
no
boatmen
;
that
would
save
at
least
a
chance
of
suspicion
,
and
any
chance
is
worth
saving
.
<EOS>
Never
mind
the
season
;
do
n't
you
think
it
might
be
a
good
thing
if
you
began
at
once
to
keep
a
boat
at
the
Temple
stairs
,
and
were
in
the
habit
of
rowing
up
and
down
the
river
?
<EOS>
You
fall
into
that
habit
,
and
then
who
notices
or
minds
?
<EOS>
Do
it
twenty
or
fifty
times
,
and
there
is
nothing
special
in
your
doing
it
the
twenty
-
first
or
fifty
-
first
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
liked
this
scheme
,
and
Provis
was
quite
elated
by
it
.
<EOS>
We
agreed
that
it
should
be
carried
into
execution
,
and
that
Provis
should
never
recognize
us
if
we
came
below
Bridge
and
rowed
past
Mill
Pond
Bank
.
<EOS>
But
,
we
further
agreed
that
he
should
pull
down
the
blind
in
that
part
of
his
window
which
gave
upon
the
east
,
whenever
he
saw
us
and
all
was
right
.
  
<EOS>
Our
conference
being
now
ended
,
and
everything
arranged
,
I
rose
to
go
;
remarking
to
Herbert
that
he
and
I
had
better
not
go
home
together
,
and
that
I
would
take
half
an
hour
's
start
of
him
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
like
to
leave
you
here
,
"
I
said
to
Provis
,
"
though
I
can
not
doubt
your
being
safer
here
than
near
me
.
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
boy
,
"
he
answered
,
clasping
my
hands
,
"
I
do
n't
know
when
we
may
meet
again
,
and
I
do
n't
like
Good
-
bye
.
<EOS>
Say
Good
Night
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Good
night
!
<EOS>
Herbert
will
go
regularly
between
us
,
and
when
the
time
comes
you
may
be
certain
I
shall
be
ready
.
<EOS>
Good
night
,
Good
night
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
We
thought
it
best
that
he
should
stay
in
his
own
rooms
,
and
we
left
him
on
the
landing
outside
his
door
,
holding
a
light
over
the
stair
-
rail
to
light
us
down
stairs
.
<EOS>
Looking
back
at
him
,
I
thought
of
the
first
night
of
his
return
when
our
positions
were
reversed
,
and
when
I
little
supposed
my
heart
could
ever
be
as
heavy
and
anxious
at
parting
from
him
as
it
was
now
.
  
<EOS>
Old
Barley
was
growling
and
swearing
when
we
repassed
his
door
,
with
no
appearance
of
having
ceased
or
of
meaning
to
cease
.
<EOS>
When
we
got
to
the
foot
of
the
stairs
,
I
asked
Herbert
whether
he
had
preserved
the
name
of
Provis
.
<EOS>
He
replied
,
certainly
not
,
and
that
the
lodger
was
Mr
Campbell
.
<EOS>
He
also
explained
that
the
utmost
known
of
Mr
Campbell
there
,
was
,
that
he
(
Herbert
)
had
Mr
Campbell
consigned
to
him
,
and
felt
a
strong
personal
interest
in
his
being
well
cared
for
,
and
living
a
secluded
life
.
<EOS>
So
,
when
we
went
into
the
parlour
where
Mrs
Whimple
and
Clara
were
seated
at
work
,
I
said
nothing
of
my
own
interest
in
Mr
Campbell
,
but
kept
it
to
myself
.
  
<EOS>
When
I
had
taken
leave
of
the
pretty
gentle
dark
-
eyed
girl
,
and
of
the
motherly
woman
who
had
not
outlived
her
honest
sympathy
with
a
little
affair
of
true
love
,
I
felt
as
if
the
Old
Green
Copper
Rope
-
Walk
had
grown
quite
a
different
place
.
<EOS>
Old
Barley
might
be
as
old
as
the
hills
,
and
might
swear
like
a
whole
field
of
troopers
,
but
there
were
redeeming
youth
and
trust
and
hope
enough
in
Chinks
's
Basin
to
fill
it
to
overflowing
.
<EOS>
And
then
I
thought
of
Estella
,
and
of
our
parting
,
and
went
home
very
sadly
.
  
<EOS>
All
things
were
as
quiet
in
the
Temple
as
ever
I
had
seen
them
.
<EOS>
The
windows
of
the
rooms
of
that
side
,
lately
occupied
by
Provis
,
were
dark
and
still
,
and
there
was
no
lounger
in
Garden
-
court
.
<EOS>
I
walked
past
the
fountain
twice
or
thrice
before
I
descended
the
steps
that
were
between
me
and
my
rooms
,
but
I
was
quite
alone
.
<EOS>
Herbert
coming
to
my
bedside
when
he
came
in
---
for
I
went
straight
to
bed
,
dispirited
and
fatigued
---
made
the
same
report
.
<EOS>
Opening
one
of
the
windows
after
that
,
he
looked
out
into
the
moonlight
,
and
told
me
that
the
pavement
was
as
solemnly
empty
as
the
pavement
of
any
Cathedral
at
that
same
hour
.
  
<EOS>
Next
day
,
I
set
myself
to
get
the
boat
.
<EOS>
It
was
soon
done
,
and
the
boat
was
brought
round
to
the
Temple
stairs
,
and
lay
where
I
could
reach
her
within
a
minute
or
two
.
<EOS>
Then
,
I
began
to
go
out
as
for
training
and
practice
:
sometimes
alone
,
sometimes
with
Herbert
.
<EOS>
I
was
often
out
in
cold
,
rain
,
and
sleet
,
but
nobody
took
much
note
of
me
after
I
had
been
out
a
few
times
.
<EOS>
At
first
,
I
kept
above
Blackfriars
Bridge
;
but
as
the
hours
of
the
tide
changed
,
I
took
towards
London
Bridge
.
<EOS>
It
was
Old
London
Bridge
in
those
days
,
and
at
certain
states
of
the
tide
there
was
a
race
and
a
fall
of
water
there
which
gave
it
a
bad
reputation
.
<EOS>
But
I
knew
well
enough
how
to
"
shoot
"
the
bridge
after
seeing
it
done
,
and
so
began
to
row
about
among
the
shipping
in
the
Pool
,
and
down
to
Erith
.
<EOS>
The
first
time
I
passed
Mill
Pond
Bank
,
Herbert
and
I
were
pulling
a
pair
of
oars
;
and
,
both
in
going
and
returning
,
we
saw
the
blind
towards
the
east
come
down
.
<EOS>
Herbert
was
rarely
there
less
frequently
than
three
times
in
a
week
,
and
he
never
brought
me
a
single
word
of
intelligence
that
was
at

.
<EOS>
Still
,
I
knew
that
there
was
cause
for
alarm
,
and
<EOS>
I
could
not
get
rid
of
the
notion
of
being
watched
.
<EOS>
Once
received
,
it
is
a
haunting

;
how
many
undesigning
persons
I
suspected
of
watching
me
,
it
would
be
hard
to
calculate
.
  
<EOS>
In
short
,
I
was
always
full
of
fears
for
the
rash
man
who
was
in
hiding
.
<EOS>
Herbert
had
sometimes
said
to
me
that
he
found
it
pleasant
to
stand
at
one
of
our
windows
after
dark
,
when
the
tide
was
running
down
,
and
to
think
that
it
was
flowing
,
with
everything

,
towards
Clara
.
<EOS>
But

thought

that

was

Magwitch
,
and
that
any
black
mark
on

surface
might
be
his
pursuers
,
going
swiftly
,
silently
,
and

,
to

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
47
 
<EOS>
SOME
weeks
passed
without
bringing
any
change
.
<EOS>
We
waited
for
Wemmick
,
and
he
made
no
sign
.
<EOS>
If
I
had
never

out
of

Britain
,
and

the

on

,
I
might
have
doubted
him
;
not
so
for
a
moment
,
knowing
him
as
I
did
.
  
<EOS>
My
worldly
affairs
began
to
wear
a
gloomy
appearance
,
and
I
was
pressed
for
money
by
more
than
one

.
<EOS>
Even
I
myself
began
to
know
the
want
of
money
(
I
mean
of
ready
money
in
my
own
pocket
)
,
and
to
relieve

by
converting
some

into
cash
.
<EOS>
But
I
had
quite
determined
that
it
would

to
take
more

from
my
patron
in
the
existing
state
of
my
uncertain

and

.
<EOS>
Therefore
,
I
had
sent
him
the
unopened
pocket

book
by
Herbert
,
to
hold
in
his
own
keeping
<EOS>
and
I
felt
a
kind
of

---
whether
it
was
a
false

or
a

,
I
hardly

---
in
not

profited
by

since

.
  
<EOS>
As

,
an

upon

that
Estella
was
married
.
<EOS>
Fearful
of
having
it
confirmed
,
though
it
was
all
but

conviction
,
I
avoided
the

,
and
begged
Herbert
(
to

confided
the
circumstances
of
our
last

)
never
to
speak

her
to

.
<EOS>
Why
I
hoarded

this
last

of
the
robe
of

that
was
rent
and
given
to
the

,

do

!
<EOS>
Why

you
who
read
this
,
commit
that
not

of
your
own
,
last
year
,
last

,
last

?
  
<EOS>
It
was
an
unhappy
life
that
I
lived
,
and
its
one

,

over

like

,

.
<EOS>
Still
,

.
<EOS>
Let

as
I

,

that
he
was

;

,

,
for
Herbert
's

at

,
lest

,

evil

;

,

.
<EOS>
Condemned

,

,
and

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
There

when
,

,

through
the

;

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
From

,

that
I

now

.
  
<EOS>
One

,

,

.
<EOS>
I
had

Greenwich

,

.
<EOS>
It

,

.
<EOS>
Both

,
All

.
  
<EOS>
As

<EOS>

cold
<EOS>
,

.
<EOS>
The

<EOS>
(

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>

Black
,

,

,

<EOS>
I

what

<EOS>

---

<EOS>

---

,

.

,

!
"
<EOS>
A

,

,

,

,

)

,
<EOS>

;

(

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
This

's
(

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Mr

,

;

.
  
<EOS>
The

,

,

,

)

.
<EOS>
But

;

,

Genius

's

.

The

,

,

,

,

,

.

?
"

"

"

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

,

old
times
a
certain
Christmas
Day
,
when
you
were
quite
a
child
,
and
I
dined
at
Gargery
's
,
and
some
soldiers
came
to
the
door
to
get
a
pair
of
handcuffs
mended
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
remember
it
very
well
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
remember
that
there
was
a
chase
after
two
convicts
,
and
that
we
joined
in
it
,
and
that
Gargery
took
you
on
his
back
,
and
that
I
took
the
lead
and
you
kept
up
with
me
as
well
as
you
could
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
remember
it
all
very
well
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Better
than
he
thought
---
except
the
last
clause
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
remember
that
we
came
up
with
the
two
in
a
ditch
,
and
that
there
was
a
scuffle
between
them
,
and
that
one
of
them
had
been
severely
handled
and
much
mauled
about
the
face
,
by
the
other
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
see
it
all
before
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
that
the
soldiers
lighted
torches
,
and
put
the
two
in
the
centre
,
and
that
we
went
on
to
see
the
last
of
them
,
over
the
black
marshes
,
with
the
torchlight
shining
on
their
faces
---
I
am
particular
about
that
;
with
the
torchlight
shining
on
their
faces
,
when
there
was
an
outer
ring
of
dark
night
all
about
us
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
I.
<EOS>
"
I
remember
all
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Then
Mr
Pip
,
one
of
those
two
prisoners
sat
behind
you
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
I
saw
him
over
your
shoulder
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Steady
!
"
I
thought
.
<EOS>
I
asked
him
then
,
"
Which
of
the
two
do
you
suppose
you
saw
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
one
who
had
been
mauled
,
"
he
answered
readily
,
"
and
I
'll
swear
I
saw
him
!
<EOS>
The
more
I
think
of
him
,
the
more
certain
I
am
of
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
This
is
very
curious
!
"
<EOS>
said
I
,
with
the
best
assumption
I
could
put
on
,
of
its
being
nothing
more
to
me
.
"
<EOS>
Very
curious
indeed
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
can
not
exaggerate
the
enhanced
disquiet
into
which
this
conversation
threw
me
,
or
the
special
and
peculiar
terror
I
felt
at
<EOS>
Compeyson
's
having
been
behind
me
"
like
a
ghost
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
For
,
if
he
had
ever
been
out
of
my
thoughts
for
a
few
moments
together
since
the
hiding
had
begun
,
it
was
in
those
very
moments
when
he
was
closest
to
me
;
and
to
think
that
I
should
be
so
unconscious
and
off
my

after
all

,
was
as
if
I
had
shut
an
avenue
of
a
hundred
doors
to
keep
him
out
,
and
then
had
found
him
at
my
elbow
.
<EOS>
I
could
not
doubt
either
that
he
was
there
,
because
I
was
there
,
and
that
however
alight
an
appearance
of
danger
there
might
be
about
us
,
danger
was
always
near
and
active
.
  
<EOS>
I
put
such
questions
to
Mr
Wopsle
as
<EOS>
,
When
did
the
man
come
in
?
<EOS>
He
could
not
tell
me
that
;
he
saw
me
,
and
over
my
shoulder
he
saw
the
man
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
until
he
had
seen
him
for
some
time
that
he
began
to
identify
him
;
but
he
had
from
the
first
vaguely
associated
him
with
me
,
and
known
him
as
somehow
belonging
to
me
in
the
old
village
time
.
<EOS>
How
was
he
dressed
?
<EOS>
Prosperously
,
but
not
noticeably
otherwise
;
he
thought
,
in
black
.
<EOS>
Was
his
face
at
all
disfigured
?
<EOS>
No
,
he
believed
not
.
<EOS>
I
believed
not
,
too
,
for
,
although
in
my
brooding
state
I
had
taken
no
especial
notice
of
the
people
behind
me
,
I
thought
it
likely
that
a
face
at
all
disfigured
would
have
attracted
my
attention
.
  
<EOS>
When
Mr
Wopsle
had
imparted
to
me
all
that
he
could
recall
or
I
extract
,
and
when
I
had
treated
him
to
a
little
appropriate
refreshment
after
the

of
the
evening
,
we
parted
.
<EOS>
It
was
between
twelve
and
one
o'clock
when
I
reached
the
Temple
,
and
the
gates
were
shut
.
<EOS>
No
one
was
near
me
when
I
went
in
and
went
home
.
  
<EOS>
Herbert
had
come
in
,
and
we
held
a
very
serious
council
by
the
fire
.
<EOS>
But
there
was
nothing
to
be
done
,
saving
to
communicate
to
Wemmick
what
I
had
that
night
<EOS>
found

,
and
to
remind

that
we
waited
for
his

.
<EOS>
As
I
thought
chat
I
might
compromise
him
if
I
went
too
often
to
the
Castle
,
I
made
this
communication
by

.
<EOS>
I
wrote
it
before
I
went
to
bed
,
and
went
out
and
posted
it
;
and
again
no
one
was
near

.
<EOS>
Herbert
<EOS>
and
I
agreed
that
we
could
do
nothing
else
but
be
very
cautious
.
<EOS>
And
we
were
very
cautious
indeed
---
more

than
before
,
if
that
were
possible
---
and
I
for
my
part
never
went
near
Chinks
's

,
except
when
I
rowed
by
,
and
then
I
only
looked
at
Mill
Pond
Bank
as
I
looked
at
anything
else
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
48
 
<EOS>
THE
second
of
the
two
meetings
referred
to
in
the
last
chapter
,
occurred
about
a
week
after
the
first
.
<EOS>
I
had
again
left
my
boat
at
the
wharf
below
Bridge
;
the
time
was
an
hour
earlier
in
the
afternoon
;
and
,
undecided
where
to
dine
,
I
had
strolled
up
into
Cheapside
,
and
was
strolling
along
it
,
<EOS>
surely
the
most
unsettled
person
in
all
the
busy
concourse
,
when
a
large
hand
was
laid
upon
my
shoulder
,
by
some
one
overtaking
me
.
<EOS>
It
was
Mr
Jaggers
's
hand
,
and
he
passed
it
through
my
arm
.
  
<EOS>
"
As
we
are
going
in
the
same
direction
,
Pip
,
we
may
walk

.
<EOS>
Where
are

bound
for
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
For
the
Temple
,
I
think
,
"
said
I.
  
"
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
know
?
"
said
Mr
Jaggers
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
I
returned
,
glad
for
once
to
get
the
better
of
him
in
cross

examination
,
"
I
do
 
\
not
\
 
<EOS>
know
,
for
I
have
not
made
up
my
mind
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
going
to
dine
?
"
said
Mr
Jaggers
.
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
mind
admitting
that
,
I
suppose
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
No
,
I
returned
,
I
do
n't

that
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
are
not
engaged
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
mind

also
,
that
I
am
not
engaged
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
,
"
said
Mr
Jaggers
,
"
come
and

me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
was
going
to

,
when
he
added
,
"
Wemmick
's
coming
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
,
I
changed
my
excuse
into
an
acceptance
---
<EOS>
the
few
words
I
had
uttered
,
serving
for
the
beginning
of
either
---
<EOS>
and
we
went
along
Cheapside
and
slanted
off
to
Little
Britain
,
while
the
lights
were
springing
up
brilliantly
in
the
shop
windows
,
and
the
street
lamp
-
lighters
,
scarcely

ground

on
in

's

,
were

and

in

,

red

in

than
my
rushlight
tower
at
the
Hummums
had
opened
white

in
the
ghostly

.
  
<EOS>
At
the
office
in
Little
Britain
there
was
the
usual
letter
-
writing
,
hand
-

,
candle
-

,
and
safe

,
that
closed
the
business

the
day
.
<EOS>
As
I
stood
idle
by
Mr
Jagger
's
fire
,
its
rising
and
falling
flame
made
the
two
casts
on
the
shelf
look
as
if

were
playing
a
diabolical
game
at
bo
-
peep
with

;
while
the
pair
of
coarse
fat
office
candles
that
dimly
lighted
Mr
Jaggers
as
he
wrote
in
a
corner
,
were
decorated
with
dirty

-
sheets
,
as
if

of
a
host
of

.
  
<EOS>
We
went
to
Gerrard
-
street
,
all
three
together
,
in
a
hackney
-

:
and
as

as

there
,

was

.
<EOS>
Although
I
should
not

thought
of
making
,
in
that

,
the
most
distant
reference
by
so
much
as

look
to
Wemmick
's
Walworth

,
yet
I
should

no

now
and
then
in

way
.
<EOS>
But

was
not

done
.
<EOS>
He
turned
his

on
Mr
Jaggers
whenever

raised

from
the

,
and
was
as
dry

distant

me
as
if
there
were
twin
Wemmicks
and
this
was

wrong

.
  
<EOS>
"
Did
you
send
that
note
of
Miss
Havisham
's
to
Mr
Pip
,
Wemmick
?
"
<EOS>
Mr
Jaggers

,
soon

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

,
"
returned
Wemmick
;
"
it

going
by
post
,
when

Mr

into

office
.
<EOS>
Here
it
is
.
"
<EOS>
He
handed

to
his

,
instead

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
note
of
two
lines
,
Pip
,
"
said
Mr
Jaggers
,
handing

on
,
"
sent
up

me

Miss
Havisham
,
on

of

.
<EOS>
She

business

mentioned

.
<EOS>
You
'll

down
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said

,

,
which

.
  
<EOS>
"
When
do

?
"
  
"
I

,
"
said

,

Wemmick
,
who
was
putting
fish
into
the
post
-
office
,
"
that
renders
me
rather

my

.
<EOS>
At
once
,
I
think
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
If

,
"
said

to

,
"
he
need

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Receiving

it

delay
I
settled
that
I
would
go
to
-
morrow
,
and
said

.
<EOS>
Wemmick
drank
a
glass
of
wine
and
looked
with
a

satisfied
air
at
Mr
Jaggers
,
but
not

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
,
Pip
!
<EOS>
Our
friend
the
Spider
,
"
said
Mr
Jaggers
,
"
has
played
his
cards
.
<EOS>
He
has
won
the
pool
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
as
much
as
I
could
do

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Hah
!
<EOS>
He
is
a
promising
fellow
---
in

---
but
he
may
not

all

.
<EOS>
The
stronger
will
win
in

end
,
but
the
stronger
has
to

.
<EOS>
If

turn

,
and
beat
her
---
"
  
"
Surely
,
"
I

,

"

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
did

,
Pip
.
<EOS>
I
am
putting
a
case
.
<EOS>
If
he
should
turn
to
and
beat
her
,
he
may
possibly
get
the
strength
on
his
side
;
if

,

.
<EOS>
It

chance

to

how

,
because

's

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
May

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
fellow

our

the
Spider
,
"
answered

Jaggers
,
"
either
beats
,
or

.
<EOS>
He
may

,
or

;
but
he
either
beats
or
cringes
.
<EOS>
Ask
Wemmick
 
<EOS>
\
<EOS>
his
\
 
opinion
.
  
<EOS>
"
Either
beats
or

,
"
said
Wemmick
,
not

.
  
<EOS>
"
So
,

's

,
"

,

,
"

<EOS>
To

the
lady
                     
GREAT
EXPECTATIONS
 
<EOS>
\
and
\
 
<EOS>
the
gentleman
,

never
will

.
<EOS>
Now
,
Molly
,
Molly
,
Molly
,
Molly
,
how
slow

are
to
-

!
"
  
<EOS>
She
was
at
his

when
he
addressed

,
putting
a
dish
upon

.
<EOS>
As
she
withdrew
her
hands
from
it
,
she

back
a

,
nervously

some

.
<EOS>
And
a
certain

of
her

as
she
spoke
arrested
my
attention
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
's
the

?
"
said
Mr
Jaggers
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
.
<EOS>
Only
the
subject
we
were
speaking
of
,
"
said
I
,
"
was
rather
painful
to
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
action
of
her
fingers
was
like
the
action
of
knitting
.
<EOS>
She
stood
looking
at
her
master
,
not
understanding
whether
she
was
free
to
go
,
or
whether
he
had
more
to
say
to
her
and
would

back
if
she
did
go
.
<EOS>
Her
look
was
very
intent
.
<EOS>
Surely
,
I
had
seen
exactly
such
eyes
and
such
hands
,
on
a
memorable
occasion
very
lately
!
  
<EOS>
He
dismissed
her
,
and
she

the

.
<EOS>
But
she
remained
before

,
as

if

.
<EOS>
I
looked
at
those
hands
,
I

I

that

;
and
I
compared

with
other
hands
,
other

,
other
hair
,
that
I

,
and
with
what

might

after
twenty

of

.
<EOS>
I
looked
again
at
those
hands
and

of
the
housekeeper
,
and
thought

the

that
had
come

when

last

---
not

---
in

,

.
<EOS>
I
thought

had

,

---

---

.
<EOS>
I

one

,

.
<EOS>
And

's

.
  
<EOS>
Mr
Jaggers
had
seen

,

I

<EOS>
He

<EOS>
Only

<EOS>
But

Estella

<EOS>
It

,
for

<EOS>
Chapter
49
 
PUTTING
Miss

's

,
that

,

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
But
I
alighted

,

,
and

the
rest

the

;
for
,
I
sought
to
get
into
the
town
quietly
by
the
unfrequented
ways
,
and
to
leave
it
in
the
same
manner
.
  
<EOS>
The
best
light
of
the
day
was
gone
when
I
passed
along
the
quiet
echoing
courts
behind
the
High
-
street
.
<EOS>
The
nooks
of
ruin
where
the
old
monks
had
once
had
their
refectories
and
gardens
,
and
where
the
strong
walls
were
now
pressed
into
the
service
of
humble
sheds
and

,
were
almost
as
silent
as
the
old
monks
in
their

.
<EOS>
The
cathedral
chimes
had
at
once
a
sadder
and
a
more
remote
sound
to
me
,
as
I
hurried
on
avoiding
observation
,
than
they
had
ever
had
before
;
so
,
the
swell
of
the
old
organ
was
borne
to
my

like

;
and
the
rooks
,

bare

of

priory
-

,
seemed
to
call
to
me
that
the
place
was
changed
,
and
that
Estella
was
gone
out
of
it
for
ever
.
  
<EOS>
An
elderly
woman
whom
I
had
seen
before
as
one
of
the
servants
who
lived

the
supplementary

-

,

.
<EOS>
The
lighted
candle
stood
in
the
dark

within
,
as
of
old
,
and
I
took
it
up
and
ascended

.
<EOS>
Miss
Havisham
was
not
in
her
own
room
,
but
was
in
the
larger
room
across
the
landing
.
<EOS>
Looking
in
at
the
door
,
after
knocking
in
vain
,
I
saw
her
sitting
on
the
hearth
in
a
ragged
chair
,
close
before
,
and
lost
in
the
contemplation
of
,
the
ashy
fire
.
  
<EOS>
Doing
as
I
had
often
done
,
I
went
in
,
and
stood
,
touching
the
old
chimney
-
piece
,
where
she
could
see
me
when
she
raised
her
eyes
.
<EOS>
There
was
an
air
of
utter
loneliness
upon
her
,
that
would
have
moved
me
to
pity
though
she
had
wilfully
done
me
a
deeper
injury
than
I
could
charge
her
with
.
<EOS>
As
I
stood
compassionating
her
and
thinking
how
in
the
progress
of
time
I
too
had
come
to
be
a
part
of
the
wrecked
fortunes
of
that
house
,
her
eyes
rested
on
me
.
<EOS>
She
stared
,
and
said
in
a
low
voice
,
"
Is
it
real
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
I
,
Pip
.
<EOS>
Mr
Jaggers
gave
me
your
note
yesterday
,
and
I
have
lost
no
time
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
.
<EOS>
Thank
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
As
I
brought
another
of
the
ragged
chairs
to
the
hearth
and
sat
down
,
I
remarked
a
new
expression
on
her
face
,
as
if
she
were
afraid
of
me
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
want
,
"
she
said
,
"
to
pursue
that
subject
you
mentioned
to
me
when
you
were
last
here
,
and
to
show
you
that
I
am
not
all
stone
.
<EOS>
But
perhaps
you
can
never
believe
,
now
,
that
there
is
anything
human
in
my
heart
?
"
  
<EOS>
When
I
said
some
reassuring
words
,
she
stretched
out
her
tremulous
right
hand
,
as
though
she
was
going
to
touch
me
;
but
she
recalled
it
again
before
I
understood
the
action
,
or
knew
how
to
receive
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
said
,
speaking
for
your
friend
,
that
you
could
tell
me
how
to
do
something
useful
and
good
.
<EOS>
Something
that
you
would
like
done
,
is
it
not
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Something
that
I
would
like
done
very
much
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
began
explaining
to
her
that
secret
history
of
the
partnership
.
<EOS>
I
had
not
got
far
into
it
,
when
I
judged
from
her
looks
that
she
was
thinking
in
a
discursive
way
of
me
,
rather
than
of
what
I
said
.
<EOS>
It
seemed
to
be
so
,
for
,
when
I
stopped
speaking
,
many
moments
passed
before
she
showed
that
she
was
conscious
of
the
fact
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
break
off
,
"
she
asked
then
,
with
her
former
air
of
being
afraid
of
me
,
"
because
you
hate
me
too
much
to
bear
to
speak
to
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
I
answered
,
"
how
can
you
think
so
,
Miss
Havisham
!
<EOS>
I
stopped
because
I
thought
you
were
not
following
what
I
said
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
I
was
not
,
"
she
answered
,
putting
a
hand
to
her
head
.
"
<EOS>
Begin
again
,
and
let
me
look
at
something
else
.
<EOS>
Stay
!
<EOS>
Now
tell
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
set
her
hand
upon
her
stick
,
in
the
resolute
way
that
sometimes
was
habitual
to
her
,
and
looked
at
the
fire
with
a
strong
expression
of
forcing
herself
to
attend
.
<EOS>
I
went
on
with
my
explanation
,
and
told
her
how
I
had
hoped
to
complete
the
transaction
out
of
my
means
,
but
how
in
this
I
was
disappointed
.
<EOS>
That
part
of
the
subject
(
I
reminded
her
)
involved
matters
which
could
form
no
part
of
my
explanation
,
for
they
were
the
weighty
secrets
of
another
.
  
<EOS>
"
So
!
"
said
she
,
assenting
with
her
head
,
but
not
looking
at
me
.
"
<EOS>
And
how
much
money
is
wanting
to
complete
the
purchase
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
was
rather
afraid
of
stating
it
,
for
it
sounded
a
large
sum
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Nine
hundred
pounds
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
give
you
the
money
for
this
purpose
,
will
you
keep
my
secret
as
you
have
kept
your
own
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Quite
as
faithfully
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
your
mind
will
be
more
at
rest
?
"
  
"
Much
more
at
rest
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
very
unhappy
now
?
"
  
<EOS>
She
asked
this
question
,
still
without
looking
at
me
,
but
in
an
unwonted
tone
of
sympathy
.
<EOS>
I
could
not
reply
at
the
moment
,
for
my
voice
failed
me
.
<EOS>
She
put
her
left
arm
across
the
head
of
her
stick
,
and
softly
laid
her
forehead
on
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
far
from
happy
,
Miss
Havisham
;
but
I
have
other
causes
of
disquiet
than
any
you
know
of
.
<EOS>
They
are
the
secrets
I
have
mentioned
.
"
  
<EOS>
After
a
little
while
,
she
raised
her
head
and
looked
at
the
fire
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
noble
in
you
to
tell
me
that
you
have
other
causes
of
unhappiness
.
<EOS>
Is
it
true
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Too
true
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Can
I
only
serve
you
,
Pip
,
by
serving
your
friend
?
<EOS>
Regarding
that
as
done
,
is
there
nothing
I
can
do
for
you
yourself
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Nothing
.
<EOS>
I
thank
you
for
the
question
.
<EOS>
I
thank
you
even
more
for
the
tone
of
the
question
.
<EOS>
But
,
there
is
nothing
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
presently
rose
from
her
seat
,
and
looked
about
the
blighted
room
for
the
means
of
writing
.
<EOS>
There
were
none
there
,
and
she
took
from
her
pocket
a
yellow
set
of
ivory
tablets
,
mounted
in
tarnished
gold
,
and
wrote
upon
them
with
a
pencil
in
a
case
of
tarnished
gold
that
hung
from
her
neck
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
still
on
friendly
terms
with
Mr
Jaggers
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Quite
.
<EOS>
I
dined
with
him
yesterday
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
This
is
an
authority
to
him
to
pay
you
that
money
,
to
lay
out
at
your
irresponsible
discretion
for
your
friend
.
<EOS>
I
keep
no
money
here
;
but
if
you
would
rather
Mr
Jaggers
knew
nothing
of
the
matter
,
I
will
send
it
to
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
Miss
Havisham
;
I
have
not
the
least
objection
to
receiving
it
from
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
read
me
what
she
had
written
,
and
it
was
direct
and
clear
,
and
evidently
intended
to
absolve
me
from
any
suspicion
of
profiting
by
the
receipt
of
the
money
.
<EOS>
I
took
the
tablets
from
her
hand
,
and
it
trembled
again
,
and
it
trembled
more
as
she
took
off
the
chain
to
which
the
pencil
was
attached
,
and
put
it
in
mine
.
<EOS>
All
this
she
did
,
without
looking
at
me
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
name
is
on
the
first
leaf
.
<EOS>
If
you
can
ever
write
under
my
name
,
"
I
forgive
her
,
"
though
ever
so
long
after
my
broken
heart
is
dust
---
<EOS>
pray
do
it
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
O
Miss
Havisham
,
"
said
I
,
"
I
can
do
it
now
.
<EOS>
There
have
been
sore
mistakes
;
and
my
life
has
been
a
blind
and
thankless
one
;
and
I
want
forgiveness
and
direction
far
too
much
,
to
be
bitter
with
you
.
  
<EOS>
She
turned
her
face
to
me
for
the
first
time
since
she
had
averted
it
,
and
,
to
my
amazement
,
I
may
even
add
to
my
terror
,
dropped
on
her
knees
at
my
feet
;
with
her
folded
hands
raised
to
me
in
the
manner
in
which
,
when
her
poor
heart
was
young
and
fresh
and
whole
,
they
must
often
have
been
raised
to
heaven
from
her
mother
's
side
.
  
<EOS>
To
see
her
with
her
white
hair
and
her
worn
face
kneeling
at
my
feet
,
gave
me
a
shock
through
all
my
frame
.
<EOS>
I
entreated
her
to
rise
,
and
got
my
arms
about
her
to
help
her
up
;
but
she
only
pressed
that
hand
of
mine
which
was
nearest
to
her
grasp
,
and
hung
her
head
over
it
and
wept
.
<EOS>
I
had
never
seen
her
shed
a
tear
before
,
and
,
in
the
hope
that
the
relief
might
do
her
good
,
I
bent
over
her
without
speaking
.
<EOS>
She
was
not
kneeling
now
,
but
was
down
upon
the
ground
.
  
<EOS>
"
O
!
<EOS>
"
she
cried
,
despairingly
.
<EOS>
"
What
have
I
done
!
<EOS>
What
have
I
done
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
mean
,
Miss
Havisham
,
what
have
you
done
to
injure
me
,
let
me
answer
.
<EOS>
Very
little
.
<EOS>
I
should
have
loved
her
under
any
circumstances
.
<EOS>
---
Is
she
married
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
needless
question
,
for
a
new
desolation
in
the
desolate
house
had
told
me
so
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
have
I
done
!
<EOS>
What
have
I
done
!
"
<EOS>
She
wrung
her
hands
,
and
crushed
her
white
hair
,
and
returned
to
this
cry
over
and
over
again
.
<EOS>
"
What
have
I
done
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
knew
not
how
to
answer
,
or
how
to
comfort
her
.
<EOS>
That
she
had
done
a
grievous
thing
in
taking
an
impressionable
child
to
mould
into
the
form
that
her
wild
resentment
,
spurned
affection
,
and
wounded
pride
,
found
vengeance
in
<EOS>
,
I
knew
full
well
.
<EOS>
But
that
,
in
shutting
out
the
light
of
day
,
she
had
shut
out
infinitely
more
;
that
,
in
seclusion
,
she
had
secluded
herself
from
a
thousand
natural
and
healing
influences
;
that
,
her
mind
,
brooding
solitary
,
had
grown
diseased
,
as
all
minds
do
and
must
and
will
that
reverse
the
appointed
order
of
their
Maker
;
I
knew
equally
well
.
<EOS>
And
could
I
look
upon
her
without
compassion
,
seeing
her
punishment
in
the
ruin
she
was
,
in
her
profound
unfitness
for
this
earth
on
which
she
was
placed
,
in
the
vanity
of
sorrow
which
had
become
a
master
mania
,
like
the
vanity
of
penitence
,
the
vanity
of
remorse
,
the
vanity
of
unworthiness
,
and
other
monstrous
vanities
that
have
been
curses
in
this
world
?
   
<EOS>
"
Until
you
spoke
to
her
the
other
day
,
and
until
I
saw
in
you
a
looking
-
glass
that
showed
me
what
I
once
felt
myself
,
I
did
not
know
what
I
had
done
.
<EOS>
What
have
I
done
!
<EOS>
What
have
I
done
!
"
<EOS>
And
so
again
,
twenty
,
fifty
times
over
,
What
had
she
done
!
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Havisham
,
"
I
said
,
when
her
cry
had
died
away
,
"
you
may
dismiss
me
from
your
mind
and
conscience
.
<EOS>
But
Estella
is
a
different
case
,
and
if
you
can
ever
undo
any
scrap
of
what
you
have
done
amiss
in
keeping
a
part
of
her
right
nature
away
from
her
,
it
will
be
better
to
do
that
,
than
to
bemoan
the
past
through
a
hundred
years
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
yes
,
I
know
it
.
<EOS>
But
,
Pip
---
my
Dear
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
There
was
an
earnest
womanly
compassion
for
me
in
her
new
affection
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
Dear
!
<EOS>
Believe
this
:
when
she
first
came
to
me
,
I
meant
to
save
her
from
misery
like
my
own
.
<EOS>
At
first
I
meant
no
more
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
!
"
said
I.
<EOS>
"
I
hope
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
But
as
she
grew
,
and
promised
to
be
very
beautiful
,
I
gradually
did
worse
,
and
with
my
praises
,
and
with
my
jewels
,
and
with
my
teachings
,
and
with
this
figure
of
myself
always
before
her
a
warning
to
back
and
point
my
lessons
,
I
stole
her
heart
away
and
put
ice
in
its
place
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Better
,
"
I
could
not
help
saying
,
"
to
have
left
her
a
natural
heart
,
even
to
be
bruised
or
broken
.
"
  
<EOS>
With
that
,
Miss
Havisham
looked
distractedly
at
me
for
a
while
,
and
then
burst
out
again
,
What
had
she
done
!
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
knew
all
my
story
,
"
she
pleaded
,
"
you
would
have
some
compassion
for
me
and
a
better
understanding
of
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Miss
Havisham
,
"
I
answered
,
as
delicately
as
I
could
,
"
I
believe
I
may
say
that
I
do
know
your
story
,
and
have
known
it
ever
since
I
first
left
this
neighbourhood
.
<EOS>
It
has
inspired
me
with
great
commiseration
,
and
I
hope
I
understand
it
and
its
influences
.
<EOS>
Does
what
has
passed
between
us
give
me
any
excuse
for
asking
you
a
question
relative
to
Estella
?
<EOS>
Not
as
she
is
,
but
as
she
was
when
she
first
came
here
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
was
seated
on
the
ground
,
with
her
arms
on
the
ragged
chair
,
and
her
head
leaning
on
them
.
<EOS>
She
looked
full
at
me
when
I
said
this
,
and
replied
,
"
Go
on
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Whose
child
was
Estella
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
shook
her
head
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
know
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
shook
her
head
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
Mr
Jaggers
brought
her
here
,
or
sent
her
here
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Brought
her
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Will
you
tell
me
how
that
came
about
?
"
  
<EOS>
She
answered
in
a
low
whisper
and
with
caution
:
"
I
had
been
shut
up
in
these
rooms
a
long
time
(
I
do
n't
know
how
long
;
you
know
what
time
the
clocks
keep
here
)
,
when
I
told
him
that
I
wanted
a
little
girl
to
rear
and
love
,
and
save
from
my
fate
.
<EOS>
I
had
first
seen
him
when
I
sent
for
him
to
lay
this
place
waste
for
me
;
having
read
of
him
in
the
newspapers
,
before
I
and
the
world
parted
.
<EOS>
He
told
me
that
he
would
look
about
him
for
such
an
orphan
child
.
<EOS>
One
night
he
brought
her
here
asleep
,
and
I
called
her
Estella
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Might
I
ask
her
age
then
?
"
  
"
Two
or
three
.
<EOS>
She
herself
knows
nothing
,
but
that
she
was
left
an
orphan
and
I
adopted
her
.
"
  
<EOS>
So
convinced
I
was
of
that
woman
's
being
her
mother
,
that
I
wanted
no
evidence
to
establish
the
fact
in

.
<EOS>
But
,
to
any
mind
,
I
thought
,
the
connection
here
was
clear
and
straight
.
  
<EOS>
What
more
could
I
hope
to
do
by
prolonging
the
interview
?
<EOS>
I
had
succeeded
on
behalf
of
Herbert
,
Miss
Havisham
had
told
me
all
she
knew
of
Estella
,
I
had
said
and
done
what
I
could
to
ease
her
mind
.
<EOS>
No
matter
with
what
other
words
we
parted
;
we
parted
.
  
<EOS>
Twilight
was
closing
in
when
I
went
down
stairs
into
the
natural
air
.
<EOS>
I
called
to
the
woman
who
had
opened
the
gate
when
I
entered
,
that
I
would
not
trouble
her
just
yet
,
but
would
walk
round
the
place
before
leaving
.
<EOS>
For
,
I
had
a
presentiment
that
I
should
never
be
there
again
,
and
I
felt
that
the
dying
light
was
suited
to
my
last
view
of
it
.
  
<EOS>
By
the
wilderness
of
casks
that
I
had
walked
on
long
ago
,
and
on
which
the
rain
of
years
had
fallen
since
,
rotting
them
in
many

,
and

and

water
upon
those
that
stood

,
I
made
my
way
to
the
ruined

.
<EOS>
I
went
all
round
it
;
round
by
the
corner
where
Herbert
and
I
had
fought
our
battle
;
round
by
the
paths
where
Estella
and
I
had
walked
.
<EOS>
So
cold
,
so
lonely
,
so
dreary
all
!
  
<EOS>
Taking
the
brewery
on
my
way
back
,
I
raised
the
rusty

of
a
little
door
at
the
garden
end
of
it
,
and
walked
through
.
<EOS>
I
was
going
out
at
the
opposite
door
---
not
easy
to
open
now
,
for
the
damp
wood
had
started
and
swelled
,
and
the
hinges
were
yielding
,
and
the
threshold
was
encumbered
with

---
when
I
turned

to
look
back
.
<EOS>
A
childish
association
revived
with
wonderful
force
in
the
moment
of
the
slight
action
,
and
I
fancied
that
I
saw
Miss
Havisham
hanging
to
the
beam
.
<EOS>
So
strong
was
the
impression
,
that
I
stood
under
the
beam
shuddering
from
head
to
foot
before
I
knew
it
was
a
fancy
---
though
to
be
sure
I
was
there
in
an
instant
.
  
<EOS>
The
mournfulness
of
the
place
and
time
,
and
the
great
terror
of
this
illusion
,
though
it
was
but

,
caused

as

came

between
the
open

gates
where
I
had
once
wrung
my
hair
after
Estella
had
wrung

heart
.
<EOS>
Passing
on
into
the
front
court
-
yard
,
I
hesitated
whether
to
call
the
woman
to
let
me
out
at
the
locked

of
which
she
had

,
or
first
to
go
up

and

that

.
<EOS>
I
took
the
latter

and
went
up
.
  
<EOS>
I
looked
into
the
room
where
I
had
left
her
,
and
I
saw
her
seated
in
the
ragged

,
with

.
<EOS>
In

when
I
was
withdrawing

to
go

,
I
saw
a
great

light
spring
up
.
<EOS>
In

same

,
I
saw
her
running
at

,
shrieking
,
with
a
whirl
of
fire
blazing
all

her
,
and
soaring
at
least

.
  
<EOS>
I
had
a
double
-
caped
great

coat

,
and
over
my
arm
another
thick
coat
.
<EOS>
That
I
got

off
,
closed

,
threw

,
and
got

;
that

for

,
and

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

we

on
the
floor

,
and
that

,
which
,

,

been
her

.
  
<EOS>
Then
,

,
and

.
<EOS>
I
still

forcibly
down

,

;
and

,

,

,
until

,
no

.
  
<EOS>
She

,
and
I
was

,

.
<EOS>
Assistance
was
sent

and
I
held

until

,
as
if

unreasonably

(
I

)
that

,

.
<EOS>
When

,
on

's

,
I

were

;
for
,

had
no

of
it
through

.
  
<EOS>
On

of

;

.
<EOS>
By

great

:
which
happened

to

.
<EOS>
When
I

again
,
an

,

,
and

would

.
  
<EOS>
Though
every

of
her
dress
was

,

,
she
still

something
of
her
old

;
for
,

had
covered

to

,

,

something
that
had
been
and
was
changed
,
was

.
  
<EOS>
I
found
,
on

,
that
Estella
was
in
Paris
,
and
I
got
a

that

.
<EOS>
Miss
Havisham
's
family
<EOS>
I
took
upon

;
intending
to
communicate
with
Mr
Matthew
Pocket
only
,
and
leave

to
do

about

rest
.
<EOS>
This
I
did
next
day
,
through
Herbert
,
as
soon
as
I
returned
to
town
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
stage
,
that
evening
,
when
she
spoke
collectedly
of
what
had
happened
,
though
with
a
certain
terrible
vivacity
.
<EOS>
Towards
midnight
she
began
to
wander
in
her
speech
,
and
after
that
it
gradually
set
in
that
she
said
innumerable
times
in
a
low

voice
,
"
What
have
I
done
!
"
<EOS>
And
then
,
"
When
she
first
came
,
I
meant
to
save
her
from
misery
like
mine
.
"
<EOS>
And
then
,
---
Take
the
pencil
and
write
under
my
name
,
"
I
forgive
her
!
"
<EOS>
"
She
never
changed
the
order
of
these
three
sentences
,
but
she
sometimes
left
out
a
word
in
one
or
other
of
them
;
never
putting
in
another
word
,
but
always
leaving

blank
and
going
on
to
the
next
word
.
  
<EOS>
As
I
could
do
no
service
there
,
and
as
I
had
,
nearer
home
,
that
pressing
reason
for
anxiety
and
fear
which
even
her
wanderings
could
not
drive
out
of
my
mind
,
I
decided
in
the
course
of
the
night
that
I
would
return
by
the
early

coach
:
walking
on
a
mile
or
so
,
and
being
taken
up

of

.
<EOS>
At
about

of

,

,
I
leaned
over
her
and
touched
her
lips
with

,
just
as

said
,
not

for

,
"
Take
the
pencil
and
write
under
my
name
,
---"I
forgive
her
.
"
<EOS>
"
    
Chapter
50
 
MY
hands
had
been
dressed
twice
or
thrice
in
the
night
,
and
again
in
the
morning
.
<EOS>
My
left
arm
was
a
good
deal
burned
to
the
elbow
,
and
,
less
severely
,
as
high
as
the
shoulder
;
it
was
very
painful
,
but
the
flames
had
set
in
that
direction
,
and
I
felt
thankful
it
was
no
worse
.
<EOS>
My
right
hand
was
not
so
badly
burnt
but
that
I
could
move
the
fingers
.
<EOS>
It
was
bandaged
,
of
course
,
but
much
less
inconveniently
than
my
left
hand
and
arm
;
those
I
carried
in
a
sling
;
and
I
could
only
wear
my
coat
like
a
cloak
,
loose
over
my
shoulders
and
fastened
at
the
neck
.
<EOS>
My
hair
had
been
caught
by
the
fire
,
but
not
my
head
or
face
.
  
<EOS>
When
Herbert
had
been
down
to
Hammersmith
and
seen
his
father
,
he
came
back
to
me
at
our
chambers
,
and
devoted
the
day
to
attending
on
me
.
<EOS>
He
was
the
kindest
of
nurses
,
and
at
stated
times
took
off
the
bandages
,
and
steeped
them
in
the
cooling
liquid
that
was
kept
ready
,
and
put
them
on
again
,
with
a
patient
tenderness
that
I
was
deeply
grateful
for
.
  
<EOS>
At
first
,
as
I
lay
quiet
on
the
sofa
,
I
found
it
painfully
difficult
,
I
might
say
impossible
,
to
get
rid
of
the
impression
of
the
glare
of
the
flames
,
their
hurry
and
noise
,
and
the
fierce
burning
smell
.
<EOS>
If
I
dozed
for
a
minute
,
I
was
awakened
by
Miss
Havisham
's
cries
,
and
by
her
running
at
me
with
all
that
height
of
fire
above
her
head
.
<EOS>
This
pain
of
the
mind
was
much
harder
to
strive
against
than
any
bodily
pain
I
suffered
;
and
Herbert
,
seeing
that
,
did
his
utmost
to
hold
my
attention
engaged
.
  
<EOS>
Neither
of
us
spoke
of
the
boat
,
but
we
both
thought
of
it
.
<EOS>
That
was
made
apparent
by
our
avoidance
of
the
subject
,
and
by
our
agreeing
---
without
agreement
---
to
make
my
recovery
of
the
use
of
my
hands
,
a
question
of
so
many
hours
,
not
of
so
many
weeks
.
  
<EOS>
My
first
question
when
I
saw
Herbert
had
been
of
course
,
whether
all
was
well
down
the
river
?
<EOS>
As
he
replied
in
the
affirmative
,
with
perfect
confidence
and
cheerfulness
,
we
did
not
resume
the
subject
until
the
day
was
wearing
away
.
<EOS>
But
then
,
as
Herbert
changed
the
bandages
,
more
by
the
light
of
the
fire
than
by
the
outer
light
,
he
went
back
to
it
spontaneously
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
sat
with
Provis
last
night
,
Handel
,
two
good
hours
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Where
was
Clara
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
little
thing
!
"
said
Herbert
.
<EOS>
"
She
was
up
and
down
with
Gruffandgrim
all
the
evening
.
<EOS>
He
was
perpetually
pegging
at

,
the

.
<EOS>
I
doubt

he
can
hold

.
<EOS>
What
with
rum
and
pepper
---
and
pepper
and
rum
---
I
should
think
his
pegging
must
be
nearly
over
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
then
you
will
be
married
,
Herbert
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
can
I
take

the
dear
child
otherwise
?
<EOS>
---
Lay
your
arm
out
upon
the
back

the
sofa
,
my
dear
boy
,
and
I
'll

down
here
,
and
get

off
<EOS>
so
gradually
that
you
shall
not
know

it
comes
.
<EOS>
I
was
speaking
of
Provis
.
<EOS>
Do
you
know
,
Handel
,
he
improves
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
said
to
you
I
thought
he
was
softened
when
I
last
saw
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
you
did
.
<EOS>
And
so
he
is
.
<EOS>
He
was
very
communicative
last
night
,
and
told
me
more
of
his
life
.
<EOS>
You
remember
his
breaking
off
here
about
some
woman
that
he
had
had
great
trouble
with
.
<EOS>
---
Did
I
hurt

"

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

---

.
<EOS>
I
had
never
seen
them
on
such
ill
terms
;
for
generally
they
got
on
very
well
indeed
together
.
  
<EOS>
But
,
they
were
both
happily
relieved
by
the
opportune
appearance
of
Mike
,
the
client
with
the
fur
cap
and
the
habit
of
wiping
his
nose
on
his
sleeve
,
whom
I
had
seen
on
the
very
first
day
of
my
appearance
within
those
walls
.
<EOS>
This
individual
,
who
,
either
in
his
own
person
or
in
that
of
some
member
of
his
family
,
seemed
to
be
always
in
trouble
(
which
in
that
place
meant
Newgate
)
,
called
to
announce
that
his
eldest
daughter
was
taken
up
on
suspicion
of
shop
-
lifting
.
<EOS>
As
he
imparted
this
melancholy
circumstance
to
Wemmick
,
Mr
Jaggers
standing
magisterially
before
the
fire
and
taking
no
share
in
the
proceedings
,
Mike
's
eye
happened
to
twinkle
with
a
tear
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
are
you
about
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
Wemmick
,
with
the
utmost
indignation
.
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
come
snivelling
here
for
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
go
to
do
it
,
Mr
Wemmick
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
did
,
"
said
Wemmick
.
<EOS>
"
How
dare
you
?
<EOS>
You
're
not
in
a
fit
state
to
come
here
,
if
you
ca
n't
come
here
without
spluttering
like
a
bad
pen
.
<EOS>
What
do
you
mean
by
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
man
ca
n't
help
his
feelings
,
Mr
Wemmick
,
"
pleaded
Mike
.
  
<EOS>
"
His
what
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
Wemmick
,
quite
savagely
.
<EOS>
"
Say
that
again
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
look
here
my
man
,
"
said
Mr
Jaggers
,
advancing
a
step
,
and
pointing
to

door
.
<EOS>
"
Get
out
of
this
office
.
<EOS>
I
'll
have
no
feelings
here
.
<EOS>
Get
out
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
serves
you
right
,
"
said
Wemmick
.
<EOS>
"
Get
out
.
"
  
<EOS>
So
the
unfortunate
Mike
very
humbly
withdrew
,
and
Mr
Jaggers
and
Wemmick
appeared
to
have
re
-
established
their
good
understanding
,
and
went
to
work
again
with
an
air
of
refreshment
upon
them
as
if
they
had
just
had
lunch
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
52
 
FROM
Little
Britain
,
I
went
,
with
my
cheque
in
my
pocket
,
to
Miss
Skiffins
's
brother
,
the
accountant
;
and
Miss
Skiffins
's
brother
,
the
accountant
,
going
straight
to
Clarriker
's
and
bringing
Clarriker
to
me
<EOS>
,
I
had
the
great
satisfaction
of
concluding
that
arrangement
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
only
good
thing
I
had
done
,
and
the
only
completed
thing
I
had
done
,
since
I
was
first
apprised
of
my
great
expectations
.
  
<EOS>
Clarriker
informing
me
on
that
occasion
that
the
affairs
of
the
House
were
steadily
progressing
,
that
he
would
now
be
able
to
establish
a
small
branch
-
house
in
the
East
which
was
much
wanted
for
the
extension
of
the
business
,
and
that
Herbert
in
his
new
partnership
capacity
would
go
out
and
take
charge
of
it
<EOS>
,
I
found
that
I
must
have
prepared
for
a
separation
from
my
friend
,
even
though
my
own
affairs
had
been
more
settled
.
<EOS>
And
now
indeed
I
felt
as
if
my
last
anchor
were
loosening
its
hold
,
and
I
should
soon
be
driving
with
the
winds
and
waves
.
  
<EOS>
But
,
there
was
recompense
in
the
joy
with
which
Herbert
would
come
home
of
a
night
and
tell
me
of
these
changes
,
<EOS>
little
imagining
that
he
told
me
no
news
,
and
would
sketch
airy
pictures
of
himself
conducting
Clara
Barley
to
the
land
of
the
Arabian
Nights
,
and
of
me
going
out
to
join
them
(
with
a
caravan
of
camels
,
I
believe
)
,
and
of
our
all
going
up
the
Nile
and
seeing
wonders
.
<EOS>
Without
being
sanguine
as
to
my
own
part
in
these
bright
plans
,
I
felt
that
Herbert
's
way
was
clearing
fast
,
and
that
old
Bill
Barley
had
but
to
stick
to
his
pepper
and
rum
,
and
his
daughter
would
soon
be
happily
provided
for
.
  
<EOS>
We
had
now
got
into
the
month
of
March
.
<EOS>
My
left
arm
,
though
it
presented
no
bad
symptoms
,
took
in
the
natural
course
so
long
to
heal
that
I
was
still
unable
to
get
a
coat
on
.
<EOS>
My
right
arm
was
tolerably
restored
;
---
disfigured
,
but
fairly
serviceable
.
  
<EOS>
On
a
Monday
morning
,
when
Herbert
and
I
were
at

,
I
received
the
following

from
Wemmick
by
the

.
  
<EOS>
"
Walworth
.
<EOS>
Burn
this
as
soon
as
read
.
<EOS>
Early
in
the
week
,
or
say
Wednesday
,
you
might
do
what
you
know
of
,
if
you
felt
disposed
to
try

.
<EOS>
Now
burn
.
<EOS>
"
  
When
I
had
shown
this
to
Herbert
and
had
put
it
in
the
fire
---
but
not
before
we
had
both
got
it
by
heart
<EOS>
---
we
considered
what
to
do
.
<EOS>
For
,
of
course
my
being
disabled
could
now
be
no
longer
kept
out
of
view
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
thought
it
over
,
again
and
again
,
"
said
Herbert
,
"
<EOS>
and
I
think
I
know
a
better

than
taking
a
Thames
waterman
.
<EOS>
Take
Startop
.
<EOS>
A
good
fellow
,
a
skilled
hand
,
fond
of
us
,
and
enthusiastic
and
honourable
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
had
thought
of
him
,
more
than
once
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
how
much
would
you
tell
him
,
Herbert
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
necessary
to
tell
him
very
little
.
<EOS>
Let
him
suppose
it
a
mere
freak
,
but
a
secret

,
until
the
morning
comes
:
then
let
him
know
that
there
is
urgent

for
your
getting
Provis
aboard
and
away
.
<EOS>
You
go
with
him
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
No
doubt
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Where
?
"
  
<EOS>
It
had
seemed
to
me
,
in
the
many
anxious
considerations
I
had
given
the
point
,
almost
indifferent
what
port
we
made
for
---
Hamburg
,
Rotterdam
,
Antwerp
---
the
place
signified
little
,
so
that
he
was
got
out
of
England
.
<EOS>
Any
foreign
steamer
that
fell
in
our
way
and
would
take
us
up
,
would
do
.
<EOS>
I
had
always
proposed
to
myself
to
get
him
well
down
the
river
in
the
boat
;
certainly
well
beyond
Gravesend
,
which
was
a
critical
place
for
search
or
inquiry
if
suspicion
were
afoot
.
<EOS>
As
foreign
steamers
would
leave
London
at
about
the
time
of
high
-
water
,
our
plan
would
be
to
get
down
the
river
by
a
previous
ebb
-
tide
,
and
lie
by
in
some
quiet
spot
until
we
could
pull

to
one
.
<EOS>
The
time
when
one
would
be
due
where
we
lay
,
wherever
that
might
be
,
could
be
calculated
pretty
nearly
,
if
we
made
inquiries
beforehand
.
  
<EOS>
Herbert
assented
to
all
this
,
and
we
went
out
immediately
after

to

our
investigations
.
<EOS>
We
found
that
a
steamer
for
Hamburg
was
likely
to
suit
our
purpose
best
,
and
we
directed
our

chiefly
to
that

.
<EOS>
But
we
noted
down
what
other
foreign
steamers
would
leave
London
with
the
same
tide
,
and
we
satisfied
ourselves
that
we
knew
the
build
and
colour
of

.
<EOS>
We
then
separated
for
a
few
hours
;
I
,
to
get
at
once
such
passports
as
were
necessary
;
Herbert
,
to
see
Startop
at
his

.
<EOS>
We
both
did
what
we
had
to
do
without
any
hindrance
,
and
when
we
met
again
at
one
o'clock
reported
it
done
.
<EOS>
I
,
for
my
part
,
was
prepared
with
passports
;
Herbert
had
seen
Startop
,
and
he
was
more
than
ready
to
join
.
  
<EOS>
Those
two
should
pull
a
pair
of
oars
,
we
settled
,
and
I
would
steer
;
our
charge
would
be
sitter
,
and
keep
quiet
;
as
speed
was
not
our
object
,
we
should
make
way
enough
.
<EOS>
We
arranged
that
Herbert
should
not
come
home
to
dinner
before
going
to
Mill
Pond
Bank
<EOS>
that
evening
;
that
he
should
not
go
there
at
all
,
to
-
morrow
evening
,
Tuesday
;
that
he
should
prepare
Provis
to
come
down
to
some
Stairs
hard

house
,
on
Wednesday
,
when

,
and

;
that

with

should

;
and
that
he
should

communicated
with
no

,
until

on

.
  
<EOS>
These
precautions
well
understood
by
both
of
us
,
I
went
home
.
  
<EOS>
On
opening
the
outer
door
of
our
chambers
with
my
key
,
I
found
a
letter
in
the
box
,
directed
to
me
;
a
very
dirty
letter
,
though
not
ill
-
written
.
<EOS>
It
had
been
delivered
by
hand
(
of
course
since
I
left
home
)
,
and
its
contents
were
these
:
  
"
If
you
are
not

to
come
to
the
old
marshes
to
-
night
or
to
-
morrow
night
at
Nine
,
and
to
come
to
the
little
sluice
-
house
by
the
limekiln
,
you
had
better
come
.
<EOS>
If
you
want
information
regarding
 
\
<EOS>
your
uncle
Provis
,
\
 
<EOS>
you
had
much

come
and
tell
no
one
and
lose

.
 
<EOS>
\
<EOS>
You
must
come
alone
.
<EOS>
\
 
<EOS>
Bring
this
with
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
had
had
load
enough
upon
my
mind
before
the
receipt
of
this
strange
letter
.
<EOS>
What
to
do
now
,
I
could
not
tell
.
<EOS>
And
the
worst
was
,
that
I
must
decide
quickly
,
or
I
should
miss
the
afternoon
coach
,
which
would
take
me
down
in
time
for
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
To
-
morrow
night
I
could
not
think
of
going
,
for
it
would
be
too
close
upon
the
time
of
the
flight
.
<EOS>
And
again
,
for
anything
I
knew
,
the
proffered
information
might
have
some
important
bearing
on
the
flight
itself
.
  
<EOS>
If
I
had
had
ample
time
for
consideration
,
I
believe
I
should
still
have
gone
.
<EOS>
Having
hardly
any
time
for
consideration
---
my
watch
showing
me
that
the
coach
started
within
half
an
hour
---
I
resolved
to
go
.
<EOS>
I
should
certainly
not
have
gone
,
but
for
the
reference
to
my
Uncle
Provis
;
that
,
coming
on
Wemmick
's
letter
and
the
morning
's
busy
preparation
,
turned
the
scale
.
  
<EOS>
It
is
so
difficult
to
become
clearly
possessed
of
the
contents
of
almost
any
letter
,
in
a
violent
hurry
,
that
I
had
to
read
this
mysterious
epistle
again
,
twice
,
before
its
injunction
to
he
to
be
secret
got
mechanically
into
my
mind
.
<EOS>
Yielding
to
it
in
the
same
mechanical
kind
of
way
,
I
left
a
note
in
pencil
for
Herbert
,
telling
him
that
as
I
should
be
so
soon
going
away
,
I
knew
not
for
how
long
,
I
had
decided
to
hurry
down
and
back
,
to
ascertain
for
myself
how
Miss
Havisham
was
faring
.
<EOS>
I
had
then
barely
time
to
get
my
great
-
coat
,
lock
up
the
chambers
,
and
make
for
the
coach
-
office
by
the
short
by
-
ways
.
<EOS>
If
I
had
taken
a
hackney
-
chariot
and
gone
by
the
streets
,
I
should
have
missed
my
aim
;
going
as
I
did
<EOS>
,
I
caught
the
coach
just
as
it
came
out
of
the
yard
.
<EOS>
I
was
the
only
inside
passenger
,
jolting
away
knee
-
deep
in
straw
,
when
I
came
to
myself
.
  
<EOS>
For
,
I
really
had
not
been
myself
since
the
receipt
of
the
letter
;
it
had
<EOS>
so
bewildered
me
ensuing
on
the
hurry
of
the
morning
.
<EOS>
The
morning
hurry
and
flutter
had
been
great
,
for
,
long
and
anxiously
as
I
had
waited
for
Wemmick
,
his
hint
had
come
like
a
surprise
at
last
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
I
began
to
wonder
at
myself
for
being
in
the
coach
,
and
to
doubt
whether
I
had
sufficient
reason
for
being
there
,
and
to
consider
whether
I
should
get
out
presently
and
go
back
,
and
to
argue
against
ever
heeding
an
anonymous
communication
,
and
,
in
short
,
to
pass
through
all
those
phases
of
contradiction
and
indecision
to
which
I
suppose
very
few
hurried
people
are
strangers
.
<EOS>
Still
,
the
reference
to
Provis
by
name
,
mastered
everything
.
<EOS>
I
reasoned
as
I
had
reasoned
already
without
knowing
it
---
if
that
be
reasoning
---
in
case
any
harm
should
befall
him
through
my
not
going
,
how
could
I
ever
forgive
myself
!
  
<EOS>
It
was
dark
before
we
got
down
,
and
the
journey
seemed
long
and
dreary
to
me
who
could
see
little
of
it
inside
,
and
who
could
not
go
outside
in
my
disabled
state
.
<EOS>
Avoiding
the
Blue
Boar
,
I
put
up
at
an
inn
of
minor
reputation
down
the
town
,
and
ordered
some
dinner
.
<EOS>
While
it
was
preparing
,
I
went
to
Satis
House
and
inquired
for
Miss
Havisham
;
she
was
still
very
ill
,
though
considered
something
better
.
  
<EOS>
My
inn
had
once
been
a
part
of
an
ancient
ecclesiastical
house
,
and
I
dined
in
a
little
octagonal
common
-
room
,
like
a
font
.
<EOS>
As
I
was
not
able
to
cut
my
dinner
,
the
old
landlord
with
a
shining
bald
head
did
it
for
me
.
<EOS>
This
bringing
us
into
conversation
,
he
was
so
good
as
to
entertain
me
with
my
own
story
---
of
course
with
the
popular
feature
that
Pumblechook
was
my
earliest
benefactor
and
the
founder
of
my
fortunes
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
the
young
man
?
"
said
I.
  
"
<EOS>
Know
him
!
"
repeated

landlord
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ever
since
he
was
---
no
height
at
all
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Does
he
ever
come
back
to
this

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ay

,
"

"
to

,
now

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

?
"
  
"
Him

,
"
said
the

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Pumblechook
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is

no

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No

"

"
but

ca

.
<EOS>
And

?
<EOS>
Because
Pumblechook

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Does

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Say

!
<EOS>
"

.
"
<EOS>
He
han't

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
I

,
"
Yet

,

<EOS>
Long

,
 
\
you
\

<EOS>
Nor

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Your

"

<EOS>
"

"
  
<EOS>
"
No

"

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
Please

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I

,
for

Joe
,
as
through

Pumblechook
.
<EOS>
The
falser
he
,
the
truer
Joe
;
the
meaner
he
,
the
nobler
Joe
.
  
<EOS>
My

and

as

for

.
<EOS>
The

,
but

or

,
and
I
got

and
had

,

.
<EOS>
I
had
previously
sought
in

for

letter
,
that
I
might
refer

it
again
,
but
I
could
not

,
and
was
uneasy

think
that

must
have
been
dropped
in
the

.
<EOS>
I
knew

,

,
that
the
appointed
place
was
the
little

-
house
by
the
limekiln
on
