,
and
the
hour
nine
.
<EOS>
Towards
the
marshes
I
now
went
straight
,
having
no
time
to
spare
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
53
 
<EOS>
IT
was
a
dark
night
,
though
the
full
moon
rose
as
I
left
the
enclosed
lands
,
and
passed
out
upon
the
marshes
.
<EOS>
Beyond
their
dark
line
there
was
a
ribbon
of
clear
sky
,
hardly
broad
enough
to
hold
the
red
large
moon
.
<EOS>
In
a
few
minutes
she
had
ascended
out
of
that
clear
field
,
in
among
the
piled
mountains
of
cloud
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
melancholy
wind
,
and
the
marshes
were
very
dismal
.
<EOS>
A
stranger
would
have
found
them
insupportable
,
and
even
to
me
they
were
so
oppressive
that
I
hesitated
,
<EOS>
half
inclined
to
go
back
.
<EOS>
But
,
I
knew
them
well
,
and
could
have
found
my
way
on
a
far
darker
night
,
and
had
no
excuse
for
returning
,
being
there
.
<EOS>
So
,
having
come
there
against
my
inclination
,
I
went
on
against
it
.
  
<EOS>
The
direction
that
I
took
,
was
not
that
in
which
my
old
home
lay
,
nor
that
in
which
we
had
pursued
the
convicts
.
<EOS>
My
back
was
turned
towards
the
distant
Hulks
as
I
walked
on
,
and
,
though
I
could
see
the
old
lights
away
on
the
spits

sand
,
I
saw
them
over
my
shoulder
.
<EOS>
I
knew
the
limekiln
as
well
as
I
knew
the
old
Battery
,
but
they
were
miles
apart
;
so
that
if
a
light
had
been
burning
at
each
point
that
night
,
there
would
have
been
a
long

of
the
blank

between
the
two
bright

.
  
<EOS>
At
first
,
I
had
to
shut
some

after
me
,
and
now
and
then
to
stand
still
while
the
cattle
that
were
lying
in
the
banked
-
up

,

and

.
<EOS>
But

,
I
seemed
to
have
the
whole
flats
to

.
  
<EOS>
It
was
another
half
-
hour
before
I
drew
near
to

kiln
.
<EOS>
The
lime
was
burning
with
a
sluggish

,
but
the
fires
were
made
up
and

,
and

.
<EOS>
Hard
by
,
was
a
small
stone
-

.
<EOS>
It
lay

in
my
way
,
and
had
been
worked
that
day
,
as
I
saw
by
the
tools
and
barrows
that

lying
about
.
  
<EOS>
Coming

to
the
marsh

out

---
for
the
rude

lay
through

---
I
saw
a
light
in

old

-

.
<EOS>
I
quickened
my

,
and
knocked
at
the
door
with

.
<EOS>
Waiting
for
some

,
I
looked
about

,
noticing
how

was
abandoned
and

,
and
how
the

---
of

---
would
not

proof
against
the
weather
much

,
if

,
and

,
and
how

of

.
<EOS>
Still

was
no
answer
,
and
I
knocked
again
.
<EOS>
No
answer
still
,
and
I
tried
the
latch
.
  
<EOS>
It
rose
under
my
hand
,
and
the
door
yielded
.
<EOS>
Looking

,
I
saw

on

,
a

,
and

on

.
<EOS>
As

above
,
I

,
"
Is

here
?
"
<EOS>
but

.
<EOS>
Then
,

,
and
,

,

,
"
Is

here
?
<EOS>
"
There

.
  
<EOS>
It

rain

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
I

,
and

,

,

,

,
that

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"

,
"
I
've

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
this
?
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
Who
is

?
<EOS>
Help

,

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Not

,
but

.
<EOS>
Sometimes
,
a

man
's

,

,

,

,

.
"
<EOS>
And

,
"

"

,

!
"
  
<EOS>
Faint

,

<EOS>
,

,

arm

were
it

.
<EOS>
But
,

.
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
  
<EOS>

,

man
had

.
<EOS>
After

,
he

flint
and

,

.
<EOS>
I

,
and

,
match

,
but
I

,

;

,
but

.
<EOS>
The

was
damp
---
<EOS>
no
wonder
there
---
and
one

another
the

out
.
  
<EOS>
The
man
was
in
no

,
and
struck
again
with
the

and

.
<EOS>
As

,
I

,

of

,

;
but

.
<EOS>
Presently

his
blue

,

,
and

,

Orlick
.
  
<EOS>
Whom
I
had

for
,
I
do
n't

.
<EOS>
I
had
not

.
<EOS>
Seeing

,
I

I

,

I

.
  
<EOS>
He

from

with

and
dropped

,
and

.
<EOS>
Then
,
he
put
the

away

on

,
so
that
he
could
see
me
,
and

.
<EOS>
I

that

---
a

---
the

ascent

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"

,

,
"
I
've

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
<EOS>

,
"
\

I
'll
\
 
<EOS>
let

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do

?
"

,

<EOS>
"

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Because

.
<EOS>
One

.
<EOS>
Oh

,

!
"
  
<EOS>
His

I

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Do

?
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
Do

you
saw

?
<EOS>
Speak
,
wolf
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
I

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

.
<EOS>
You
did
.
<EOS>
Speak
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

,

,

.
<EOS>
How

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
When

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
When

?
<EOS>
It

as

Old
Orlick

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

;

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

.
<EOS>
And

,

,

"

,

"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
If

,
to
the

farden
!
"
<EOS>
As

,

,

felt

true

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

;
and
I
saw
in
his
hand
a
stone
-
hammer
with
a
long
heavy
handle
.
  
<EOS>
The
resolution
I
had
made
did
not
desert
me
,
for
,
without
uttering
one
vain
word
of
appeal
to
him
,
I
shouted
out
with
all
my
might
,
and
struggled
with
all
my
might
.
<EOS>
It
was
only
my
head
and
my
legs
that
I
could
move
,
but
to
that
extent
I
struggled
with
all
the
force
,
until
then
unknown
,
that
was
within
me
.
<EOS>
In
the
same
instant
I
heard
responsive
shouts
,
saw
figures
and
a
gleam
of
light
dash
in
at
the
door
,
heard
voices
and
tumult
,
and
saw
Orlick
emerge
from
a
struggle
of
men
,
as
if
it
were
tumbling
water
,
clear
the
table
at
a
leap
,
and
fly
out
into
the
night
.
  
<EOS>
After
a
blank
,
I
found
that
I
was
lying
unbound
,
on
the
floor
,
in
the
same
place
,
with
my
head
on
some
one
's
knee
.
<EOS>
My
eyes
were
fixed
on
the
ladder
against
the
wall
,
when
I
came
to
myself
---
had
opened
on
it
before
my
mind
saw
it
---
and
thus
as
I
recovered
consciousness
,
I
knew
that
I
was
in
the
place
where
I
had
lost
it
.
  
<EOS>
Too
indifferent
at
first
,
even
to
look
round
and
ascertain
who
supported
me
,
I
was
lying
looking
at
the
ladder
,
when
there
came
between
me
and
it
,
a
face
.
<EOS>
The
face
of
Trabb
's
boy
!
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
he
's
all
right
!
"
said
Trabb
's
boy
,
in
a
sober
voice
;
"
but
ai
n't
he
just
pale
though
!
"
  
<EOS>
At
these
words
,
the
face
of
him
who
supported
me
looked
over
into
mine
,
and
I
saw
my
supporter
to
be
---
  
"
<EOS>
Herbert
!
<EOS>
Great
Heaven
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Softly
,
"
said
Herbert
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Gently
,
Handel
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
be
too
eager
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
our
old
comrade
,
Startop
!
<EOS>
"
I
cried
,
as
he
too
bent
over
me
.
  
<EOS>
"
Remember
what
he
is
going
to
assist
us
in
,
"
said
Herbert
,
"
and
be
calm
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
allusion
made
me
spring
up
;
though
I
dropped
again
from
the
pain
in
my
arm
.
<EOS>
"
The
time
has
not
gone
by
,
Herbert
,
has
it
?
<EOS>
What
night
is
to
-
night
?
<EOS>
How
long
have
I
been
here
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
For
,
I
had
a
strange
and
strong
misgiving
that
I
had
been
lying
there
a
long
time
---
a
day
and
a
night
---
two
days
and
nights
---
more
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
time
has
not
gone
by
.
<EOS>
It
is
still
Monday
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
God
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
have
all
to
-
morrow
,
Tuesday
,
to
rest
in
,
"
said
Herbert
.
<EOS>
"
But
you
ca
n't
help
groaning
,
my
dear
Handel
.
<EOS>
What
hurt
have
you
got
?
<EOS>
Can
you
stand
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
yes
,
"
said
I
,
"
I
can
walk
.
<EOS>
I
have
no
hurt
but
in
this
throbbing
arm
.
  
<EOS>
They
laid
it
bare
,
and
did
what
they
could
.
<EOS>
It
was
violently
swollen
and
inflamed
,
and
I
could
scarcely
endure
to
have
it
touched
.
<EOS>
But
,
they
tore
up
their
handkerchiefs
to
make
fresh
bandages
,
and
carefully
replaced
it
in
the
sling
,
until
we
could
get
to
the
town
and
obtain
some
cooling
lotion
to
put
upon
it
.
<EOS>
In
a
little
while
we
had
shut
the
door
of
the
dark
and
empty
sluice
-
house
,
and
were
passing
through
the
quarry
on
our
way
back
.
<EOS>
Trabb
's
boy
---
Trabb
's
overgrown
young
man
now
---
went
before
us
with
a
lantern
,
which
was
the
light
I
had
seen
come
in
at
the
door
.
<EOS>
But
,
the
moon
was
a
good
two
hours
higher
than
when
I
had
last
seen
the
sky
,
and
the
night
though
rainy
was
much
lighter
.
<EOS>
The
white
vapour
of
the
kiln
was
passing
from
us
as
we
went
by
,
and
,
as
I
had
thought
a
prayer
before
,
I
thought
a
thanksgiving
now
.
  
<EOS>
Entreating
Herbert
to
tell
me
how
he
had
come
to
my
rescue
---
which
at
first
he
had
flatly
refused
to
do
,
but
had
insisted
on
my
remaining
quiet
<EOS>
---
I
learnt
that
I
had
<EOS>
in
my
hurry
dropped
the
letter
,
open
,
in
our
chambers
,
where
he
,
coming
home
to
bring
with

Startop
<EOS>
whom
he
had
met
in
the
street
on

me
,
found
it
,
very
soon
after
I
was
gone
.
<EOS>
Its
tone
made
him
uneasy
,
and
the
more
so
because
of
the
inconsistency
between
it
and
the
hasty
letter
I
had
left
for

.
<EOS>
His

increasing
instead
of
subsiding
after
a
quarter
of
an
hour
's

,
he
set
off
for
the
coach
-
office
,
with
Startop
,
who
volunteered
his
company
,
to
make
inquiry
when
the
next
coach
went
down
.
<EOS>
Finding
that
the
afternoon
coach
was
gone
,
and
finding
that
his
uneasiness
grew
into
positive
alarm
,
as
obstacles
came
in
his
way
,
he
resolved
to
follow
in
a
post
-
chaise
.
<EOS>
So
,
he
and
Startop
arrived
at
the
Blue
Boar
,
fully
expecting
there
to
find
me
,
or
tidings
of
me
;
but
,
finding
neither
,
went
on
to
Miss
Havisham
's
,
where
they
lost
me
.
<EOS>
Hereupon
they
went
back
to
the
hotel
(
doubtless
at
about
the
time
when
I
was
hearing
the
popular
local
version
of
my
own

)
,
to
refresh

and
to
get
some

.
<EOS>
Among
the

under
the
Boar
's

,
happened
to
be
Trabb
's
boy
---
true
to
his
ancient

of

to
be
everywhere
where
he
had
no

---
and
Trabb
's
boy
had
seen
me
passing
from
Miss
Havisham
's
in
the

of
my

-

.
<EOS>
Thus
,
Trabb
's
boy
became
their
guide
,
and
with

they
went
out
to
the
sluice
-
house
:
though
by
the
town
way
to
the
marshes
,
which
I
had
avoided
.
<EOS>
Now
,
as
they
went
along
,
Herbert
reflected
,
that
I
might
,
after
all
,
have
been

there
on
some

serviceable

tending
to
Provis
's

,
and
,

that
in
that
case
interruption
must
be

,
left
his
guide
and
Startop
on
the

,
and
went
on
by

,
and
stole
round
the
house
two
or
three
times
,
endeavouring
to
ascertain
whether
all
was
right
within
.
<EOS>
As
he
could

nothing
but

of
one

(
this
was
while
my

was
so

)
<EOS>
,
he
even

I
was
there
,
when

cried
out

,
and
he
answered

,
and
rushed

,
closely

.
  
<EOS>
When

Herbert
what
had
passed
within

,
he
was
for
our

going
before
a

in
the

,
late
at
night
as

was
,
and
getting
out

.
<EOS>
But
,
I
had
already
considered
that
such
a

,
by
detaining
us
there
,
or
binding

to

,
might
be
fatal
to
Provis
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
gainsaying
this

,
and
we
relinquished
all

of
pursuing
Orlick
at
that

.
<EOS>
For

,
under

,
we
deemed
it
prudent
to
make
rather
light
of
the
matter
to
Trabb
's
boy
;
who
I
am
convinced
would
have
been
much
affected
by
disappointment
,
if
he
had
known
that
his

saved
me
from

.
<EOS>
Not

Trabb
's
boy
was
of
a

,
but
that
he
had
too
much
spare

,
and
that

was

to
want

and

at

's

.
<EOS>
When

,
I
presented
him
with
two

(
which
seemed
to
meet
his
views
)
,
and
told

that
I
was
sorry
ever
to
have
had
an
ill
opinion
of
him
(
which
made
no

on
him
at

)
.
  
<EOS>
Wednesday
being
so
close
upon
us
,
we
determined
to
go
back
to
London
that
night
,
three
in
the
post
-
chaise
;
the
rather
,
as
we
should
then
be
clear
away
,
before
the
night
's

began
to

.
<EOS>
Herbert
got
a
large

of
stuff
for
my
arm
,
and
by
dint
of
having
this
stuff
dropped
over
it
all
the
night
through
,
I
was
just
able
to
bear
its
pain
on

.
<EOS>
It
was
daylight
when
we
reached
the
Temple
,
and
I
went
at
once
to
bed
,
and
lay
in
bed
all

.
  
<EOS>
My
terror
,
as
I
lay
there
,
of
falling
ill
and
being
unfitted
for
to
-
morrow
,
was
so
besetting
,
that
I
wonder
it
did
not
disable
me
of
itself
.
<EOS>
It
would
have
done
so
,
pretty
surely
,
in
conjunction
with
the
mental
wear
and
tear
<EOS>
I
had
suffered
,
but
for
the
unnatural
strain
upon
me
that
to
-
morrow
was
.
<EOS>
So
anxiously
looked
forward
to
,
charged
with
such
consequences
,
<EOS>
its
results
so
impenetrably
hidden
though
so
near
.
  
<EOS>
No
precaution
could
have
been
more
obvious
than
our
refraining
from
communication
with
him
that
day
;
yet
this
again
increased
my
restlessness
.
<EOS>
I
started
at
every
footstep
and
every
sound
,
believing
that
he
was
discovered
and
taken
,
and
this
was
the
messenger
to
tell
me
so
.
<EOS>
I
persuaded
myself
that
I
knew
he
was
taken
;
that
there
was
something
more
upon
my
mind
than

fear
or
a
presentiment
;
that
the
fact
had
occurred
,
and
I
had
a
mysterious
knowledge
of
it
.
<EOS>
As
the
day
wore
on
and
no
ill
news
came
,
as
the
day
closed
in
and
darkness
fell
,
my
overshadowing
dread
of
being
disabled
by
illness
before
to
-
morrow
morning
,
altogether
mastered
me
.
<EOS>
My
burning
arm
throbbed
,
and
my
burning
head
throbbed
,
and
I
fancied
I
was
beginning
to
wander
.
<EOS>
I
counted
up
to
high
numbers
,
to
make
sure
of
myself
,
and
repeated
passages
that
I
knew
in
prose
and
verse
.
<EOS>
It
happened
sometimes
that
in
the
mere
escape
of
a
fatigued
mind
,
I
dozed
for
some
moments
or
forgot
;
then
I
would
say
to
myself
with
a
start
,
"
Now
it
has
come
,
and
I
am
turning
delirious
!
"
  
<EOS>
They
kept
me
very
quiet
all
day
,
and
kept
my
arm
constantly
dressed
and
gave
me
cooling
drinks
.
<EOS>
Whenever
I
fell
asleep
,
I
awoke
with
the
notion
I
had
had
in
the
sluice
-
house
,
that
a
long
time
had
elapsed
and
the
opportunity
to
save
him
was
gone
.
<EOS>
About
midnight
I
got
out
of
bed
and
went
to
Herbert
,
with
the
conviction
that
I
had
been
asleep
for
four
-
and
-
twenty
hours
,
and
that
Wednesday
was
past
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
last
self
-
exhausting
effort
of
my
fretfulness
,
for
,
after
that
,
I
slept
soundly
.
  
<EOS>
Wednesday
morning
was
dawning
when
I
looked
out
of
window
.
<EOS>
The
winking
lights
upon
the
bridges
were
already
pale
,
the
coming
sun
was
like
a
marsh
of
fire
on
the
horizon
.
<EOS>
The
river
,
still
dark
and
mysterious
,
was
spanned
by
bridges
that
were
turning
coldly
grey
,
with
here
and
there
at
top
a
warm
touch
from
the
burning
in
the
sky
.
<EOS>
As
I
looked
along
the
clustered
roofs
,
with
Church
towers
and
spires
shooting
into
the
unusually
clear
air
,
the
sun
rose
up
,
and
a
veil
seemed
to
be
drawn
from
the
river
,
and
millions
of
sparkles
burst
out
upon
its
waters
.
<EOS>
From
me
too
,
a
veil
seemed
to
be
drawn
,
and
I
felt
strong
and
well
.
  
<EOS>
Herbert
lay
asleep
in
his
bed
,
and
our
old
fellow
-
student
lay
asleep
on
the
sofa
.
<EOS>
I
could
not
dress
myself
without
help
,
but
I
made
up
the
fire
,
which
was
still
burning
,
and
got
some
coffee
ready
for
them
.
<EOS>
In
good
time
they
too
started
up
strong
and
well
,
and
we
admitted
the
sharp
morning
air
at
the
windows
,
and
looked
at
the
tide
that
was
still
flowing
towards
us
.
  
<EOS>
"
When
it
turns
at
nine
o'clock
,
"
said
<EOS>
Herbert
,
cheerfully
,
"
look
out
for
us
,
and
stand
ready
,
you
over
there
at
Mill
Pond
Bank
!
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
54
 
IT
was
one
of
those
March
days
when
the
sun
shines
hot
and
the
wind
blows
cold
:
when
it
is
summer
in
the
light
,
and
winter
in
the
shade
.
<EOS>
We
had
our
pea
-
coats
with
us
,
and
I
took
a
bag
.
<EOS>
Of
all
my
worldly
possessions
I
took
no
more
than
the
few
necessaries
that
filled
the
bag
.
<EOS>
Where
I
might
go
,
what
I
might
do
,
or
when
I
might
return
,
were
questions
utterly
unknown
to
me
;
nor
did
I
vex
my
mind
with
them
,
for
it
was
wholly
set
on
Provis
's
safety
.
<EOS>
I
only
wondered
for
the
passing
moment
,
as
I
stopped
at
the
door
and
looked
back
,
under
what
altered
circumstances
I
should
next
see
those
rooms
,
if
ever
.
  
<EOS>
We
loitered
down
to
the
Temple
stairs
,
and
stood
loitering
there
,
as
if
we
were
not
quite
decided
to
go
upon
the
water
at
all
.
<EOS>
Of
course
I
had
taken
care
that
the
boat
should
be
ready
and
everything
in
order
.
<EOS>
After
a
little
show
of
indecision
,
which
there
were
none
to
see
but
the
two
or
three
amphibious
creatures
belonging
to
our
Temple
stairs
,
we
went
on
board
and
cast
off
;
Herbert
in
the
bow
,
<EOS>
I
steering
.
<EOS>
It
was
then
about
high
-
water
---
half
-
past
eight
.
  
<EOS>
Our
plan
was
this
.
<EOS>
The
tide
,
beginning
to
run
down
at
nine
and
being
with
us
until
three
,
we
intended
still
to
creep
on
after
it
had
turned
,
and
row
against
it
until
dark
.
<EOS>
We
should
then
be
well
in
those
long
reaches
below
Gravesend
,
between
Kent
and
Essex
,
where
the
river
is
broad
and
solitary
,
where
the
waterside
inhabitants
are
very
few
,
and
where
lone
public
-
houses
are
scattered
here
<EOS>
and
there
,
of
which
we
could
choose
one
for

.
<EOS>
There
we
meant
to
lie
by
,
all
night
.
<EOS>
The
steamer
for
Hamburg
,
and
the
steamer
for
Rotterdam
,
would
start
from
London
at
about
nine
on
Thursday
morning
.
<EOS>
We
should
know
at
what
time
to
expect
them
,
according
to
where
we
were
,
and
would
hail
the
first
;
so
that
if

were
not
taken

,
we
should
have
another

.
<EOS>
We
knew
the
distinguishing
marks
of

.
  
<EOS>
The
relief
of
being
at
last
engaged
in
the
execution
of
the
purpose
,
was
so
great
to

that
I
felt

in

I
had
been
a

.
<EOS>
The
crisp

,
the

,
the

,

---

,

,

,

---

.
<EOS>
I
felt

in

;
but
,
there
were
few
better

than
my

,
and
they
rowed
with
a
steady
stroke
that
was
to
last
all

.
  
<EOS>
At
that

,

,

watermen

.
<EOS>
Of

,

,

,

,
of

.
<EOS>
Early

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
Old

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

!
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Oars

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
He

"
Dear

!
"

"
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
Again

,

<EOS>
rusty

<EOS>
At

,

<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
We

,

<EOS>
If

,

.
<EOS>
But
,

.
  
<EOS>
He

,

,

,
a

.
<EOS>
It

(

,

<EOS>
He

<EOS>
When

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
But

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
You

,

but
I
ai

a
going

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
Everybody

,

"

<EOS>

,

,
"
Do

,

?
"
<EOS>
and

.
  
<EOS>
The
air
felt
cold
upon
the
river
,
but
it
was
a
bright

,
and
the
sunshine
was
very

.
<EOS>
The
tide
ran
strong
,
I
took
care
to
lose
none
of
it
,
and
our
steady
stroke
carried
us
on
thoroughly
well
.
<EOS>
By
imperceptible

,
as
the
tide
ran
out
,

lost

and

of
the
nearer

and

,
and
dropped
lower
and
lower
between
the
muddy

,
but
the
tide
was
yet
with
us
when

were

Gravesend
.
<EOS>
As

charge
was

in

,
I
purposely
passed
within
a
boat
or
two
's

of

Custom

,
and
so
out
to

the
stream
,
alongside
of
two
emigrant

,
and
under

bows
of
a
large

with

.
<EOS>
And
soon
the
tide
began
to
slacken
,
and
the
craft
lying
at
anchor
to
swing
,
and
presently

had
all
swung
round
,
and
the
ships
that
were
taking
advantage
of
the
new
tide
to
get
up
to
the
Pool
,
began
to
crowd
upon
us
in
a

,
and
we
kept
under
the
shore
,
as
much
out
of
the
strength
of
the
tide
now
as
we
could
,
standing

off
from
low

and

-
banks
.
  
<EOS>
Our
oarsmen
were
so
fresh
,
by
dint
of
having
occasionally
let
her
drive
with
the
tide
for
a
minute
or
two
,
that
a

of
an
hour
's
rest
proved
full
as
much
as
they
wanted
.
<EOS>
We
got
ashore
among
some
slippery
stones
while
we
ate
and
drank
what
we
had
with
us
,
and
looked
about
.
<EOS>
It
was
like
my
own
marsh
country
,
flat
and

,
and
with
a
dim

;
while
the
winding
river
turned
and
turned
,
and
the
great

buoys
upon
it
turned
and
turned
,
and
everything
else
seemed
stranded
and
still
.
<EOS>
For
,
now
,
the
last
of
the
fleet
of
ships
was
round
the
last
low
point
we
had
headed
;
and
the
last

,
straw

,
with

brown

,
had
followed
;
and
some

-

,
shaped

's
first

boat
,

;
and

-

,
stood

in
the

;
and

stakes
stuck
out
of
the
mud
,
and
slimy
stones
stuck
out
of
the
mud
,
and
red
landmarks
and
tidemarks
stuck
out
of
the
mud
,
and
an
old
landing
-
stage
and
an
old
roofless
building
slipped
into
the
mud
,
and
all
about
us
was
stagnation
and
mud
.
  
<EOS>
We
pushed
off
again
,
and
made
what
way
we
could
.
<EOS>
It
was
much
harder
work
now
,
but
Herbert
and
Startop
persevered
,
and
rowed
,
and
rowed
,
and
rowed
,
until
the
sun
went
down
.
<EOS>
By
that
time
the
river
had
lifted
us
a
little
,
so
that
we
could
see
above
the
bank
.
<EOS>
There
was
the
red
sun
,
on
the
low
level
of
the
shore
,
in
a
purple
haze
,
fast
deepening
into
black
;
and
there
was
the
solitary
flat
marsh
;
and
far
away
there
were
the
rising
grounds
,
between
which
and
us
there
seemed
to
be
no
life
,
save
here
and
there
in
the
foreground
a
melancholy
gull
.
  
<EOS>
As
the
night
was
fast
falling
,
and
as
the
moon
,
being
past
the
full
,
would
not
rise
early
,
we
held
a
little
council
:
a
short
one
,
for
clearly
our
course
was
to
lie
by
at
the
first
lonely
tavern
we
could
find
.
<EOS>
So
,
they
plied
their
oars
once
more
,
and
I
looked
out
for
anything
like
a
house
.
<EOS>
Thus
we
held
on
,
speaking
little
,
for
four
or
five
dull
miles
.
<EOS>
It
was
very
cold
,
and
,
a
collier
coming
by
us
,
with
her
galley
-
fire
smoking
and
flaring
,
looked
like
a
comfortable
home
.
<EOS>
The
night
was
as
dark
by
this
time
as
it
would
be
until
morning
;
and
what
light
we
had
,
seemed
to
come
more
from
the
river
than
the
sky
,
as
the
oars
in
their
dipping
struck
at
a
few
reflected
stars
.
  
<EOS>
At
this
dismal
time
we
were
evidently
all
possessed
by
the
idea
that
we
were
followed
.
<EOS>
As
the
tide
made
,
it
flapped
heavily
at
irregular
intervals
against
the
shore
;
and
whenever
such
a
sound
came
,
one
or
other
of
us
was
sure
to
start
and
look
in
that
direction
.
<EOS>
Here
and
there
,
the
set
of
the
current
had
worn
down
the
bank
into
a
little
creek
,
and
we
were
all
suspicious
of
such
places
,
and
eyed
them
nervously
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
,
"
What
was
that
ripple
?
"
<EOS>
one
of
us
would
say
in
a
low
voice
.
<EOS>
Or
another
,
"
Is
that
a
boat
yonder
?
"
<EOS>
And
afterwards
,
we
would
fall
into
a
dead
silence
,
and
I
would
sit
impatiently
thinking
with
what
an
unusual
amount
of
noise
the
oars
worked
in
the
thowels
.
  
<EOS>
At
length
we
descried
a
light
and
a
roof
,
and
presently
afterwards
ran
alongside
a
little
causeway
made
of
stones
that
had
been
picked
up
hard
by
.
<EOS>
Leaving
the
rest
in
the
boat
,
I
stepped
ashore
,
and
found
the
light
to
be
in
a
window
of
a
public
-
house
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
dirty
place
enough
,
and
I
dare
say
not
unknown
to
smuggling
adventurers
;
but
there
was
a
good
fire
in
the
kitchen
,
and
there
were
eggs
and
bacon
to
eat
,
and
various
liquors
to
drink
.
<EOS>
Also
,
there
were
two
double
-
bedded
rooms
---
"
such
as
they
were
,
"
the
landlord
said
.
<EOS>
No
other
company
was
in
the
house
than
the
landlord
,
his
wife
,
and
a
grizzled
male
creature
,
the
"
Jack
"
of
the
little
causeway
,
who
was
as
slimy
and
smeary
as
if
he
had
been
low
-
water
mark
too
.
  
<EOS>
With
this
assistant
,
I
went
down
to
the
boat
again
,
and
we
all
came
ashore
,
and
brought
out
the
oars
,
and
rudder
,
and
boat
-
hook
,
and
all
else
,
and
hauled
her
up
for
the
night
.
<EOS>
We
made
a
very
good
meal
by
the
kitchen
fire
,
and
then
apportioned
the
bedrooms
:
<EOS>
Herbert
and
Startop
were
to
occupy
one
;
I
and
our
charge
the
other
.
<EOS>
We
found
the
air
as
carefully
excluded
from
both
,
as
if
air
were
fatal
to
life
;
and
there
were
more
dirty
clothes
and
bandboxes
under
the
beds
than
I
should
have
thought
the
family
possessed
.
<EOS>
But
,
we
considered
ourselves
well
off
,
notwithstanding
,
for
a
more
solitary
place
we
could
not
have
found
.
  
<EOS>
While
we
were
comforting
ourselves
by
the
fire
after
our
meal
,
the
Jack
---
who
was
sitting
in
a
corner
,
and
who
had
a
bloated
pair
of
shoes
on
,
which
he
had
exhibited
while
we
were
eating
our
eggs
and
bacon
,
as
interesting
relics
that
he
had
taken
a
few
days
ago
from
the
feet
of
a
drowned
seaman
washed
ashore
---
asked
me
if
we
had
seen
a
four
-
oared
galley
going
up
with
the
tide
?
<EOS>
When
I
told
him
No
,
he
said
she
must
have
gone
down
then
,
and
yet
she
"
took
up
too
,
"
when
she
left
there
.
  
<EOS>
"
They
must
ha
'
thought
better
on't
for
some
reason
or
another
,
"
said
the
Jack
,
"
and
gone
down
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
four
-
oared
galley
,
did
you
say
?
"
said
I.
  
<EOS>
"
A
four
,
"
said
the
Jack
,
"
and
two
sitters
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Did
they
come
ashore
here
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
put
in
with
a
stone
two
-
gallon
jar
,
for
some
beer
.
<EOS>
I
'd
ha
'
been
glad
to
pison
the
beer
myself
,
"
said
the
Jack
,
"
or
put
some
rattling
physic
in
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
why
,
"
said
the
Jack
.
<EOS>
He
spoke
in
a
slushy
voice
,
as
if
much
mud
had
washed
into
his
throat
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
thinks
,
"
said
the
landlord
:
a
weakly
meditative
man
with
a
pale
eye
,
who
seemed
to
rely
greatly
on
his
Jack
:
"
<EOS>
he
thinks
they
was
,
what
they
was
n't
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
knows
what
I
thinks
,
"
observed
the
Jack
.
  
<EOS>
"
\
<EOS>
You
\
 
thinks
Custum
'
Us
,
Jack
?
"
said
the
landlord
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
"
said
the
Jack
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
you
're
wrong
,
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
AMI
!
"
  
<EOS>
In
the
infinite
meaning
of
his
reply
and
his
boundless
confidence
in
his
views
,
the
Jack
took
one
of
his
bloated
shoes
off
,
looked
into
it
,
knocked
a
few
stones
out
of
it
on
the
kitchen
floor
,
and
put
it
on
again
.
<EOS>
He
did
this
with
the
air
of
a
Jack
who
was
so
right
that
he
could
afford
to
do
anything
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
do
you
make
out
that
they
done
with
their
buttons
then
,
Jack
?
"
asked
the
landlord
,
vacillating
weakly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Done
with
their
buttons
?
"
returned
the
Jack
.
<EOS>
"
Chucked
'em
overboard
.
<EOS>
Swallered
'em
.
<EOS>
Sowed
'em
,
to
come
up
small
salad
.
<EOS>
Done
with
their
buttons
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
cheeky
,
Jack
,
"
remonstrated
the
landlord
,
in
a
melancholy
and
pathetic
way
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
Custum
'
Us
officer
knows
what
to
do
with
his
Buttons
,
"
said
the
Jack
,
repeating
the
obnoxious
word
with
the
greatest
contempt
,
"
when
they
comes
betwixt
him
and
his
own
light
.
<EOS>
A
Four
and
two
sitters
do
n't
go
hanging
and
hovering
,
up
with
one
tide
and
down
with
another
,
and
both
with
and
against
another
,
without
there
being
Custum
'
Us
at
the
bottom
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
Saying
which
he
went
out
in
disdain
;
and
the
landlord
,
having
no
one
to
rely
upon
,
found
it
impracticable
to
pursue
the
subject
.
  
<EOS>
This
dialogue
made
us
all
uneasy
,
and
me
very
uneasy
.
<EOS>
The
dismal
wind
was
muttering
round
the
house
,
the
tide
was
flapping
at
the
shore
,
and
I
had
a
feeling
that
we
were
caged
and
threatened
.
<EOS>
A
four
-
oared
galley
hovering
about
in
so
unusual
a
way
as
to
attract
this
notice
,
was
an
ugly
circumstance
that
I
could
not
get
rid
of
.
<EOS>
When
I
had
induced
Provis
to
go
up
to
bed
,
I
went
outside
with
my
two
companions
<EOS>
(
Startop
by
this
time
knew
the
state
of
the
case
)
,
and
held
another
council
.
<EOS>
Whether
we
should
remain
at
the
house
until
near
the
steamer
's
time
,
which
would
be
about
one
in
the
afternoon
;
or
whether
we
should
put
off
early
in
the
morning
;
was
the
question
we
discussed
.
<EOS>
On
the
whole
we
deemed
it
the
better
course
to
lie
where
we
were
,
until
within
an
hour
or
so
of
the
steamer
's
time
,
and
then
to
get
out
in
her
track
,
and
drift
easily
with
the
tide
.
<EOS>
Having
settled
to
do
this
,
we
returned
into
the
house
and
went
to
bed
.
  
<EOS>
I
lay
down
with
the
greater
part
of
my
clothes
on
,
and
slept
well
for
a
few
hours
.
<EOS>
When
I
awoke
,
the
wind
had
risen
,
and
the
sign
of
the
house
(
the
Ship
)
was
creaking
and
banging
about
,
with
noises
that
startled
me
.
<EOS>
Rising
softly
,
for
my
charge
lay
fast
asleep
,
I
looked
out
of
the
window
.
<EOS>
It
commanded
the
causeway
where
we
had
hauled
up
our
boat
,
and
,
as
my
eyes
adapted
themselves
to
the
light
of
the
clouded
moon
,
I
saw
two
men
looking
into
her
.
<EOS>
They
passed
by
under
the
window
,
looking
at
nothing
else
,
and
they
did
not
go
down
to
the
landing
-
place
which
I
could
discern
to
be
empty
,
but
struck
across
the
marsh
in
the
direction
of
the
Nore
.
  
<EOS>
My
first
impulse
was
to
call
up
Herbert
,
and
show
him
the
two
men
going
away
.
<EOS>
But
,
reflecting
before
I
got
into
his
room
,
which
was
at
the
back
of
the
house
and
adjoined
mine
,
that
he
and
Startop
had
had
a
harder
day
than
I
,
and
were
fatigued
,
I
forbore
.
<EOS>
Going
back
to
my
window
,
I
could
see
the
two
men
moving
over
the
marsh
.
<EOS>
In
that
light
,
however
,
I
soon
lost
them
,
and
feeling
very
cold
,
lay
down
to
think
of
the
matter
,
and
fell
asleep
again
.
  
<EOS>
We
were
up
early
.
<EOS>
As
we
walked
to
and
fro
,
all
four
together
,
before
breakfast
,
I
deemed
it
right
to
recount
what
I
had
seen
.
<EOS>
Again
our
charge
was
the
least
anxious
of
the
party
.
<EOS>
It
was
very
likely
that
the
men
belonged
to
the
Custom
House
,
he
said
quietly
,
and
that
they
had
no
thought
of
us
.
<EOS>
I
tried
to
persuade
myself
that
it
was
so
---
as
,
indeed
,
it
might
easily
be
.
<EOS>
However
,
I
proposed
that
he
and
I
should
walk
away
together
to
a
distant
point
we
could
see
,
and
that
the
boat
should
take
us
aboard
there
,
or
as
near
there
as
might
prove
feasible
,
at
about
noon
.
<EOS>
This
being
considered
a
good
precaution
,
soon
after
breakfast
he
and
I
set
forth
,
without
saying
anything
at
the
tavern
.
  
<EOS>
He
smoked
his
pipe
as
we
went
along
,
and
sometimes
stopped
to
clap
me
on
the
shoulder
.
<EOS>
One
would
have
supposed
that
it
was
I
who
was
in
danger
,
not
he
,
and
that
he
was
reassuring
me
.
<EOS>
We
spoke
very
little
.
<EOS>
As
we
approached
the
point
,
I
begged
him
to
remain
in
a
sheltered
place
,
while
I
went
on
to
reconnoitre
;
for
,
it
was
towards
it
that
the
men
had
passed
in
the
night
.
<EOS>
He
complied
,
and
I
went
on
alone
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
boat
off
the
point
,
nor
any
boat
drawn
up
anywhere
near
it
,
nor
were
there
any
signs
of
the
men
having
embarked
there
.
<EOS>
But
,
to
be
sure
the
tide
was
high
,
and
there
might
have
been
some
footprints
under
water
.
  
<EOS>
When
he
looked
out
from
his
shelter
in
the
distance
,
and
saw
that
I
waved
my
hat
to
him
to
come
up
,
he
rejoined
me
,
and
there
we
waited
;
sometimes
lying
on
the
bank
wrapped
in
our
coats
,
and
sometimes
moving
about
to
warm
ourselves
:
until
we
saw
our
boat
coming
round
.
<EOS>
We
got
aboard
easily
,
and
rowed
out
into
the
track
of
the
steamer
.
<EOS>
By
that
time
it
wanted
but
ten
minutes
of
one
o'clock
,
and
we
-
began
to
look
out
for
her
smoke
.
  
<EOS>
But
,
it
was
half
-
past
one
before
we
saw
her
smoke
,
and
soon
afterwards
we
saw
behind
it
the
smoke
of
another
steamer
.
<EOS>
As
they
were
coming
on
at
full
speed
,
we
got
the
two
bags
ready
,
and
took
that
opportunity
of
saying
good
-
bye
to
Herbert
and
Startop
.
<EOS>
We
had
all
shaken
hands
cordially
,
and
neither
Herbert
's
eyes
nor
mine
were
quite
dry
,
when
I
saw
a
four
-
oared
galley
shoot
out
from
under
the
bank
but
a
little
way
ahead
of
us
,
and
row
out
into
the
same
track
.
  
<EOS>
A
stretch
of
shore
had
been
as
yet
between
us
and
the
steamer
's
smoke
,
by
reason
of
the
bend
and
wind
of
the
river
;
but
now
she
was
visible
,
coming
head
on
.
<EOS>
I
called
to
Herbert
and
Startop
to
keep
before
the
tide
,
that
she
might
see
us
lying
by
for
her
,
and
I
adjured
Provis
to
sit
quite
still
,
wrapped
in
his
cloak
.
<EOS>
He
answered
cheerily
,
"
Trust
to
me
,
dear
boy
,
"
and
sat
like
a
statue
.
<EOS>
Meantime
the
galley
,
which
was
very
skilfully
handled
,
had
crossed
us
,
let
us
come
up
with
her
,
and
fallen
alongside
.
<EOS>
Leaving
just
room
enough
for
the
play
of
the
oars
,
she
kept
alongside
,
drifting
when
we
drifted
,
and
pulling
a
stroke
or
two
when
we
pulled
.
<EOS>
Of
the
two
sitters
,
one
held
the
rudder
lines
,
and
looked
at
us
attentively
---
as
did
all
the
rowers
;
the
other
sitter
was
wrapped
up
,
much
as
Provis
was
,
and
seemed
to
shrink
,
and
whisper
some
instruction
to
the
steerer
as
he
looked
at
us
.
<EOS>
Not
a
word
was
spoken
in
either
boat
.
  
<EOS>
Startop
could
make
out
,
after
a

,
which
steamer
was
first
,
and
gave
me
the
word
"
Hamburg
,
"
in

as
we
sat
face
to

.
<EOS>
She
was
nearing
us
very
fast
,
and
the
beating
of
her
paddles
grew
louder
and
louder
.
<EOS>
I
felt
as
if
her
shadow
were
absolutely
upon
us
,
when
the
galley
hailed
us
.
<EOS>
I
answered
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
a
returned
Transport
there
,
"
said
the
man
who
held
the
lines
.
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
man
,
wrapped
in
the
cloak
.
<EOS>
His
name
is
Abel
Magwitch
,
otherwise
Provis
.
<EOS>
I
apprehend
that
man
,
and
call
upon
him
to
surrender
,
and
you
to
assist
.
"
  
<EOS>
At
the
same
moment
,
without
giving
any

direction
to

,
he
ran
the
galley
aboard
of
us
.
<EOS>
They
had
pulled
one
sudden
stroke
ahead
,
had
got
their
oars
in
,
had
run
athwart

,
and
were
holding

to
our

,
before

.
<EOS>
This
caused
great

on
board
the
steamer
,
and
I
heard
them
calling
to
us
,
and
heard

given
to

,
and
heard

stop
,
but
felt
her
driving
down
upon
us

.
<EOS>
In
the
same

,
I
saw
the
steersman
of
the
galley
lay
his

on
his
prisoner
's
shoulder
,
and
saw
that
both

were
swinging
round

,
and
saw

all

on

were

.
<EOS>
Still

prisoner

,

,
and

.
<EOS>
Still

,

,

of
the
other

.
<EOS>
Still

,

that

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
It

but

with

and

;
that
instant
past
,
I
was
taken

.
<EOS>
Herbert
was
there
,
and
Startop

;
but
our
boat
was

,
and
the

.
  
<EOS>
What

the

aboard

,

,

,

on
,

;

,

,

,

water
astern
.
<EOS>
Presently

was

,
bearing

on

.
<EOS>
No

,
but
the

held

,
and
all

backed
water
,
and

.
<EOS>
As

,
I
saw

to
be
Magwitch
,
swimming
,

.
<EOS>
He
was
taken
on
board
,
and
instantly

.
  
<EOS>
The
galley
was
kept

,
and
the
silent
eager
look
-
out
at
the
water
was

.
<EOS>
But
,
the
Rotterdam
steamer
now

,

.
<EOS>
By

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

-

was

,

;

,

.
  
<EOS>
At

,

we

,

.
<EOS>
Here
,

---
<EOS>
Provis
no

---
who
had

.
  
<EOS>
He

to
have

,

.
<EOS>
The

to

chest
(
which

)
<EOS>
he

received
against

.
<EOS>
He

)

.
<EOS>
He

,

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
The

.
  
<EOS>
When

:

<EOS>
So

.
<EOS>

;

,

.
  
<EOS>
The

where

,

.
<EOS>
His

.
<EOS>
Probably
,

.
  
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
Herbert

.
<EOS>
We

,

's

,
I

that

.
  
<EOS>
For

,

all

,

in

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
  
<EOS>
His

drew

,

often

.
<EOS>
I

arm
I

,

;
but
,

,

.
<EOS>
That

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
That

,
I
could
not

.
<EOS>
He
who
had
been

in

,

since

,

,
and
who
had

.
  
<EOS>
As

we
had

,
and

,
I
told

to

come

.
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
boy
,
"
he

,
"
I
'm
quite

to
take

chance
.
<EOS>
I
've
seen
my
boy
,
and
he
can
be
a
gentleman
without
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
I
had
thought
about
that
,
while
we
had
been
there
side
by
side
.
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
Apart
from
any

of
my
own
,
I
understood
Wemmick
's
hint
now
.
<EOS>
I
foresaw
that
,
being
convicted
,
his

would
be
forfeited
to
the

.
  
<EOS>
"
Lookee
here
,

,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
It
's
best
as
a
gentleman
should
not

.
<EOS>
Only

as

alonger

.
<EOS>
Sit

,

the
last
o
'
many

,

I
do

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
never

,
"
said

,
"
when
I
am
suffered

.
<EOS>
Please
God
,
I
will
be
as

,

!
"
  
<EOS>
I
felt
his
hand

as
it
held

,
and
he
turned

away
as

lay

,

I

---
softened

,
like

.
<EOS>
It
was

that
he
had

,

put

what

until

:
<EOS>
That
he
need
never
know
how
his

of

had

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
55
 
<EOS>
HE
was
taken
to
the
Police
Court
next
day
,
and
would
have
been
immediately
committed
for
trial
,
but
that
it
was
necessary
to
send
down
for
an
old
officer
of
the
prison
-
ship
from
which
he
had
once
escaped
,
to
speak
to
his
identity
.
<EOS>
Nobody
doubted
it
;
but
,
Compeyson
,
who
had
meant
to
depose
to
it
,
was
tumbling
on
the
tides
,
dead
,
and
it
happened
that
there
was
not
at
that
time
any
prison
officer
in
London
who
could
give
the
required
evidence
.
<EOS>
I
had
gone
direct
to
Mr
Jaggers
at
his
private
house
,
on
my
arrival
over
night
,
to
retain
his
assistance
,
and
Mr
Jaggers
on
the
prisoner
's
behalf
would
admit
nothing
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
sole
resource
,
for
he
told
me
that
the
case
must
be
over
in
five
minutes
when
the
witness
was
there
,
and
that
no
power
on
earth
could
prevent
its
going
against
us
.
  
<EOS>
I
imparted
to
Mr
Jaggers
my
design
of
keeping
him
in
ignorance
of
the
fate
of
his
wealth
.
<EOS>
Mr
Jaggers
was
querulous
and
angry
with
me
for
having
"
let
it
slip
through
my
fingers
,
"
and
said
we
must
memorialize
by
-
and
-
by
,
and
try
at
all
events
for
some
of
it
.
<EOS>
But
,
he
did
not
conceal
from
me
that
although
there
might
be
many
cases
in
which
the
forfeiture
would
not
be
exacted
,
there
were
no
circumstances
in
this
case
to
make
it
one
of
them
.
<EOS>
I
understood
that
,
very
well
.
<EOS>
I
was
not
related
to
the
outlaw
,
or
connected
with
him
by
any
recognizable
tie
;
he
had
put
his
hand
to
no
writing
or
settlement
in
my
favour
before
his
apprehension
,
and
to
do
so
now
would
be
idle
.
<EOS>
I
had
no
claim
,
and
I
finally
resolved
,
and
ever
afterwards
abided
by
the
resolution
,
that
my
heart
should
never
be
sickened
with
the
hopeless
task
of
attempting
to
establish
one
.
  
<EOS>
There
appeared
to
be
reason
for
supposing
that
the
drowned
informer
had
hoped
for
a
reward
out
of
this
forfeiture
,
and
had
obtained
some
accurate
knowledge
of
Magwitch
's
affairs
.
<EOS>
When
his
body
was
found
,
many
miles
from
the
scene
of
his
death
,
and
so
horribly
disfigured
that
he
was
only
recognizable
by
the
contents
of
his
pockets
,
notes
were
still
legible
,
folded
in
a
case
he
carried
.
<EOS>
Among
these
,
were
the
name
of
a
banking
-
house
in
New
South
Wales
where
a
sum
of
money
was
,
and
the
designation
of
certain
lands
of
considerable
value
.
<EOS>
Both
these
heads
of
information
were
in
a
list
that
Magwitch
,
while
in
prison
,
gave
to
Mr
Jaggers
,
of
the
possessions
he
supposed
I
should
inherit
.
<EOS>
His
ignorance
,
poor
fellow
,
at
last
served
him
;
he
never
mistrusted
but
that
my
inheritance
was
quite
safe
,
with
Mr
Jaggers
's
aid
.
  
<EOS>
After
three
days
'
delay
,
during
which
the
crown
prosecution
stood
over
for
the
production
of
the
witness
from
the
prison
-
ship
,
the
witness
came
,
and
completed
the
easy
case
.
<EOS>
He
was
committed
to
take
his
trial
at
the
next
Sessions
,
which
would
come
on
in
a
month
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
at
this
dark
time
of
my
life
that
Herbert
returned
home
one
evening
,
a
good
deal
cast
down
,
and
said
:
  
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Handel
,
I
fear
I
shall
soon
have
to
leave
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
His
partner
having
prepared
me
for
that
,
I
was
less
surprised
than
he
thought
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
shall
lose
a
fine
opportunity
if
I
put

going
to
Cairo
,
and
I
am
very
much
afraid
I
must
go
,
Handel
,
when
you
most
need
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Herbert
,
I
shall
always
need
you
,
because
I
shall
always
love
you
;
but
my
need
is
no
greater
now
,
than
at
another
time
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
be
so
lonely
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
leisure
to
think
of
that
,
"
said
I.
<EOS>
"
You
know
that
I
am
always
with
him
to
the
full
extent
of
the
time
allowed
,
and
that
I
should
be
with
him
all
day
long
,
if
I
could
.
<EOS>
And
when
I
come
away
from
him
,
you
know
that
my
thoughts
are
with
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
dreadful
condition
to
which
he
was
brought
,
was
so
appalling
to
both
of
us
,
that
we
could
not

it
in

.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
fellow
,
"
said
Herbert
,
"
let
the
near

our

---
for
,

---

my

for
troubling
you
about

.
<EOS>
Have
you
thought

your

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
for
I
have
been
afraid
to

any

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
yours

not

;

<EOS>
I

,

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
,
"
said

<EOS>
"
In
this

of

,
Handel
,
we
must

a
---
"
  
I

"
A

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
clerk
.
<EOS>
And

<EOS>

,
Handel
---
in

<EOS>
There

after

"
Now
,
Handel
,
"
as

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Clara
and
I
have

again

,
"

"

the
dear

begged

,

.
<EOS>
We

,
Handel
!
"
  
<EOS>
I

,
and
I

,
but
said
I
could
not
yet

as

.
<EOS>
Firstly
,

.
<EOS>
Secondly
<EOS>
---
Yes
!
<EOS>
Secondly
,
there
was
a
vague
something
lingering
in

that
will

.
  
<EOS>
"
But

,
Herbert
,

,

"
  
"

,
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Six

!
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not

,
"

"
Two

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Herbert

,
and

<EOS>
"
And

?
"

<EOS>

,
"

"

;

wo

.
<EOS>
Mrs
Whimple

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not

.
  
<EOS>

"
<EOS>

the
dear

thing
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Remember
!
<EOS>
The

comes
of
no

,
my

Handel
,
and
never

red

,

n't

.
<EOS>
What

for

son

!
"
  
<EOS>
On

in

,
I
took
my

Herbert
---
full

,
but
sad

sorry
to

---
as
he

on
one
of

seaport
mail

.
<EOS>
I
went
into
a
coffee
-
house
to

a
little
note
to
Clara
,
telling
her
he
had
gone
off
,
sending
his
love
to
her
over
and
over
again
,
and
then
went
to
my
lonely
home
---
if
it
deserved
the
name
,
for
it
was
now
no
home
to
me
,
and
I
had
no
home
anywhere
.
  
<EOS>
On
the
stairs
I
encountered
Wemmick
,
who
was
coming
down
,
after
an
unsuccessful
application
of
his
knuckles
to
my
door
.
<EOS>
I
had
not
seen
him
alone
,
since
the
disastrous
issue
of
the
attempted
flight
;
and
he
had
come
,
in
his
private
and
personal

,
to

.
  
<EOS>
"
The
late
Compeyson
,
"
said
Wemmick
,
"
had
by
little
and
little
got
at
the
bottom
of
half
of
the
regular
business
now
transacted
,
and
it
was
from
the
talk
of
some
of
his
people
in
trouble
(
some
of
his
people
being
always
in
trouble
)
<EOS>
that
I
heard
what
I
did
.
<EOS>
I
kept
my
ears
open
,
seeming

,
until
I
heard
that
he
was
absent
,
and
I
thought

.
<EOS>
I
can
only

,
that
it
was
a

his
policy
,
as
a
very
clever
man
,
habitually
to

.
<EOS>
You
do

,

,
<EOS>
Mr

?
<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank

,

<EOS>
It

,
"

,

"

I

I

.
<EOS>
What

.
<EOS>
Dear

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Yes
,

,

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
But

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
That

"
  
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
But

\
could
\

<EOS>
It

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
I

would

---

.
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
Punctual

my
appointment
<EOS>
,

,

:
who

.
<EOS>
Within
,

two

-

,

.
<EOS>
The
Aged
must

,

,

his

<EOS>
,

.
  
<EOS>
When

-

on

<EOS>
,

,

.
<EOS>
"
Why
,
we
are
not

!
"
<EOS>

"
No
,
"

,
"
but
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
thought
this
odd
;
however
,
I

,

.
<EOS>
We
went
towards
Camberwell
Green
,
and
when
we
were

,
Wemmick
said

:
  
"
<EOS>
Halloa
!
<EOS>
Here
's
a
church
!
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
nothing
very
surprising
in
that
;
but
again
,
I
was
rather

,
when
he
said
,
as

:
  
"
<EOS>
Let
's

!
"
  
<EOS>
We

in
,
Wemmick
leaving
his
fishing
-
rod
in

,
and
looked
all

.
<EOS>
In
the

,
Wemmick
was

into

,
and

something
out

there
.
  
<EOS>
"
Halloa
!
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here
's
a
couple
of
pair
of

!
<EOS>
Let
's

'em
on
!
"
  
<EOS>
As

were
white
kid

,
and
as
the

-
office
was
widened
to

,
I
now
began
to
have
my
strong
suspicions
.
<EOS>
They
were
strengthened
into
certainty
when
I
beheld
the
Aged
enter
at
a
side

,

a
lady
.
  
<EOS>
"
Halloa
!
"
said
Wemmick
.
<EOS>
"
Here
's
Miss
Skiffins
!
<EOS>
Let
's
have
a
wedding
.
"
  
<EOS>
That
discreet
damsel
was
attired
as
usual
,
except
that
she
was
now
engaged
in
substituting
for
her
green
kid
gloves
,
a
pair
of
white
.
<EOS>
The
Aged
was
likewise
occupied
in
preparing
a
similar
sacrifice
for
the
altar
of
Hymen
.
<EOS>
The
old
gentleman
,
however
,
experienced
so
much
difficulty
in
getting
his
gloves
on
,
that
Wemmick
found
it
necessary
to
put
him
with
his
back
against
a
pillar
,
and
then
to
get
behind
the
pillar
himself
and
pull
away
at
them
,
while
I
for
my
part
held
the
old
gentleman
round
the
waist
,
that
he
might
present
an
equal
and
safe
resistance
.
<EOS>
By
dint
of
this
ingenious
scheme
,
his
gloves
were
got
on
to
perfection
.
  
<EOS>
The
clerk
and
clergyman
then
appearing
,
we
were
ranged
in
order
at
those
fatal
rails
.
<EOS>
True
to
his
notion
of
seeming
to
do
it
all
without
preparation
,
I
heard
Wemmick
say
to
himself
as
he
took
something
out
of
his
waistcoat
-
pocket
before
the
service
began
,
"
<EOS>
Halloa
!
<EOS>
Here
's
a
ring
!
"
  
<EOS>
I
acted
in
the
capacity
of
backer
,
or
best
-
man
,
to
the
bridegroom
;
while
a
little
limp
pew
opener
in
a
soft
bonnet
like
a
baby
's
,
made
a
feint
of
being
the
bosom
friend
of
Miss
Skiffins
.
<EOS>
The
responsibility
of
giving
the
lady
away
,
devolved
upon
the
Aged
,
which
led
to
the
clergyman
's
being
unintentionally
scandalized
,
and
it
happened
thus
.
<EOS>
When
he
said
,
"
Who
giveth
this
woman
to
be
married
to
this
man
?
"
<EOS>
the
old
gentlemen
,
not
in
the
least
knowing
what
point
of
the
ceremony
we
had
arrived
at
,
stood
most
amiably
beaming
at
the
ten
commandments
.
<EOS>
Upon
which
,
the
clergyman
said
again
,
"
WHO
giveth
this
woman
to
be
married
to
this
man
?
"
<EOS>
The
old
gentleman
being
still
in
a
state
of
most
estimable
unconsciousness
,
the
bridegroom
cried
out
in
his
accustomed
voice
,
"
Now
Aged
P
you
know
;
who
giveth
?
<EOS>
"
To
which
the
Aged
replied
with
great
briskness
,
before
saying
that
 
\
<EOS>
he
\
 
<EOS>
gave
,
"
All
right
,
John
,
all
right
,
my
boy
!
"
<EOS>
And
the
clergyman
came
to
so
gloomy
a
pause
upon
it
,
that
I
had
doubts
for
the
moment
whether
we
should
get
completely
married
that
day
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
completely
done
,
however
,
and
when
we
were
going
out
of
church
,
Wemmick
took
the
cover
off
the
font
,
and
put
his
white
gloves
in
it
,
and
put
the
cover
on
again
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Wemmick
,
more
heedful
of
the
future
,
put
her
white
gloves
in
her
pocket
and
assumed
her
green
.
"
<EOS>
\
<EOS>
Now
,
\
 
Mr
Pip
,
"
said
Wemmick
,
triumphantly
shouldering
the
fishing
-
rod
as
we
came
out
,
"
let
me
ask
you
whether
anybody
would
suppose
this
to
be
a
wedding
-
party
!
"
  
<EOS>
Breakfast
had
been
ordered
at
a
pleasant
little
tavern
,
a
mile
or
so
away
upon
the
rising
ground
beyond
the
Green
;
and
there
was
=
<EOS>
bagatelle
board
in
the
room
,
in
case
we
should
desire
to
unbend
our
minds
after
the
solemnity
.
<EOS>
It
was
pleasant
to
observe
that
Mrs
Wemmick
no
longer
unwound
Wemmick
's
arm
when
it
adapted
itself
to
her
figure
,
but
sat
in
a
high
-
backed
chair
against
the
wall
,
like
a
violoncello
in
its
case
,
and
submitted
to
be
embraced
as
that
melodious
instrument
might
have
done
.
  
<EOS>
We
had
an
excellent
breakfast
,
and
when
any
one
declined
anything
on
table
,
Wemmick
said
,
"
Provided
by
contract
,
you
know
;
do
n't
be
afraid
of
it
!
"
<EOS>
I
drank
to
the
new
couple
,
drank
to
the
Aged
,
drank
to
the
Castle
,
saluted
the
bride
at
parting
,
and
made
myself
as
agreeable
as
I
could
.
  
<EOS>
Wemmick
came
down
to
the
door
with
me
,
and
I
again
shook
hands
with
him
,
and
wished
him
joy
.
  
<EOS>
"
Thankee
!
<EOS>
"
said
Wemmick
,
rubbing
his
hands
.
<EOS>
"
She
's
such
a
manager
of
fowls
,
you
have
no
idea
.
<EOS>
You
shall
have
some
eggs
,
and
judge
for
yourself
.
<EOS>
I
say
,
Mr
Pip
!
"
<EOS>
calling
me
back
,
and
speaking
low
.
<EOS>
"
This
is
altogether
a
Walworth
sentiment
,
please
.
"
  
"
I
understand
.
<EOS>
Not
to
be
mentioned
in
Little
Britain
,
"
said
I.
  
Wemmick
nodded
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
After
what
you
let
out
the
other
day
,
Mr
Jaggers
may
as
well
not
know
of
it
.
<EOS>
He
might
think
my
brain
was
softening
,
or
something
of
the
kind
.
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
56
 
<EOS>
He
lay
in
prison
very
ill
,
during
the
whole
interval
between
his
committal
for
trial
,
and
the
coming
round
of
the
Sessions
.
<EOS>
He
had
broken
two
ribs
,
they
had
wounded
one
of
his
lungs
,
and
he
breathed
with
great
pain
and
difficulty
,
which
increased
daily
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
consequence
of
his
hurt
,
that
he
spoke
so
low
as
to
be
scarcely
audible
;
therefore
,
he
spoke
very
little
.
<EOS>
But
,
he
was
ever
ready
to
listen
to
me
,
and
it
became
the
first
duty
of
my
life
to
say
to
him
,
and
read
to
him
,
what
I
knew
he
ought
to
hear
.
  
<EOS>
Being
fur
too
ill
to
remain
in
the
common
prison
,
he
was
removed
,
after
the
first
day
or
so
,
into
the
infirmary
.
<EOS>
This
gave
me
opportunities
of
being
with
him
that
I
could
not
otherwise
have
had
.
<EOS>
And
but
for
his
illness
he
would
have
been
put
in
irons
,
for
he
was
regarded
as
a
determined
prison
-
breaker
,
and
<EOS>
I
know
not
what
else
.
  
<EOS>
Although
I
saw
him
every
day
,
it
was
for
only
a
short
time
;
hence
,
the
regularly
recurring
spaces
of
our
separation
were
long
enough
to
record
on
his
face
any
alight
changes
that
occurred
in
his
physical
state
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
recollect
that
I
once
saw
any
change
in
it
for
the
better
;
he
wasted
,
and
became
slowly
weaker
and
worse
,
day
by
day
,
from
the
day
when
the
prison
door
closed
upon
him
.
  
<EOS>
The
kind
of
submission
or
resignation
that
he
showed
,
was
that
of
a
man
who
was
tired
out
.
<EOS>
I
sometimes
derived
an
impression
,
from
his
manner
or
from
a
whispered
word
or
two
which
escaped
him
,
that
he
pondered
over
the
question
whether
he
might
have
been
a
better
man
under
better
circumstances
.
<EOS>
But
,
he
never
justified
himself
by
a
hint
tending
that
way
,
or
tried
to
bend
the
past
out
of
its
eternal
shape
.
  
<EOS>
It
happened
on
two
or
three
occasions
in
my
presence
,
that
his
desperate
reputation
was
alluded
to
by
one
or
other
of
the
people
in
attendance
on
him
.
<EOS>
A
smile
crossed
his
face
then
,
and
he
turned
his
eyes
on
me
with
a
trustful
look
,
as
if
he
were
confident
that
I
had
seen
some
small
redeeming
touch
in
him
,
even
so
long
ago
as
when
I
was
a
little
child
.
<EOS>
As
to
all
the
rest
,
he
was
humble
and
contrite
,
and
I
never
knew
him
complain
.
  
<EOS>
When
the
Sessions
came
round
,
Mr
Jaggers
caused
an
application
to
be
made
for
the
postponement
of
his
trial
until
the
following
Sessions
.
<EOS>
It
was
obviously
made
with
the
assurance
that
he
could
not
live
so
long
,
and
was
refused
.
<EOS>
The
trial
came
on
at
once
,
and
,
when
he
was
put
to
the
bar
,
he
was
seated
in
a
chair
.
<EOS>
No
objection
was
made
to
my
getting
close
to
the
dock
,
on
the
outside
of
it
,
and
holding
the
hand
that
he
stretched
forth
to
me
.
  
<EOS>
The
trial
was
very
shod
and
very
clear
.
<EOS>
Such
things
as
could
be
said
for
him
,
were
said
---
how
he
had
taken
to
industrious
habits
,
and
had
thriven
lawfully
and
reputably
.
<EOS>
But
,
nothing
could
unsay
the
fact
that
he
had
returned
,
and
was
there
in
presence
of
the
Judge
and
Jury
.
<EOS>
It
was
impossible
to
try
him
for
that
,
and
do
otherwise
than
find
him
guilty
.
  
<EOS>
At
that
time
,
it
was
the
custom
(
as
I
learnt
from
my
terrible
experience
of
that
Sessions
)
to
devote
a
concluding
day
to
the
passing
of
Sentences
,
and
to
make
a
finishing
effect
with
the
Sentence
of
Death
.
<EOS>
But
for
the
indelible
picture
that
my
remembrance
now
holds
before
me
,
I
could
scarcely
believe
,
even
as
I
write
these
words
,
that
I
saw
two
-
and
-
thirty
men
and
women
put
before
the
Judge
to
receive
that
sentence
together
.
<EOS>
Foremost
among
the
two
-
and
-
thirty
,
was
he
;
seated
,
that
he
might
get
breath
enough
to
keep
life
in
him
.
  
<EOS>
The
whole
scene
starts
out
again
in
the
vivid
colours
of
the
moment
,
down
to
the
drops
of
April
rain
on
the
windows
of
the
court
,
glittering
in
the
rays
of
April
sun
.
<EOS>
Penned
in
the
dock
,
as
I
again
stood
outside
it
at
the
corner
with
his
hand
in
mine
,
were
the
two
-
and
-
thirty
men
and
women
;
some
defiant
,
some
stricken
with
terror
,
some
sobbing
and
weeping
,
some
covering
their
faces
,
some
staring
gloomily
about
.
<EOS>
There
had
been
shrieks
from
among
the
women
convicts
,
but
they
had
been
stilled
,
and
a
hush
had
succeeded
.
<EOS>
The
sheriffs
with
their
great
chains
and
nosegays
,
other
civic
gewgaws
and
monsters
,
criers
,
ushers
,
a
great
gallery
full
of
people
---
a
large
theatrical
audience
---
looked
on
,
as
the
two
-
and
-
thirty
and
the
Judge
were
solemnly
confronted
.
<EOS>
Then
,
the
Judge
addressed
them
.
<EOS>
Among
the
wretched
creatures
before
him
whom
he
must
single
out
for
special
address
,
was
one
who
almost
from
his
infancy
had
been
an
offender
against
the
laws
;
who
,
after
repeated
imprisonments
and
punishments
,
had
been
at
length
sentenced
to
exile
for
a
term
of
years
;
and
who
,
under
circumstances
of
great
violence
and
daring
had
made
his
escape
and
been
re
-
sentenced
to
exile
for
life
.
<EOS>
That
miserable
man
would
seem
for
a
time
to
have
become
convinced
of
his
errors
,
when
far
removed
from
the
scenes
of
his
old
offences
,
and
to
have
lived
a
peaceable
and
honest
life
.
<EOS>
But
in
a
fatal
moment
,
yielding
to
those
propensities
and
passions
,
the
indulgence
of
which
had
so
long
rendered
him
a
scourge
to
society
,
he
had
quitted
his
haven
of
rest
and
repentance
,
and
had
come
back
to
the
country
where
he
was
proscribed
.
<EOS>
Being
here
presently
denounced
,
he
had
for
a
time
succeeded
in
evading
the
officers
of
Justice
,
but
being
at
length
seized
while
in
the
act
of
flight
,
he
had
resisted
them
,
and
had
---
he
best
knew
whether
by
express
design
,
or
in
the
blindness
of
his
hardihood
---
caused
the
death
of
his
denouncer
,
to
whom
his
whole
career
was
known
.
<EOS>
The
appointed
punishment
for
his
return
to
the
land
that
had
cast
him
out
,
being
Death
,
and
his
case
being
this
aggravated
case
,
he
must
prepare
himself
to
Die
.
  
<EOS>
The
sun
was
striking
in
at
the
great
windows
of
the
court
,
through
the
glittering
drops
of
rain
upon
the
glass
,
and
it
made
a
broad
shaft
of
light
between
the
two
-
and
-
thirty
and
the
Judge
,
linking
both
together
,
and
perhaps
reminding
some
among
the
audience
,
how
both
were
passing
on
,
with
absolute
equality
,
to
the
greater
Judgment
that
knoweth
all
things
and
can
not
err
.
<EOS>
Rising
for
a
moment
,
a
distinct
speck
of
face
in
this
way
of
light
,
the
prisoner
said
,
"
My
Lord
,
I
have
received
my
sentence
of
Death
from
the
Almighty
,
but
I
bow
to
yours
,
"
and
sat
down
again
.
<EOS>
There
was
some
hushing
,
and
the
Judge
went
on
with
what
he
had
to
say
to
the
rest
.
<EOS>
Then
,
they
were
all
formally
doomed
,
and
some
of
them
were
supported
out
,
and
some
of
them
sauntered
out
with
a
haggard
look
of
bravery
,
and
a
few
nodded
to
the
gallery
,
and
two
or
three
shook
hands
,
and
others
went
out
chewing
the
fragments
of
herb
they
had
taken
from
the
sweet
herbs
lying
about
.
<EOS>
He
went
last
of
all
,
because
of
having
to
be
helped
from
his
chair
and
to
go
very
slowly
;
and
he
held
my
hand
while
all
the
others
were
removed
,
and
while
the
audience
got
up
(
putting
their
dresses
right
,
as
they
might
at
church
or
elsewhere
)
and
pointed
down
at
this
criminal
or
at
that
,
and
most
of
all
at
him
and
me
.
  
<EOS>
I
earnestly
hoped
and
prayed
that
he
might
die
before
the
Recorder
's
Report
was
made
,
but
,
in
the
dread
of
his
lingering
on
,
I
began
that
night
to
write
out
a
petition
to
the
Home
Secretary
of
State
,
setting
forth
my
knowledge
of
him
,
and
how
it
was
that
he
had
come
back
for
my
sake
.
<EOS>
I
wrote
it
as
fervently
and
pathetically
as
I
could
,
and
when
I
had
finished
it
and
sent
it
in
,
I
wrote
out
other
petitions
to
such
men
in
authority
as
I
hoped
were
the
most
merciful
,
and
drew
up
one
to
the
Crown
itself
.
<EOS>
For
several
days
and
nights
after
he
was
sentenced
I
took
no
rest
except
when
I
fell
asleep
in
my
chair
,
but
was
wholly
absorbed
in
these
appeals
.
<EOS>
And
after
I
had
sent
them
in
,
I
could
not
keep
away
from
the
places
where
they
were
,
but
felt
as
if
they
were
more
hopeful
and
less
desperate
when
I
was
near
them
.
<EOS>
In
this
unreasonable
restlessness
and
pain
of
mind
,
I
would
roam
the
streets
of
an
evening
,
wandering
by
those
offices
and
houses
where
I
had
left
the
petitions
.
<EOS>
To
the
present
hour
,
the
weary
western
streets
of
London
on
a
cold
dusty
spring
night
,
with
their
ranges
of
stern
shut
-
up
mansions
and
their
long
rows
of
lamps
,
are
melancholy
to
me
from
this
association
.
  
<EOS>
The
daily
visits
I
could
make
him
were
shortened
now
,
and
he
was
more
strictly
kept
.
<EOS>
Seeing
,
or
fancying
<EOS>
,
that
I
was
suspected
of
an
intention
of
carrying
poison
to
him
,
I
asked
to
be
searched
before
I
sat
down
at
his
bedside
,
and
told
the
officer
who
was
always
there
,
that
I
was
willing
to
do
anything
that
would
assure
him
of
the
singleness
of
my
designs
.
<EOS>
Nobody
was
hard
with
him
,
or
with
me
.
<EOS>
There
was
duty
to
be
done
,
and
it
was
done
,
but
not
harshly
.
<EOS>
The
officer
always
gave
me
the
assurance
that
he
was
worse
,
and
some
other
sick
prisoners
in
the
room
,
and
some
other
prisoners
who
attended
on
them
as
sick
nurses
(
malefactors
,
but
not
incapable
of
kindness
,
GOD
be
thanked
!
)
,
always
joined
in
the
same
report
.
  
<EOS>
As
the
days
went
on
,
I
noticed
more
and
more
that
he
would
lie
placidly
looking
at
the
white
ceiling
,
with
an
absence
of
light
in
his
face
,
until
some
word
of
mine
brightened
it
for
an
instant
,
and
then
it
would
subside
again
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
he
was
almost
,
or
quite
,
unable
to
speak
;
then
,
he
would
answer
me
with
slight
pressures
on
my
hand
,
and
I
grew
to
understand
his
meaning
very
well
.
  
<EOS>
The
number
of
the
days
had
risen
to
ten
,
when
I
saw
a
greater
change
in
him
than
I
had
seen
yet
.
<EOS>
His
eyes
were
turned
towards
the
door
,
and
lighted
up
as
I
entered
.
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
boy
,
"
he
said
,
as
I
sat
down
by
his
bed
:
"
I
thought
you
was
late
.
<EOS>
But
I
knowed
you
could
n't
be
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
just
the
time
,
"
said
I.
<EOS>
"
I
waited
for
it
at
the
gate
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
always
waits
at
the
gate
;
do
n't
you
,
dear
boy
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
Not
to
lose
a
moment
of
the
time
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank'ee
dear
boy
,
thank'ee
.
<EOS>
God
bless
you
!
<EOS>
You
've
never
deserted
me
,
dear
boy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
pressed
his
hand
in
silence
,
for
I
could
not
forget
that
I
had
once
meant
to
desert
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
what
's
the
best
of
all
,
"
he
said
,
"
you
've
been
more
comfortable
alonger
me
,
since
I
was
under
a
dark
cloud
,
than
when
the
sun
shone
.
<EOS>
That
's
best
of
all
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
lay
on
his
back
,
breathing
with
great
difficulty
.
<EOS>
Do
what
he
would
,
and
love
me
though
he
did
,
the
light
left
his
face
ever
and
again
,
and
a
film
came
over
the
placid
look
at
the
white
ceiling
.
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
in
much
pain
to
-
day
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
complain
of
none
,
dear
boy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
never
do
complain
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
had
spoken
his
last
words
.
<EOS>
He
smiled
,
and
I
understood
his
touch
to
mean
that
he
wished
to
lift
my
hand
,
and
lay
it
on
his
breast
.
<EOS>
I
laid
it
there
,
and
he
smiled
again
,
and
put
both
his
hands
upon
it
.
  
<EOS>
The
allotted
time
ran
out
,
while
we
were
thus
;
but
,
looking
round
,
I
found
the
governor
of
the
prison
standing
near
me
,
and
he
whispered
,
"
You
need
n't
go
yet
.
<EOS>
"
I
thanked
him
gratefully
,
and
asked
,
"
Might
I
speak
to
him
,
if
he
can
hear
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
governor
stepped
aside
,
and
beckoned
the
officer
away
.
<EOS>
The
change
,
though
it
was
made
without
noise
,
drew
back
the
film
from
the
placid
look
at
the
white
ceiling
,
and
he
looked
most

at
me
.
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
Magwitch
,
I
must
tell
you
,
now
at
last
.
<EOS>
You
understand
what
I
say
?
"
  
<EOS>
A
gentle
pressure
on
my
hand
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
had
a
child
once
,
whom
you
loved
and
lost
.
"
  
<EOS>
A
stronger
pressure
on
my
hand
.
  
<EOS>
"
She
lived
and
found
powerful
friends
.
<EOS>
She
is
living
now
.
<EOS>
She
is
a
lady
and
very
beautiful
.
<EOS>
And
I
love
her
!
"
  
<EOS>
With
a
last
faint

,
which
would
have
been
powerless
but
for
my
yielding
to
it
and
assisting

,
he
raised
my
hand
to
his
lips
.
<EOS>
Then
,
he
gently
let
it
sink
upon
his
breast
again
,
with
his
own
hands
lying
on
it
.
<EOS>
The
placid
look
at
the
white
ceiling
came
back
,
and
passed
away
,
and
his
head
dropped
quietly
on
his

.
  
<EOS>
Mindful
,
then
,
of
what
we
had
read
together
,
I
thought
of
the
two
men
who
went
up

the

to

,
and
I
knew

were
no
better

could
say

,
than
"
O
Lord
,
be
merciful
to
him
,
a
sinner
!
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
57
 
<EOS>
Now
that
I
was
left
wholly
to
myself
,
I
gave
notice
of
my
intention
to
quit
the
chambers
in
the
Temple
as
soon
as
my
tenancy
could
legally
determine
,
and
in
the
meanwhile
to
underlet
them
.
<EOS>
At
once
I
put
bills
up
in
the
windows
;
for
,
I
was
in
debt
,
and
had
scarcely
any
money
,
and
began
to
be
seriously
alarmed
by
the
state
of
my
affairs
.
<EOS>
I
ought
rather
to
write
that
I
should
have
been
alarmed
if
I
had
had
energy
and
concentration
enough
to
help
me
to
the
clear
perception
of
any
truth
beyond
the
fact
that
I
was
fulling
very
ill
.
<EOS>
The
late
stress
upon
me
had
enabled
me
to
put
off
illness
,
but
not
to
put
it
away
;
I
knew
that
it
was
coming
on
me
now
,
and
I
knew
very
little
else
,
and
was
even
careless
as
to
that
.
  
<EOS>
For
a
day
or
two
,
I
lay
on
the
sofa
,
or
on
the
floor
---
anywhere
,
according
as
I
happened
to
sink
down
---
with
a
heavy
head
and
aching
limbs
,
and
no
purpose
,
and
no
power
.
<EOS>
Then
there
came
one
night
which
appeared
of
great
duration
,
and
which
teemed
with
anxiety
and
horror
;
and
when
in
the
morning
I
tried
to
sit
up
in
my
bed
and
think
of
it
,
I
found
I
could
not
do
so
.
  
<EOS>
Whether
I
really
had
been
down
in
Garden
-
court
in
the
dead
of
the
night
,
groping
about
for
the
boat
that
I
supposed
to
be
there
;
whether
I
had
two
or
three
times
come
to
myself
on
the

with
great
terror
,
not
knowing
how
I
had
got
out
of
bed
;
whether
I
had
found
myself
lighting
the
lamp
,
possessed
by
the
idea
that
he
was
coming
up
the
stairs
,
and
that
the
lights
were
blown
out
;
whether
I
had
been
inexpressibly
harassed
by
the
distracted
talking
laughing
,
and
groaning
,
of
some
one
,
and
had
half
suspected
those
sounds
to
be
of
my
own
making
;
whether
there
had
been
a
closed
iron

in
a
dark
corner
of
the
room
,
and
a
voice
had
called
out
over
and
over
again
that
Miss
Havisham
was
consuming
within
it
;
these
were
things
that
I
tried
to
settle
with
myself
and
get
into
some
order
,
as
I
lay
that
morning
on
my
bed
.
<EOS>
But
,
the
vapour
of
a
limekiln
would
come
between
me
and
them
,
disordering
them
all
,
and
it
was
through
the
vapour
at
last
that
I
saw
two
men
looking
at
me
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
want
?
<EOS>
"
I
asked
,
starting
;
"
I
do
n't
know
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
"
returned
one

,
bending

and
touching

,
"
this

matter
that
you
'll
soon

,
I
dare

,
but
you
're

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hundred

-
three
pound
,

,
six
.
<EOS>
Jeweller
's
account
,
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

?
"
  
"
You
had
better
come

house
,
"
said

man
.
<EOS>
"
I
keep
a
very
nice
house
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
made
some
attempt
to
get
up
and
dress

.
<EOS>
When
I
next
attended
to
them
,
they

a

bed
,
looking
at

.
<EOS>
I
still
lay
there
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
see
my
state
,
"
said
I.
<EOS>
"
I
would
come
with
you
if
I

;
but

quite

.
<EOS>
If
you
take
me
from
here
,
I

I
shall
die
by
the

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Perhaps

replied
,
or
argued

,
or
tried
to
encourage
me
to
believe
that
I
was
better
than

.
<EOS>
Forasmuch

hang

this
one

,
I
do

what
they
did
,
except

forbore

.
  
<EOS>
That
I
had
a
fever
and
was
avoided
,
that
I

greatly
,
that
I
often
lost

,
that

,
that
I
confounded

with

own

;
that
I
was
a

,
and
yet

where
the

;
that
I
was
a

of
a

,
clashing
and

over
a

,
and
yet
that
I
implored
in
my
own

to
have
the

stopped
,
and
my
part
in
it
hammered

;
that
I
passed
through
these

of
disease
,
I
know
of
my
own

,
and
did
in
some
sort
know

the
time
.
<EOS>
That
I
sometimes
struggled
with
real
people
,
in
the
belief
that
they
were
murderers
,
and
that
I
would
all

,

,
and

to
lay
me
down
,
I
also
knew
at
the

.
<EOS>
But
,
above

,
I
knew
that

a
constant

in
all
these

---
who
,

,

,

would

much

---
above
all
<EOS>
,

say
,

in
all
these
people
,
sooner

to
settle
down

the

of
Joe
.
  
<EOS>
After
I
had
turned
the
worst

of
my

,
I
began
to
notice
that
while
all
its
other

changed
,
this

did
not

.
<EOS>
Whoever
came
about
me
,
still
settled
down
into
Joe
.
<EOS>
I
opened
my

in
the
night
,
and
I
saw
in
the
great
chair

the
bedside
,
Joe
.
<EOS>
I
opened
my

in
the

,
and
,

the
window
-
seat
,

pipe
in

,
still
I
saw
Joe
.
<EOS>
I
asked
for
cooling

,
and
the
dear
hand
that
gave

me
was
Joe
's
.
<EOS>
I
sank

after

,
and
the

that
looked
so
hopefully
and

upon
me
was
the
face
of
Joe
.
  
<EOS>
At
last
,
one
day
,
I
took

,
and
said
,
"
\
<EOS>
Is
\
 
<EOS>
it
Joe
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
And
the
dear
old
home
-
voice
answered
,
"
Which
it
air
,
old
chap
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
O
Joe
,
you
break
my
heart
!
<EOS>
Look

,
Joe
.
<EOS>
Strike

,
Joe
.
<EOS>
Tell
me
of
my

.
<EOS>
Do
n't
be
so

!
"
  
<EOS>
For
,

had
actually
laid
his

down
on
the

at

and
put
his

,
in
his
joy
that
I

.
  
<EOS>
"
Which
dear

Pip
,

,
"
said

,
"
you

was
ever
friends
.
<EOS>
And

you
're
well
enough
to

---
what
larks
!
"
  
<EOS>
After

,
Joe
withdrew
to

,
and
stood
with

me
,

.
<EOS>
And
as
my
extreme

prevented
me
from
getting

and
going
to
him
<EOS>
,
I
lay

,

,
"
O
God

him
!
<EOS>
O
God

this

man
!
"
  
<EOS>
Joe
's
eyes
were
red
when
I
next
found
him
beside
me
;
but
,
I
was
holding
his
hand
,
and
we
both
felt
happy
.
  
<EOS>
"

tell
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
58
 
<EOS>
THE
tidings
of
my
high
fortunes
having
had
a
heavy
fall
,
had
got
down
to
my
native
place
and
its
neighbourhood
,
before
I
got
there
.
<EOS>
I
found
the
Blue
Boar
in
possession
of
the
intelligence
,
and
I
found
that
it
made
a
great
change
in
the
Boar
's
demeanour
.
<EOS>
Whereas
the
Boar
had
cultivated
my
good
opinion
with
warm
assiduity
when
I
was
coming
into
property
,
the
Boar
was
exceedingly
cool
on
the
subject
now
that
I
was
going
out
of
property
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
evening
when
I
arrived
,
much
fatigued
by
the
journey
I
had
so
often
made
so
easily
.
<EOS>
The
Boar
could
not
put
me
into
my
usual
bedroom
,
which
was
engaged
(
probably
by
some
one
who
had
expectations
)
,
and
could
only
assign
me
a
very
indifferent
chamber
among
the
pigeons
and
post
-
chaises
up
the
yard
.
<EOS>
But
,
I
had
as
sound
asleep
in
that
lodging
as
in
the
most
superior
accommodation
<EOS>
the
Boar
could
have
given
me
,
and
the
quality
of
my
dreams
was
about
the
same
as
in
the
best
bedroom
.
  
<EOS>
Early
in
the
morning
while
my
breakfast
was
getting
ready
,
I
strolled
round
by
Satis
House
.
<EOS>
There
were
printed
bills
on
the
gate
,
and
on
bits
of
carpet
hanging
out
of
the
windows
,
announcing
a
sale
by
auction
of
the
Household
Furniture
and
Effects
,
next
week
.
<EOS>
The
House
itself
was
to
be
sold
as
old
building
materials
and
pulled
down
.
<EOS>
LOT
was
marked
in
whitewashed
knock
-
knee
letters
on
the
brew
house
;
LOT
on
that
part
of
the
main
building
which
had
been
so
long
shut
up
.
<EOS>
Other
lots
were
marked
off
on
other
parts
of
the
structure
,
and
the
ivy
had
been
torn
down
to
make
room
for
the
inscriptions
,
and
much
of
it
trailed
low
in
the
dust
and
was
withered
already
.
<EOS>
Stepping
in
for
a
moment
at
the
open
gate
and
looking
around
me
with
the
uncomfortable
air
of
a
stranger
who
had
no
business
there
,
I
saw
the
auctioneer
's
clerk
walking
on
the
casks
and
telling
them
off
for
the
information
of
a
catalogue
compiler
,
pen
in
hand
,
who
made
a
temporary
desk
of
the
wheeled
chair
I
had
so
often
pushed
along
to
the
tune
of
Old
Clem
.
  
<EOS>
When
I
got
back
to
my
breakfast
in
the
Boar
's
coffee
-
room
,
I
found
Mr
Pumblechook
conversing
with
the
landlord
.
<EOS>
Mr
Pumblechook
(
not
improved
in
appearance
by
his
late
nocturnal
adventure
)
was
waiting
for
me
,
and
addressed
me
in
the
following
terms
.
  
<EOS>
"
Young
man
,
I
am
sorry
to
see
you
brought
low
.
<EOS>
But
what
else
could
be
expected
!
<EOS>
What
else
could
be
expected
!
"
  
<EOS>
As
he
extended

hand
with
a
magnificently
forgiving
air
,
and
as
I
was
broken
by
illness
and
unfit
to
quarrel
,
I
took
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
William
,
"
said
Mr
Pumblechook
to

waiter
,
"
put
a

on
table
.
<EOS>
And
has
it
come
to
this
!
<EOS>
Has
it
come
to
this
!
"
  
<EOS>
I
frowningly

to

.
<EOS>
Mr
Pumblechook
stood
over

and
poured

my
tea
---
before

could
touch

teapot
---
with

a

was

.
  
<EOS>
"
William
,
"

"
put

.
<EOS>

"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
True

<EOS>
The

earth
.
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
You
need

,
William
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
went
on
with

,
and
Mr
Pumblechook
continued
to
stand
over
me
,
staring
fishily
and
breathing
noisily
,
as
he
always
did
.
  
<EOS>
"
Little
more
than
skin
and
bone
!
"

Pumblechook
,

.
"
<EOS>
And
yet
when
he
went
away
from
here
(
I
may

,

my

,
like
the
Bee
,
he
was
as

Peach
!
"
  
<EOS>
This
reminded

of

between

had
offered

?
"
and

same
fat
five

.
  
<EOS>
"
Hah
!
<EOS>
"
he

,

.
"
<EOS>
And
air
you
a
going
to
Joseph
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
In
Heaven
's
name
,
"
said

,
<EOS>

,

?
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

,

!
<EOS>
Tell

it

;

!
"
  
<EOS>
A

.
<EOS>
The

.
  
<EOS>
"
This

,
"

,
"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

untoe

Georgiana
M'ria

<EOS>

,

.

Young

,
"

.

.

<EOS>
The

,

<EOS>
But
,

,

,
<EOS>
if

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

,

,
and

sense
of
leaving

and
untruthfulness
further
and
further

.
  
<EOS>
The
June
weather
was
delicious
.
<EOS>
The
sky
was
blue
,
the
larks
were

high
over

green
corn
,
I
thought
all
that
country
-
side
more

and

fur
than
I
had
ever

to

yet
.
<EOS>
Many
pleasant
pictures
of
the
life
that
I
would

,
and

change
for
the
better
that

when
I

at

whose
simple
faith
and

home
-

<EOS>
I
had
proved
,

way
.
<EOS>
They
awakened
a

in
me
;
for
,
my
heart
was
softened
by
my
return
,
and
such

change
had
come
to
pass
<EOS>
,
that
I
felt
like
one
who
was

from
distant
travel
,
and
whose
wanderings
had
lasted
many

.
  
<EOS>
The
schoolhouse
where
Biddy
was
mistress
,
I
had
never

;
but
,

by

the
village
for
quietness
'

,

.
<EOS>
I
was

to
find
that
the
day
was
a

;
no
children
were
there
,
and
Biddy
's

was

.
<EOS>
Some
hopeful
notion
of
seeing
her
busily

in
her
daily

,
before
she
saw
me
,
had

my

and
was

.
  
<EOS>
But
,
the
forge
was
a
very
short
distance
off
,
and
I
went
towards
it
under
the
sweet
green
limes
,

's

.
<EOS>

it
but
<EOS>
a
fancy
,

.
<EOS>
The

,

's

not

.
  
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
I
,

"

,

;

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

fellow

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
Chapter
59
 
FOR

,

.
  
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
But
,

,

.
  
<EOS>
There

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
A

in

standing
ajar
<EOS>
,

,

.
  
<EOS>
A

,

.
<EOS>
But
,

were

beyond

,
and
the

was
coming
,
and
the

was
not
dark
.
<EOS>
I
could
trace
out
where
every
part
of
the
old
house
had
been
,
and
where
the
brewery
had
been
,
and
where
the
gates
,
and
where
the
casks
.
<EOS>
I
had
done
so
,
and
was
looking
along
the
desolate
garden
-
walk
,
when
I
beheld
a
solitary
figure
in
it
.
  
<EOS>
The
figure
showed
itself
aware
of
me
,
as
I
advanced
.
<EOS>
It
had
been
moving
towards
me
,
but
it
stood
still
.
<EOS>
As
I
drew
nearer
,
I
saw
it
to
be
the
figure
of
a
woman
.
<EOS>
As
I
drew
nearer
yet
,
it
was
about
to
turn
away
,
when
it
stopped
,
and
let
me
come
up
with
it
.
<EOS>
Then
,
it
faltered
as
if
much
surprised
,
and
uttered
my
name
,
and
I
cried
out
:
  
"
Estella
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
greatly
changed
.
<EOS>
I
wonder
you
know
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
freshness
of
her
beauty
was
indeed
gone
,
but
its
indescribable
majesty
and
its
indescribable
charm
remained
.
<EOS>
Those
attractions
in
it
,
I
had
seen
before
<EOS>
;
what
I
had
never
seen
before
,
was
the
saddened
softened
light
of
the
once
proud
eyes
;
what
I
had
never
felt
before
,
was
the
friendly
touch
of
the
once
insensible
hand
.
  
<EOS>
We
sat
down
on
a
bench
that
was
near
,
and
I
said
,
"
After
so
many
years
,
it
is
strange
that
we
should
thus
meet
again
,
Estella
,
here
where
our
first
meeting
was
!
<EOS>
Do
you
often
come
back
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
never
been
here
since
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Nor
I.
"
  
The
moon
began
to
rise
,
and
I
thought
of
the
placid
look
at
the
white
ceiling
,
which
had
passed
away
.
<EOS>
The
moon
began
to
rise
,
and
I
thought
of
the
pressure
on
my
hand
when
I
had
spoken
the
last
words
he
had
heard
on
earth
.
  
<EOS>
Estella
was
the
next
to
break
the
silence
that
ensued
between
us
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
very
often
hoped
and
intended
to
come
back
,
but
have
been
prevented
by
many
circumstances
.
 
<EOS>
Poor
,
poor
old
place
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
silvery
mist
was
touched
with
the
first
rays
of
the
moonlight
,
and
the
same
rays
touched
the
tears
that
dropped
from
her
eyes
.
<EOS>
Not
knowing
that
I
saw
them
,
and
setting
herself
to
get
the
better
of
them
,
she
said
quietly
:
  
"
Were
you
wondering
,
as
you
walked
along
,
how
it
came
to
be
left
in
this
condition
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
Estella
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
ground
belongs
to
me
.
<EOS>
It
is
the
only
possession
I
have
not
relinquished
.
<EOS>
Everything
else
has
gone
from
me
,
little
by
little
,
but
I
have
kept
this
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
subject
of
the
only
determined
resistance
I
made
in
all
the
wretched
years
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Is
it
to
be
built
on
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
At
last
it
is
.
<EOS>
I
came
here
to
take
leave
of
it
before
its
change
.
<EOS>
And
you
,
"
she
said
,
in
a
voice
of
touching
interest
to
a
wanderer
,
"
you
live
abroad
still
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Still
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
do
well
,
I
am
sure
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
work
pretty
hard
for
a
sufficient
living
,
and
therefore
---
Yes
,
I
do
well
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
often
thought
of
you
,
"
said
Estella
.
  
<EOS>
"
Have
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
late
,
very
often
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
long
hard
time
when
I
kept
far
from
me
,
the
remembrance
of
what
I
had
thrown
away
when
I
was
quite
ignorant
of
its
worth
.
<EOS>
But
,
since
my
duty
has
not
been
incompatible
with
the
admission
of
that
remembrance
,
I
have
given
it
a
place
in
my
heart
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
always
held
your
place
in
 
\
<EOS>
my
\
 
heart
,
"
I
answered
.
  
<EOS>
And
we
were
silent
again
,
until
she
spoke
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
little
thought
,
"
said
Estella
,
"
that
I
should
take
leave
of
you
in
taking
leave
of
this
spot
.
<EOS>
I
am
very
glad
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Glad
to
part
again
,
Estella
?
<EOS>
To
me
,
parting
is
a
painful
thing
.
<EOS>
To
me
,
the
remembrance
of
our
last
parting
has
been
ever
mournful
and
painful
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
said
to
me
,
"
returned
Estella
,
very
earnestly
,
"
"
God
bless
you
,
God
forgive
you
!
"
<EOS>
And
if
you
could
say
that
to
me
then
,
you
will
not
hesitate
to
say
that
to
me
now
---
now
,
when
suffering
has
been
stronger
than
all
other
teaching
,
and
has
taught
me
to
understand
what
your
heart
used
to
be
.
<EOS>
I
have
been
bent
and
broken
,
but
---
I
hope
---
into
a
better
shape
.
<EOS>
Be
as
considerate
and
good
to
me
as
you
were
,
and
tell
me
we
are
friends
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
are
friends
,
"
said
I
,
rising
and
bending
over
her
,
as
she
rose
from
the
bench
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
will
continue
friends
apart
,
"
said
Estella
.
  
<EOS>
I
took
her
hand
in
mine
,
and
we
went
out
of
the
ruined
place
;
and
,
as
the
morning
mists
had
risen
long
ago
when
I
first
left
the
forge
,
so
,
the
evening
mists
were
rising
now
,
and
in
all
the
broad
expanse
of
tranquil
light
they
showed
to
me
<EOS>
,
I
saw
no
shadow
of
another
parting
from
her
.
     
<EOS>
